site_title: US: Wall Street falls as S&P suffers biggest quarterly drop in 2 years
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, March 31, 2022, with the S&P 500 suffering its biggest quarterly drop in 2 years, down 4.9% for the quarter. The decline was driven by concerns over the ongoing conflict in Ukraine and its impact on inflation and the Federal Reserve's response. Despite a brief optimism boost earlier in the week, Russia's President Vladimir Putin's threat to halt gas supplies unless paid in rubles and US President Joe Biden's measures to lower petrol prices weighed on the market.

site_title: KKR buys Twenty Anson for nearly S$600m from AEW
summary: KKR has acquired Twenty Anson in Singapore for nearly S$600 million from AEW, marking the private equity group's maiden direct Singapore real estate exposure. The 20-storey office building has a net lettable area of 206,200 sq ft and is on a site with a balance leasehold tenure of 84.5 years. The acquisition price works out to S$2,900 per sq ft, providing potential for expansion under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Master Plan 2019. This deal is part of an expected active year for Singapore office investment sales, driven by sustainable economic growth and tight office supply.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on April 1, 2022, due to concerns over the Russian invasion of Ukraine, tracking falls on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.71% to 27,624.11, and the Topix index lost 0.69% to 1,933.04.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.71 per cent or 197.32 points to 27,624.11 at the open.

site_title: China censors Shanghai protest videos as lockdown anger grows
summary: China is struggling to manage growing public unhappiness over tough Covid Zero measures in Shanghai, with residents revolt against lockdown orders. Tech giant Tencent censored videos of a rare protest at a Shanghai housing compound, where residents chanted for basic rights and freedom. The lockdowns, which have stretched up to a month, have sparked widespread discontent among Shanghai's residents, who are frustrated with the lack of information and freedom. The situation highlights the challenges China faces in managing public dissatisfaction with its strict COVID policies.

site_title: Which companies are going public in 2022? Almost none so far
summary: The US IPO market has slowed significantly in 2022 due to market volatility, geopolitical turbulence, and tightening monetary policy. As of April 1, 2022, there were no initial public offerings this week and just one last week, marking a stark contrast to the banner 2021. The US IPO market is now considered "on life support," according to Renaissance Capital CEO Bill Smith.

site_title: HDB resale prices climb at a slower pace in Q1 2022
summary: HDB resale prices rose 2.3% in Q1 2022, the 8th consecutive quarterly growth, but at a slower pace than Q4 2021. The seasonal Lunar New Year lull contributed to the slower growth. Prices rose 12% year-on-year, with 82 flats sold for over S$1 million, and 4 units selling for over S$1.3 million. Analysts predict the market will remain buoyant, with over 31,000 flats reaching their minimum occupation period, leading to a 6-8% rise in HDB resale prices for 2022.

site_title: SocGen traders making temporary move from Hong Kong to Singapore
summary: Societe Generale is temporarily relocating at least a dozen traders from Hong Kong to Singapore due to the city's stringent Covid strategy. The traders, working in fixed income and equity derivatives, will be based in Singapore for at least 8 weeks. This move follows other international firms, including Citigroup and JPMorgan Chase & Co, which have also relocated staff from Hong Kong. The relocation is driven by the challenges posed by Hong Kong's strict Covid measures, which have isolated the city and made it difficult for expatriate staff to see their families.

site_title: Soaring mortgage rates in US dent demand for vacation homes
summary: Demand for second homes in the US has plummeted as mortgage rates climb steeply. After a pandemic-fueled buying frenzy, mortgage-rate locks to buy second homes dropped to the lowest level since May 2020, according to Redfin. Rising mortgage rates and increased fees have slowed the boom, with vacation-home demand peaking in March 2021. Experts attribute the decline to vacation homes being optional, and the increased costs are pushing even primary-home buyers to the sidelines, particularly first-time buyers struggling to find affordable properties.

site_title: Job vacancies hit all-time high in 2021, indicating recovery from Covid-19: MOM
summary: Singapore's job vacancies reached an all-time high in 2021, with nearly half of them being newly created positions. Unemployment rates dropped to 2.3% in January, matching pre-pandemic levels. The majority of job vacancies were in growth industries like information and communications, financial services, and construction. Employers cited physical demands, low pay, and poor working conditions as reasons for unfilled positions. The government is encouraging companies to bring in higher-calibre foreign workers and is exploring alternative workforce options, including older workers and women who are not currently working.

site_title: STI dips, tracking Wall Street losses as Russia-Ukraine peace talks stall
summary: Singapore shares ended Thursday with a 0.99% decline, tracking Wall Street losses amid stalled Russia-Ukraine peace talks. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,408.52, with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) being the top gainer. Regional markets ended mixed, with Japan's Nikkei index down 0.73% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index down 1.06%. The local banking trio, including Jardine Matheson, UOB, DBS, and OCBC, ended in the red.

site_title: Solomon Islands says won't allow Chinese military base and knows 'ramification'
summary: The Solomon Islands has announced it will not allow a Chinese military base, despite plans to sign a security pact with Beijing. The country's Prime Minister, Manasseh Sogavare, stated that hosting a military base would pose significant security risks. The decision comes amid concerns from regional leaders, including the Federated States of Micronesia and New Zealand, which have warned of potential war between China and the US. Australia's Defence Minister, Peter Dutton, also expressed concerns, stating that a Chinese base in the Solomon Islands would prompt a significant increase in Australian military deployment.

site_title: Hotel industry takings could be near-normal by year-end
summary: Singapore saw a 19% increase in visitor arrivals in February, reaching 67,760, compared to 57,170 in January, as international borders reopened. Hotel room revenues remained stable. The uptick in visitor numbers is a positive sign for the hotel industry, which could return to near-normal takings by year-end.

images.alt_text: Transport Minister S Iswaran recently announced the goal of bringing Changi Airport's passenger volume to at least half of its pre-pandemic levels this year.

site_title: Eyes of football world on Doha for World Cup draw
summary: The 2022 FIFA World Cup draw is set to take place in Doha, Qatar, on Friday, with the focus on the football tournament despite controversy surrounding the awarding of the event. Qatar has faced accusations of vote-buying and human rights concerns, but FIFA president Gianni Infantino has emphasized the tournament's unique features. The draw will feature top seeds such as Brazil, Belgium, and England, with 3 spots still to be decided for the 32-team tournament. Concerns remain over the treatment of LGBTQ+ supporters and labor rights in Qatar.

images.alt_text: The draw for this year's World Cup takes place in the shadow of Doha's skyscrapers on Friday (Apr 1), with the focus for the evening on the actual football after a build-up dominated by the many off-field issues surrounding the awarding of the tournament.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB upgrades Japfa to 'add' on listing of China dairy unit
summary: CGS-CIMB has upgraded Japfa to "add" from "hold" due to the planned listing of its China dairy unit, AustAsia Investment Holdings, which could realize a valuation of up to US$730 million for Japfa shareholders. Analyst Tay Wee Kuang estimates Japfa's share price could hit S$0.81, representing a 12.5% potential upside. Japfa plans to distribute its entire AustAsia shares to eligible shareholders, with the company's remaining equity value estimated at US$358.5 million.

site_title: Chinese developers say funding woes, local government caution undermine pledges of support
summary: Chinese developers face significant challenges in accessing funding, despite government pledges to support the embattled property industry. Executives at top developers cited difficulties in obtaining new loans from banks, forcing them to rely on cash from sales to build new projects. Local government authorities' cautious approach to easing rules has also hindered efforts to stimulate demand from wary buyers. While some cities have relaxed purchase curbs, the lack of coherence between central authorities and local governments has limited the effectiveness of support measures.

images.alt_text: China needs more decisive policy easing at the city level to stimulate demand from wary buyers and inject new credit to stop more property- related firms from defaulting, executives at top developers say.

site_title: US envoy to Moscow says Russia ties sunk to 'Mariana Trench' depths
summary: US envoy to Moscow John Sullivan has described Russia's invasion of Ukraine as having "sunk to 'Mariana Trench' depths" in terms of diplomatic relations. The US embassy in Moscow has reduced its staff to about 130 people, and Sullivan faces challenges including Russia's nuclear saber-rattling and threats to sever relations. Sullivan has stated he will not leave his post until the US can no longer advocate for detained Americans, including basketball star Brittney Griner and former Marines Trevor Reed.

site_title: No Signboard closes its Esplanade outlet just as Singapore reopens
summary: No Signboard, a seafood restaurant, will close its Esplanade outlet in Singapore as the country reopens its borders, citing continued financial losses due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. The company, which has been battling economic impacts since the pandemic, believes the closure will help reduce operating costs and focus on other outlets. This decision comes despite the government's recent easing of restrictions, which may take several more months to return to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Toshiba rises after top holder spurs Bain buyout speculation
summary: Toshiba shares rose 6.3% after its largest shareholder, Effissimo Capital Management, stated it would tender its 9.9% stake if US private equity firm Bain Capital launched a takeover bid for two-thirds or more of the company. Bain denied any decision on a bid, and Toshiba stated it was not involved in discussions between Bain and Effissimo. Japan's trade minister expressed concern over a potential Bain takeover due to Toshiba's national security-related technologies, including nuclear power and semiconductors.

site_title: Sri Lanka lifts curfew imposed after violent protests over economic crisis
summary: Sri Lanka lifted its curfew after violent protests over an economic crisis, with dozens arrested and several policemen injured. Hundreds of protesters gathered near President Gotabaya Rajapaksa's residence, which was dispersed with tear gas and water cannons. The protests were sparked by the country's worst economic crisis in years, including rolling blackouts and a lack of foreign exchange. The government has urged constructive protests, but warned of economic consequences, including a decline in tourism. The country's stock market was suspended for the third day in a row due to the main index's 10% drop.

site_title: China weighs raising billions for new fund to rescue troubled financial firms
summary: China is considering a plan to raise billions of yuan for a new stability fund to backstop troubled financial firms, with the goal of shoring up confidence in the country's $60 trillion financial system. The fund, led by the People's Bank of China, aims to address a debt crisis in the property industry and stabilize hundreds of weak rural banks and distressed developers with at least $1 trillion in liabilities. The fund's capital will come from various sources, including local governments and major banks, and is expected to be completed by September, with the possibility of increasing its size if needed.

site_title: Ships face power blackouts from contaminated fuel in Singapore
summary: A growing number of ships in Singapore have suffered power blackouts due to contaminated marine fuel, according to Veritas Petroleum Services. 34 ships received tainted supplies between February and March, with almost half experiencing a fuel system failure that led to a blackout. The tainted fuel originated from two Singaporean suppliers, but their names have not been disclosed. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore and Veritas Petroleum Services have not provided further information on the matter.

site_title: China's March new home prices up marginally: private survey
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.03% in March, matching February's growth, despite weak demand in small cities and renewed Covid-19 flare-ups. Authorities have eased local policy measures, such as allowing smaller down payments and cuts in mortgage rates, in 20 small cities. However, demand remains weak, with 53 cities reporting declines in new home prices. The pace of recovery is being interrupted by Covid outbreaks, and regulators are expected to introduce more policies to stabilize the market.

site_title: Australia names RBA's first female No 2, likely Lowe successor
summary: Australia has appointed Michele Bullock as its first female deputy governor of the Reserve Bank, marking a significant milestone in efforts to address the institution's male-dominated leadership. Bullock, a 5-year term holder, is seen as a front-runner to succeed Philip Lowe, who is likely to step down. This appointment follows a series of moves to diversify the RBA's leadership, with Bullock being the first female deputy governor in the bank's 62-year history.

site_title: Skyports plans to take flying taxi terminals to Japan, Australia
summary: Skyports, a UK-based company, plans to expand into Japan and Australia, aiming to build terminals for electric vertical take-off and landing (eVTOL) aircraft. The company has partnered with Kanematsu in Japan and Goodman Group in Australia, with plans for commercial flights as early as 2025. This expansion follows significant investment in the eVTOL market, with over US$7 billion poured in the last year, according to Yun Yuan Tay, head of Skyports in Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Panasonic to spend 600b yen on EV cells, supply chain software
summary: Panasonic plans to invest 600 billion yen (S$6.65 billion) in electric vehicle cells and supply chain software over 3 years through fiscal 2024. The company aims to accumulate an operating profit of 1.5 trillion yen during this period. Panasonic is focusing on new growth areas, including EV cells and hydrogen energy, to steer the company towards sustained growth. The company's CEO, Yuki Kusumi, plans to spend 2 years "specializing and sharpening" Panasonic's remaining businesses to increase efficiency and free up funds for new initiatives.

site_title: MAS, BIS form analytics platform for supervision
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) Innovation Hub Singapore Centre have developed a prototype analytics platform called Project Ellipse to enhance regulatory supervision. The platform integrates various data, including regulatory and news, to identify potential risks to individual banks and the banking system. It aims to improve analytical capabilities and provide forward-looking and data-driven insights to regulators. The platform will be made available to global regulators through a collaboration community, with the potential to revolutionize supervisory data collection and analysis.

site_title: Japan's Jera sets up Singapore unit to modernise terms for LNG contracts
summary: Jera, Japan's largest LNG buyer, has set up a Singapore-based subsidiary to modernize its long-term LNG contracts. The subsidiary, Jera LNG Portfolio Strategy Pte Ltd, will negotiate with suppliers to review prices and terms, aiming to speed up the process. This move follows the outdated terms of existing 30 long-term contracts signed in the early 2000s, which do not align with current spot market standards. The new team will hire 10 staff initially and expand to 20, with the goal of diverting more cargoes to the spot market.

site_title: Australia's house prices begin to cool as Sydney, Melbourne drop
summary: Australia's housing market shows signs of cooling, with Sydney home prices dropping 0.2% and Melbourne prices falling 0.1% in March. This marks the second consecutive month of decline in Sydney and the lowest monthly gain for the country's 8 major cities since October 2020. The slowdown is attributed to rising expectations of policy tightening and cooling buyer ardor.

site_title: Islamic finance deals have the best start ever with oil up 40%
summary: Islamic finance deals have seen their best start on record, with $24 billion in sukuk sales maturing in at least a year, driven by the high price of oil. Saudi Arabia and Turkey were the top issuers. The surge in sukuk issuance is attributed to the high oil prices, which have boosted investor confidence in the sector.

site_title: US officials circle globe to keep pressure on Putin as rouble rises
summary: US officials are intensifying pressure on Russia by visiting world leaders, including London, Brussels, Paris, Berlin, and Abu Dhabi, as the war in Ukraine enters its fifth week. The US is considering its next economic steps to isolate Russian President Vladimir Putin amid a partially recovered ruble. Despite sanctions on Russian banks and companies, energy sales to Europe remain unaffected, and Russia is demanding payments in rubles for gas starting on April 1. The US aims to maintain momentum on sanctions and counter China and India's influence on Russia.

site_title: Europe: Shares log first quarterly loss in 8; H&M slumps
summary: European shares fell 0.9% on Thursday, marking the first quarterly loss in 8 years, led by a 12.9% plunge in H&M due to weak quarterly profit and plans to raise prices. Retail stocks lost 5%, their worst day in over 2 years, amid high raw material and transportation costs. A global risk-off tone and concerns about fresh Russian attacks in Ukraine also contributed to the decline.

site_title: UK's surging jobs market shows signs of stabilisation
summary: The UK's jobs market is showing signs of stabilisation, with new job postings falling 25% in the last week of March, returning to pre-February levels. This trend may alleviate concerns for the Bank of England about long-term inflation pressure. The Recruitment and Employment Confederation attributed the slowdown to the "spring" season, as job postings had surged in the first few months of the year. The stabilisation of the jobs market could be a positive sign for the UK economy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on Ukraine, recession fears
summary: South Korean shares ended lower on Friday, April 1, 2022, due to concerns over the Ukraine crisis and recession fears. The Kospi benchmark closed 0.65% down at 2,739.85, despite a third straight weekly gain. Chip heavyweights Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fell 0.72% and 1.69%, respectively. The country's exports grew, but the trade balance swung to a deficit due to rising energy and raw material prices. Foreigners sold 67.2 billion won worth of shares, and the won weakened 0.28% against the dollar.

images.alt_text: The Korean won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield rose.

site_title: China factory, services activity contract together for first time since 2020 amid lockdowns
summary: China's manufacturing and services activity contracted simultaneously in March for the first time since 2020, amid the ongoing Covid-19 lockdowns. This is the first time these two sectors have contracted together since the pandemic's peak in 2020. The simultaneous contraction is putting pressure on the economy and threatening global supply chains. The move is prompting calls for more contingency plans to address the risks posed by the lockdowns, which are affecting China's GDP growth.

site_title: Biden orders huge oil release, prods drillers to step up output
summary: President Joe Biden announced a 6-month plan to release 1 million barrels of oil per day from US reserves, aiming to achieve energy independence from foreign suppliers. The move was attributed to Russian President Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine, which led to a spike in petrol prices. Biden also criticized US oil companies for being reluctant to increase production, calling for Congress to charge fees to firms with unused drilling leases on federal lands. The plan aims to alleviate pressure on American families and reduce reliance on foreign energy suppliers.

site_title: EU-China summit sullied by storm clouds
summary: The EU-China summit, set to take place on April 1, comes amidst strained bilateral relations, with tensions heightened by China's support for Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Despite these challenges, both sides are seeking to stress areas of common interest, including cooperation on climate change and a multilateral trading system. The EU and China have a history of cooperation on climate change and could potentially benefit from a deeper partnership, but politics and the conflict in Ukraine may hinder progress.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat, post third straight weekly gain
summary: Australia's shares closed flat on Friday, ending the week with a 1.2% gain, as technology and financial stocks offset gains in miners amid concerns over the Ukraine crisis and inflation. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.08% but posted its third straight weekly gain. Mining stocks rose 1.7%, driven by iron ore price increases, while energy stocks ended 1.2% higher. Global sentiment remains subdued due to recession worries and the US Federal Reserve's plans to hike interest rates aggressively.

site_title: First Reit prices S$100m of guaranteed bonds due 2027 at 3.25%
summary: First Reit priced S$100 million of guaranteed healthcare social bonds due 2027 at 3.25% per annum, marking Singapore's first-ever healthcare social bond. The bonds are part of the Reit's Social Finance Framework, aiming to issue bonds with social benefit outcomes and sustainability goals. The net proceeds will be used to refinance an existing term loan, with any excess amount allocated as agreed. The bonds, rated "AA" by S&P Global Ratings, are guaranteed by Credit Guarantee and Investment Facility (CGIF), a trust fund of the Asian Development Bank.

site_title: HSBC's new insurance chief eyes 'crucial' new China expansion
summary: HSBC's new insurance chief, Greg Hingston, is focusing on expanding the bank's insurance business in Asia, particularly in China, as a crucial growth opportunity. Hingston aims to increase the bank's presence in mainland China, where risks are multiplying amid economic challenges, and has already hired 700 financial planners. HSBC plans to increase this number to 3,000 over the next few years and is exploring deals in India and Singapore. The bank's expansion in insurance fits into its vision of becoming the leading bank in Asia wealth, with insurance falling under this goal.

site_title: 'More time and deliberation' needed in potential combination of Keppel O&M, Sembmarine
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (O&M) and Sembcorp Marine (Sembmarine) need more time and deliberation to advance their proposed combination, despite significant progress made. The parties must complete due diligence, reach mutual agreement on transaction terms, and finalize definitive legal documentation. The announcement comes nearly 9 months after the initial talks on a potential combination.

site_title: US says no 'red line' for India's oil imports from Russia
summary: The US has stated that it will not set a "red line" for India's oil imports from Russia, but urged its European and Asian partners to cut their reliance on the country due to its "unreliable energy supply". India has bought at least 13 million barrels of Russian crude oil since the Ukraine invasion. The US is ready to help India diversify its energy resources, but does not want to see a rapid acceleration in energy imports from Russia.

site_title: High-rolling 'Fujian Gang' caught in China property crisis
summary: China's "Fujian Gang," a group of high-rolling property developers from the province, are facing a severe property crisis. Zhenro Properties Group, led by Ou Zongrong, has been downgraded to restricted default and its stock has plummeted 77% for the year. The group's debt has ballooned to $32 billion, with some developers, such as Yango Group Co and Yuzhou Group Holdings Co, responsible for over $3.2 billion in defaults. Market watchers are questioning the firm's transparency, eroding confidence in corporate governance, and experts warn that the liquidity strain in China's property sector will have a long shadow on the land market.

site_title: Shanghai Covid curbs prompt half of US firms to cut revenue forecasts: survey
summary: US multinational companies in Shanghai have reduced their annual revenue projections due to the recent Covid-19 outbreak, with 54% cutting 2022 revenue forecasts. The outbreak has led to slowed or reduced production, with 82% of manufacturers reporting disruptions. Some companies have implemented "closed-loop" production arrangements to keep production lines running, but this is deemed unsustainable long-term. The lockdown has also disrupted life in Shanghai, with many companies experiencing suspended operations, stagnant sales, and delayed financial disclosures.

site_title: GovTech appoints Joseph Leong as new chairman
summary: GovTech appoints Joseph Leong as new chairman, replacing Ng Chee Khern since October 2016. Leong, currently Permanent Secretary of SNDGG, brings greater synergies to digital government, economy, and society with his concurrent appointments. Prior to this, Leong served in various roles, including director at the Security and Intelligence Division and Second Permanent Secretary at the Ministry of Communication and Information.

site_title: 'Slow-balisation': How war and the pandemic are reshaping global trade
summary: The article discusses how war and the pandemic are reshaping global trade, with governments and companies recognizing the need for more resilient supply chains. Despite warnings of an end to globalisation, World Trade Organization (WTO) Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala advocates for a stronger focus on multilateralism and global cooperation. The article notes that Russia's invasion of Ukraine and China's opposition to sanctions have led to a surge in protectionism, with 49 export controls on food and fertilizers implemented this year. Analysts predict a slowdown in global trade growth, with some experts suggesting a "slow-balisation" period, where services trade continues to grow while goods trade is reshored to some extent.

site_title: The smart car buying guide
summary: There is no article to summarize. The provided content appears to be a collection of article titles and publication dates from a news website, but no actual article is included.

site_title: Grab's technology head leaves for a future in crypto gaming
summary: Grab's head of technology, Foo Wui Ngiap, will leave the company on April 1 to become CEO of Ethlas, a blockchain-based gaming marketplace he founded with 3 former Grab employees. Foo's departure coincides with the growth of Web3 technology. This move may impact Grab at a challenging time, but it also reflects the company's involvement in the Web3 vision.

images.alt_text: At Grab, Foo has held a wide spectrum of portfolios, including spearheading artificial intelligence strategy and growing a team of more than 400 trust and safety specialists.

site_title: SingPost issues S$250m in perpetual securities at initial rate of 4.35% per annum
summary: SingPost issued S$250m in perpetual securities with an initial distribution rate of 4.35% per annum for the first 5 years. The distribution rate will be reset on Jul 6, 2027, to a rate equivalent to the 5-year Singapore Overnight Rate Average Overnight Indexed Swaps, plus an initial spread and step-up margin. This move aims to provide investors with a relatively stable income stream for the initial period.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.1% to 3,410.51, despite global markets retreating due to concerns over the ongoing Ukraine war. The STI was led by E27, which saw its share price soar 10.8% after brisk trading. US stocks slumped, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.6% and the S&P 500 losing 1.6%. The mixed performance was attributed to concerns about the conflict in Ukraine and its inflationary effect on prices.

site_title: WHO lays out plan to emerge from emergency phase of pandemic
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has released a plan to emerge from the emergency phase of the COVID-19 pandemic, outlining three possible scenarios for the virus's evolution in 2022. The base-case scenario suggests a reduction in disease severity, while the best-case scenario proposes a highly transmissible but less severe variant. The worst-case scenario involves a new, deadly threat. To end the emergency, WHO calls for continued surveillance, diagnostic testing, and vaccine distribution, with a focus on vulnerable populations, and aims to vaccinate 70% of the world's population against COVID-19.

images.alt_text: Director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus says the WHO's latest report on Covid is its third, and will likely be its last.

site_title: GoTo to raise US$1.1b after finalising IPO at top end of price range
summary: GoTo Group, Indonesia's largest tech firm, has finalized its initial public offering (IPO) and plans to raise US$1.1 billion, pricing the deal in the top half of its indicative range. This makes it one of Asia's biggest IPOs this year. GoTo, formed by the merger of Gojek and Tokopedia, surprised investors with its IPO process despite global equity market turbulence. The company's IPO marks a significant milestone in its growth, with the raised funds expected to be used for future investments and expansion.

site_title: Singapore stocks brave turbulence to log 2.8% gains in March
summary: Singapore stocks ended March with a 2.8% gain, despite volatile conditions driven by geopolitical tensions and inflationary concerns. The market value of listed companies rose from S$860.2 billion to S$884.2 billion, with 314 companies gaining and 182 closing lower. Key economic indicators and market events, such as oil price increases and tariff threats, impacted the market. The strong performance was attributed to market confidence, with no significant downturns reported throughout the month.

site_title: Arts' pandemic recovery picks up pace
summary: The global arts sector is recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic, with local and international signs indicating a strong comeback. Christie's is auctioning Andy Warhol's "Shot Sage Blue Marilyn" for $200 million, a record for a 20th-century artwork. Singapore's arts scene has also begun to flourish, with live performances and exhibitions resuming after two years of restrictions. The global art market saw a 29% increase in sales in 2021, with the US market accounting for 43% of worldwide sales. Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) have also seen significant growth, with a 100-fold increase in sales in 2021.

site_title: Most UK homeowners would give up gains to ease property market
summary: Most UK homeowners would give up future gains in property value to ease the housing market, according to a survey by Positive Money. 54% of homeowners would allow house prices to stagnate over the next 10 years to make property more affordable for others. The campaign group suggests the Bank of England should set a sustainable house price target to keep inflation low. This approach would address the issue of unaffordable housing, where typical full-time employees now need to spend 9.1 times their annual earnings to buy a home.

site_title: Japan business mood sours as Ukraine war, rising fuel price take toll
summary: Japan's business confidence has soured due to supply disruptions and rising raw material costs caused by the Ukraine crisis, according to the Bank of Japan's quarterly central bank survey. The big manufacturers' sentiment index slipped to plus 14 in March, and big non-manufacturers' sentiment worsened to plus 9. Companies expect conditions to worsen further in the next three months, clouding the outlook for the fragile economic recovery. Rising fuel and food prices, coupled with a weak yen, are contributing to the economic pain.

images.alt_text: Soaring fuel and food prices blamed on the Ukraine war, coupled with rising import bills from a weak yen, have added to pain for households and Japan's economy still reeling from the coronavirus pandemic's hit.

site_title: Asia takes most Russian Urals oil in 23 months amid Europe snub
summary: Russia's flagship Urals crude oil is increasingly being shipped to Asia, with 1.24 million tons bound for Asia in March, the highest volume since April 2020. European buyers have scaled back purchases due to international sanctions and concerns about reputational damage. Asia, particularly India, is taking advantage of the discounts, with refineries processing the majority of the oil. This shift is expected to continue, with supertankers transferring crude from smaller vessels in Europe to Asian ports. European refineries are also cutting back on Russian Urals crude due to the country's invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Russia's flagship Urals crude oil is increasingly heading to Asia, as European buyers scale back purchases following Russia's invasion of Ukraine and international sanctions aimed at isolating Moscow.

site_title: US warned firms about Russia's Kaspersky software day after invasion
summary: The US government warned some American companies that Russian cybersecurity company Kaspersky's software could be manipulated to cause harm, just a day after Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The classified briefings, part of a broader strategy to prepare critical infrastructure providers for potential Russian intrusions, cite the increased risk calculation due to the Ukraine conflict. Kaspersky, founded by a former Russian intelligence officer, denies wrongdoing and says its transparency centers are insufficient to address US concerns, which include the risk of malicious commands sent through software updates.

site_title: More companies setting net-zero targets but boards are skeptical on execution: survey
summary: A survey by Insead and Boston Consulting Group (BSG) found that 55% of directors reported that their companies have prepared a plan for hitting net-zero targets, but only 43% published financial statements accounting for climate change implications. Directors cited a lack of knowledge, data, and capabilities as the top barrier to providing effective ESG oversight. Many boards remain skeptical of their ability to execute on environmental, social, and governance goals, and only 47% believed their board had sufficient competence and experience to challenge management on ESG plans.

site_title: Ukraine war: What explains the calm in global stock markets?
summary: Global stock markets have shown surprisingly resilience despite the Ukraine war, with the MSCI All Country World Index returning above its pre-war level and the Vix volatility index below its long-term average. However, experts warn that systemic risks remain, particularly with Russia's sovereign debt default looming and potential contagion through the commodities market. Analysts caution that the crisis could still produce unanticipated problems, and some fear that the financial ramifications may not be fully felt until later. The international exposure to Russia is relatively low, and many investors have already written off their holdings of Russian debt, reducing the risk of a major financial shock.

site_title: More earnings downgrade in store for Chinese companies
summary: Morgan Stanley expects further earnings downgrades for Chinese companies, with about half of listed companies on the MSCI China Index having issued fourth-quarter 2021 reports, showing a stabilisation in corporate earnings. However, this is compared to a low base in Q3 2021. The financial and healthcare sectors are the only ones beating consensus earnings and revenues, while the consumer discretionary sector has also seen some success. Companies such as Tencent and Yonyou Network have missed consensus earnings, mainly due to the tech down cycle and inflation. A clearer exit strategy from zero-Covid policy and improved global geopolitical tensions are needed for a sustainable rally in Chinese stocks.

site_title: Electricity tariff to rise by an average of 9.9% in Q2 as global energy prices surge
summary: Singapore's electricity tariff is set to rise by an average of 9.9% in Q2 due to surging global oil and gas prices, exacerbated by the conflict in Ukraine. The tariff increase will be implemented from Apr 1 to Jun 30, with a rate of S$0.0249 per kilowatt hour. The rise is attributed to higher energy costs, and the measure is expected to remain in place until end-June, as the Energy Market Authority (EMA) extends its measures to secure energy supply and stabilize prices.

site_title: SGX partners UK to support sustainable growth in Asia
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is partnering with the UK government's Mobilising Institutional Capital Through Listed Product Structures (Mobilist) to support sustainable growth in Asia. The partnership aims to identify and fund companies that offer products or solutions aligned with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and are preparing to list in Singapore. SGX will provide equity capital, technical assistance funding, and advisory services to these companies. The partnership seeks to mobilize public capital markets to support sustainable development in emerging markets in Asia, with SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye emphasizing the need for public and private sectors to work together to finance innovative SDG solutions.

site_title: Hatten Land rises 11.6% on latest crypto mining tie-up
summary: Hatten Land shares rose 11.6% on March 31, 2022, after announcing a new partnership for crypto mining activities in Melaka. The company's share price reached an intra-day high of S$0.049, with 59 million securities traded. This makes Hatten Land the second-most actively traded counter by volume. The company's stock price ended at S$0.048, following the announcement.

site_title: US senators complain Biden's Indo-Pacific plan won't cut tariffs
summary: US Trade Representative Katherine Tai deflected complaints from senators that the Biden administration's Indo-Pacific economic plan won't include a free trade deal that lowers tariffs. The plan, aimed at countering China's influence in the region, will instead offer "economically meaningful outcomes" to promote trade and market access. Tai emphasized that the plan will set standards for enhanced digital trade, environmental and labor standards, and supply chain resilience, while also addressing China's "industrial targeting practices" and "Made in China 2025" efforts to dominate strategic industries.

site_title: Indonesia sees sharp rise in foreign visitors in Jan-Feb
summary: Indonesia reported a 260% increase in foreign visitors in January-February, reaching 33,593, mainly from China, Russia, and South Korea. This surge comes after the relaxation of Covid-19 travel restrictions. However, the number still lags behind pre-pandemic levels, which typically saw around 2 million overseas visitors during the same period. Indonesia's resort island of Bali reopened to visitors in October 2021, contributing to the recent increase in foreign arrivals.

site_title: Corporate purposes should go beyond just profits, shareholder value: panel
summary: A panel at the Stewardship Asia Roundtable 2022 emphasized the need for companies to shift beyond focusing solely on profits and shareholder value, instead aligning themselves with societal needs and a "higher purpose." Speakers, including Dilhan Pillay and Narayan Pant, argued that purpose-driven companies achieve higher market share gains and better workforce and customer satisfaction. However, demanding accountability for complex issues like sustainability and climate change can be challenging, and regulators like the Monetary Authority of Singapore are taking steps to promote better behaviors and outcomes, including setting out a roadmap for mandatory climate-related disclosures.

site_title: UK house price growth in March at strongest pace since 2004
summary: UK house prices increased by 1.1% in March, marking their strongest annual pace of growth since 2004. This is the eighth consecutive monthly increase, with prices rising 14.3% from last year. The average property price reached a record high of £265,312. Despite this, Nationwide's chief economist predicts the market will slow in the quarters ahead due to a cost-of-living squeeze and rising interest rates.

site_title: Singtel's ATN to acquire Australia telco infrastructure provider Axicom for A$3.6b
summary: Singtel's unit, Australia Tower Network (ATN), has proposed acquiring Axicom, an Australian telecommunications tower infrastructure provider, for A$3.6 billion (S$3.7 billion). ATN, which owns mobile networks and rooftop sites in Australia, will gain a national footprint, while Singtel will hold an 18% stake in the combined business. The acquisition aims to improve economies of scale and provide growth opportunities for customers, employees, and the community.

images.alt_text: Singtel, which currently has a 30 per cent stake in ATN, will hold an effective interest of 18 per cent in the combined ATN and Axicom business after the proposed acquisition.

site_title: DBS not opening crypto services to retail market anytime soon: CEO
summary: DBS Bank CEO Piyush Gupta stated that the bank will not extend crypto trading services to retail consumers in the near future due to regulatory concerns. Despite the growing popularity of crypto, Gupta acknowledged that the banking sector will eventually need to create guidelines for retail investors. DBS will instead focus on designing guidelines for retail investors, and the bank plans to launch a carbon offset program for retail consumers. The bank's net profit increased 44% to S$6.8 billion, but dividends did not keep pace with growth.

site_title: Euro dips on Ukraine caution, Norwegian krone dives
summary: The euro fell 0.5% to $1.1105 due to caution over Ukraine developments and limited progress in peace talks, while the Norwegian krone plummeted 1.6% against the euro and 2.1% against the dollar. Oil prices dived, contributing to the Norwegian krone's decline. The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to raise interest rates, with 20 basis points of hikes priced in by July 2022. Other commodity currencies, such as the Australian and New Zealand dollar, also dropped.

site_title: Biden administration weighs largest ever draw from emergency oil reserve: sources
summary: The Biden administration is considering releasing up to 180 million barrels of oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, the largest ever draw from the reserve, to lower fuel prices amid surging oil prices due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The move would be the third time the US has tapped its strategic reserves in six months, but its impact on prices remains uncertain. The US SPR currently holds 568.3 million barrels, its lowest since 2002, and the White House has not commented on the plan.

site_title: Putin to enforce rouble payments for gas from Apr 1
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has signed a decree requiring foreign buyers to pay for Russian gas in roubles starting April 1. If payments are not made, existing contracts will be halted. This move has boosted the Russian currency and is seen as a way for Putin to strengthen Russia's sovereignty and stick to its obligations. Western companies and governments have rejected the move as a breach of existing contracts, and a possible energy crisis in Europe is feared.

site_title: US consumer spending slows sharply in February; weekly jobless claims increase
summary: US consumer spending slowed to a 0.2% increase in February, the smallest rise in over a year, as households cut back on spending due to higher petrol, rent, and food prices. The personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index rose 6.4% in the 12 months through February, the largest annual gain since the early 1980s. Despite this, the Federal Reserve raised its policy interest rate by 25 basis points, citing inflation concerns. Initial jobless claims also increased to 202,000, while employers announced 21,387 job cuts in March.

site_title: SPAC tied to Trump's social media venture sinks as downloads slump 95%
summary: Shares of Digital World Acquisition Corp, a special-purpose acquisition company merging with Trump Media & Technology Group, have declined 31% since the launch of Trump's social media app, Truth Social, due to a 95% drop in daily downloads. The app initially reached 170,000 downloads but has since dropped to 8,000 per day. This decline has negatively impacted the value of the company, which has lost 31% of its value since shares soared in February.

site_title: Oil slumps 7% as US plans record crude reserve release
summary: US President Joe Biden announced a record 180 million-barrel release from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, equivalent to about 2 days of global demand, to boost oil supply amid high prices. The move, part of a 6-month plan to release 1 million barrels per day, aims to offset lost Russian exports and stabilize the market. However, analysts say the release is not a permanent fix and may not resolve the structural supply deficit. Oil prices fell 7% on the announcement, with Brent crude futures down 4.8% and WTI down 7%.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for May, which expired on Thursday, closed down US$5.54 or 4.8 per cent at US$107.91 a barrel.

site_title: Yes, an electric car can save you money... but only if you choose the right one
summary: In Singapore, owning an electric vehicle (EV) can save money, but only if the right model is chosen. According to a survey, 72% of Singaporeans consider saving money on fuel as a reason to buy an EV. However, the cost difference between EVs and their combustion equivalents varies. The BMW iX3, for example, costs S$308,888 and is cheaper to run, saving up to S$3,806 a year in fuel costs. In contrast, the Kia Niro EV is S$52,000 more expensive and may not break even for a buyer until half a century. Home charging and maintenance costs also play a significant role in determining the financial viability of EVs.

images.alt_text: Property agent Christopher Quek with his BMW iX3 electric car.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: The Singapore Government Bonds quotation as of March 31, 2022, is not provided in the given article. However, other key news includes: Oil prices rose over 2% due to market and geopolitical factors. Stocks in Europe and the US declined due to bank and healthcare concerns, while US-EU tariffs are under focus. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Companies like Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss shortfalls. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case related to 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Fast evolving fintech scene threatens to upend universal banking
summary: The traditional universal banking model is evolving as fintechs and changing consumer demands threaten the status quo. Analysts say banks must reconsider their approach to remain competitive, with many opting for specialists that focus on specific segments of the financial services spectrum. Big banks like Citigroup and Singapore's DBS are scaling back their universal banking model, while others like Siam Commercial Bank are investing in financial technology to become regional fintech conglomerates. Experts predict that specialists and universal banks with strong digital offerings will be rewarded by investors.

site_title: OCBC talks sustainability, targets S-E Asia, China in growth strategy
summary: OCBC Bank has set a sustainability-focused growth strategy, targeting South-east Asia and China, under the leadership of CEO Helen Wong. Wong aims to promote green financing and invest in new economies, with the bank's 2021 net profit reaching S$4.9 billion. Wong's remuneration package includes a base salary, bonus, deferred shares, and other benefits, totaling S$7.6 million. Despite geopolitical tensions, Wong expects OCBC to capture growth in its core markets in Asia, driven by strong GDP growth prospects in the region.

site_title: Australia's soaring property prices drive wealth to record high
summary: Australia's household wealth reached a record high of A$14.7 trillion in the final quarter of 2021, driven by soaring property prices and record-low borrowing costs. Home values contributed 3.5 percentage points to the quarterly increase, while net worth on a per capita basis also hit an all-time high. Economists predict property prices will cool in the period ahead as the Reserve Bank of Australia embarks on a policy tightening path, with some predicting a 6% decline in nationwide home prices in 2023.

site_title: LHN Logistics lodges preliminary offer document
summary: LHN Logistics, a subsidiary of property player LHN, has lodged a preliminary offer document for a spin-off and listing on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The company plans to use the funds to increase its scale of operations by buying 20 prime movers and 70 trailers to support cross-border transportation services between Singapore and Malaysia. The remaining proceeds will be used for expansion plans, including building an ISO tank depot and expanding into more countries in the Asean region.

site_title: Looted Libyan artefacts returned by US
summary: Libyan authorities received 9 ancient artefacts, including funerary stone heads and pottery, returned by the US after being smuggled out of the North African country. The pieces, identified by archaeologists working with the Manhattan District Attorney's office, were found to have been illegally excavated and shipped to the US. Libyan antiquities department head Muhammad Faraj Muhammad stated that the artefacts were not stolen from museums or recorded with the Libyan government. The artefacts were returned to the Museum of Libya in Tripoli.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge up at open, before US jobs data
summary: European stocks rose at the start of trading on Friday, April 1, 2022, ahead of US jobs data, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.1% to 7,520.02 points. The eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices also gained 0.1% each. The moves come as investors await an update on the world's biggest economy, facing soaring global inflation.

site_title: US slaps sanctions on Russian tech firms, including largest chip maker
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on 21 Russian tech firms, including the largest chip maker, Mikron, in response to Moscow's invasion of Ukraine. The sanctions target companies involved in the Russian government's war machine and are part of the US Treasury's crackdown on sanctions evasion networks. The targeted firms include AO NII-Vektor, T-Platforms, and Molecular Electronics Research Institute, with their US assets frozen. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that the sanctions will continue to target Vladimir Putin's war machine, aiming to limit Russia's economic progress.

site_title: Shanghai to lift eastern lockdown with some compounds sealed
summary: Shanghai will lift its eastern lockdown on Friday, but certain compounds will remain sealed due to Covid-19 infections. Movement restrictions will remain in place for apartment buildings and compounds with positive cases, with residents confined to their neighborhoods for 7 days. The city's lockdowns are part of China's efforts to curb a record outbreak, which has brought unprecedented disruptions to the financial hub and threatens to disrupt global supply chains.

site_title: Airline chiefs want government aid to reduce carbon emissions
summary: Europe's leading airlines are calling for government aid and legislation to help reduce carbon emissions, citing the need to remain competitive during the transition to cleaner energy. The airlines, including Deutsche Lufthansa and Ryanair Holdings, are seeking support for sustainable aviation fuel, the Corsia carbon-offset scheme, and the Single European Sky project, which could cut emissions by up to 15%. Airlines say government backing is vital to keep flying affordable and competitive, particularly with rising energy costs due to the conflict in Ukraine.

site_title: Corporate purposes should go beyond just profits and shareholder value: panel
summary: Corporate leaders are shifting focus from solely maximizing profits and shareholder value to a broader purpose that benefits society and the environment. Speakers at the Stewardship Asia Roundtable 2022 emphasized the need for companies to prioritize their social and governance responsibilities, citing research that shows purpose-driven companies achieve higher market share gains and better workforce and customer satisfaction. Regulators, such as the Monetary Authority of Singapore, are also taking steps to promote high-quality sustainability-related disclosures and accountability among companies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, April 1, 2022, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.70 points or 0.3% to 1,582.66. The market saw 186.7 million lots traded worth RM82.2 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 234 to 103.

site_title: US mortgage rates soar, reaching highest since late 2018
summary: US mortgage rates have surged to a 7-year high, reaching 4.67% for a 30-year loan, the highest since December 2018. This marks a 25-cent increase from last week and a 1.5% rise since the start of the year, the largest three-month increase since 1987. Higher borrowing costs are deterring homebuyers, particularly entry-level buyers, who struggle to afford homes due to rising interest rates and home prices. Experts predict rates may reach 5% within a few weeks.

site_title: At least 33 Hong Kong firms halted after earnings deadline
summary: At least 33 Hong Kong-listed firms halted trading after missing the deadline to report annual results, adding uncertainty to a market facing a bleak economic outlook and regulatory headwinds. Embattled Chinese developers, including Sunac China Holdings and Shimao Group Holdings, were among those suspended. The halt comes as investors' confidence remains low, with the Hang Seng Index down 6% this year, and regulatory risks persist due to lockdowns in China and a credit crunch.

images.alt_text: Embattled Chinese developers, including Sunac China Holdings and Shimao Group Holdings, were among the Hong Kong stocks to be suspended from Friday.

site_title: Court sanctions Cuscaden takeover scheme; SPH's last day of trading on Apr 7
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has been sanctioned by court for its takeover scheme by Cuscaden Peak, a consortium backed by Hotel Properties and Temasek-linked entities. The last day of trading for SPH will be April 7, with shares suspended and delisted on May 13. Shareholders have until April 26 to choose between an all-cash offer of S$2.36 or S$2.40 per share comprising cash and an SPH Reit unit.

site_title: Cocktail bar scene poised for revival
summary: Singapore's cocktail bar scene is poised for revival as pandemic restrictions ease, allowing more patrons to dine-in and enjoy drinks beyond 10:30 pm. Top cocktail bars, including those on the Asia's 50 Best Bars list, have spent the past two years adapting and reinventing themselves to prepare for a new normal. Many now offer a strong food programme, with some incorporating local ingredients and innovative renditions of classic dishes. Bar owners are cautiously optimistic about the future, but acknowledge higher operating costs and manpower shortages.

site_title: India plans 8.45 trillion rupees of bond sales in fiscal first half
summary: India plans to auction 8.45 trillion rupees (S$151 billion) of bonds in the first half of the fiscal year, about 59% of its full-year target. The government will borrow this amount in 26 weekly tranches, with yields expected to rise to 7% over the first half due to global headwinds. Despite the RBI's accommodative stance, traders anticipate higher yields and a potential rate hike in August. The borrowing plan may push up yields in the market, which have already seen a 6 basis point increase in the 10-year government bond yield to 6.84%.

images.alt_text: India announced the fiscal first-half borrowing plan largely in line with previous years amid a global bond rout and lingering geopolitical uncertainties.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corporation announced it will sell its entire stake in Keppel Logistics to Geodis International SAS for S$80 million. This move is part of the company's 2030 plans to simplify its business. Meanwhile, Keppel T&T's mainboard-listed builder, BT, reported a net loss of S$4.3 million in the fiscal second half, down from S$3.1 million a year ago. Additionally, Wing Tai Holdings acquired 50% interest in its freehold properties in Melbourne, Australia for A$50.1 million.

site_title: Opec+ refuses to deviate from gradual oil output hikes
summary: Opec+ has refused to deviate from its scheduled gradual oil output hikes, despite US President Joe Biden's plan to release 1 million barrels of crude from emergency stockpiles to ease market disruption caused by Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The cartel ratified a 432,000 barrel-a-day supply increase for May at its online meeting, which was in line with expectations. This decision was seen as a snub to the International Energy Agency, which represents oil consumers' interests. As a result, Opec+ will exclude data from the agency from its crude-production estimates starting from May.

site_title: Gold eases ahead of US jobs data as dollar ticks higher
summary: Gold prices eased 0.2% to $1,934.10 per ounce, widening weekly losses, as a stronger US dollar outweighed safe-haven demand. Investors await March US jobs data for policy tightening clues. Russia's President Putin threatened to halt gas supplies to Europe unless paid in rouble, increasing tensions. Gold reserves fell to $604.4 billion, their lowest since August 2021.

site_title: Brokers' take: Jefferies downgrades DBS, OCBC, UOB to 'hold' on flattening yield curve
summary: Jefferies downgraded its call on three Singapore banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, to "hold" from "buy", citing a flattening yield curve and muted transmission of US Federal Reserve rate hikes. Analyst Krishna Guha lowered target prices, expecting balanced risk-reward profiles and slower loan growth due to stagflation. This may weigh on margins and dampen non-interest income growth, with potential writebacks from rising oil prices.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.38% at the start of trade on April 1, 2022, following a sell-off on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index fell 303.75 points to 21,693.10. Tech firms were among the worst performers. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai Index shedding 0.54% and the Shenzhen Index dropping 0.64%. The decline was attributed to a hefty sell-off on Wall Street.

site_title: Putin said not right time for Ukraine ceasefire: Draghi
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin told Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi that conditions are not yet in place for a ceasefire in Ukraine, according to Draghi. Putin also confirmed that current gas contracts remain in force and European firms will continue to pay in euros and US dollars, not roubles. Italy aims to meet NATO's 2% GDP defence spending goal by 2028, but no specific increase will be outlined in its upcoming economic forecasting document.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin told Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi that conditions were not yet in place for a ceasefire in Ukraine, Draghi told a news conference on Thursday (Mar 31) when asked about a telephone call with Putin the previous day.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares fall on weaker Wall Street, profit-taking
summary: Japanese shares fell 0.56% to 27,665.98 on Friday, April 1, 2022, due to weaker Wall Street performance and profit-taking. The Nikkei and Topix indexes posted 1.7% and 1.8% weekly losses, respectively. Investors sold stocks to book profits ahead of the new fiscal year, according to Shoichi Arisawa, a general manager at IwaiCosmo Securities.

site_title: BlackRock cuts fees on world's biggest bond ETF and several more
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest issuer of exchange-traded funds, has cut fees on several of its ETFs, including the $85 billion iShares Core US Aggregate Bond ETF, reducing its expense ratio to 0.03% from 0.04%. The company also lowered fees on two stock ETFs, the iShares MSCI USA Multifactor ETF and the iShares MSCI International Multifactor ETF. These cuts follow fee reductions by other major issuers, such as State Street and Vanguard Group, and reflect the growing competition in the $7 trillion US ETF market.

site_title: GameStop soars on plans to extend rebound with stock split
summary: GameStop shares surged 22% in extended trading after the company announced plans to request a stock split, increasing the number of Class A shares to 1 billion from 300 million. The move follows similar proposals from tech firms Alphabet, Amazon.com, and Tesla. The split is seen as a sentiment effect, but Chairman Ryan Cohen's recent confidence in the company's growth may have contributed to the surge. The company cited the split as providing flexibility for future corporate needs, although the timing of the annual meeting and definitive proxy statement remain unclear.

site_title: Volkswagen selects banks for Porsche sports car IPO
summary: Volkswagen has selected Goldman Sachs Group, Bank of America, and JPMorgan Chase as joint global coordinators for the proposed IPO of Porsche, potentially valuing the sports car maker at up to 90 billion euros. The listing could allow Volkswagen to finance its electric car push and boost its valuation, while also enabling the Porsche and Piech families to regain direct influence in the company. Preparations for the IPO are ongoing, despite potential negative implications due to the ongoing conflict.

site_title: Superstar Jay Chou's mum plans IPO of bulletproof coffee brand
summary: Taiwanese pop superstar Jay Chou's mother, Yeh Hui-Mei, is planning an initial public offering (IPO) of Star Plus Legend Holdings, the top Chinese bulletproof coffee brand. The company, which holds a 40.6% market share, has filed a listing application with the Hong Kong stock exchange. Star Plus is expanding into new areas and leveraging Chou's celebrity-related intellectual property. The company's business was started in 2017 and has pre-IPO investors including Simon Ho and Vincent Fang. The IPO aims to capitalize on the growing popularity of low-carb diets and bulletproof coffee.

site_title: Another side of tech titans?
summary: Tech industry startups face criticism for poor work environments, including unclear targets, unrealistic timelines, and organisational injustice. Workers are leaving despite Big Tech offering salary bumps of 20-25%. This trend raises concerns about a culture mismatch, similar to China's notorious 996 work culture. Meanwhile, unrelated articles discuss lifestyle, entrepreneurship, and sustainability initiatives.

site_title: PM Lee: Effort to tackle climate crisis not helped by geopolitical tensions
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that global efforts to mitigate climate change will be "inadequate" due to geopolitical tensions, including the Russia-Ukraine war and US-China relations. Despite Singapore's own efforts, with a goal of reaching net-zero emissions by 2050, PM Lee believes that the lack of cooperation among major emitters will hinder progress. He emphasized that trust and dialogue are crucial for addressing climate change, citing the need for "serious conversations at very senior levels" to resolve issues.

site_title: Toshiba's top shareholder would sell stake if Bain launches tender offer
summary: Toshiba's top shareholder, Effissimo Capital Management, has agreed to sell its 9.9% stake to Bain Capital if the US private equity firm launches a tender offer. Bain plans to team up with Japanese investment funds to make a buyout offer, with the goal of owning at least 2/3 of Toshiba. Toshiba's devices unit was previously voted down by shareholders, but the company is open to reconsidering its strategic options to enhance value. Other global private equity firms are also interested in taking Toshiba private.

site_title: Property price index grows at slower pace in Q1 2022 post-cooling measures: URA
summary: The property price index in Singapore grew 0.4% in Q1 2022, marking the eighth consecutive quarter of increases, but at a slower pace than the 5% jump in Q4 2021. The growth is attributed to the government's property curbs and rising interest rates, which are expected to keep the market subdued in Q2. Despite this, demand from genuine homebuyers is expected to remain strong, with transaction volumes likely to pick up as more projects are launched for sale.

site_title: Shanghai residents rush to stock up as second stage of lockdown looms
summary: Residents in Shanghai's western districts stock up on groceries ahead of a second stage of lockdown, which will restrict public transport and lock residents in their homes. The city is in its fourth day of a two-stage lockdown, with authorities urging cooperation to stop the spread of Covid-19. Despite easing of daily Covid caseload, residents express frustration over disruptions to their lives and businesses. The Shanghai government acknowledges its limitations in addressing the crisis and vows to improve food supplies and medical assistance.

site_title: Keppel T&T to divest entire stake in Keppel Logistics for S$80m
summary: Keppel Telecommunications and Transportation (Keppel T&T) will divest its entire stake in Keppel Logistics to Geodis International SAS for S$80 million, a move aimed at simplifying and focusing its business. The divestment, expected to take place in the second quarter, will cease Keppel Logistics as a subsidiary and unlock capital for Keppel Group's growth initiatives. Keppel Logistics has been operating at a sub-scale level and is considered a non-core business, with the transaction valued at S$150 million on a cash-free, debt-free basis.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 open lower on last day of rough quarter
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 opened lower on the last day of the quarter, with the Dow falling 27.29 points (0.08%) and the S&P 500 down 3.43 points (0.07%). Investors focused on the conflict in Ukraine and concerns over US interest rate hikes. The Nasdaq Composite gained 2.50 points (0.02%). This marked the worst quarter for the main indexes since the pandemic crash in 2020.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 27.29 points or 0.08 per cent, at the open to 35,201.52.

site_title: Asia: Shares slip on gloomy outlook as Ukraine, recession risks weigh
summary: Asian shares fell on Friday, April 1, 2022, amid a gloomy outlook due to the Russian-Ukrainian war and rising recession risks. The largest quarterly drop in global equities in 2 years weighed on investors, with Japan's business confidence hitting a 9-month low. US shares, however, defied concerns with a late comeback in the S&P500 index, finishing the quarter about 5% off. Investors will monitor US March jobs data for indications of wage inflation, which may impact the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance.

images.alt_text: Seoul's Kospi lost about 0.6 per cent while Hong Kong's Hang Seng dipped 1.1 per cent. Chinese blue-chips turned around from a lower open to rise 0.7 per cent.

site_title: PetroChina plans to boost renewables output, posts biggest profit in 7 years
summary: PetroChina, China's largest oil and gas producer, aims to boost its renewable energy output to 1/3 of its energy portfolio by 2035 and 50% by 2050. The company reported its largest profit in 7 years, with a net profit of 92.17 billion yuan in 2021. PetroChina plans to reduce capital expenditure and increase spending on exploration and production to boost production at key domestic basins. The company also aims to peak its carbon emissions by 2025 and reach near zero emissions by 2050, ahead of China's national target of peaking carbon by 2030.

site_title: UOB to issue US$2.1b worth of notes under US$30b global MTN programme
summary: UOB announced plans to issue US$2.1 billion worth of notes under its US$30 billion global medium-term note (MTN) programme, with three series of notes to be issued on April 7, 2022. The senior notes will be priced at 3.059% and 3.863% respectively, while the subordinated notes will be priced at 3.863%. The offerings are expected to be well-received by global investors, with UOB's orderbook reaching over US$4.5 billion before the Europe open.

site_title: Oil prices dive as US considers record reserves release
summary: US oil prices dropped by 6-7% as the country considers releasing 180 million barrels from its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, the largest in nearly 50 years. This move aims to stabilize prices amid market volatility. The release, if implemented, would be the largest in SPR history. Brent crude futures fell to $106.50 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate futures fell to $100.54 a barrel.

site_title: Coffee sales slow in Vietnam on low supplies, Indonesia discounts steady
summary: Vietnam's coffee supplies tightened due to farmers holding onto remaining beans, while discounts in Indonesia remained steady. In Vietnam, coffee prices remained unchanged, with farmers asking for higher prices due to rising production costs. Coffee exports from Vietnam rose 19.4% in the first quarter, valued at US$394 million. In Indonesia, robusta beans were offered at discounts of US$150 to US$160, with some areas experiencing a mini harvest.

site_title: Dubai to close shutters on lavish world fair
summary: Dubai's Expo 2020 world fair is set to close on March 31, marking the end of a six-month extravaganza that drew 23 million visitors, exceeding its 25 million target. The $7 billion event, which opened six months late due to the pandemic, featured performances by Christina Aguilera and DJ Tiesto, and will leave behind a multi-billion-dollar mini-city in the desert. Despite inauspicious start and safety concerns, Expo has been a point of pride for Dubai's rulers, and its legacy will live on as a car-free "15-minute city" with a focus on innovation and sustainability.

site_title: 'More time and deliberation' needed in potential combination of Keppel O&M, Sembmarine
summary: Keppel Corporation and Sembcorp Marine have stated that more time and deliberation are needed to advance the proposed combination of their entities, Keppel Offshore & Marine (O&M) and Sembmarine. The companies made significant progress but still need to complete due diligence, reach mutual agreement on transaction terms, and finalize definitive legal documentation. They have committed to continuing exclusive negotiations and working towards a definitive agreement by April 30 this year. The proposed combination aims to create a stronger combined entity, leveraging respective strengths to deliver sustainable value over the long term for shareholders.

site_title: US jobless claims rise more than forecast, but level remains low
summary: US jobless claims rose 14,000 to 202,000 in the week ended March 26, surpassing the median forecast. Continuing claims fell to 1.3 million, indicating a tight labor market. The increase likely reflects the data's volatility, with employers competing to retain workers amid dwindling savings and high inflation. This data precedes the Friday employment report, which is expected to show the US added 500,000 jobs in March with a 3.7% unemployment rate.

site_title: Nets to work with local banks to pilot loan solutions for SMEs
summary: Nets, a payment services group, has announced a partnership with local banks to pilot loan solutions for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore. The initiative aims to provide flexible repayment plans and quick approvals, with payment-related data from Nets helping to streamline the loan application process. Participating banks, such as DBS, will offer tailored financing solutions to SMEs, allowing them to expand their businesses or address cash flow needs. The pilot phase is expected to refine loan-related products and ultimately enable seamless payments via Nets' point-of-sales terminals.

site_title: Fifa heads for record US$7b revenues
summary: FIFA is on track to generate record revenues of $7 billion, surpassing its target of $6.4 billion for the 4-year period up to 2022 by $600 million. The organization's finances, despite past scandals, have seen a significant boost from television broadcasting rights, sponsors, and marketing. FIFA's revenue for 2021 was $766 million, with the organization already reaching $6.11 billion of its target income by the end of last year. The financial boom is attributed to the World Cup in Qatar, which has attracted new sponsors and broadcasters, and FIFA's efforts to expand its presence in new platforms.

site_title: Norway central bank to buy currency for wealth fund for first time since 2013
summary: Norway's central bank, Norges Bank, plans to buy foreign currency for its sovereign wealth fund in April, the first time in almost nine years. The move is due to the surge in the country's oil and gas revenues, weakening the crown currency. The central bank will exchange $231.9 million per day into foreign currency, to be invested abroad by the wealth fund, valued at $1.3 trillion. This may weaken the currency, according to economists, who also note that structural liquidity is expected to improve.

site_title: Japan will not abandon Sakhalin-2 LNG stake, PM Kishida says
summary: Japan will not abandon its stake in the Sakhalin-2 liquefied natural gas (LNG) project in Russia, according to Prime Minister Fumio Kishida. The project is essential to Japan's energy security, and Tokyo has repeatedly stated its importance despite Western oil majors planning to pull out due to the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Kishida emphasized that securing a stable and low-priced LNG supply is crucial for Japan's long-term energy needs.

site_title: Bank of Japan offers to boost April-June bond buying in yield cap defence
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) announced plans to increase its bond purchases in the second quarter, aiming to defend its yield cap against rising global interest rates. The BOJ will boost purchases for government bonds across the yield curve, with the 10-year Japanese government bond yield falling to 0.210% after rising to 0.225%. The move aims to keep monetary policy ultra-loose, despite the US Federal Reserve's plans for rate hikes. The BOJ's yield curve control policy targets the 10-year JGB yield around zero, with a cap of 0.25%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.14 points to 1,587.36, closing higher on Thursday. The index saw a volume of 2.860 billion lots worth RM2.363 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 530 to 370.

site_title: Singapore hotel industry takings could be near-normal by year-end
summary: Singapore's hotel industry is expected to recover near-normal by year-end, with visitor arrivals and hotel revenues picking up in February amid the reopening of international borders. Hotel room revenues reached S$100.8 million, with occupancy improving by 5-10 percentage points year-on-year and room rates rising by 8-10%. RevPAR is projected to hit over 70% of pre-pandemic levels, driven by room rates and aviation-related bookings. The easing of restrictions in source countries, such as India and Indonesia, is expected to contribute to the growth.

site_title: DBS not opening crypto services to retail market 'anytime in the immediate future': Piyush Gupta
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, will not extend crypto trading services to retail consumers in the near future, according to CEO Piyush Gupta. Gupta stated that regulators are "rightfully concerned" about allowing crypto in the retail market and that the environment will not allow for its availability anytime soon. This decision comes despite DBS's existing crypto trading services being available to accredited and institutional investors. The bank plans to focus on designing guidelines for retail investors and will instead launch a carbon offset program for retail consumers.

site_title: All beefed up at Yakiniquest
summary: Yakiniquest, a Japanese yakiniku restaurant in Singapore, offers a unique dining experience where customers can enjoy high-quality beef dishes cooked to perfection by expert chefs. The restaurant features ceramic charcoal gas stoves that provide a BBQ flavor without the smoke and fumes. With a focus on omakase and add-ons, diners can customize their meal to suit their preferences. The restaurant's menu showcases a range of beef cuts, including wagyu, and offers a variety of cooking styles and timing. Despite some minor flaws, Yakiniquest delivers a good to very good dining experience for its price, earning a rating of 7.

site_title: Low Keng Huat sinks deeper into red in H2 with S$4.3m loss
summary: Low Keng Huat, a Singaporean builder, reported a net loss of S$4.3 million for the 6 months ended Jan 31, 2022, compared to a net loss of S$3.1 million in the same period last year. The company attributed the loss to lower profit from its investment segment, but its hotel and development segments performed better. Revenue rose 44% to S$72.7 million in the 6 months and 120.4% to S$161.6 million for the full year. The board has proposed a 2 Singapore cents per share dividend, pending shareholder approval.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open after oil prices slump
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on March 31, driven by a 4% slump in oil prices. The FTSE 100 index gained 0.1%, while the DAX and CAC 40 indices rose 0.4% and 0.1%, respectively. The US is considering tapping its oil reserves to combat a supply crisis sparked by the Ukraine war.

images.alt_text: European stock markets climbed at the open on Thursday (Mar 31) following a slump in oil prices.
