site_title: China Evergrande to sell stake in Crystal City Project for 3.7b yuan
summary: China Evergrande will sell its stake in the Crystal City Project for 3.7 billion yuan, repaying construction fees and expecting a gain of about 216 million yuan. The sale comes as the embattled developer addresses liquidity issues and plans to unveil a debt restructuring proposal by the end of July. This move is part of efforts to resolve financial health concerns, following a delay in publishing annual results.

site_title: New York man admits to insider trading, after being linked to reporter's tips
summary: A New York City man, Jason Peltz, 39, pleaded guilty to 2 counts of insider trading and tax evasion, admitting to using information from a Bloomberg News reporter about certain deals to trade. Peltz's scheme, which ran from 2015 to 2020, involved frequent conversations with reporter Ed Hammond, who is not accused of any wrongdoing. Peltz is scheduled to be sentenced in July and faces up to 20 years in prison.

site_title: Embrace digital payments now to profit from tomorrow's seamless ecosystem
summary: The adoption of digital payments in Asean is accelerating due to changing customer expectations for simpler, faster, and more flexible payment options. The region's digital payment market has grown 20% in 2021 to $707 billion, forecast to reach $1,169 billion by 2025. Strong regulatory support and the launch of real-time payment platforms such as Singapore's FAST and PromptPay are driving this growth. Companies of all sizes and sectors must embrace digital payments to tap into the region's borderless digital payment ecosystem, offering seamless and contactless cross-border payments in local currencies.

images.alt_text: We are heading towards a future where Asean can be borderless and the region is connected by a digital payment ecosystem, in which there is a common digital language across real-time information exchange and instantaneous payments in the region says Standard Chartered's Ankur Kanwar.

site_title: Seafarer crisis worsens as war drags on
summary: The ongoing war in Ukraine is taking a devastating toll on seafarers, with nearly 15% of the global shipping industry's workforce from Ukraine and Russia affected. Approximately 1,000 crew members are stranded on ships in Ukrainian ports, facing life-threatening conditions due to lack of food, water, and bunkers. Despite efforts by the International Transport Workers' Federation and International Chamber of Shipping, the situation remains dire, with 5 seafarers reported killed. The International Maritime Organization has condemned Russia's actions and proposed the establishment of a "blue safe maritime corridor" to evacuate seafarers, but its implementation is uncertain due to ongoing hostilities.

site_title: CDL to make 'significant gains' from sale of Tanglin Shopping Centre
summary: CDL is set to make a "significant gain" from the sale of Tanglin Shopping Centre to Hillthorpe Investments for S$868 million, representing a sale price of S$2,769 per square foot per plot ratio. The sale, which includes 85 strata lots, complements CDL's strategy to divest assets at a premium to net book value. The sale price is about 10% above the reserve price, marking a successful fourth attempt at a collective sale.

images.alt_text: Exterior of Tanglin Shopping Centre, which is being sold by City Developments for S$868 million to Pacific Eagle Real Estate.

site_title: Lululemon forecasts strong 2022, plans selective price hikes
summary: Lululemon Athletica forecasts full-year 2022 revenue between $7.5 billion and $7.6 billion, exceeding analyst estimates, and plans selective price hikes to offset pressure on average unit cost due to supply chain issues. The company reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter adjusted earnings, with shares rising 8% in extended trading. Lululemon expects full-year profit between $9.15 and $9.35 per share, beating estimates. CEO Calvin McDonald stated that the price increases will be modest and impact only a small portion of styles.

site_title: Putin and the myths of Western decadence
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine was a catastrophic mistake that destroyed Russia's military reputation and battered its economy. Putin's decision was likely driven by a strongman syndrome, where he surrounded himself with yes-men and believed in his own propaganda about his army's martial prowess and Ukrainian submission. The article suggests that the real decadence in the West lies not in traditional family values, but in the decline of democratic values such as the rule of law and a willingness to accept election results. This decline is exemplified in the US, where politicians have shown contempt for democratic principles and a willingness to do whatever it takes to win, including attempting to overturn the election.

site_title: US prosecutors cast doubt on ex-Goldman banker's wife testimony at 1MDB trial
summary: US prosecutors cast doubt on the testimony of Tan Teck Long, the wife of former Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng, who is on trial for allegedly helping to loot Malaysia's 1MDB sovereign wealth fund. Ng, 49, has pleaded not guilty to conspiring to launder money and violating an anti-corruption law. Prosecutors question the reliability of Tan Teck Long's testimony, citing inconsistencies and potential biases. The trial continues, with Ng's defense team working to discredit the prosecution's case.

site_title: CNN+ subscription streaming news service launches
summary: CNN launched its streaming news service, CNN+, on March 29, 2022, with a mix of familiar faces, original series, and new features. The service costs $5.99/month and offers live, on-demand, and interactive programming with an emphasis on original content. The launch comes ahead of the anticipated sale of CNN parent WarnerMedia to Discovery, with Chris Licht becoming chairman and CEO of CNN Global in May. The service is available on Amazon Fire TV, Android, and Apple devices, and offers a 50% discount for subscribers who sign up within the first 4 weeks.

images.alt_text: CNN launched its streaming news service CNN+ on Tuesday (Mar 29) with a mix of familiar faces such as Anderson Cooper and Chris Wallace, original series and new features like the Interview Club, where viewers pose their own questions to experts.

site_title: US job openings hover near record high in February
summary: US job openings fell 17,000 to 11.266 million in February, near a record high of 11.448 million set in December. This marks the second straight monthly decline, but economists had forecast 11 million vacancies. Despite this, labor demand remains strong, indicating companies continue to struggle to find workers.

site_title: Bayer shareholder Union Investment says CEO should stay on
summary: Bayer's CEO Werner Baumann is facing renewed pressure to step down, but top shareholder Union Investment has come out in support of his remaining contract until 2024. The decision comes after Singapore state investor Temasek pushed for his removal, citing concerns over the company's performance and lack of succession planning. Union Investment's head of capital markets, Janne Werning, cited recent positive changes, including improved crop science division results and successful drug development transactions, as reasons for supporting Baumann's continuation.

site_title: DoorDash weighs speed versus profits in rapid delivery pilot
summary: DoorDash, the largest US food-delivery company, is weighing the balance between speed and profits in its rapid delivery pilot. CEO Christopher Payne stated that offering a 15-minute delivery service may not be profitable, and instead, 30-minute delivery might be more viable. DoorDash has launched a 15-minute delivery pilot in New York and plans to scale up for better efficiency. Payne believes customers will still be delighted by 30-minute delivery, and growth in the delivery sector remains high despite decelerated growth from the COVID-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: It may not be possible to offer a 15-minute delivery service and be profitable, DoorDash chief operating officer Christopher Payne said at an industry conference on Tuesday (Mar 29).

site_title: Vietnam's Q1 GDP growth tops 5%, though headwinds seen
summary: Vietnam's GDP grew 5.03% in the first quarter, surpassing the 4.72% recorded last year. The country's manufacturing and construction sectors expanded 6.38% and 4.58%, respectively, while services grew 4.58% and agriculture by 2.45%. Exports rose 12.9% to $88.6 billion, and imports increased 15.9% to $87.8 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of $809 million. However, new headwinds, including higher oil prices and slowing global growth, may impact Vietnam's recovery.

site_title: Announcement of SOPs for Malaysian workers in Singapore postponed to Mar 30
summary: The standard operating procedures (SOPs) for Malaysian workers commuting to Singapore have been postponed to March 30, after a dry run at Second Link. Johor's Health and Unity committee, led by Ling Tian Soon, will discuss the SOPs. The land borders will reopen on April 1 for inoculated travelers, with no need for pre-departure and arrival tests or quarantine. Over 1,600 police officers will be deployed to manage traffic and ensure visitor safety.

site_title: New loan scheme to help seniors unlock an income from their home
summary: A new loan scheme, AN LIVING Wealth Access, has been launched to help Singaporean retirees unlock an income from their homes. The interest-free loan disburses up to 80% of the property's future sales proceeds, with a 20-year term and fees including an upfront non-refundable fee and a 20-year utilisation fee. To qualify, homeowners must be 55 or older, have unencumbered freehold or 999-year leasehold properties, and be accredited investors. The loan is designed to enhance financial security and support healthcare needs, with excess funds to be managed by financial advisory firms.

site_title: Asia tech opportunities abound
summary: Asia is a fertile ground for promising technology investments, driven by its role as the nucleus of the global semiconductor supply chain. Key themes include electric vehicles, metaverse, and automation and industrial digitization. Panelists identify opportunities in infrastructure and content for the metaverse, and in industrial technology companies, such as EV battery and solar suppliers. Asia's large digital consumer base, low labor costs, and robust infrastructure make it an attractive location for technology investments. Despite concerns about valuation, Asia's technology sector is expected to deliver sustainable growth and double its intrinsic value in the coming 3-5 years.

site_title: HK home prices drop to 13-month low after new Covid infections
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices dropped 2.08% in February to their lowest since January 2021, amid a new wave of Covid-19 infections. The decline, the largest since November 2018, follows a year of consolidating prices after reaching an all-time high in September. The city remains the world's most unaffordable housing market for the 12th consecutive year. Experts expect a 50% drop in home transaction volume in the first quarter, but a recovery in the second half if the pandemic is brought under control.

site_title: Old Chang Kee weathers pandemic with 'zero retrenchment' thanks to JSS
summary: Old Chang Kee, a Singaporean fried food and beverage chain, weathered the pandemic without retrenching a single staff member due to payouts from the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS). As of March 2022, the company had around 596 employees, despite reducing costs by reducing overtime and freezing salary increments in 2021. The company also provided bonuses and training to its staff during the pandemic, and is now in a better position to do without the extra support. This is a notable achievement for the company, which has over 90 outlets across the island.

images.alt_text: During the peak of the pandemic, the company sought to maintain the base salaries of all its staff by reducing overtime, to bring total costs down.

site_title: JSS kept premium gifts brand Risis afloat so it could pivot to e-commerce, rebrand
summary: Jewellery and premium gifts brand Risis, which cut staff from 87 to 49 due to the pandemic, credits Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) payouts for its ability to rebrand and pivot to e-commerce. CEO Verene Ng stated that staff reductions were mainly due to natural attrition and non-key positions, rather than layoffs. Without JSS, the cuts might have been deeper, highlighting the impact of the scheme on the company's ability to adapt and survive during the pandemic.

site_title: Asean Exchanges publishes table comparing sustainability reporting regimes
summary: ASEAN Exchanges has published a table comparing sustainability reporting regimes across its 7 member exchanges in 6 countries, aiming to establish a set of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) metrics for listed companies. The table lists foundational environmental metrics, including greenhouse gas emissions, energy consumption, water consumption, and waste generation. The group plans to align social and governance metrics and has solicited investor feedback on the proposal. The voluntary common set of Asean ESG metrics aims to improve ESG disclosure practices by listed companies in the region.

site_title: Tokyo's historic Nakagin tower to be demolished
summary: The historic Nakagin Capsule Tower in Tokyo, designed by Kisho Kurokawa in 1972, will be demolished on April 12 after a long battle to save the building. Owners plan to extract some of the deteriorated white cuboid capsules, refurbish them, and send them to museums. The demolition comes after years of redevelopment threats and increasing maintenance costs. While some capsule owners are sad to see the building go, others see it as a necessary decision to dismantle a structure that had become shabby and expensive to maintain.

site_title: Global art market has fully rebounded from its Covid-19 downswing
summary: The global art market has fully rebounded from its Covid-19 downswing, reaching US$65.1 billion in 2021, a 29% increase from 2020. The US led global sales with US$28 billion, followed by Greater China and the UK. Post-war and contemporary art dominated the auction market, with global auction sales rising 47% to US$26.3 billion. Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) also saw significant growth, with sales totaling US$2.6 billion and a median expenditure of US$9,000 among high-net-worth collectors.

site_title: Lotus electric SUV is a lean, mean, China-made driving machine
summary: Lotus, a British carmaker, unveiled its first electric SUV, the Eletre, at a London event. The 600-horsepower vehicle will be built in China and features a 4-door design with a flat "skateboard-style" battery pack and 2 electric motors. The Eletre boasts a top speed of 161 mph and a 0-62 mph time of 3 seconds, rivaling other premium electric EVs. The SUV is part of Geely's plan to pivot Lotus to "lifestyle" vehicles and aims to boost sales from 1,710 vehicles in 2021 to 150,000 annually. Deliveries are planned for early 2023 in 10 markets, with sales in other world markets starting in 2024.

images.alt_text: The Lotus Eletre is the British brand's first SUV.

site_title: Sembmarine drops 4.9% after giving notice of 3 straight years of losses
summary: Sembcorp Marine shares dropped 4.9% after the company announced three consecutive years of pre-tax losses. The marine and offshore group's shares closed at S$0.10, with 297.8 million shares changing hands. Despite the losses, the group still meets the financial entry criteria to avoid being placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch list, with a 6-month average daily market capitalization of S$2.6 billion. The company had previously reported net losses of S$523.3 million for its second half in 2021, citing challenges from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Britain may be wasting nearly £3b on Covid gear
summary: The UK's National Audit Office reported that the government may have wasted nearly £3 billion on Covid-19 gear, with £700 million spent on storage alone. The health ministry identified 3.6 billion unsuitable items, and 1.5 billion PPE items were past expiry date. The audit office estimated £2.7 billion at risk, with 176 contracts deemed unvalueable. The government defended its actions, citing the need for adequate PPE during the pandemic. The public may lose patience with ongoing costs, with the taxpayer expected to foot the bill for storing unneeded gear.

site_title: Employers to receive over S$145m in final JSS payouts from Mar 31
summary: Employers in Singapore will receive over S$145 million in final Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) payouts starting March 31, supporting the wages of over 289,500 local employees. The payouts cover wages from November to December 2021, primarily benefiting sectors affected by safe management measures, such as food services. Eligible employers must have made mandatory CPF contributions and registered for PayNow Corporate. The JSS has saved over 165,000 local jobs since its introduction in 2020.

site_title: Want to be a better investor? Learn from your errors
summary: Investors can learn from their mistakes to improve their investment process. Recognizing errors is crucial, as it represents a violation of expectations and provides learning opportunities. By acknowledging mistakes, investors can refine their investment philosophy and adapt to new information. Keeping a diary of investment decisions and analyzing past mistakes can help identify unhealthy patterns and bad habits. An iterative process of learning from mistakes is essential, and investors should avoid justifying or explaining errors. By doing so, investors can reduce the frequency of mistakes and ensure that future errors are minor, ultimately becoming better investors.

site_title: Debate over CPF for gig workers masks real problem of fair wages
summary: Singapore's gig workers, particularly food delivery riders, are facing financial uncertainty due to the potential reclassification to employee status, which could lead to mandatory Central Provident Fund (CPF) contributions. Despite platforms claiming median hourly earnings of $12-$18, riders face variable earnings, lack of paid waiting time, and volatile incentives. Critics argue that this masks the real issue of insufficient fair wages, and that riders' concerns have been under-represented. The Advisory Committee on Platform Workers will consider feedback from recent surveys, emphasizing the need for more recognition of employee status and labor rights.

images.alt_text: A recent survey showed that over 60 per cent of delivery riders do not want CPF contributions to be deducted from their earnings. Could this indicate that their delivery earnings are insufficient?

site_title: Analysts say Shopee's India exit raises Sea's prospect of profitability
summary: Sea is shutting down its Shopee business in India, citing "global market uncertainties". This move could allow the company to focus on other markets and raise its prospect of profitability. The decision only affects retail and not gaming activities. Sea will withdraw from India's retail market, marking a strategic shift in its business strategy.

site_title: How Bridgerton touches on colonialism in India
summary: The Netflix series Bridgerton includes Indian characters in Regency-era London, accurately reflecting the historical ties between India and England during the 1800s. The show's inclusion of South Asian characters and cultural elements is a deliberate choice to expand the series' "multi-hued, multi-ethnic" world. Historians and experts consulted on the show's authenticity, which explores themes of colonialism, racism, and relationships between Indian women and white men. The series also highlights the flow of goods and culture between India and England during this period, showcasing the complexities of colonialism and its impact on Indian communities.

site_title: Linking ESG to remuneration: The case of Top Glove
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest glove manufacturer, has linked its ESG metrics to executive remuneration since FY2021, but lacks transparency on the actual impact of these metrics on remuneration. The company has set 40% of key performance indicators tied to social and environmental pillars, but did not disclose individual weightings or how ESG metrics affect remuneration. Only two of the top 10 executives received bonuses in FY2021, suggesting little short-term incentive pay. The company should consider providing more information and linking ESG to both short-term and long-term incentive pay.

images.alt_text: Although the company disclosed an overall 40 per cent weighting for the ESG key performance indicators (KPIs) for FY2021, it did not disclose the individual weighting for the KPIs.

site_title: Democracy is the next identity politics
summary: Global reactions to Russia's invasion of Ukraine contradict Putin's claim that the liberal idea is obsolete. The invasion highlights the importance of democracy and human rights. The article references a 20-year-old Harvard anecdote about vegetarian meal options being considered morally equivalent to the Holocaust, showcasing the growing awareness of social and environmental issues. The invasion serves as a stark reminder of the need for global cooperation and the preservation of democratic values.

site_title: Among glove makers, Riverstone has most attractive margins
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest glove manufacturer, has the lowest profit margins and returns among its peers, with operating profit margins at 12.3% and a small net profit margin of 9%. In contrast, Riverstone Holdings has the highest profit margins, with a 39.3% gain, and lower borrowings, which likely resulted in lower financing costs. Despite its low profit margins, Top Glove has the highest price-to-earnings ratio among its peers, leading some to speculate that the market may be anticipating a recovery for the company.

site_title: Realising Singapore's ambition to become a Little Green Dot
summary: Singapore has set an ambitious goal to achieve net zero emissions by mid-century, accelerating its initial target of "as soon as viable in the second half of the century". To achieve this, the government has introduced a higher carbon tax rate, increasing from S$5 to S$50-80 per tonne of emissions by 2030. The government plans to reinvest carbon tax proceeds into skills development and green capabilities, including upskilling the workforce in sustainable finance and investments. The move aims to cushion the impact on companies and encourage a smooth transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: JSS kept premium gifts brand Risis afloat so it could pivot to e-commerce, rebrand
summary: Jewellery brand Risis, heavily reliant on brick-and-mortar sales, pivoted to e-commerce during the pandemic thanks to Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) payouts, allowing it to retain key employees. The company cut staff from 87 to 49 due to Covid-19's impact, but JSS helped sustain most jobs for 9 months. Risis will rebrand as a fashion and lifestyle brand, shifting focus from souvenirs and gifts to online sales, and will complete the rebranding in April with a launch event.

site_title: Portfolio of 18 strata units at Orchard Shopping Centre for sale at S$90m indicative price
summary: A portfolio of 18 strata-titled retail units at Orchard Shopping Centre in Singapore is up for sale with an indicative price of S$90 million. The freehold units, spanning 8,934 square feet, are fully occupied and include tenants such as Maybank and a Chinese hotpot restaurant. The sale is expected to attract interest from local and foreign buyers, with no Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) or Seller's Stamp Duty (SSD) imposed on the commercial property transaction. The expression of interest exercise closes on May 4 at 3pm.

site_title: Cathay Pacific's new Hong Kong-New York route the world's longest
summary: Cathay Pacific is launching the world's longest commercial passenger flight, a 16,618 km route from Hong Kong to New York, taking 17 hours to complete. The flight will avoid Russian airspace, a decision made due to the conflict in Ukraine. The airline plans to fly over the Atlantic Ocean, the UK, southern Europe, and central Asia. The new route is expected to be more cost-effective and competitive, and Cathay is seeking overflight permits.

site_title: Creditors of KTL, NutryFarm may not share boards' faith in chairman Wu Yongqiang
summary: Creditors of KTL Global and NutryFarm International have raised concerns about the suitability of their newly appointed chairman, Wu Yongqiang, due to his involvement in several lawsuits in China. Wu has been sued in multiple cases and has unsatisfied judgments against him, including a 2015 judgment from Mercedes-Benz Financial Services for over $107,000. Despite this, the companies' boards believe Wu's lawsuits are commercial in nature and do not reflect any flaws in his character or integrity. However, Wu's creditors may view his attitude towards loans and guarantees as concerning, and it remains to be seen whether he can discharge his duties as a director without breaching listing rules.

site_title: FDA authorises second booster of Pfizer/BioNTech Covid shot
summary: The US FDA has authorised a second booster dose of Pfizer/BioNTech's Covid-19 vaccine for people 50 and older, as well as those aged 12 and older with compromised immune systems. The new boosters aim to offer more protection against severe disease and hospitalization, particularly with the highly contagious BA.2 Omicron subvariant. The move comes as Covid-19 cases in the US have seen a small uptick, and the companies plan to develop an updated vaccine that provides more durable responses.

site_title: Oil drops US$3 on positive signals from Russia-Ukraine peace talks
summary: Oil prices dropped by $3 on Tuesday, extending losses from the previous day, due to positive signals from Russia-Ukraine peace talks and new lockdowns in China. Brent crude fell 2.6% to $109.61 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell 2.8% to $103.01 a barrel. Ukrainian and Russian negotiators met in Turkey, with Russia promising to scale down military operations and Ukraine proposing a neutral status with international guarantees. However, a formal agreement remains uncertain, and analysts caution that the situation is unlikely to resolve quickly.

site_title: Deep tech finds hope in emerging sectors after heavy pandemic blow
summary: Singapore's deep tech startup industry is expected to see growth in the coming years, particularly in the spacetech and sustainable materials sectors. Despite the pandemic's impact, the industry peaked in 2019 with 87 startups incorporated, but declined to 68 in 2020 and 36 in 2021. As pandemic rules ease, SGInnovate sees opportunities emerging, with at least 8 spacetech startups incorporated since 2017 and a growing trend in sustainability. However, challenges remain, including capital intensity and unclear business models for spacetech startups.

site_title: Afghan women footballers revel in freedom to beat British MPs
summary: Afghan women's football team, resettled in the UK after an evacuation flight funded by Kim Kardashian, played a match against a British Women's Parliamentary Football Club in South London. The team, who have faced traumatic experiences under Taliban rule, prioritized their freedom to play over the match, with former sports minister Tracey Crouch praising their strength and resilience. The team's focus on human rights and playing together was deemed more important than the score, with many expressing concern for family and friends left behind in Afghanistan.

images.alt_text: Young Afghan women footballers on Tuesday (Mar 29) enjoyed a one-sided drubbing over a select team of British female MPs - but the score was secondary to their freedom to play at all.

site_title: UAE, Saudi say Opec+ should not play politics
summary: UAE and Saudi Arabia's energy ministers, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman and Suhail al-Mazrouei, stated that Opec+ should not engage in politics, emphasizing the group's focus on balancing crude oil markets and satisfying consumers. They rejected calls to expel Russia from the group, citing the potential for higher prices and instability. Opec+ is expected to stick to its plans for a modest increase in oil output in May, despite pressure from the US and other consuming nations.

site_title: Saudi Crown Prince's US$100b investment chase takes off
summary: Saudi Arabia's foreign direct investment reached its highest level in over a decade, totaling $19.3 billion in 2021, driven by a $12.4 billion oil pipeline deal. The country aims to secure $100 billion in annual FDI by 2030 under Crown Prince Mohammed Salman's national investment strategy, which includes revamping regulations and creating special economic zones to attract more investment. Despite obstacles, including investor concerns over regulations and the 2018 murder of Jamal Khashoggi, the government expects to see more multinationals establish regional headquarters in the country, with a surge in FDI expected in 2022.

site_title: Interest in VC portfolio consolidation picks up, but roadblocks aplenty
summary: Venture capitalists in South-east Asia are increasingly exploring portfolio consolidation as fund lives mature. This involves merging assets within large portfolios to create a more valuable company. However, transactions are difficult to execute due to conflicting shareholder interests and limited control. Despite the challenges, 58 M&A deals between VC-backed startups were closed last year, with 22 such transactions this year. VCs aim to exit their investee companies at a more attractive combined valuation during an initial public offering or trade sale, while also realizing some returns.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine's focus on renewables is paying off even as oil prices recover
summary: Marco Polo Marine, a Singapore-based vessel charterer and shipyard operator, is shifting focus from the oil and gas industry to renewable energy. After a debt restructuring in 2017, the company reduced its reliance on oil and gas and now offers repairs and maintenance services to merchant vessels. Revenue from ship building and repair services segment grew 51.1% in FY2021, and the company reported a profit of S$14.8 million. Marco Polo Marine is expanding into offshore wind farms, with a focus on utilizing its existing vessels, and has signed agreements to co-develop specialized wind service vessels and explore the use of drones.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit gives 2nd extension for divestment due diligence
summary: United Hampshire US Reit has given its second extension for divestment due diligence, pushing the deadline to April 4. The real estate investment trust (Reit) initially announced a March 28 deadline for the proposed sale of two self-storage properties. The purchaser is still carrying out due diligence, and the manager stated that the purchaser may terminate the agreement at any time during the extended period, resulting in a refund of the deposit. Unitholders are advised to exercise caution due to the uncertainty surrounding the divestment.

images.alt_text: Robert Schmitt, chief executive officer of United Hampshire US Reit's manager.

site_title: Cathay plans world's longest passenger flight, avoids Russian airspace
summary: Cathay Pacific plans the world's longest passenger flight, a non-stop New York to Hong Kong route covering 10,357 miles in 16-17 hours, avoiding Russian airspace. The flight path will steer clear of Russia's airspace due to the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. Cathay is seeking an overflight permit for the journey, which will fly across the Atlantic, Europe, and Central Asia, taking advantage of favorable seasonal winds. The airline aims to revive its service, which has been affected by COVID-19 restrictions and frequent cancellations.

site_title: US consumer confidence unexpectedly rises despite inflation
summary: US consumer confidence unexpectedly rose to 107.2 in March, surpassing economists' expectations, despite decades-high inflation and the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict. The Conference Board's index increased from a revised 105.7 in February, with a gauge of current conditions reaching its highest level since June. Solid job growth, with the unemployment rate at 3.7%, and steady employment gains have buoyed US households, offsetting concerns over inflation and its impact on spending.

site_title: Singapore firms keeping close eye on Shanghai lockdown
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies, including CapitaLand Investment, Yanlord Land Group, and Nanofilm Technologies, are closely monitoring the Shanghai lockdown, which began on March 28 and is expected to last until April 5. The lockdown will impact daily life and operations, with offices and construction sites closed and staff required to work from home. Companies such as Yanlord and CapitaLand plan to adjust their operations and catch up on development pace when the city reopens. Nanofilm has strict protocols in place to reduce cross-infection and is closely monitoring the situation.

images.alt_text: CLI's Raffles City The Bund. A spokesperson from CLI said "we plan to continue operating our office and logistics properties under the authorities' advisory for Shanghai's workforce to work from home, except for those in the essential sectors".

site_title: Is America back from isolationism?
summary: The US is not becoming more isolationist, contrary to recent concerns. Despite this, the country has maintained its military presence in the Pacific and expanded it under a strategy to counter China's growing power. President Joe Biden's diplomatic efforts have united the Western alliance and strengthened NATO, with Germany, Sweden, and Finland considering joining the grouping. The US has also announced new military deployments to Europe, and bipartisan support for interventionism has grown, with 70% of Americans backing economic sanctions on Russia.

site_title: Messi signs US$20m deal to promote crypto fan token firm Socios
summary: Lionel Messi has signed a 3-year deal worth over US$20 million to promote Socios.com, a crypto fan token firm, in the lead-up to the Qatar World Cup. The agreement includes a publicity and promotion campaign and does not involve crypto payments. Messi joins a growing list of global sports personalities in the crypto world, including Tom Brady and LeBron James. The deal is part of Socios' efforts to enhance the fan experience and create a more connected and rewarding future for fans worldwide.

site_title: China's largest banks signal tough times ahead
summary: China's largest banks, including China Construction Bank and Bank of China, have signaled tough times ahead due to the pandemic, global politics, and domestic real estate turmoil. Rising loan delinquencies in service sectors, such as wholesale and retail, are expected to be a major impact. Despite beating estimates with full-year net profit figures, the banks' warnings highlight a more complicated and severe business environment. Analysts predict a slowdown in China's GDP growth, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: America seems to be back from isolationism - for now
summary: The US appears to be moving away from isolationism, contrary to concerns raised by former President Trump and some allies. Despite this, the Biden administration has maintained and even expanded US military presence in the Pacific and Europe, particularly in response to China's growing military power. The recent NATO summit saw a unified Western alliance, with President Biden successfully uniting members to strengthen the alliance. Bipartisan support for the administration's interventionist approach has also been evident, with 70% of Americans supporting economic sanctions on Russia and 56% believing President Biden's response was not tough enough.

site_title: Bank of China sees fastest profit growth since 2013 on recovery
summary: Bank of China reported its fastest profit growth since 2013, with a 12.3% increase to 216.6 billion yuan in 2021, beating a median estimate. The lender's results come as China's banking sector recovers after authorities loosened lending restrictions. However, challenges persist, including a debt crisis in the property market and a resurgence of Covid infections, which threaten to sap momentum in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: UK police recommend 20 'partygate' fines with probe ongoing
summary: UK police recommend 20 fines to staff and officials close to Boris Johnson over parties during the pandemic, breaking rules imposed to contain coronavirus. The investigation into a dozen gatherings, including one in Johnson's apartment, is ongoing. The prime minister is unlikely to be targeted, but the scandal, dubbed "partygate," could heighten pressure on Johnson at a critical time. The fallout may impact local elections in May and the party's position ahead of the 2024 national poll.

site_title: Russia to buy back US$2b in Eurobond-2022 for roubles
summary: Russia announced a buyback offer on its $2 billion Eurobonds maturing on April 4, to be paid in roubles, amid tightening Western sanctions. The move follows Moscow's demand for foreign companies to pay for Russian gas in roubles. Bondholders must submit requests by March 30 to participate in the offer, which will pay 100% of the bond's nominal value. The finance ministry reserved the right to change the buyback timing and did not disclose how much of the outstanding bonds it planned to buy back.

site_title: STI up 0.06%, tracking Wall Street optimism on Ukraine-Russia peace talks
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.06% on Tuesday, led by optimism on Wall Street over Ukraine-Russia peace talks, with the benchmark Straits Times Index closing at 3,433.9. The gains were largely driven by a fall in oil prices, while Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 1.1% and Korea's Kospi increased 0.42%. However, Asian markets outside of Singapore were mixed, with mainland Chinese markets declining due to lockdowns in Shanghai.

site_title: Hong Kong replaces State Street as manager of largest ETF
summary: Hong Kong's central bank has replaced State Street's unit, State Street Global Advisors, as manager of the territory's largest exchange-traded fund, TraHK, with a value of over $14 billion. The decision follows a U-turn by SSGA last year over an investment decision linked to US sanctions on Chinese firms. Hang Seng Investment Management, a subsidiary of Hang Seng Bank, has been selected as the new manager, promising to reduce the management fee from 0.05% to 0.022% and 0.019% in the first and fourth years, respectively.

site_title: 8,164 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, 728 patients in hospitals
summary: Singapore reported 8,164 new Covid-19 cases on March 29, with 728 patients in hospitals, including 4 deaths. The number of daily cases is higher than the previous day, but lower than the figure from March 22. The Covid-19 week-on-week infection ratio remained below one for the 28th straight day at 0.69. Total Covid-19 cases in Singapore now stand at 1,085,094, with 1,258 deaths.

images.alt_text: The number of people hospitalised rose to 728 on Tuesday (March 29), MOH said in an update on its website.

site_title: Nielsen to go private in deal valuing TV-ratings company at US$16b
summary: Nielsen Holdings has agreed to be acquired by a consortium of Evergreen Coast Capital, Elliott Investment Management, and Brookfield Asset Management in a deal valuing the TV-ratings company at approximately US$16 billion. The all-cash offer has fully committed debt and equity financing, with no financing conditions, and is expected to close in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: The take-private deal values Nielsen, the television-ratings gold standard since the 1950s, at about US$16 billion including debt, according to a statement on Tuesday (Mar 29).

site_title: Russia promises to drastically scale down operations; Ukraine proposes neutrality
summary: Russia has agreed to scale down its military operations around Kyiv and Chernihiv, and Ukraine has proposed a neutral status with international guarantees to protect it from attack. Ukraine's negotiators, including Oleksander Chaly, outlined a 15-year consultation period on the status of Russian-annexed Crimea, and suggested countries like Israel, Canada, Poland, and Turkey could provide security guarantees. The proposals were made during face-to-face talks in Istanbul, marking the first meeting between the sides since March 10, and could pave the way for a ceasefire and dialogue.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on positive signs from Russia-Ukraine peace talks
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Tuesday, driven by positive signs from Russia-Ukraine peace talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 158.46 points, or 0.45%, to 35,114.35, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 27.34 and 145.49 points, respectively, at the opening bell. This uptick was attributed to optimism over the talks, which have been ongoing for weeks.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 158.46 points or 0.45 per cent at the open to 35,114.35.

site_title: French sportswear retailer Decathlon suspends activities in Russia
summary: Decathlon, a French sportswear retailer, has suspended activities in Russia due to supply difficulties, following Western companies such as McDonald's and Deutsche Bank. The decision comes amid international sanctions and pressure from customers and governments to inflict an economic price on Moscow for its invasion of Ukraine. Decathlon will continue to support its 2,500 Russian staff, while its parent company, Mulliez, will maintain operations in Russia, citing a desire to avoid losing assets or exposing local managers to legal troubles.

site_title: Singapore property developers expect little impact from Shanghai lockdown
summary: Singapore-listed property developers expect minimal disruption from Shanghai's two-stage lockdown, assuming it doesn't extend beyond April 5. Yanlord Land Group, CapitaLand Investment, and GuocoLand plan to continue operations with some staff working from home, and are prepared to catch up on development pace after the lockdown. Most properties will remain operational, with some adjustments to office and construction site closures. The lockdown's impact is expected to be relatively short-term, with no significant delay in construction progress or office operations.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 14.53 points to 1,583.42, closing lower on Tuesday. The market saw 2.61 billion lots traded worth RM1.971 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 550 to 358.

site_title: China property - Unstable foundations
summary: China's property developers have seen a 31% rally in equity prices since March 15, driven by regulatory statements suggesting the structural crisis is easing. However, sentiment remains cautious, with default rates accelerating and liquidity crunches persisting. Analysts warn that positive noises from regulators are unlikely to change the risk-adverse lending behavior among banks without concrete policy action. To change their minds, legislation supporting the property sector would be needed, including measures to dilute or relax restrictions, intervene in corporate defaults, and increase US dollar bond issuance.

site_title: Sumitomo Metal sees global nickel demand for battery use at 410,000 tonnes in 2022
summary: Global demand for nickel used in batteries is expected to rise 20% in 2022 to 410,000 tonnes, driven by solid demand for electric vehicles. Japan's Sumitomo Metal Mining, a major supplier of cathode materials for Tesla's lithium-ion batteries, made the forecast. Nickel demand for EVs is growing faster than expected, but higher prices may erode demand in the long term. The global nickel market deficit is expected to narrow to 68,000 tonnes in 2022, with supply increasing by 11.4% and demand by 8.4%.

site_title: Singapore, US sign expanded infrastructure development MOU that now covers green projects
summary: Singapore and the US have signed an expanded Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to deepen cooperation on infrastructure development, covering green and sustainable projects in Asia. The agreement, renewed and expanded from 2019, aims to mobilize private sector participation and explore new approaches. The MOU will focus on renewable energy, carbon capture, and hydrogen projects, and will foster collaboration through information sharing, deal facilitation, and capability building initiatives. The partnership is expected to unlock Asia's potential and provide more infrastructure development and financing opportunities.

site_title: NTU to work with partners to explore hydrogen-storage solutions
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) has partnered with several companies, including Chiyoda Corporation and Sembcorp Industries, to develop hydrogen-storage solutions for a green-energy future. The project aims to extract hydrogen from liquid organic hydrogen carriers and transport it efficiently, paving the way for a more economical means of hydrogen transportation. The goal is to semi-commercialize the technology by 2025 and fully commercialize it by 2030, contributing to Singapore's expansion of global hydrogen supply chains and achieving net-zero emissions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end up, lockdown drags on Shanghai
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.12% on Tuesday, driven by hopes for a Ukraine-Russia ceasefire, while mainland Chinese markets were affected by a Shanghai lockdown. The Hang Seng Index rose to 21,927.63, but the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.33% and 0.57% respectively.

site_title: Nanofilm's Shanghai operations could be disrupted from Friday
summary: Nanofilm Technologies' Shanghai operations may be disrupted due to a potential lockdown starting from Friday, April 1, in response to the Covid-19 surge. The company has strict protocols to reduce cross-infection and believes the lockdown will not have a significant impact on its business. Nanofilm has two plants in Shanghai, with the second plant commencing operations in February 2021. The company is in active supply-chain dialogue to mitigate disruptions and will make timely announcements if production activities are affected.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Yanlord pauses construction on Shanghai projects amid lockdown. Employers to receive over S$145m in final Jobs Support Scheme payouts starting March 31. The Land Transport Authority calls for 12,000 EV charging points installation by 2025. A new interest-free loan scheme for seniors aims to unlock income from their homes. Sembcorp Marine records 3 consecutive years of pre-tax losses but meets criteria to avoid watch list. Singapore stocks rise 0.06% on Wall Street optimism over peace talks between Ukraine and Russia.

site_title: Tata Motors says 20% rise in battery cell costs increasing short-term pressure
summary: Tata Motors, India's top-selling electric carmaker, faces short-term pressure due to a 20% increase in battery cell costs, mainly due to a global surge in raw material prices such as lithium. The company expects this pressure to moderate within a year, but rising demand for "green personal mobility" is expected to offset some costs by increasing locally sourced components. The global trend of falling battery prices is threatened by Russia's invasion of Ukraine, potentially slowing the adoption of electric vehicles in price-sensitive markets like India.

site_title: Indonesia raises 17.05 trillion rupiah from bond auction, below target
summary: Indonesia raised 17.05 trillion rupiah from a biweekly bond auction, falling short of its target of 20 trillion rupiah due to market uncertainty. The auction saw 41.62 trillion rupiah in bids, the lowest in the past year, amid concerns over the conflict between Russia and Ukraine. Investors were cautious, with most bonds selling at higher weighted average yields. The finance ministry plans an additional auction to raise 2.95 trillion rupiah, despite Indonesia having a $1.4 billion budget surplus.

site_title: New interest-free loan scheme to help seniors unlock an income from their homes
summary: AN LIVING has launched a new interest-free loan scheme called "Wealth Access" to help Singaporean seniors unlock an income from their homes. The scheme allows homeowners aged 55 or older to borrow up to 80% of their property's value for up to 20 years, with no monthly repayments required. The loan is disbursed interest-free, but comes with upfront and utilisation fees. The loan proceeds are used to top up the senior's Central Provident Fund (CPF) Retirement Account, maximizing CPF Life monthly payouts from age 65.

site_title: Realising Singapore's ambitions to become the Little Green Dot
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced a shift to achieving net-zero emissions by mid-century, a marked acceleration from the initial timeline. The government increased carbon taxes to S$50-80 per tonne by 2030, signaling companies to seriously investigate their emissions and transition plans. To cushion the impact, the government will reinvest carbon tax revenue to support a just transition and invest in building green capabilities, including upskilling the workforce in sustainable finance and investments. This move aims to position Singapore as a leading green finance hub regionally and globally, creating new job opportunities in the low-carbon economy.

site_title: Kim Jong Un lied about firing newer version of ICBM, says Seoul
summary: North Korea claimed to have successfully tested a new, highly advanced ICBM, but South Korean defence officials say the footage was likely from a 2017 test, and the actual missile launched last week was an older model, the Hwasong-15. The officials pointed to inconsistencies in the video, including shadows and cloud cover that didn't match the weather on the day of the launch. The claim was seen as an attempt by the Kim regime to bolster its image and distract from technical problems with its more advanced Hwasong-17 missile.

site_title: Want to be a better investor? Learn from your errors
summary: Investors can learn from their mistakes to become better investors, just like the aviation industry uses black boxes to analyze crashes. Recognizing errors and learning from them is essential in a complex world. By keeping an open mind and acknowledging the possibility of mistakes, investors can refine their process and avoid costly errors. Writing down investment decisions and analyzing past mistakes can help identify unhealthy patterns and bad habits, leading to a more robust investment process. The goal is to make fewer mistakes and ensure that any future errors are minor, allowing for continued learning and improvement.

site_title: Britain blocks US$5b Cargotec-Konecranes merger on competition concerns
summary: Britain's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) blocked a proposed US$4.95 billion merger between Finnish industrial machinery firms Cargotec and Konecranes Abp due to "substantial" competition concerns. The merger would harm competition in the supply of container handling products in the UK, potentially leading to higher prices and lower quality products. The CMA's decision comes after the European Union gave the deal conditional antitrust approval last month. The two companies will need to address competition concerns before any further action can be taken.

site_title: Putin and the myths of Western decadence
summary: Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine was a catastrophic blunder that destroyed Russia's military reputation and battered its economy. The invasion was fueled by Putin's strongman syndrome and his belief in the propaganda that his army was invincible and that Ukrainians would submit to Russian rule. However, modern democracies are not weakened by decadence in traditional family values, but by the decline of traditional democratic values such as a belief in the rule of law and a willingness to accept election results. The article argues that the US is also vulnerable to this type of decadence, with a growing contempt for democratic principles and a willingness to undermine the democratic system.

site_title: Omicron sub-variant BA.2 makes up about 55% of Covid variants in US, says CDC
summary: The BA.2 sub-variant of Omicron, accounting for approximately 55% of circulating Covid variants in the US, has raised concerns of another wave of infections. Despite this, overall cases are declining, and health experts believe a new surge is unlikely. The 7-day moving average of US Covid-19 cases was 27,895 as of March 26, a 4% increase from the previous week. The CDC has revised its estimates, with BA.2 making up 39% of circulating variants, down from 34.9% previously.

site_title: Kuaishou sales top estimates in defiance of China slowdown
summary: Kuaishou Technology's revenue for the 3 months ended December rose 35% to 24.4 billion yuan, beating analyst estimates. Despite China's economic slowdown, the company's online advertising business is coping with scrutiny in industries like insurance and edtech. Its net loss narrowed to 6.2 billion yuan, thanks to government grants and tax subsidies. Kuaishou is joining peers in embracing cautious expansion in China's giant internet sector, where live-streaming and e-commerce may suffer from shrinking consumer appetite during Covid-19 lockdowns.

site_title: US ready to take action for non-compliance of sanctions, but so far Asia is complying
summary: The US is prepared to take action against Russia for non-compliance with sanctions, but so far, Asia has demonstrated substantial support and self-sanctioning efforts. US Commerce Department Deputy Assistant Secretary Matthew Borman stated that the restrictions have been in place for a month with no indication of non-compliance, and companies are taking self-sanctions. The US has reached out to Asian allies and Chinese companies to ensure cooperation and prevent workarounds, with requirements for analyzing exports to Russia and ensuring US content does not exceed 25% of the product's value.

site_title: Democracy is the next identity politics
summary: A shift in global politics is underway as the atrocities committed by Russian President Vladimir Putin have brought attention to the virtues of democracy and liberalism. Despite flaws in Western democracies, Putin's actions have put them in perspective, and citizens are uniting against his aggression. A new identity politics is emerging, one based on liberal values of freedom, dignity, and human rights, challenging divisive blood-and-soil identity politics. This shift is evident in the response of Western countries, including NATO, the European Union, and the US, which are now speaking with a single voice and acting with moral backbone.

site_title: Boustead Projects unit fined S$94,000 for illegal drone usage
summary: Boustead Projects' engineering and construction subsidiary pleaded guilty to 10 charges for using unmanned drones at two construction sites in 2022, breaching the Air Navigation Act. The company was fined S$94,000, with a total of 69 charges also taken into consideration for sentencing. The offenses occurred as part of efforts to increase efficiency and productivity during the pandemic, but the company has since reviewed and implemented standard operating procedures to prevent similar incidents.

images.alt_text: All 10 charges faced by Boustead Projects E&C were related to the use of unmanned drones by the company at 2 of its construction sites.

site_title: Australia's budget pitches cash to key voters ahead of election
summary: Australia's budget focuses on boosting key voters ahead of the May election by offering fuel-tax cuts and cash handouts. The budget projects a narrowing deficit of A$78 billion by 2023, and A$43.1 billion by 2026, better than the G20 nations average. Treasurer Josh Frydenberg attributes this to the country's strong economy, driven by soaring commodity prices and a strengthening labor market. The measures aim to cushion the impact of rising living costs and support Prime Minister Scott Morrison's re-election bid.

site_title: Singapore CBD Grade A office rents book fastest quarterly growth since recovery: JLL
summary: Singapore's Grade A office rents in the Central Business District (CBD) experienced the fastest quarterly growth since the recovery began in Q2 2021, rising 2.3% to S$10.46 per square foot (psf) per month in Q1 2022. This marks the third consecutive quarter of accelerated growth, with overall CBD rents recovering by 6.9% from the recent bottom in Q1 2021. Strong demand from corporates seeking healthy and sustainable workplaces is driving the growth, with major leasing deals including KPMG and Guoco Midtown.

site_title: Europe: Stocks ahead at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Tuesday, lifted by optimism over peace talks between Ukraine and Russia. London's FTSE 100 gained 0.6%, Frankfurt's DAX climbed 1.0%, and Paris' CAC 40 rose 1.1%. Asian equities also gained ground, driven by another drop in oil prices. The first face-to-face talks between Ukrainian and Russian officials since March 10 are set to take place in Istanbul, with Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky emphasizing the need for peace "without delay".

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank initiates Grab with 'buy', expects breakeven by 2025
summary: Maybank has initiated coverage of Grab with a "buy" rating, expecting the ride-hailing platform to break even by 2025 with an estimated earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization of US$86 million. The analysts predict a compounded annual growth rate (CAGR) of 27.1% for Grab's gross merchandise value (GMV) to US$42 billion between 2021 and 2025, driven by growth in financial services and enterprise segments. A potential upside of over 25% is offered from the current stock price of US$3.44.

site_title: Barclays shares fall after top investor offloads stake
summary: Barclays shares plummeted 6% in early trading on March 29 after a top investor offloaded approximately a 3% stake, facilitated by Goldman Sachs. The sale, priced at 150 pence, was a 6% discount to the previous day's closing price. The move comes as Barclays grapples with a £450 million loss due to a compliance and risk mis-step, forcing the bank to delay a planned £1 billion share buyback. The sale puts pressure on the bank's new CEO, CS Venkatakrishnan, as he faces an early test in addressing the regulatory blunder.

site_title: Kyiv seeks cease-fire deal in Russia talks
summary: Ukraine is seeking a cease-fire agreement in talks with Russian negotiators starting on March 29 in Turkey. The talks aim to improve the humanitarian situation, which has led to millions fleeing their homes. Russia's siege of Mariupol has killed almost 5,000 people, while Ukraine's military recaptured the town of Irpin. Turkish President Erdogan expects "good news" from the talks, but disagreements remain over security guarantees and further military aid. France and Germany favor a quick cease-fire, while some NATO members believe the current dialogue is counterproductive.

site_title: Sony launches Game Pass counterattack with subscription service upgrade
summary: Sony has revamped its PlayStation subscription service, PlayStation Plus, with a new tiered pricing model and hundreds of games available for a flat monthly fee. The service, set to launch in June, will offer three tiers: Essential (US$9.99/month), Extra (US$17.99/month), and Premium (US$119.99/year). New releases will not be included, but users can access recent hits like "Spider-Man: Miles Morales" and big-budget titles like "Returnal" and "God of War." Analysts say the move is a counterattack to Microsoft's Game Pass, but may dampen enthusiasm due to the lack of new releases.

images.alt_text: Sony Group's revamp of its PlayStation subscription service is a major step toward levelling the playing field with Microsoft's rival Game Pass, although holding back new releases may dampen enthusiasm, analysts say.

site_title: Linking ESG to remuneration: The case for Top Glove
summary: Top Glove, the world's largest glove manufacturer, reported significant financial growth during the Covid-19 pandemic, with a 381% increase in net profit and a 131.3% return on equity. However, the company faced public scrutiny over its labour practices, including poor working conditions and forced labour, leading to import bans and criticism from institutional investors. Despite this, Top Glove's board members were re-elected by a narrow margin, sparking concerns about accountability and corporate governance. The company's stellar performance has raised questions about the need to link ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) factors to remuneration.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher on Ukraine peace hopes, lower oil prices
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.42% on Tuesday, driven by hopes of peace talks between Russia and Ukraine and a drop in oil prices. The Kospi index closed at 2,741.07, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading gains. Oil prices fell, easing inflation concerns, while South Korean sovereign bonds experienced a mixed day. Foreigners sold 280.4 billion won worth of shares, but the won strengthened against the dollar.

site_title: Explainer: What would Japan's currency intervention to combat a weak yen look like?
summary: Japan's policymakers have escalated warnings against sharp yen falls, with Vice-Finance Minister Masato Kanda stating Tokyo and Washington will communicate closely on currencies. Japan has historically focused on arresting yen rises, but has considered intervening to buy yen in the market to combat a weak yen. The last time Japan intervened was in 1998, and it would likely require a "triple" selling of yen, domestic stocks, and bonds to prompt action. The Bank of Japan would execute the order, and Japan's foreign reserves, which stood at $1.38 trillion, would be tapped to sell dollars in exchange for yen.

site_title: Weak demand, cautious price-setting keeping Japan inflation low: BOJ's Amamiya
summary: Japan's inflation remains low due to weak household demand and cautious price-setting by companies, according to Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Masayoshi Amamiya. Demand shifts from services to goods have been slow, and Japan has not seen a surge in goods prices like the US. This is attributed to overall demand being relatively weak in Japan, and the country's low inflation is expected to continue.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher for sixth day as tech, financials rally
summary: Australian shares closed higher for a sixth straight day, driven by technology and financial stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.7%, its highest since January 13, as domestic tech stocks jumped over 3% and financials added 0.6%. Miners and energy stocks lost ground after China's Covid-19 lockdown in Shanghai raised concerns over commodity demand. Australia-listed shares of Block and Xero surged, while the "Big Four" banks climbed between 0.2% and 1.1%.

site_title: Old Chang Kee weathers pandemic with 'zero retrenchment', thanks to JSS
summary: Old Chang Kee, a fried food and beverage chain, weathered the pandemic without retrenching staff, thanks to payouts from Singapore's Jobs Support Scheme (JSS). As of March 2022, the company had 516 staff members across 90 outlets, with no staff retrenched. To mitigate costs, the company froze salary increments and implemented a flat monthly allowance for employees, partially funded by JSS payouts. With the final JSS payout received, Old Chang Kee has since reinstated salary increments and ceased the allowance, demonstrating its ability to adapt and maintain staff without government support.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB raises SGX TP on expected boost to earnings from higher treasury income
summary: RHB has raised its target price on Singapore Exchange (SGX) to S$10 from S$9.80 due to expected boost in earnings from higher treasury income amid interest rate hikes. Analyst Shekhar Jaiswal notes SGX's long-term growth prospects from acquisitions and pipeline of new listings, but maintains a "neutral" call due to near-term re-rating challenges. SGX shares rose 0.2% to S$9.81 on the news.

site_title: LTA calls tender for installation of 12,000 EV charging points by 2025
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) is launching a tender for the installation of 12,000 electric vehicle (EV) charging points at public housing carparks by 2025. The tender, set to be launched in April, will be awarded in the fourth quarter of this year and will comprise up to 10 packages. Contractors will need to install at least 3-6 charging points in their designated carparks by the end of 2025, with the option to add up to 12 points. The LTA will assess tenderers on their plans for affordable, reliable, and sustainable charging services.

site_title: Maersk warns Shanghai city lockdown to boost transport costs further
summary: Maersk warns that the Shanghai lockdown will severely impact trucking services and increase transport costs, with 30% trucking service disruption and longer delivery times expected. The lockdown, which began on Monday and will last for 4 days, has barred unapproved vehicles from streets and told millions to stay home. This further rattles global supply chains, with Seko Logistics anticipating a sharp increase in air freight rates and a rise in transport costs.

site_title: Ant-backed Philippine unicorn weighs growing fintech before IPO
summary: A Philippine fintech venture, Globe Fintech Innovations, is considering an initial public offering (IPO) after expanding its services, including cryptocurrency and stock trading. The company, which operates the GCash payment platform, saw gross transactions surge almost 12-fold to 3.8 trillion pesos in 2021. Globe Fintech aims to diversify revenue and grow transactions by at least 10% annually, with new services expected to be profitable in 4-5 years. The company values itself at over $2 billion following a $300 million funding round.

site_title: Yanlord pauses construction on Shanghai projects; property management staff on frontline
summary: Yanlord Land Group, a Singapore-listed Chinese property developer, has paused construction on several Shanghai projects due to the ongoing lockdown. The company plans to increase working shifts when the city reopens, aiming to catch up on development pace. Yanlord has ongoing developments in multiple Chinese cities and has implemented online platforms for project launches and pre-sales to minimize physical contact. The company expects the lockdown to be temporary and hopes for a quick containment of the Covid-19 outbreak in Shanghai.

site_title: Ericsson CEO faces investor ire over handling of Iraq probe
summary: Ericsson CEO Borje Ekholm faces scrutiny from investors over his handling of a probe into possible corruption in Iraq. Shareholders are upset the company didn't disclose an internal probe from 2019 until February, causing a significant share price drop. At the annual general meeting, shareholders will vote on whether Ekholm and board members can be personally liable for their actions. Based on responses from contacted shareholders, the votes are expected to pass the 10% threshold, potentially denting Ekholm's efforts to turn the company around.

site_title: Philippines' GrowSari bags US$77.5 million in KKR-led round
summary: GrowSari, a Philippine startup, has raised US$77.5 million in a Series C funding round led by KKR, bringing its total funds raised to US$110 million. The company will use the funds to hire workers and expand its operations. Founded in 2016, GrowSari provides digital services to small stores and roadside shops, serving over 100,000 stores across 220 municipalities. The startup plans to launch in the Visayas and Mindanao, with over 50 fulfillment centers nationwide.

site_title: South Korean consumers' inflation expectations hit 8-year high
summary: South Korean consumers' inflation expectations have reached an 8-year high, reaching 2.9% this month, up 0.2 percentage points from the previous month. The Bank of Korea is under pressure to rein in inflation, which hit 3.7% last month, and break a potential cycle of wage and price increases. The country's manufacturing sector is heavily reliant on imported energy, exacerbating concerns over supply chain snags and rising energy costs due to the war in Ukraine. The Bank of Korea holds its benchmark rate on April 14.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares track Wall Street gains; autos and shippers shine
summary: Japanese shares rose 1.1% to close at 28,252.42, tracking overnight Wall Street gains, driven by auto makers and shippers. Demand for securing dividend allotments boosted the market, while a fall in oil prices lifted sentiment.

site_title: Keeping up with the ever-evolving retail landscape in Asean
summary: Retailers in ASEAN are adapting to the "new normal" of retail, incorporating technology to support a well-connected, omnichannel approach. The region's consumers are increasingly using both online and in-store shopping, with 85% of Singaporeans purchasing from physical stores in Q1 2021. Retailers must prioritize technological innovation, leveraging data and automation to improve customer experiences and close the trust gap between shoppers and retailers. Successful retailers will adopt a culture of innovation, embracing technology to simplify work and enhance planning, ultimately driving growth and competitiveness in the region.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts say Shopee's India exit raises Sea's prospect of profitability
summary: Sea Ltd is shutting down its Shopee business in India, citing global market uncertainties, to focus on other markets and potentially raise its profitability. Analysts at CGS-CIMB and Citi expect the move to save at least US$60 million per quarter and allow Shopee to concentrate on its core markets in South-east Asia and Latin America. The exit also removes concerns over Shopee's significant cash burn in India, where its gaming app Free Fire was recently banned.

site_title: Singapore's restaurants and bars are being flooded with reservations
summary: Singapore's restaurants and bars are experiencing a surge in reservations after the government announced it would allow larger gatherings and permit alcohol to be sold later in the night. Reservations have jumped by at least 50% for some establishments, with daily takings expected to increase by 20-30%. The move comes as the country takes steps to live with Covid-19, with mask mandates lifted and travel curbs relaxed. The hospitality industry is also benefiting, with aviation stocks rising and airlines seeing increased demand for travel in Asia.

site_title: Content creator platform by ex-Kudo CEO raises US$10m led by East Ventures
summary: TIPTIP, a content creator platform launched by Indonesian entrepreneur Albert Lucius, has raised US$10 million in seed funding led by East Ventures. The platform aims to provide a platform for content creators to earn money through personalized video sessions, premium digital content sales, and direct fan interaction. With over 70 employees, TIPTIP plans to launch in April, initially on a by-invitation basis, followed by a public launch in Indonesia. East Ventures' managing partner, Willson Cuaca, expressed confidence in the potential of the content creator economy, citing consumer behavior formed during the pandemic.

site_title: Portfolio of 18 strata units at Orchard Shopping Centre for sale at S$90m indicative price
summary: A portfolio of 18 strata-titled retail units at Orchard Shopping Centre in Singapore is being sold via an expression of interest exercise with an indicative price of S$90 million. The units are located on levels 1 and 2, spanning 8,934 square feet, and are currently fully occupied by tenants. The sale is expected to attract interest from local and foreign family offices, high net worth individuals, and real estate funds, with no Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) or Seller's Stamp Duty (SSD) imposed on the commercial property transaction.

site_title: STI up 0.06%, tracking Wall Street optimism on peace talks
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index rose 0.06% to 3,433.9 on Tuesday, driven by optimism on Wall Street over peace talks between Ukraine and Russia. This uptrend was also supported by a decline in oil prices. The 5-day rally marks a positive trend for Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open on March 29, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.40% or 86.32 points to 21,771.29, following a strong performance on Wall Street due to hopes for Ukraine-Russia ceasefire talks.

site_title: UK faces crypto exodus as firms sound off before FCA deadline
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is set to shut its temporary registration regime for cryptoasset businesses on March 31, prompting concerns of an impending exodus of firms from the country. Only 12 firms remain on the temporary register, including crypto custodian Copper Technologies and digital bank Revolut, which face having to suspend services if they don't gain approval before the deadline. Some firms are moving operations abroad, targeting European destinations like Croatia and Switzerland, while others are withdrawing applications or being rejected due to anti-money laundering requirements.

site_title: China lockdowns cost at least 295b yuan a month, academic says
summary: China's Covid lockdowns are estimated to cost the country at least $46 billion a month, or 3.1% of gross domestic product (GDP), according to a Chinese University of Hong Kong economist. The impact could double if more cities tighten restrictions. Lockdowns in Shanghai alone could reduce China's real GDP by 4%, while a nationwide lockdown could cut GDP by 53%. The economist predicts a better outcome if cities can achieve a similar result to Shenzhen, which saw a week-long lockdown with limited economic impact.

site_title: Cushman & Wakefield ditches Russia business, Ball Corp also plans exit
summary: Real estate services company Cushman & Wakefield and sustainable metal packaging maker Ball Corp announced plans to exit their businesses in Russia due to global sanctions over Moscow's invasion of Ukraine. Cushman & Wakefield will transfer its Russian business to a local operator, while Ball Corp will reduce operations immediately and pursue the sale of its Russian business. The move follows other companies, including Apple and Ford Motor, that have limited or exited operations in Russia.

site_title: Employers to receive over S$145m in final JSS payouts from Mar 31
summary: Employers in Singapore will receive over S$145 million in final Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) payouts starting March 31, supporting the wages of over 289,500 local employees. The payouts cover wages from November to December 2021 and are primarily for sectors affected by safe management measures, such as food services. Employers must have made mandatory CPF contributions by the stipulated deadlines to qualify.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembmarine drops 4.9% after giving notice of 3 straight years of losses
summary: Sembcorp Marine shares dropped 4.9% after the company announced it recorded three consecutive years of pre-tax losses. The shares hit a low of S$0.098 before recovering to S$0.099 by 2:34 pm. Heavy trading volume of 273.6 million shares was recorded.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend gains ahead of Ukraine-Russia talks
summary: Asian markets continued their upward trend, driven by optimism over Ukraine-Russia talks aimed at ending the month-long conflict. Oil prices dropped, further supporting the market. Analysts attribute the shift to traders seeking quality returns, as the conflict has hindered alternative investment options.

site_title: Solomon Islands' PM calls China security deal backlash 'insulting'
summary: Solomon Islands Prime Minister Manasseh Sogavare has called Australian concerns over a draft security pact with China "insulting" and "unfortunate perceptions". The leaked agreement would allow Chinese security and naval deployments to the Pacific island nation, raising concerns about regional security. Sogavare confirmed that his government and Beijing had reached agreement on the deal, despite existing security arrangements with Australia remaining intact. He argued that diversifying the country's relationships is necessary to achieve security needs, contradicting Australian and US concerns about China's growing influence in the South Pacific.

site_title: Bankers who stay in Hong Kong are rewarded with a pay bonanza
summary: Hong Kong's finance industry is experiencing a talent war as the city's strict Covid-19 restrictions have driven many workers away, leaving a shortage of skilled professionals. Those who stay are being rewarded with pay increases of 20-30% or more, with some companies offering bonuses to attract top talent. The industry's resurgence is driven by the growing crypto sector, with companies like Amber Group and Animoca Brands expanding their teams and offering competitive compensation packages. However, experts warn that this trend may reverse if Hong Kong's leaders fail to chart a path out of Covid Zero or if companies shift jobs elsewhere.

site_title: Vietnam's Q1 GDP growth tops 5%, though headwinds seen
summary: Vietnam's gross domestic product (GDP) grew 5.03% in the first quarter of 2022, beating the 4.72% recorded in the same period last year. The country's economy reopened after relaxing coronavirus restrictions, with the manufacturing and construction sectors growing 6.38% and 4.58%, respectively. Exports rose 12.9% to $88.6 billion, while imports increased 15.9% to $87.8 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of $809 million. Despite this, Capital Economics warns of emerging headwinds, including higher oil prices and disruptions to supply chains.

site_title: Heavy rains slam Australia, triggers fresh round of flood evacuations
summary: Heavy rains in Australia have triggered a fresh round of flood evacuations, affecting thousands of residents across northern New South Wales and southeast Queensland states. The intense weather system, which could bring isolated rainfall of up to 300 mm, is expected to persist for 24 hours, with potentially life-threatening flash floods along the northern New South Wales coast. The floods, which occurred just a month ago, have killed at least 21 people and caused widespread damage. Authorities have declared the floods a national emergency and designated catastrophe zones to receive extra recovery funds.

site_title: Russia and West at odds over gas payments in roubles
summary: Russia has refused to supply gas to Europe unless payments are made in roubles, following the US and European allies' sanctions against Russia. The European Union has rejected the demand, calling it a breach of existing contracts. As a result, wholesale gas prices in the Netherlands and UK rose by up to 20% on concerns about Russian gas supply. The EU aims to cut its dependency on Russian gas by two-thirds this year.

site_title: South Korea bonds off to a shaky start, BOK chief nominee vows to manage risks
