summary: South Korea's sovereign bonds experienced a shaky start on March 29, with yields rising slightly across 3-year and 10-year treasury bonds. The yield on 10-year notes surged to 2.980% after a 16 basis point increase on Monday, the highest since September 2014. Nominee to be South Korea's central bank chief, Rhee Chang-yong, vowed to focus on risk management amid external uncertainties, including US interest rate hikes and inflation concerns. The Bank of Korea declined to comment on potential policy intervention to curb bond yields.

images.alt_text: South Korea's sovereign bonds got off to a shaky start on Tuesday (Mar 29) after crashing in the previous session, as investors bet the US Federal Reserve will tighten policy rapidly enough to risk a sustained slowdown in growth.

site_title: Singapore, US reaffirm defence ties and discuss Russia's invasion of Ukraine
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin reaffirmed their countries' defence ties during a meeting at the Pentagon. They discussed Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with Lee explaining Singapore's strong stance and Austin expressing appreciation for Singapore's position. Both leaders emphasized the importance of the US presence in the Asia-Pacific region for regional peace and stability. They also discussed expanding defence cooperation, including cyber and artificial intelligence, and reaffirmed the Memorandum of Understanding on US use of Singaporean facilities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 2.64 points lower, or 0.17%, at 1,595.31 on Tuesday. Volume was 104.58 million lots worth RM32.96 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 146 to 80.

site_title: Omicron 'stealth' Covid variant BA.2 now dominant globally
summary: A sub-variant of the Omicron coronavirus, BA.2, has become the dominant global variant, representing nearly 86% of sequenced cases. It is more transmissible than its Omicron siblings, but evidence suggests it causes less severe disease. Vaccines are less effective against BA.2, but a booster jab can restore protection, particularly against hospitalization and death. The rise of BA.2 has led to surges in infections in Europe and Asia, but some countries are seeing slower upticks or declines. Scientists attribute the surge to lifted public health interventions, but warn the virus remains a significant public health problem, particularly among unvaccinated populations.

site_title: Australian retail sales jump in Feb, augur well for Q1 growth
summary: Australian retail sales rose 1.8% in February, exceeding forecasts and marking the second-best month ever, with sales up 9.1% from the previous year. Discretionary spending industries, including cafes and restaurants, saw significant gains, while the department store and clothing sectors also rose more than 11%. The strong sales suggest a strong first quarter for household spending, but rising petrol prices and inflation expectations pose challenges, with the Reserve Bank of Australia considering interest rate hikes to combat inflation.

site_title: Empty shelves and anxiety as Shanghai Covid-19 cases surge
summary: Shanghai recorded a surge in Covid-19 cases, with 4,400 cases detected in the city, prompting widespread panic-buying and lockdowns. Authorities split the city into two, confining residents to their homes for four days and subjecting them to mandatory testing. China reported 6,886 domestic cases nationwide, with Shanghai at the center of the worst outbreak since the early days of the pandemic, affecting its 25 million residents.

site_title: Sembmarine records 3 straight years of losses, but meets criteria to avoid watch list
summary: Sembcorp Marine, a marine and offshore engineering group, recorded its third consecutive year of pre-tax losses. Despite this, the company's 6-month average daily market capitalization of S$2.6 billion meets the criteria to avoid being placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch list. This comes after the company posted a net loss of S$523.3 million in February, widening from a loss of S$390.4 million the previous year. The group's recent contract win for a wind turbine installation vessel has boosted its stock price to a 7-month high.

site_title: Japan policymakers warn against rapid yen weakening
summary: Japanese policymakers are warning against rapid yen weakening, as the currency hit six-year lows beyond 125 yen versus the US dollar. Minister of Finance Shunichi Suzuki and Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno expressed concerns about the impact on the cost of living for the trade-reliant economy. Suzuki stated that currency stability is crucial, while Matsuno warned against rapid yen swings. The Bank of Japan's decision to contain rising bond yields also contributed to the yen's weakening, with Suzuki saying the central bank should steer monetary policy with responsibility.

images.alt_text: Japan will carefully watch foreign exchange market moves to avoid "bad yen weakening", Minister of Finance Shunichi Suzuki said on Tuesday, as Tokyo tries to navigate the economic impact of the rapidly rising cost of imports from a weakening currency.

site_title: Australia: Tech, financial stocks lift shares; China curbs weigh on miners
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Tuesday, led by technology and financial stocks, but mining and oil stocks fell amid concerns over a drop in commodity demand. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,462.4. Tech stocks climbed 3.4%, with Xero and Block Inc rising 2.8% and 6.5%, respectively. Investors weigh the prospect of interest rate hikes amid global inflationary pressures and geopolitical tensions. In contrast, miners, including Rio Tinto and BHP Group, lost between 0.6% and 1.5% due to China's Covid-19 curbs.

site_title: Gold industry embraces blockchain to secure its supply chain
summary: The gold industry is embracing blockchain technology to secure its supply chain. The London Bullion Market Association (LBMA) and the World Gold Council (WGC) are developing a digital system, the Gold Bar Integrity Programme, to track gold from mine to vault. The initiative aims to improve transparency and prevent illicit gold from entering the market. The first phase will involve all parts of the supply chain, including banks, and will focus on kilobars of gold, which have historically been vulnerable to fraud. The goal is to increase demand for gold and make gold markets more accessible.

site_title: Gold flat as firmer dollar, yields counter Ukraine talks
summary: Gold prices remained flat at US$1,925.71 per ounce on Tuesday, as a stronger US dollar offset hopes for peace talks between Russia and Ukraine. The dollar index hit a 3-week high, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. US yields rose, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Ukraine is seeking a ceasefire in talks with Russia, while China's gold imports fell 13.7% in February, and the country reported a record number of Covid-19 cases.

images.alt_text: Gold prices were flat on Tuesday (Mar 29), as the dollar held firm at a 3-week high hit in the previous session and yields climbed higher offsetting hopes for peace talks between Russia and Ukraine to be held this week.

site_title: JTC launches reserve list site at Jalan Papan for application
summary: JTC has launched a 0.56-hectare industrial site at Jalan Papan for application under the 2022 industrial government land sales programme. The site has a 20-year tenure, a gross plot ratio of 1.4, and is zoned B2 for heavy industrial use. This is the third of four reserve list sites under the programme, aiming to offer more choices for industrial development.

images.alt_text: The land plot, which has a 20-year tenure, spans 0.56 hectare. It has a gross plot ratio of 1.4 and is zoned B2 for heavy industrial use.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembmarine, Singtel, ComfortDelGro, Venture Corp, BBR Holdings
summary: Sembcorp Marine recorded 3 consecutive years of pre-tax losses but still meets the Singapore Exchange's watch list criteria. Meanwhile, Singtel's technology services arm NCS acquired Melbourne-based ARQ Group for A$290 million. The transaction brings NCS's headcount in Australia to 1,900.

site_title: Apac governments should collaborate to support air travel recovery
summary: Governments in the Asia-Pacific region should collaborate to simplify travel regulations and boost passenger confidence, as the industry lags behind others due to complex protocols. The region's airports are expected to lose US$27 billion in revenue in 2022. Experts recommend implementing compatible digital Covid certificates, standardizing protocols and health credentials, and adopting International Civil Aviation Organisation and World Health Organisation-recommended travel regimes. By reducing onerous protocols and requirements, governments can increase consumer appetite for travel and help the region regain its competitiveness in air travel.

site_title: Terra adds US$135m in Bitcoin purchases to back stablecoin
summary: Terra, a blockchain firm, has purchased over $1 billion in Bitcoin since January, including $135 million in a single day. The purchase is aimed at backing the TerraUSD stablecoin, which is not backed by a fiat currency. Co-founder Do Kwon believes Bitcoin is the strongest digital reserve asset and plans to eventually reach a $10 billion Bitcoin reserve. This move aims to improve UST's ability to maintain its dollar peg, particularly during times of high redemption demand.

site_title: BBR registers joint venture for Cross Island Line project
summary: BBR Holdings' wholly-owned subsidiary Singapore Engineering & Construction has registered a joint venture partnership with Sinohydro Corporation to design and construct the Pasir Ris East train station under the Cross Island Line project's first phase. Both companies hold a 50% stake in the joint venture. The investment is expected to have no material impact on BBR's earnings or net assets for the current financial year.

site_title: World moves from shortages to possible glut of Covid-19 vaccines
summary: The global Covid-19 vaccine industry is shifting from shortages to a possible glut, with over 11 billion doses administered worldwide. As demand wanes, companies are struggling with excess supply, particularly in India, where manufacturers are grappling with domestic and global oversupply. The number of shots needed is expected to decline, and a growing number of manufacturers are breaking into the market. Some companies, like Pfizer, Moderna, and AstraZeneca, are facing declining sales, while others, like Biological E in India, are looking to diversify into other vaccines.

site_title: E-sports startup Ampverse raises US$12m in Series A round
summary: Ampverse, an e-sports startup based in Singapore, has raised US$12 million in a Series A round led by Falcon Capital. The funds will be used for expansion in Indonesia and the Philippines, acquiring e-sports teams, and expanding its play-to-earn business unit. Ampverse's revenue grew 125% over the last 12 months, driven by expansion into Vietnam and India. The company plans to acquire play-to-earn guilds, complementing its e-sports intellectual property business. Existing investors include Vulpes, Gandel Invest, and Rob Gilby, former managing director at The Walt Disney Company South East Asia.

site_title: Abramovich, Ukraine negotiators suffer suspected poisoning
summary: Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich and Ukrainian negotiators were targets of a suspected poison attack, potentially by Moscow hardliners seeking to sabotage peace talks. The incident occurred after a meeting in Ukraine's capital, with Abramovich and at least two senior Ukrainian negotiators developing symptoms including red eyes and peeling skin. The attack was not intended to kill, but rather a warning, according to investigator Christo Grozev. The conditions of Abramovich and the other negotiators have improved, and they are not in danger.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on hopes for Ukraine talks
summary: US stocks rose on Monday as hopes for peace talks between Russia and Ukraine drove gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 0.3%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes rose 0.7% and 1.3%, respectively. Oil prices fell due to concerns over a Covid-19 outbreak in China. President Joe Biden released a budget plan allocating $6.9 billion to Ukraine for defense against Russia's invasion. Analysts viewed a proposed minimum tax on ultra-wealthy taxpayers as unlikely to pass in a divided Congress.

site_title: Kioxia to spend US$8b on chip plant as industry bulks up
summary: Kioxia Holdings is investing approximately $11 billion to build a new plant in Japan, aiming to increase production capacity and stay competitive in the booming data storage market. The investment, part of the chip industry's efforts to address shortages, will enable the company to meet growing demand from various industries, including automotive and cloud computing. Construction will begin in April and finish next year, with the Japanese government providing over $5.8 billion in financial incentives to support the domestic chip industry.

site_title: Seven EU countries urge their citizens not to join fight in Ukraine
summary: Seven European Union countries, including France, Germany, and Belgium, have urged their citizens not to join the Ukrainian military resistance against Russia's invading troops. The justice ministers of the seven countries have discouraged Europeans from joining the International Legion, with few departures from France confirmed. The appeal aims to prevent foreigners from traveling to a war zone, with around 20,000 people already answering Ukraine's call for aid. The move comes after Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky invited foreigners to join the fight against Russia.

images.alt_text: Seven European Union countries on Monday urged their citizens to refrain from joining the Ukrainian military resistance against Russia's invading troops.

site_title: Trump 'more likely than not' obstructed Congress: US judge
summary: A US federal judge ruled that former President Donald Trump "more likely than not" engaged in criminal conduct by attempting to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election. Judge David Carter's 44-page ruling comes amid efforts by a congressional committee investigating the January 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol. The judge found that Trump corruptly attempted to obstruct Congress and ordered a lawyer's emails to be handed over to the committee. The ruling may increase pressure on Attorney General Merrick Garland to bring charges against Trump over the Capitol riot.

images.alt_text: A federal judge ruled on Monday that former US president Donald Trump "more likely than not" engaged in criminal conduct with his efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election.

site_title: Oscars ratings bounce back as Will Smith hooks viewers
summary: The Oscars ratings saw a significant recovery with 15.36 million viewers tuning in for the ceremony, surpassing last year's record-low 9.85 million live viewers. The event's talking point was Will Smith's on-stage slap of Chris Rock, which sparked widespread controversy and online discussion. The moment may have boosted viewership, but Academy producers had anticipated this publicity, incorporating changes such as pre-taped announcements and a "fan favourite" prize. Despite this, the incident raised questions about the Academy's desire for controversy and its impact on the awards show's relevance.

site_title: North Korea's Kim calls for ramping up ideological campaigns amid 'worst difficulties'
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has called for a propaganda campaign to boost support for the country's ideology of self-reliance amid "the worst difficulties." In a letter to ruling Workers' Party officials, Kim emphasized the need to spread his vision for "juche" and advance innovation in the party's ideological work. The move aims to increase popular support and motivation for socialism.

site_title: Oil slides about 7% on concerns of weaker Chinese demand
summary: Oil prices plummeted 7% on Monday as China's Shanghai lockdown to curb Covid-19 infections raised concerns of demand destruction, prompting a 6.8% drop in Brent crude futures and a 7% decline in US West Texas Intermediate crude futures. Analysts expect China's oil demand to be 800,000 barrels per day softer than usual in April, while supply deficits loom due to declining orders for Russian oil. Despite Opec+ plans to increase production quotas, oil markets are expected to feel the effects of widespread avoidance of Russian oil.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on hopes for Ukraine talks
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.72% or 202.40 points at 28,146.29, driven by hopes for peace talks between Russia and Ukraine. Investors also bought shares to gain dividend rights. The broader Topix index was up 0.45%.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending US gains on hopes over peace talks between Russia and Ukraine, while investors also bought shares to gain rights to receive dividends.

site_title: Johor to announce SOPs for Malaysian workers in Singapore
summary: The Johor government is set to announce standard operating procedures (SOPs) for Malaysian workers commuting to Singapore on April 1, ahead of the border reopening. The SOPs, which include vehicle entry permits, will be unveiled by Johor Chief Minister Onn Hafiz Ghazi. A dry run at the land checkpoints will also be conducted on March 30 to ensure a smooth reopening. The move comes after Singapore and Malaysia announced the lifting of quarantine and on-arrival testing requirements for fully vaccinated travelers.

site_title: Biden says 'not walking back' suggestion Putin should leave power
summary: US President Joe Biden refused to back down on his statement that Russian leader Vladimir Putin "cannot stay in power," saying he was voicing personal "moral outrage." Biden made the remark in a speech in Warsaw, sparking concern among Republicans and analysts. He emphasized that he wasn't changing US policy, but rather expressing his feelings on the conflict in Ukraine. Biden left the door open for further diplomacy with Putin, but emphasized the need for concrete discussions to justify an end to the war. Ukraine's government reports up to 10,000 deaths since the invasion.

site_title: Opec+ still sees no need to change plan despite Russia crisis
summary: OPEC+ reaffirmed its plan to increase oil supplies by 430,000 barrels a day in May, despite the Russia-Ukraine conflict, which threatens to disrupt global markets. The alliance, led by Saudi Arabia, remains committed to its plan, prioritizing market balance over potential supply disruptions. The decision may exacerbate inflationary pressure and tighten global markets, but OPEC+ sees no need to adapt its plan. The alliance's focus on preserving ties with Russia, the largest crude producer, is also at odds with US President Biden's efforts to isolate Vladimir Putin.

images.alt_text: Opec and its allies signalled that they still see no need to adapt their oil-supply plans even as the Russia-Ukraine conflict threatens the biggest market disruption in decades.

site_title: Protecting investor interests in the Singapore stock market
summary: A Singaporean investor urges the establishment of a separate regulatory body to protect investor interests in the country's stock market, citing the need to eliminate conflicts of interest. The investor recalls a past incident involving China Paper, a listed company that misled investors with false promises of growth and scale, resulting in significant losses for shareholders. The investor suggests class action suits and calls for a more independent regulatory body to prevent similar incidents.

site_title: CNN+ will launch on Amazon, Apple and Android devices
summary: CNN's new streaming service, CNN+, will launch on March 29, 2022, on Amazon, Android, and Apple devices, offering live and on-demand programs, including shows hosted by network stars. The service will cost $6/month or $60/year and features CNN reporters and experts answering viewer questions live. This launch comes after WarnerMedia, CNN's parent, secured deals with major distributors, including Amazon and Apple, to reach a wider audience, potentially boosting the growth of the new app.

site_title: Academy 'condemns' and launches 'formal review' into Will Smith slap at Oscars
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has launched a formal review into the incident where Will Smith slapped Chris Rock on stage at the Oscars. The Academy condemned Smith's actions, stating it will explore further action and consequences in accordance with its Bylaws, Standards of Conduct, and California law. The review will examine the incident and determine any necessary consequences for Smith.

site_title: Singapore 3rd most expensive market in world for flexible offices
summary: Singapore ranks third most expensive market for flexible offices globally, behind New York and San Francisco, with an average private office desk space costing US$834 a month. The city's popularity among startups has contributed to its strong recovery in the flexible office market. London is in fourth place at US$803 per desk, while Berlin follows at US$800. The market remains relatively tight, with vacant seats being quickly snapped up, and construction delays expected to continue.

site_title: After 50 years, FedEx founder to step down as CEO
summary: FedEx founder Frederick Smith is stepping down as CEO after 50 years, marking the end of his five-decade tenure at the company. Raj Subramaniam, current chief operating officer, will take over as president and CEO, effective June 1. Smith will become executive chairman. FedEx, which has grown into a global logistics network, reported nearly $84 billion in revenues last year. The transition follows a successful period under Smith, who first devised the idea for Federal Express while at Yale University.

site_title: Japan to begin work on relief package to counter rising fuel, food costs
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida plans to order the government to create a relief package by the end of April to counter rising fuel and food costs fueled by the Ukraine crisis. The package, expected to be around 10 trillion yen, aims to cushion the economic blow and support industries hit by the price surge. The move comes as Japan's economy lags in recovering from the pandemic, with rising fuel and raw material prices adding to the challenges. Kishida is under pressure to balance spending and funding, with some lawmakers calling for an extra budget.

site_title: US would up aid to Ukraine, tax rich under Biden's proposed budget
summary: US President Joe Biden has unveiled a $5.8 trillion budget proposal that includes billions of dollars in aid to Ukraine, a minimum tax on the wealthy, and a reduction in the national debt. The plan would allocate $6.9 billion to Ukraine and $1 billion to counter Russian influence, while also lowering the US budget deficit by $1.3 trillion. The proposal also includes a four percent increase in defense spending and a 28 percent corporate tax rate. The budget must be approved by Congress, with lawmakers from both parties expected to demand changes.

site_title: Europe: Stocks inch up as investors assess bond moves; oil stocks lag
summary: European shares rose 0.1% on Monday, led by automakers and defensive sectors, amid hopes for a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine. Oil stocks lagged due to a drop in crude prices. Investors shifted to equities due to toxic bond markets and high inflation, with dividends expected to grow over time.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, extending gains on Wall Street due to hopes over peace talks between Russia and Ukraine. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.5% or 15.32 points to 3,447.31. Key gainers included Singtel, ComfortDelGro, and local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC. The US market also rose, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average advancing 0.3% and the S&P 500 gaining 0.7%.

site_title: Singtel's NCS acquires Australia digital services company ARQ for A$290m
summary: Singtel's technology services arm NCS acquired ARQ Group, a Melbourne-based digital consultancy, for A$290 million (S$296.8 million). This is NCS's fourth acquisition in Australia in the past 15 months, part of its regionalisation plans. ARQ specializes in mobile applications, cloud, and data analytics.

site_title: To shale and back, redux
summary: The price of oil has spiked due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, adding to high inflation and inhibiting Western responses to Vladimir Putin's aggression. Despite high prices, oil producers are reluctant to expand production, with the US oil industry being the main source of potential additional supply. A recent survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas found that bankers are the main reason for this reluctance, blaming debt-financed shale industry practices from the 2010s. This caution is understandable, as the financial industry has been burned in the past, and the aftermath of the debt-financed shale bubble is still affecting the energy sector.

site_title: Ukraine talks to resume; Kremlin calls Biden remarks 'alarming'
summary: Ukraine and Russia are set to resume face-to-face peace talks in Istanbul after a two-week hiatus, with Ukraine insisting on no concessions on ceding territory. Kyiv has gained momentum on the battlefield, shifting Russia's focus to eastern Ukraine. The talks come amid a backdrop of shifting power dynamics, with US President Joe Biden calling for an end to Vladimir Putin's rule. Ukrainian officials downplay the chances of a breakthrough, while the Kremlin describes Biden's comments as "alarming."

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden speaking in Warsaw on Mar 26. "For God's sake, this man (Putin) cannot remain in power," he ad-libbed at the end of the speech - a comment the Kremlin called "alarming".

site_title: Most restrictions eased, but it's not time to release the handbrakes fully
summary: Singapore lifts various Covid-19 restrictions, including limits on gatherings, mask mandates, and work-from-home policies, as the country aims to live with the virus. Starting April 1, fully vaccinated travelers can enter Singapore without a pre-departure test. Land borders with Malaysia will also reopen to private vehicles and motorcycles. However, experts caution that the easing of restrictions may not be sufficient, as the Omicron wave is still present and new variants may emerge, emphasizing the need for continued caution and vigilance.

site_title: Sea e-commerce arm Shopee to shut down India operations
summary: Sea Ltd, the Singapore-based e-commerce and gaming firm, is withdrawing from India's retail market due to "global market uncertainties." This decision comes months after Shopee began operations in India and follows India's ban on Sea's popular gaming app Free Fire. The move is expected to impact the company's valuation, which has dropped by $16 billion since the ban. Shopee will continue to support local seller and buyer communities in India until the process is completed.

site_title: KIT trustee-manager proposes pegging base, performance fees to distributions
summary: The trustee-manager of Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) has proposed new base fee and performance fee structures, pegging them to distributable income and distribution per unit (DPU) growth, respectively. The proposed changes aim to better align the trustee-manager's interests with KIT's unitholders and support its growth plans. The new fee structures, if approved, will be implemented progressively and give the trustee-manager more resources to manage KIT's portfolio, bolstering its ability to "optimise and create greater value."

site_title: Global bond rout sparks BOJ intervention
summary: A global bond rout continues, with yields on 2-year Treasuries surging 14 basis points to 2.41% and the US yield curve inverting for the first time in 16 years. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) stepped in twice to cap yield rises, while investors expect the Federal Reserve to lead aggressive interest rate hikes this year amid Russia's war in Ukraine driving up inflation. The BOJ also announced unlimited bond purchases to keep yields below 0.25%, and 10-year Japanese yields rose to 0.25%.

images.alt_text: The steepest global bond rout of the modern era extended on Monday (Mar 28), with Treasuries sliding, a key portion of the US curve inverting and the Bank of Japan (BOJ) stepping in twice to cap the rise in yields there.

site_title: Yangzijiang hits 6-month high after capital injection into proposed spin-off
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's shares surged 5.5% to a 6-month high, reaching S$1.54, after the company increased its share capital of Yangzijiang Financial Holding, a proposed spin-off. Analysts expect the spin-off to improve earnings quality and attract investors seeking direct exposure to the shipbuilding business, with target prices ranging from S$1.98 to S$2.15. The move is seen as a potential rerating for the stock, with potential upside of 32.9% to 68.5%.

site_title: Malaysia's fundraising activities to stay resilient in 2022: Securities Commission
summary: Malaysia's fundraising activities are expected to remain resilient in 2022, with 35 initial public offerings (IPOs) anticipated, according to the Securities Commission. Despite a challenging environment, fundraising activities are expected to continue as economic activities normalize. This is attributed to the economic recovery and the domestic capital market's encouraging performance.

site_title: Positive rental momentum buoys home landlords but challenges loom
summary: Singapore's private residential landlords can celebrate rising rental rates, with a 9.9% increase in Q4 2021, despite slower growth compared to private home prices. However, challenges loom, including rising supply of private homes and increasing tax burden. Low interest rates have contributed to prices rising faster than rental rates, but rising interest rates could reverse this trend. Rental demand is expected to continue, driven by factors such as delayed home completions and increasing international travel. Nevertheless, policy moves, including higher property taxes and competition from serviced residences, may hurt landlords in the long term.

site_title: Viking Offshore and Marine to change name, diversify business; proposes rights cum warrants issue, share placement
summary: Viking Offshore and Marine, a CATALIST-LISTED company, is proposing to change its name and diversify into supply chain management and lifestyle retail. The company plans a rights cum warrants issue and share placement to raise funds, strengthening its financial position and expanding its capital base. The proposed changes aim to support the company's future growth and development.

site_title: Climate change is threat multiplier for instability globally
summary: Climate change is exacerbating global instability, posing a significant threat to national security. Rising temperatures and resource scarcity are contributing to conflicts, such as the Syrian refugee crisis, and are expected to worsen tensions in stable regions. The European Union is accelerating its renewable energy transition, with Germany aiming to be 100% renewable by 2035. The energy transition is seen as a key factor in mitigating the impact of climate change, with green energy potentially helping to bring down energy prices and reduce inflation.

site_title: Singapore signs international pact for space exploration
summary: Singapore has become the first South-east Asian country to sign the Artemis Accords, an international pact promoting peaceful and sustainable use of space. The agreement, initiated by NASA in 2020, aims to ensure transparency in space policies and the sharing of scientific data. Singapore is the 18th signatory, joining founding members such as the UK, Japan, and the UAE. The signing coincided with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's visit to the US, where he discussed global challenges and cooperation.

site_title: Koufu to delist from SGX on Mar 29
summary: Koufu will delist from the Singapore Exchange mainboard on March 29 at 9 am after Dominus Capital completed a compulsory acquisition of shares from dissenting shareholders. The deal, which closed on February 24 with 98.19% valid acceptances, was initially made in December 2021 with a S$0.77 per share cash offer. Trading in Koufu's shares has been suspended since February 24.

site_title: Indonesia expects fiscal pressure from high global fuel, food prices
summary: Indonesia's strong fiscal position is expected to face pressure from inflationary shocks due to high global fuel and food prices. The country has kept fuel prices steady despite surging global oil prices, and the cost of maintaining this stability is reflected in a potential increase in subsidies and energy spending. Indonesia's budget surplus in the first two months of 2022 was 19.7 trillion rupiah, but the government may need to adjust its spending to protect society from commodity price shocks.

site_title: Yen crashes; BOJ moves against rising bond yields
summary: The Japanese yen plummeted to a 6-year low against the dollar, reaching 124.65 yen per dollar, due to the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) efforts to contain rising bond yields. The BOJ offered to buy unlimited debt with maturities over 5 years to stabilize markets. US Treasury yields soared to new multi-year highs, lifting the dollar to 2-week peaks, while the euro gained 1.7% against the yen, a 4-year high, as investors anticipate potential interest rate hikes from the European Central Bank.

site_title: ComfortDelGro temporarily increasing taxi fares on spike in fuel prices
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singaporean taxi company, will temporarily increase distance fares by 1 Singapore cent every 400m (or every 350m after 10km) and waiting-time fees by 1 cent every 45 seconds, starting April 4, due to a surge in fuel prices. This move aims to cushion the impact on drivers, who are facing increased fuel costs. The fare hike is expected to improve drivers' daily earnings by between S$3.20 and S$3.84. The temporary increase will be reviewed by May and removed if fuel prices decrease.

site_title: Ng Yu Zhi slapped with 12 new charges from nickel trading fraud
summary: Singapore businessman Ng Yu Zhi has been slapped with 12 new charges related to a US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam. The charges include transferring funds, purchasing luxury items, and transferring money to foreign bank accounts. Ng, who was director of Envy Asset Management, allegedly raised at least S$1 billion from investors for fake deals. The total number of charges he faces now stands at 105, with his next court date scheduled for May 10.

site_title: America's macroeconomic outlook
summary: The US economy has achieved a significant policy victory over the past two years, with employment rising 5% in just one year and the labor market re-knitting faster than in the Great Recession. The Fed's decision not to slow down the recovery too soon has been credited with this success. While higher inflation is expected, the bond market anticipates price stability returning in the medium term, with inflation averaging 2.2% per year in 5-10 years. However, supply-chain disruptions, particularly due to the Russia-Ukraine conflict, pose a risk to this outlook.

site_title: China equities are cheap, but not everyone is sold
summary: China's equities have seen a mixed reaction despite a policy pivot and easing of regulatory crackdowns, with some analysts viewing the market as oversold and others warning of ongoing geopolitical risks. The CSI 300 Index fell 0.65% on Monday after Beijing ordered a lockdown of Shanghai, renewed concerns over the economic toll on the mainland. Analysts expect China to outperform Asia and emerging markets in the coming months, but note that the fundamental outlook remains challenging, with elevated commodity prices and uncertainty around geopolitical spillover risk.

site_title: As US ties with Mid-East allies fray, China benefits
summary: US President Joe Biden's attempts to arrange phone calls with Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and the UAE's Crown Prince Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan have been met with no response. The US is seeking their help in lowering oil prices amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine. However, the deteriorating relationship between the US and its Arab allies could harm US strategic and economic interests in the Middle East, as these countries diversify their diplomatic ties with China and Russia. The US's policies, including ending support for the Saudi war against the Houthis and removing the terrorist designation, have contributed to this shift.

site_title: Looking for election rally? Better to focus on Malaysia's economic rebound instead
summary: Malaysia's stock market, represented by the FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI, may experience a market rally if the country's ruling Barisan Nasional (BN) party secures a clear victory in upcoming national polls. This could indicate stability and clarity, which has been lacking in the country since the 2018 general election. However, investors may be better off focusing on the country's economic rebound narrative, as Malaysia's macroeconomic conditions are on the mend, driven by reopening businesses and borders, and elevated commodity prices.

site_title: China chip startup Biren seeking funds at 17 billion yuan valuation
summary: China chip startup Biren is seeking 2 billion yuan in funding at a valuation of 17 billion yuan. The company, founded in 2019, is looking to fuel its growth in areas like graphics processing units, cloud computing, and integrated solutions. Biren's co-CEO, Allen Lee, a former AMD China head, joined the company last year. The startup has previously raised 4.7 billion yuan from investors, including IDG Capital and Ping An Insurance Group. Discussions with investors are ongoing, and the company plans to disclose details publicly when available.

images.alt_text: Chip designer Shanghai Biren Intelligent Technology is seeking to raise fresh funds at a valuation of about 17 billion yuan (S$3.6 billion) to fuel its growth, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: CODA named best picture, Will Smith slaps Chris Rock at Oscars
summary: At the 94th Academy Awards, CODA won Best Picture, becoming the first movie from a streaming service to win the top prize. CODA also took home Oscars for Best Supporting Actor and Best Adapted Screenplay. Will Smith won Best Actor for his role in King Richard, but his victory was overshadowed by a slap he gave presenter Chris Rock after Rock made a joke about Smith's wife, Jada Pinkett-Smith. The ceremony also honored Jane Campion as Best Director and Jessica Chastain as Best Actress, with Troy Kotsur making history as the first deaf man to win an Oscar for Best Supporting Actor.

images.alt_text: The cast and crew of CODA accept the award for best picture. Actor Troy Kotsur (in black hat) also made history as the first deaf man to win an Oscar.
Will Smith (right) strode up to the stage and slapped Chris Rock (left) after the presenter made a joke about the actor's wife.
Supporting actress went to Ariana DeBose for playing the spirited Anita in Steven Spielberg's remake of West Side Story. She is only the second Latina actress to win an acting Oscar.

site_title: Venture Corp: Temporary halt of Shanghai ops not big impact
summary: Venture Corp, a Singapore-listed company, has temporarily halted its Shanghai operations due to a 9-day lockdown in the city, starting with residents east of the Huangpu river. The company assesses the lockdown as having a minimal impact on its business, with 85% of employees in China vaccinated and no infected cases detected. The company continues to monitor the situation closely and prioritizes employee safety. Despite the halt, Venture Corp's shares rose 0.5% on Monday.

site_title: Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund expects AUM to reach up to US$20b over next 2-3 years
summary: Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund, the Indonesia Investment Authority (INA), expects its assets under management (AUM) to reach $20 billion over the next 2-3 years. INA has several upcoming deals in the infrastructure, digital, healthcare, and energy sectors, including a partnership with Canadian pension fund CDPQ and Dutch pension fund APG. The fund aims to attract foreign direct investment and local investments to support Indonesia's numerous projects. INA's CEO, Ridha Wirakusumah, is bullish on the prospects of Indonesia's infrastructure sector and digital economy, with a focus on creating value and returns for investors.

site_title: WWE signs deal with Fanatics for e-commerce, collectibles
summary: World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE) has signed a long-term deal with Fanatics for e-commerce, collectibles, and licensed merchandise. The partnership allows Fanatics to design, manufacture, and distribute WWE products, including T-shirts and caps, with a new online store set to debut later this year. The deal also grants Fanatics permission for WWE trading cards once the current arrangement expires. WWE's CEO Vince McMahon described the partnership as a "first-of-its-kind" arrangement that will set a new standard for the company's merchandise business.

site_title: Shanghai launches 2-phase lockdown as Covid surges
summary: Shanghai, China's financial hub, has launched a 2-phase lockdown to contain surging Covid-19 cases. The 9-day lockdown, starting March 28, will split the city in two along the Huangpu River, restricting highway traffic and closing bridges and tunnels for "staggered" testing. The move aims to control the spread of the virus among the 26 million residents, marking the biggest Covid-related disruption to hit the city. Authorities have taken the drastic measure in response to the surge in cases, with the lockdown expected to have a significant impact on daily life in Shanghai.

site_title: Netflix shares reel on loss of status as pandemic darling
summary: Netflix Inc. is experiencing its biggest quarterly drop since 2012, with its stock down about 38% as the first quarter comes to a close. The streaming giant's underperformance is attributed to a disappointing growth outlook, which led to a 30% stock drop in the four days after its quarterly results in January. Despite being cheap by its own history, Netflix's stock is still more expensive than its peers, with a multiple of 30 times estimated earnings, compared to 25 for the Nasdaq 100.

site_title: Tourism-dependent stocks to benefit from Malaysia reopening: UOBKH
summary: Malaysia's border reopening on April 1 is expected to benefit tourism-dependent stocks, with UOBKH analysts naming Genting Malaysia, MYEG, and GHL as top picks. Other sectors that could see an upturn include e-payment services, breweries, and manufacturers reliant on foreign workers. While demand won't recover immediately due to ongoing Omicron infections and China's travel restrictions, analysts expect investors to re-rate reopening beneficiaries and anticipate a fuller recovery in 2023.

site_title: Maybank's charity walk raises close to S$270,000 for Singapore Red Cross
summary: Maybank's charity walk, "Walk for Humanity", raised close to S$270,000 for the Singapore Red Cross, exceeding its target of S$200,000. The virtual event, held from Feb 20 to March, saw over 4,500 walkers and 400 donors participate, with more than 230,000 km clocked. The funds will support local and regional humanitarian efforts, including essential services and scaling up services to mitigate the impact of Covid-19. The event increased awareness of social needs on the ground, promoting a kinder community.

site_title: Car sharing heats up amid high COEs, generational shift in ownership mindset
summary: Car sharing platforms in Singapore are gaining popularity as high Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices and a generational shift towards shared mobility drive drivers to consider alternatives to car ownership. Recent COE prices have surged past S$71,000, making car sharing more attractive. Car sharing platforms like Tribecar, GetGo, and BlueSG are expanding their fleets to capture new demand, with Tribecar acquiring CarClub and GetGo reaching over 1,300 vehicles. Technology and new business models are making car sharing more sustainable, with platforms using data and automation to optimize car usage.

images.alt_text: There is a generational shift in car ownership at play. BlueSG's biggest customer segment ranges from 20 years old to 30 years old. Tribecar's biggest customer segment is in the 18-40 age range, while GetGo's average customer is between 35 and 36 years old.

site_title: Singapore signs international pact for space exploration
summary: Singapore has become the first South-east Asian country to sign the Artemis Accords, an international pact for space exploration. The agreement, initiated by NASA in 2020, promotes peaceful, sustainable, and beneficial use of space. Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong signed the Accords on behalf of Singapore in Washington DC on March 28, 2022. This move aims to advance cooperation and responsible space exploration practices among nations.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong met with United States Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen on Mar 28, during a working trip to the US.

site_title: Tesla seeks investor approval for stock split
summary: Tesla is seeking investor approval to increase its number of shares, enabling a stock split in the form of a dividend. The proposal, approved by the board and shareholders, would make Tesla shares cheaper for investors. This follows a 5-for-1 split in 2020, which increased the stock's value by 128% and boosted market capitalization to over $1 trillion. The stock split, contingent on final approval, would be the latest in a trend of tech companies like Alphabet, Amazon, and Apple to split their shares to make them more affordable.

site_title: 4,925 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, infection ratio down for 27th day
summary: Singapore reported 4,925 new Covid-19 cases, with 717 hospitalizations, and 4 deaths on Monday, March 28. The infection ratio remained below one for the 27th consecutive day at 0.73. Of the local cases, 4,019 were detected through antigen rapid tests, while 794 were detected through PCR tests. The total number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore stands at 1,076,930, with 1,254 deaths.

site_title: Why the West's reset is not yet complete
summary: The West's rejuvenation as a political and economic force is not yet complete, despite recent unified efforts to counter Russia's invasion of Ukraine. US President Joe Biden's presidency has helped rebuild the transatlantic alliance, but more needs to be done to address ongoing challenges such as international trade tensions, economic disparities, and the rise of populism. A multi-year dialogue under Biden's presidency, involving forums like NATO and the G7, is necessary to address these issues and explore a new Western-led approach to global governance.

site_title: S&P Global lowers SEA growth forecast
summary: S&P Global has lowered its growth forecast for emerging South-east Asia to 5% due to inflationary risks, with the Philippines seeing the biggest cut in growth forecast. The region's growth is expected to slow in 2022 and 2023-2025, with South-east Asia's growth revised down to 5% and the Philippines' forecast cut to 6.5%. Higher energy prices and US policy rate rises are expected to weigh on the region's economy, with some countries like Malaysia and Indonesia well-positioned to weather the impact.

site_title: NFT of Mandela's arrest warrant auctioned for US$130,000
summary: Nelson Mandela's arrest warrant NFT sold for US$130,550 at an auction in Cape Town, South Africa, with proceeds going to the Liliesleaf Museum to preserve the history of the country's anti-apartheid struggle. The NFT, which features a handwritten document from 1961, was sold for 1.9 million rand (US$130,550) to a foreign buyer based in the United Arab Emirates. The sale helps the museum stay afloat after it closed its doors in September 2021 due to financial difficulties.

site_title: Philippine tycoon Manuel Villar seeks to raise 9.18b pesos in Reit IPO
summary: Manuel Villar, the Philippines' richest person, is seeking to raise up to 9.18 billion pesos (S$239 million) in the maiden share sale of a real estate investment trust (Reit) called VistaREIT. The Reit comprises some of Villar's Vista Land & Lifescapes offices and shopping malls, with an initial portfolio of 10 shopping centers and 2 office buildings. The properties have high occupancy rates and delivered sustained rental income growth, despite the pandemic. The shares will be sold by subsidiaries of Vista Land and are being underwritten by several banks.

site_title: US: S&P 500 opens flat, Tesla boosts Nasdaq
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 28.21 points and the S&P 500 opening lower by 1.97 points. However, the Nasdaq Composite gained 7.91 points to reach 14,177.21. Tesla shares rose after the company announced plans to seek investor approval for a stock split. The market awaited updates on Ukraine-Russia peace talks in Istanbul.

site_title: Credit Suisse stops new business in Russia, cuts exposure
summary: Credit Suisse has stopped pursuing new business in Russia and is cutting its exposure to the country, following other lenders in response to the Ukraine invasion. The bank is helping clients unwind their Russia exposure, relocating employees, and applying all sanctions. Credit Suisse had an exposure of 848 million francs (S$1.23 billion) to Russia at the end of last year and about 125 employees there, with about 4% of its wealth management unit assets held by Russian clients. The bank joins a growing list of lenders pulling back from Russia.

site_title: Top China brokerage Citic posts 55% rise in 2021 profit on investment gains
summary: Citic Securities, China's largest brokerage, reported a 55.01% rise in 2021 profit to 23.1 billion yuan, driven by strong gains in securities investments. Revenue from stock investments jumped 37.14% and asset management fees rose 41.35%. This is in line with preliminary results released in January, citing a booming capital market. China's brokerages earned 191.12 billion yuan in net profit in 2021, a 21.32% increase.

images.alt_text: Citic Securities, China's biggest brokerage, reported on Monday (Mar 28) a 55.01 per cent rise in profit in 2021, led by strong gains in securities investments.

site_title: Singapore stocks end higher amid mixed regional showing
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.5% higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,431.99, driven by gains from SATS and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. However, a worsening Covid-19 situation in China and regional mixed performances may pose "serious headwinds" for Asian equities. Gainers beat losers 271-176, while Japan's Nikkei 225 lost 0.7% and South Korea's Kospi dipped 0.02%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Monday by 5.35 points, or 0.33%, at 1597.95. Losers outnumbered gainers 582 to 393, with 2.4 billion lots traded worth RM1.89 billion.

site_title: SP Group, CJ OliveNetworks to develop rooftop solar projects across Vietnam
summary: SP Group and CJ OliveNetworks Vina Co (CJ ONS) have partnered to develop up to 50 megawatt-peak (MWp) worth of rooftop solar projects in Vietnam over the next two years. CJ ONS will handle engineering, procurement, and construction for the projects, while SP Group will provide expertise and resources. The first project involves installing rooftop solar panels for a CJ Agri manufacturing plant, expected to deliver 3,577 megawatt-hour of electricity annually and cut carbon emissions by 3,500 tonnes.

site_title: AIG says BlackRock will manage up to US$150b of its assets
summary: American International Group (AIG) has agreed to partner with BlackRock to manage up to $150 billion of its assets, including $60 billion of its global investment portfolio and $90 billion of its life and retirement portfolio. This deal is part of AIG's preparations for an initial public offering of its life and retirement business, planned for the first half of this year. BlackRock's Aladdin platform will also provide investment-management technology for both AIG and its life and retirement business.

site_title: India's top multiplexes to merge to survive 'streaming onslaught'
summary: India's two largest multiplex operators, PVR and INOX Leisure, are set to merge to survive the "streaming onslaught" in the film industry. The merger, valued at creating a combined 1,546 screens across 109 cities, aims to fight the decline of traditional cinema due to the rise of digital OTT platforms. The entertainment market in India, valued at $24 billion, is expected to continue growing, with smartphone adoption forecast to expand further. The deal is expected to pick up market share from smaller cinema chains and single-screen theatres.

site_title: Apple to cut iPhone, AirPods output: Nikkei
summary: Apple plans to reduce iPhone and AirPods production due to a demand slowdown caused by the Ukraine crisis and rising inflation. The company is expected to produce 20% fewer iPhone SE units (2-3 million) and reduce AirPods orders by over 10 million units. This mirrors forecasts from analysts warning of weaker smartphone demand this year. The lack of a design upgrade for the iPhone SE and a price increase may also contribute to the demand slowdown.

site_title: Employers must consider flexi-work requests by 2024
summary: Employers in Singapore must consider staff requests for flexible work arrangements by 2024, according to the Manpower Minister of State. Flexible work arrangements can help widen the talent pool and retain staff, and employers can assess business needs when deciding whether to grant approval. The government aims to increase the adoption of flexible work arrangements from 27% to 40% by the end of this year, and plans to enshrine guidelines on fair employment practices in law to protect workers from discrimination and harassment.

images.alt_text: A woman on her laptop working from home.

site_title: Frasers Property Retail to set up EV charging stations at 12 malls
summary: Frasers Property Retail is launching an initiative to set up 36 electric vehicle charging points at 12 malls in Singapore. The 36 EV charging points will be rolled out in two phases, with the first 27 points to be completed by September 2022. Each mall will have up to five EV charging points, with Tesla Supercharger stations and Charge+ Turbo chargers available at select locations. The initiative aims to support Singapore's growing EV market and encourage the adoption of sustainable transportation.

site_title: UAE crypto push sees Bybit, Crypto.com announce Dubai offices
summary: UAE has made significant strides in becoming a hub for the virtual asset sector, with major crypto exchanges Bybit and Crypto.com announcing plans to open offices in Dubai. Bybit will establish its global headquarters, while Crypto.com plans to launch a regional hub. The UAE has issued its first law governing virtual assets and formed the Virtual Asset Regulatory Authority to oversee the sector. The move aims to attract new businesses and talent to the region amidst growing regional economic competition, with Dubai's Director General stating the UAE aspires to become a global capital for virtual assets.

site_title: Budget Omega watch lures mobs of shoppers, buoys Swatch stock
summary: Swatch Group shares rose 5.3% after the release of a low-priced Swatch version of the Omega Speedmaster timepiece, called the MoonSwatch, which caused mobs of shoppers to queue for the new timepiece. The US$260 watch, a collaboration between Omega and Swatch, resembles the iconic Speedmaster Professional and is available in select stores. Despite stores running out of stock, Swatch Group says the watches are not limited and will be available in the weeks to come, reversing a trend of lower-priced watches lagging behind high-priced timepieces.

site_title: Telok Blangah House in Harbourfront up for collective sale with S$98m guide price
summary: Telok Blangah House, a 9-storey mixed-use development in Harbourfront, Singapore, has been put up for collective sale with a guide price of S$98 million. The site, spanning 14,841 sq ft, is zoned for residential and commercial use and has a gross plot ratio of 3.5. A new development could include 34 residential units and 20,788 sq ft of commercial spaces, subject to approval. The site offers a rare opportunity for developers to own a freehold site in the waterfront enclave, which is poised for redevelopment under the Great Southern Waterfront Master Plan.

site_title: EU seeks end to golden passport schemes, halt to sales of visas to Russians
summary: The European Commission has urged EU governments to end national programmes selling citizenship to investors, known as golden passports schemes, and suspend the sale of visas to Russians and Belarusians. The move follows concerns that individuals affected by EU sanctions over Russia's invasion of Ukraine may hold EU citizenship or privileged access. Currently, only Malta, Cyprus, and Bulgaria have such schemes, with Cyprus committing to end its program. The Commission also advises EU governments to check if sanctioned individuals hold golden passports or visas and to immediately withdraw residence permits.

site_title: The West's reset is not yet complete
summary: US President Joe Biden's presidency has helped rebuild the transatlantic and wider Western alliance, with the West's response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine showing renewed confidence among US allies. However, the West's rejuvenation as a leading political and economic force is far from complete. Key steps include acknowledging the need for a new Western-led approach to global governance and addressing challenges such as international trade and economic tensions. A multi-year dialogue under Biden's presidency is needed, with forums like NATO and the G7 playing a crucial role in shaping the new West.

site_title: SpaceX ending production of flagship crew capsule, says company executive
summary: SpaceX has ended production of its Crew Dragon astronaut capsules, with the company having manufactured only four units. The decision comes as SpaceX focuses on its next-generation Starship program, which aims to colonize Mars. The company plans to refurbish existing Crew Dragons instead of producing new ones, citing "fleet management" as key. This move is part of SpaceX's reusable spacecraft business model, which involves refurbishing and reusing vehicles after each flight.

site_title: Venture Corp to halt Shanghai operations temporarily, sees no significant impact to business
summary: Venture Corp, a Singapore-listed company, will temporarily halt its Shanghai operations due to a 9-day lockdown in the city, starting with residents east of the Huangpu river. The company, which trades and manufactures electronic products, expects no significant impact to its business. 85% of its Chinese employees are vaccinated, and no infected cases have been detected. The company has set up task forces to deal with operational challenges and will continue to monitor the situation. Shares rose 0.5% on Monday following the announcement.

site_title: BOJ offers 4 days unlimited bond-buying to defend yield cap
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) defended its 0.25% yield cap on Monday by offering unlimited government bond purchases for 4 days, following a surge in interest rates globally. The move pushed the yen to a 6-year low against the dollar, exacerbating Japan's economic struggles. The BOJ aims to keep borrowing costs low to stimulate the economy, but its grip on yield curve control may be weakening, with some economists warning that the central bank's resolve is at risk of slipping.

site_title: Sterling edges higher versus euro, falls against dollar
summary: Sterling edges higher against the euro, but falls against the dollar as investors focus on the Bank of England's next moves to tame inflation while avoiding recession risks. The pound rose 0.05% to 83.32 pence per euro, while falling 0.25% to US$1.315 against the US dollar. Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey will give a speech on Monday, and concerns about a prolonged war in Ukraine have boosted demand for safe-haven assets. The pound's movement may be influenced by the BoE's monetary policy decisions, which could balance inflation targets with economic downturn risks.

site_title: Huawei 2021 profit leaps 76% on asset sales; CFO Meng returns to spotlight
summary: Huawei reported a 76% profit leap in 2021, driven by asset sales, with net profit rising to 113.7 billion yuan. The company's revenue declined 29% to 636.8 billion yuan. CFO Meng Wanzhou, who returned to China after nearly 3 years' detention in Canada, attributed the performance to increased cash flows and ability to deal with uncertainty. The company's asset sales were partly due to US sanctions and weaker domestic consumer demand amid the pandemic.

site_title: Thai minister projects economy to grow 3.0%-3.5% this year, interest rate to stay low
summary: Thailand's finance minister projects the country's economy to grow 3.0%-3.5% this year, down from earlier forecasts, due to soaring oil prices from the Russia-Ukraine war. Despite this, strong exports and improved tourism are expected to support growth, with exports projected to grow 5%-6% and tourism expected to recover as pandemic-related curbs are eased. The minister also stated that interest rates will remain low to underpin recovery, with several government infrastructure projects set to be completed in 2023, potentially leading to better growth next year.

images.alt_text: Thailand's economy could grow 3.0 per cent-3.5 per cent this year, less than an earlier forecast due to soaring oil prices driven by the Russia-Ukraine war, and the key interest rate should remain low to underpin recovery, the Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith said on Monday (Mar 28).

site_title: TSMC, Samsung urge US to allow them into US$52b chip plan
summary: TSMC and Samsung urge the US to allow foreign companies to participate in a $52 billion chip production program, citing the need for competition and innovation. The Taiwanese and South Korean companies, which are already building new US plants, argue that excluding foreign firms would be unfair and inefficient. TSMC and Samsung request reform of immigration policies to attract foreign talent and ensure equal competition for US funding. The US House and Senate are currently negotiating a final package, with a deadline expected before the end of May.

site_title: Oil producers as 'superheroes' is not how it works, UAE minister says
summary: UAE Energy Minister Suhail al-Mazrouei stated that oil producers, who felt like outcasts at the COP 26 climate conference, are now being treated like "superheroes" due to strong demand. He emphasized the need for long-term planning, suggesting that underinvesting in oil and gas while promoting renewables won't work. Mazrouei said Opec+ needs to replace 5-8 million barrels lost per year to maintain production levels, and the UAE will work with Opec+ to ensure market stability. The UAE aims to increase oil production to 5 million barrels per day, but will do so within the Opec+ framework.

site_title: Carlsberg and Heineken to exit Russia in wake of Ukraine war
summary: Carlsberg and Heineken, two major brewers, plan to sell their Russian businesses and exit the country due to the ongoing Ukraine war. Carlsberg, the largest brewer in Russia, had already withdrawn its financial forecast and stopped investing in the country. Heineken announced it would pull out of Russia, becoming the latest Western firm to exit the country, and would aim for an "orderly transfer" of its business at a cost of 400 million euros. Hundreds of Western firms have closed operations in Russia since the war started, including Ikea, Coca-Cola, and MacDonald's.

site_title: Climate change is threat multiplier for instability globally
summary: Climate change is exacerbating global instability, posing a significant threat to national security and human life. Rising temperatures, sea levels, and resource scarcity are driving conflicts and tensions, particularly in volatile regions. The European Union has proposed a "REPowerEU" plan to reduce dependence on Russian fossil fuels and accelerate renewable energy targets, with Germany aiming to be 100% renewable by 2035. A holistic assessment of climate change's effects highlights the need for accelerated adaptation and mitigation efforts, requiring all-in action from investors, governments, and other stakeholders to address the broader risks of climate security on global geopolitics.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: European stock markets opened higher on Monday, March 28, 2022, driven by hopes for Ukraine-Russia peace talks. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.2%, while Frankfurt's DAX index rose 1.2% and the Paris CAC 40 climbed 0.9%. However, gains were capped by China's phased Shanghai lockdown.

site_title: To shale and back, redux
summary: The price of oil has spiked due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, adding to high inflation and limiting Western sanctions against Russian energy exports. Despite high prices, the US oil industry is reluctant to expand production, with bankers being the main inhibitors. A survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas found that bankers, not regulators or environmentalists, were the main reason for the industry's caution. This is attributed to the aftermath of the debt-financed shale bubble of the 2010s, where bankers were overly enthusiastic about fracking, leading to a reluctance to invest in the industry again.

site_title: Barclays hit by £450m loss on product sales blunder
summary: Barclays reported an estimated £450 million loss due to mishandled structured product sales, primarily affecting exchange-traded notes linked to crude oil and market volatility. The bank oversold securities in the US by $15.2 billion, exceeding its $20.8 billion limit. The loss will delay a planned £1 billion share buyback until the second quarter and may reduce future capital distributions to shareholders. Barclays has commissioned an independent review and is cooperating with regulators, which are conducting inquiries and requesting information.

site_title: China's DJI rejects claim that Russian military uses its drones in Ukraine
summary: China's DJI rejects claims that Russian military is using its drones in Ukraine, calling accusations "utterly false" after a German retailer removed DJI products from its shelves due to the allegations. DJI stated it promotes civilian drone applications and does not support harm to people's lives, rights, and interests. The move comes amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine, where Western firms have pulled out in protest, but DJI has stayed on, taking Beijing's stance of refraining from criticism of Moscow.

images.alt_text: DJI's flagship store in Shenzhen, Guangdong province. Earlier this month, when Mykhailo Fedorov, Ukraine's minister of digital transformation, said he had asked DJI to cut ties with Russia, accusing its troops of using DJI products for the navigation of missiles that kill Ukrainian civilians, DJI responded on Twitter that its products are designed for civilian use and are inappropriate for military missions.

site_title: Rouble firms, Russian stocks extend slide in volatile trade
summary: The Russian rouble strengthened against the dollar, reaching a near 4-week high, while Russian stocks slid lower on their third day of trading after a month-long suspension due to Western sanctions. The rouble was 2.3% stronger against the dollar at 93.84, and 2.5% stronger against the euro at 102.39. Russian stocks, including Aeroflot, recovered from earlier losses, with the MOEX Russian index down 1.8% at 2,440.2 points. Russia is set to pay a $102 million coupon on a Eurobond due in 2035, testing its ability to service foreign currency debt.

site_title: Sri Lanka 'seeking another US$1b credit line from India'
summary: Sri Lanka has sought an additional US$1 billion credit line from India to import essential items amid its economic crisis. The request comes after a 70% drop in foreign exchange reserves since January 2020, leading to a currency devaluation. This new credit line, on top of a US$1 billion already pledged by India, will be used for imports of rice, wheat flour, pulses, sugar, and medicines. Indian Foreign Minister talks with the Sri Lankan government are ongoing.

site_title: ComfortDelGro to temporarily increase taxi fares on spike in fuel prices
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singaporean taxi company, will temporarily increase taxi fares by 32 Singapore cents for every 10km traveled due to a spike in fuel prices. The increase, effective April 4, aims to cushion the impact of rising fuel costs on drivers, who face a 14% increase in fuel prices in March. The hike will be reviewed by the end of May and removed if fuel prices decrease.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: ComfortDelGro to temporarily increase taxi fares due to a spike in fuel prices, starting April 4. Singtel's NCS acquired Australian digital services company ARQ Group for A$290m. Telok Blangah House in Harbourfront is up for collective sale with a guide price of S$98m. Businessman Ng Yu Zhi faces 12 new charges related to nickel trading fraud, bringing the total to 105. SP Group and CJ OliveNetworks to develop rooftop solar projects in Vietnam, and Singapore stocks closed higher on Monday, up 0.5% or 18.3 points.

images.alt_text: For regular taxis, distance-timed rates will rise by 1 Singapore cent every 400m (or every 350m after 10km) and waiting-time fees will go up by 1 cent every 45 seconds.

site_title: UK's Ted Baker rebuffs US PE firm's takeover proposals
summary: UK fashion retailer Ted Baker has rejected unsolicited takeover proposals from private-equity firm Sycamore Partners Management, valuing the company at £253.8 million. Sycamore initially proposed 130 pence per share, but raised the offer to 137.5 pence, representing a 39.2% premium. Ted Baker cited that the proposals undervalued the company and failed to compensate shareholders for its upside potential. The retailer is currently in a 3-year turnaround plan under boss Rachel Osborne. Sycamore has until April 15 to make a firm offer for the company.

site_title: TalkMed receives SGX approval to transfer to mainboard
summary: TalkMed Group received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on March 25 for its transfer to the mainboard. The company will seek shareholder approval at an upcoming extraordinary general meeting. A mainboard listing is expected to enhance the company's long-term value and provide access to a wider and more diverse investor base. Shares rose 3.9% to close at S$0.40 following the announcement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise, Shanghai gains tempered by lockdown
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.31% on Monday, driven by anticipation of a Russia-Ukraine ceasefire. However, Shanghai saw minimal gains due to a phased lockdown, which pushed the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.07%. The Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.82%. Despite the mixed results, investors remained optimistic, awaiting the outcome of Russia-Ukraine ceasefire talks.

site_title: US ties with Middle East allies have frayed; China benefits
summary: US President Joe Biden's efforts to secure oil from Saudi Arabia and the UAE to lower global gas prices have been met with a cold shoulder. The two countries, key oil producers, have been increasingly resentful of the US, which they perceive as retreating from the Middle East. The deterioration in the relationship could damage US interests in the region and affect its global position. The US has been losing influence to China, which is strengthening ties with Saudi Arabia, and Russia. The Biden administration's decision to renew the nuclear deal with Iran and remove sanctions has further strained relations.

site_title: America's macroeconomic outlook
summary: The US economy has achieved a significant policy victory over the past two years, with employment rising by 5% in just one year, outpacing the 1.3% annual increase during the post-2008 recession. This robust recovery has led to higher inflation, but the bond market expects price stability to return in the medium term, with inflation averaging 2.2% per year in 5-10 years. Despite potential risks, including supply-chain disruptions, the author believes that the Fed's actions have been effective in re-knitting the labor market and reducing the likelihood of a wage-price spiral.

site_title: Protecting investor interests in Singapore stock market
summary: A letter to the editor from Kwong Leong Onn expresses concern over investor interests in Singapore's stock market, citing the need for a separate regulatory body to eliminate conflicts of interest between the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and its dual role as a profit-seeking entity and regulator. He references the China Paper incident, where the company issued two rights issues, only to have its factory catch fire and financial records destroyed, leaving many shareholders with significant losses. Onn suggests that setting up an independent regulatory body would help protect investor interests and rebuild confidence in the market.

images.alt_text: Besides the suggestion of class action suits, I think there is the greater need for Singapore to seriously consider setting up a separate regulatory body independent of Singapore Exchange (SGX), to eliminate the conflict of interests of being a dual profit-seeking entity and as a regulatory body.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end flat, bond yields surge on Fed rate hike bets
summary: South Korean stocks ended nearly flat on Monday, while the nation's 10-year bond yields surged to a near 8-year high due to concerns about the US Federal Reserve's potential rate hike to combat inflation. The benchmark Kospi fell 0.02% to 2,729.56, and the 10-year treasury bond yield rose to 3.086%, the highest since 2014. Foreigners were net sellers of 273.3 billion won worth of shares, and the won lost 0.69% against the dollar.

site_title: Singapore stocks end higher on Monday amid mixed regional showing; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.5% higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,431.99, amid a mixed regional performance. The gains were driven by local banks and inflight caterer SATS, while Jardine Matheson was the biggest loser. A worsening Covid-19 situation in China and wider restrictions may bring "serious headwinds" for Asian equities.

site_title: Singtel's NCS acquires Australia digital services company ARQ Group for A$290m
summary: Singtel's technology services arm NCS acquired Australian digital services company ARQ Group for A$290 million (S$296.8 million), as part of its regional expansion plans. ARQ, a Melbourne-based digital consultancy, specializes in mobile applications, cloud, and data analytics. The deal, expected to be completed by May 2022, will scale up NCS Next and increase its headcount in Australia to 1,900. The acquisition is NCS's fourth in Australia in the past 15 months, and is seen as a strategic move to compete as a regional digital powerhouse in the market.

site_title: Sea's e-commerce arm Shopee to shut down India operations
summary: Shopee, the e-commerce arm of South-east Asia's Sea, is closing down its India operations due to global market uncertainties. The move comes weeks after Shopee pulled out of France and after India banned its popular gaming app Free Fire. The closure is expected to support local seller and buyer communities and its local team, with the goal of a smooth transition. This decision follows a significant drop in Sea's market value after the India ban, prompting some investors to cut their holdings.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher as miners and financials gain
summary: Australia's shares rose for a fifth straight session, driven by gains in miners and financials. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended 0.1% higher at 7,412.4, its highest since mid-January. Miners like Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals Group climbed 1.4% and 0.8% respectively, while financials rose 0.6% on gains in "Big Four" banks. Expectations of higher interest rates by the Reserve Bank of Australia may have contributed to the market's cautious tone.

site_title: Evergrande electric vehicle arm to start taking car orders 'imminently'
summary: China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle Group will start accepting orders for its Hengchi 5 electric vehicle "imminently" and open sales centers in 15 major cities. The move comes after the EV firm struggled to secure external investment, with Evergrande chairman Hui Ka Yan stating mass production will begin on June 22, pending regulatory approval. The sales centers will be located in cities such as Tianjin, Shanghai, and Guangzhou, marking the company's efforts to bolster its finances and expand its electric vehicle business.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS trims Haidilao TP on lower FY23 net profit estimate
summary: DBS Group Research has lowered its net profit estimate for Haidilao International to HK$20.90, down 4% from previous forecasts, due to challenges from the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite this, the analysts maintain a "buy" rating and note signs of improvement in post-Covid revenue recovery. Haidilao has closed underperforming stores, expanded sub-brands, and raised table turnover, which the analysts believe will help streamline operations and reduce redundancy. The target price represents a 51.2% potential upside from the last closing price.

images.alt_text: Waiters serve customers at a Haidilao hotpot restaurant in Beijing, China October 11, 2021. Picture taken October 11, 2021.

site_title: Singapore ranks third for most expensive flexible office space globally: Workthere
summary: Singapore ranks third globally for most expensive flexible office space, with private office desk spaces costing an average of US$834 a month. New York and San Francisco top the list at US$961 and US$950, respectively. The city's popularity for startups has contributed to its growth, and the market remains tight due to construction delays.

site_title: Viking Offshore and Marine to change name, diversify business; proposes rights cum warrants issue, share placement
summary: Viking Offshore and Marine is proposing to change its name to "9R Limited" and diversify its business into supply chain management and lifestyle retail. The company aims to raise funds through a rights cum warrants issue and share placement, with net proceeds to be used to repay loans and fund working capital requirements. It also plans to dispose of its entire shareholding interest in subsidiaries Viking Airtech and Viking HVAC for $50,000. The proposals, subject to shareholder approval, will allow the company to exit a loss-making business segment and free up cash flows.
