site_title: HDB launches pilot project to harvest rainwater in existing Yishun, Jurong estates
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has launched a pilot project to harvest rainwater in existing Yishun and Jurong estates, with about 15 UrbanWater Harvesting Systems (UWHS) to be installed. The project aims to save 17,500 cubic meters of water per year, equivalent to the average yearly consumption of over 85 potable water units. The systems will collect rainwater for non-potable uses, such as washing common areas and watering plants, and can mitigate flood risks during heavy downpours. The pilot project is expected to complete in 2027.

site_title: SP Group, CJ OliveNetworks to develop rooftop solar projects across Vietnam
summary: SP Group has partnered with CJ OliveNetworks Vina Co to develop up to 50 megawatt-peak rooftop solar projects in Vietnam within the next 2 years. CJ ONS will handle engineering, procurement, and construction for the joint projects. The companies will combine expertise and resources to explore sustainable energy solutions for CJ ONS' affiliates and commercial/industrial customers in Vietnam.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index closed 0.7% lower on profit-taking amid a 9-day winning streak, snapping its winning streak. The benchmark index fell 205.95 points to 27,943.89 after a lockdown was imposed in Shanghai to curb an Omicron-fuelled Covid-19 outbreak. China-related shares declined, while airlines such as ANA Holdings and Japan Airlines rose. The dollar strengthened to 123.18 yen, while SoftBank Group remained flat despite reports of US$10 billion in bank loans.

site_title: Ng Yu Zhi slapped with 12 new charges from nickel trading fraud; total charges now at 105
summary: Businessman Ng Yu Zhi, director of Envy Asset Management and Envy Global Trading, faces 105 charges related to a US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam. The new charges include transferring funds, purchasing property, and spending on luxury items like diamond jewellery and cars. Ng allegedly raised S$1 billion from investors for fake deals, with transactions made between December 2019 and February 2020. He is scheduled for a pre-trial conference on May 10.

site_title: Philippine's Villar eyes US$176m IPO for real estate Reit
summary: Manuel Villar, the Philippines' richest person, is planning to raise up to $239 million through the initial public offering (IPO) of VistaREIT, a real estate investment trust (Reit) comprising some of his office and shopping mall properties. The IPO will see the sale of up to 3.33 billion secondary shares at a maximum price of 2.50 pesos apiece. The Reit's initial portfolio includes 10 shopping centers and 2 office buildings with 93-100% occupancy rates, delivering sustained rental income growth. The IPO is being led by China Bank Capital and BDO Capital & Investment.

site_title: Will Smith wins best actor Oscar for 'King Richard' after slap on Chris Rock goes viral
summary: Will Smith won the Best Actor Oscar for his portrayal of Richard Williams in 'King Richard' after a viral incident where he slapped presenter Chris Rock on stage for making a joke about his wife. Smith, 53, accepted the award in a tear-filled speech, without apologizing to Rock. The film, which also earned Smith his first Oscar nomination, tells the story of Richard Williams, the father of tennis champions Venus and Serena Williams.

site_title: Tesla suspends work at key Shanghai factory for 4 days to fall in with Covid-19 curbs: sources
summary: Tesla has suspended production at its Shanghai factory for 4 days due to Shanghai's phased lockdown to curb a surge in Covid-19 cases. The factory was initially halted for a day but will now resume production on April 1. The lockdown affects areas east of the Huangpu River, where the plant is located, and may impact Tesla workers who may be able to return to work after the lockdown shifts. The Shanghai factory is crucial for Tesla, producing half of the company's vehicles last year.

site_title: Gold slips ahead of Ukraine-Russia peace talks
summary: Gold prices fell 0.5% to $1,947.90 per ounce, as hopes of Russia-Ukraine peace talks this week reduced safe-haven demand. US Treasury yields rose, making gold less expensive for holders, and a stronger US dollar also weighed on the metal. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky insisted on the territorial integrity of his country amid peace talks.

site_title: Will Smith strikes Chris Rock across face in viral Oscars moment
summary: Will Smith stormed the Oscars stage, striking comedian Chris Rock across the face after a joke about his wife, Jada Pinkett Smith, who has alopecia. The incident occurred during the best documentary prize presentation. Smith shouted profanities and returned to his seat, prompting a commercial break and tears from Smith. After the show, Smith was comforted by Denzel Washington and Tyler Perry. The incident sparked confusion and a viral moment, with some questioning if it was scripted or genuine.

site_title: 'CODA' wins best picture in a streaming first at the Oscars
summary: CODA, a heartwarming movie about a deaf family with a hearing daughter, won the Best Picture award at the Oscars, marking the first time a streaming service took home the prize. Apple TV+ released CODA, beating Netflix's contender The Power of the Dog. CODA also made history with its cast, including Troy Kotsur, who became the first deaf man to win an Oscar for Best Supporting Actor. The ceremony was marred by a disruption when Will Smith slapped presenter Chris Rock after a joke about his wife.

site_title: Self-driving Chinese startup Zongmu raises US$157m in new funds
summary: Chinese autonomous driving system startup Zongmu Technology Shanghai has raised over $213 million in a new round of funding, led by state-backed funds Dongyang State-Owned Assets Investment and Zhejiang Caitong Capital Investment. The funding will be used to accelerate research and development and set up a base in Zhejiang province capable of producing 2 million sets of autonomous driving systems annually. Zongmu plans to use the funds to build a new production plant and accelerate its expansion in the autonomous driving market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin marginally higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with small gains, edging up 0.08% to 21,422.20, following a hefty loss at the end of last week. In contrast, Shanghai fell 0.84% to 3,185.17 after officials announced a phased Covid lockdown of China's biggest city.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed, eyes on Ukraine talks and Shanghai lockdown
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Monday, with traders hopeful for progress in Ukraine ceasefire talks, despite a Shanghai lockdown that raised concerns about supply chains. Treasury yields surged, dampening sentiment, while investors expect the Federal Reserve to increase interest rates to combat inflation. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky expressed hope for a peaceful resolution, while Russian President Vladimir Putin's reduced "main goal" of controlling Donbas offers a glimmer of hope for a ceasefire. Oil prices fell, but concerns about China's economy and the Fed's interest rate hikes weighed on markets.

site_title: US, Philippines kick off their largest-ever war games
summary: The Philippines and the US launched the largest-ever joint military drills, dubbed Balikatan, on March 28, 2022, amidst tensions in the South China Sea. Nearly 9,000 soldiers will participate in 12 days of training exercises on Luzon, focusing on maritime security, amphibious operations, and counterterrorism. The drills come as President Rodrigo Duterte's term ends in June, with the US seeking to deepen its defense ties with the Philippines. The exercises reflect the "deepening alliance" between the two countries, with US Major General Jay Bargeron stating that the "friendship and trust" between their armed forces will enable successful operations.

site_title: Hong Kong's tycoons spend billions on Chinese property bargains
summary: Hong Kong's property tycoons are investing billions in mainland China as Chinese developers struggle with a credit crisis. With mainland developers facing a record wave of defaults, Hong Kong developers are seizing the opportunity to acquire prime land and projects. New World Development and Swire Properties are among those making significant investments, with New World planning to acquire cheap land and land with high margins in the crisis. This move gives Hong Kong developers another avenue for growth as their own market becomes saturated, and authorities focus on affordability.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts mostly positive on CICT's acquisition of office on Robinson Rd
summary: Analysts at UOB Kay Hian, Maybank, and RHB are generally positive on CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust's (CICT) acquisition of a Grade-A office building at 79 Robinson Road for S$1.3 billion. Analysts highlight the property's attractive yield, prime location, and diversified tenant base. They also expect improving fundamentals at CICT, with forecasts of rising office rents and potential future collaborations between CICT and the acquiring fund. Despite some concerns over the acquisition price, analysts maintain "buy" calls and target prices ranging from S$2.20 to S$2.55.

site_title: Brokers' take: Tourism-dependent stocks to benefit from Malaysia reopening, says UOBKH
summary: Malaysia is set to reopen its borders on April 1, with tourism-dependent stocks expected to benefit. Analysts from UOB Kay Hian identify key sectors such as hospitality, e-payment services, breweries, and manufacturers reliant on foreign workers as top picks. Companies like Genting Malaysia, MYEG, GHL, Heineken, and Pavillion Reit are among the top picks, with estimated revenue and profit increases of over 20% due to reduced quarantine and testing costs. The reopening is expected to boost inbound and outbound tourism, consumer demand, and business travel, despite potential delays in full recovery.

site_title: Global bond rout accelerates, sparks intervention from BOJ
summary: A global bond rout accelerated, with Australian and New Zealand notes sliding, and the Bank of Japan intervening to cap yields. Aussie 3-year yields jumped 12 basis points to 2.33%, while Japan 10-year yields rose to 0.245%. The BOJ announced an unlimited buying operation to keep yields below 0.25%. Global bond losses reached a record 7% this year, driven by Fed-hike expectations and inflation concerns.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.98 points or 0.25% to 1,599.32. Volume was 172.63 million lots worth RM93.10 million. The decline followed a global trend, with stocks in Europe and the US also falling due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, as well as US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, ending nine consecutive gains, due to investor concerns over developments in Ukraine. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 0.39% to 28,038.97, while the Topix index dropped 0.06% to 1,980.33. This follows a similar trend in European markets, where bank and healthcare stocks were dragged down by US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Shanghai locks down half the city to nail growing Covid outbreak
summary: China's financial hub of Shanghai has implemented a two-stage lockdown to contain a growing COVID-19 outbreak, affecting 26 million residents. The city, home to Tesla's Shanghai factory, has locked down areas east of the Huangpu River for 4 days, followed by another 4-day lockdown in the west. Residents are barred from leaving their homes, and public transport has been suspended. The move comes as China experiences its worst COVID spread since the virus's emergence in Wuhan, testing the country's virus strategy and impacting the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Oil slumps as Shanghai lockdown raises fears over drop in demand
summary: Oil prices dropped by US$4 on Monday, reaching US$116.77 per barrel, amid concerns over slower fuel demand in China due to a nine-day Covid-19 testing blitz in Shanghai. The uncertainty also comes from the ongoing war between Ukraine and Russia, the world's second-largest crude exporter. The Shanghai lockdown has raised fears of a potential drop in demand, contributing to the market's volatility.

images.alt_text: Oil prices plunged about US$4 on Monday as concerns over slower fuel demand in China grew after authorities in Shanghai said they would shut the country's financial hub for a Covid-19 testing blitz over nine days.

site_title: Nato not seeking regime change in Russia: Scholz
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz stated that regime change in Russia is not NATO's objective, despite US President Joe Biden calling Vladimir Putin a "butcher" who "cannot remain in power." Scholz clarified this in an interview with German state television, saying that NATO and the US president do not seek to overthrow Putin. Scholz emphasized the importance of democracy, freedom, and justice, but left the decision to fight for these values up to the people and nations themselves.

site_title: Middle East feels the pinch of rising food prices
summary: Rising food prices are affecting the Middle East and North Africa ahead of Ramadan, a festive season where people traditionally gather and feast. Global supply chain disruptions and the war between Russia and Ukraine have led to surging prices of staples like oil, sugar, flour, and rice. Countries such as Egypt, Morocco, Lebanon, and Syria are feeling the pinch, with households and governments struggling to afford essentials. Egypt has announced talks with the IMF and implemented measures to stabilize the economy, but many are worried about the impact on the poor, who rely on cheap food for survival.

site_title: Australia: Shares rally for fifth day as iron ore strength boosts miners
summary: Australian shares rose for the fifth consecutive day, with the S&P/ASX 200 index up 0.4% to 7,431.80, driven by strong iron ore prices. Miners like Rio Tinto, Fortescue Metals Group, and BHP Group led gains, while technology stocks limited the advance. Financials and energy stocks also rose, despite oil prices falling in China. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.1% to 12,038.66.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose on Monday, led by miners on strong iron ore prices, as investors assessed interest rate hikes and the impact of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, though subdued technology stocks limited gains.

site_title: Russian tankers going dark raises flags on sanctions evasion
summary: Russian tankers are increasingly concealing their movements, with at least 33 occurrences of "dark activity" reported in the week ended March 25, according to Windward. This phenomenon may signal attempts to evade sanctions prompted by Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Disabling AIS systems is a top deceptive shipping practice cited by the US Treasury Department, and experts warn that Russian ships may engage in illicit shipping to stay afloat. The increase in dark activity raises concerns about sanctions evasion and potential manipulation of Russian ships.

site_title: Zelensky says Ukraine studying issue of neutrality
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky stated that Ukraine is studying the issue of neutrality, a key demand from Russia during conflict negotiations. Zelensky acknowledged the point of discussion and said it is being carefully examined. The Kremlin previously mentioned Sweden and Austria as models of neutrality that Ukraine could adopt to end Russia's invasion in Ukraine.

site_title: Biden's 'gaffe' on Putin scrambles US message on Ukraine
summary: President Joe Biden's comment that Vladimir Putin "cannot remain in power" during a speech in Warsaw sparked an administration scramble to correct the US message on Ukraine, amid concerns it could escalate the conflict. The US clarified that Biden was not advocating "regime change" in Russia, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken stating that Putin's choice is "up to the Russians." The comments drew criticism from allies and raised eyebrows in Moscow, with some experts warning it could prolong the war.

site_title: Hot stock: Yangzijiang hits 6-month high after capital injection into proposed spin-off
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's shares hit a 6-month high after the company announced a capital injection into its proposed spin-off, Yangzijiang Financial Holding. The move is expected to improve earnings quality, attracting investors seeking direct exposure to the shipbuilding business. Analysts predict a potential re-rating, with Citi targeting S$1.98 and DBS Group Research aiming for S$2.15, implying a potential upside of 32.9% to 68.5%. The spin-off will leverage the investment unit's track record and diversify into new asset classes, further supporting the stock's growth prospects.

images.alt_text: On Mar 25, Yangzijiang said increased the share capital of Yangzijiang Financial Holding, the investment unit it is proposing the spin off.

site_title: Frasers Property subsidiary inks JV agreement to explore land projects in China
summary: Frasers Property's subsidiary, Suzhou Sing Heng Le Enterprise Development, has signed a joint venture agreement with a partner to explore land projects in China. The agreement involves a 1.8 billion yuan (S$394.41 million) funding commitment and a bridging loan of 1.2 billion yuan (S$257.16 million). If the project materializes, Suzhou Sing Heng Le will acquire up to 25% interest in the joint ventures and be entitled to a full refund if the funds are not used as intended. The agreement is expected to impact Frasers Property's earnings, with estimated profit declines and decreased earnings per share.

site_title: Abbas slams West's 'double standards' on Ukraine, Palestinians
summary: Palestinian President Mahmud Abbas criticized the West's "double standards" for not holding Israel accountable for its actions against Palestinians while condemning Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Abbas stated that despite Israel's alleged ethnic cleansing and racial discrimination, no one is holding Israel responsible. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken visited Abbas, aiming to revitalize US relations with the Palestinians, but did not raise the Ukraine issue or other contentious topics. Blinken pledged to maintain support for the Palestinians, providing $500 million in humanitarian aid in the past year.

site_title: Mapletree's support for MCT-MNACT merger may raise expectations of other Reit sponsors
summary: Mapletree Investments, the sponsor of Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) and Ma-pletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT), has doubled down on its support for the merger by agreeing to invest up to S$2.2 billion in cash. This move is expected to increase the likelihood of the merger succeeding, but may also set a precedent for other Reit sponsors to pursue similar deals. The merger, which was initially met with resistance from investors, now has the potential to be cited as a notable precedent for future deals.

site_title: Meituan shares surge as much as 14% after earnings report
summary: Meituan shares surged 14% in Hong Kong after its fourth-quarter earnings report, snapping a 2-day loss. The company reported a net loss of 5.3 billion yuan and revenue rose 31% to 49.5 billion yuan, meeting analyst estimates. Despite a severe regulatory crackdown and pressure to share wealth, Meituan's stock had dropped 40% this year before Monday's gain. The company's results were seen as a positive sign, but its struggles with delivery riders' welfare and restaurant commissions remain concerns.

images.alt_text: Shares of Chinese food delivery giant Meituan surged as much as 14 per cent in Hong Kong after its fourth-quarter results impressed analysts.

site_title: Scholz's SPD clears first election test with thumping win in Germany
summary: Chancellor Olaf Scholz's Social Democratic Party (SPD) secured a thumping win in regional polls in Saarland, Germany, with 29 of 51 seats, surpassing the absolute majority. This marks the party's first electoral success since taking power, and it surpasses former Chancellor Angela Merkel's CDU party, which secured just 19 mandates. The SPD's victory lends momentum ahead of upcoming regional polls, including the North Rhine-Westphalia polls in May, and deepens the conservatives' struggles in the state.

site_title: Coinbase nears deal to buy Brazil crypto unicorn 2TM, media says
summary: US cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase Global is set to acquire Brazilian crypto unicorn 2TM, controlling Latin America's largest crypto brokerage Mercado Bitcoin, by the end of April. The acquisition, valued at roughly $2.2 billion, would give Coinbase leverage in the Latin American market and allow 2TM to expand into Chile, Colombia, Mexico, and Argentina. The deal is part of Coinbase's push to broaden operations in an increasingly competitive market, which has also caught the eye of rival Binance Holdings.

site_title: KIT trustee-manager proposes to peg base, performance fees to distributions
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) trustee-manager proposes new base and performance fee structures pegged to distributable income and DPU growth, respectively. The proposed base fee is 10% of distributable income, compared to the current $2 million per annum. The move aims to align the trustee-manager's interests with unitholders and support KIT's growth plans.

site_title: Last EU train out of Russia arrives in Helsinki
summary: The last train out of Russia to the EU, the Allegro express, has arrived in Helsinki, marking the closure of the last rail link between Russia and the EU. The train, which has been sold-out since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, was suspended by Finnish railway operator VR due to heavy sanctions against Russia. Thousands of Russians have left their country since the invasion, with many relying on the train service to escape. The closure will make it more difficult for Russians to leave, with those wishing to return to Moscow facing uncertain travel options.

site_title: Grab-Singtel among favourites to bag Malaysia's first digital banking licences
summary: Grab-Singtel and RHB Bank-Axiata Group are among the top contenders to win Malaysia's first digital banking licenses, according to analysts. The Grab-Singtel consortium, which secured a digital banking license in Singapore in 2020, has a strong background and is well-poised to operate a digital bank in Malaysia. The RHB Bank-Axiata Group consortium has a large existing customer base and strong technological capabilities. Other likely awardees include Aeon Credit-Aeon Financial Group and BigPay-MIDF-Ikhlas Capital. The licenses are expected to be awarded soon, with Bank Negara Malaysia's annual report publication on March 31 potentially coinciding with the announcement.

site_title: Bringing sustainable period products to women in poverty
summary: Singapore-based start-up Freedom Cups aims to bring sustainable period products to women in poverty through its eco-friendly menstrual cups, which are manufactured in the US and sold online. Founded in 2016, the company uses a buy-one-give-one model, donating a cup to a woman in an underprivileged community for every one purchased. Despite initial challenges, Freedom Cups has seen high receptivity rates in beneficiary communities, with women embracing the practical solution and reduced waste. The company plans to expand its product lines and global distribution, driven by growing demand and increasing awareness of period poverty and sustainability.

site_title: Hollywood stars hit Oscars red carpet with Ukraine on mind
summary: Celebrities gathered on the Oscars red carpet, celebrating the year in movies while acknowledging the crisis in Ukraine. The ceremony, held without pandemic restrictions, featured a rainbow of colors and included a tribute to Betty White. The best picture prize is between dark Western "The Power of the Dog" and feel-good deaf family drama "CODA", with a streaming service milestone at stake. Actor Mila Kunis, born in Ukraine, presented alongside actor Jason Momoa, who wore a Ukrainian flag handkerchief. The ceremony also honored diversity, with potential winners including Will Smith and Ariana DeBose.

images.alt_text: The cast of Encanto pose on the red carpet during the Oscars arrivals at the 94th Academy Awards in Hollywood, Los Angeles, California on March 27, 2022.

site_title: US boost fines for automakers not meeting fuel economy rules in Tesla win
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) reinstated sharp fuel economy penalties for automakers, increasing fines for model years 2019 and beyond. The decision, a win for Tesla, could cost other automakers hundreds of millions of dollars. The penalty increase incentivizes manufacturers to improve fuel efficiency, with fines rising from $5.50 to $14 per 0.1 mpg shortfall for 2019-2021 models, and to $15 for 2022 models.

site_title: Hyatt cites sanctions as it cuts ties with Moscow hotel
summary: HYATT Hotels has cut ties with its Moscow hotel, the Hyatt Regency Moscow Petrovsky Park, due to compliance with "applicable sanctions and government directives". The hotel, which opened in 2017, is one of five Hyatt properties in Russia. The US Treasury has imposed full-blocking sanctions against VTB Bank, which is the bank of the hotel. This decision follows a measured approach by US hotel companies to pause new development deals in Russia while keeping existing properties open. The hotel will cease operations at 11:59pm local time on March 25.

site_title: Oscars' best-picture contest is a battle for streaming glory
summary: The Oscars' best-picture contest is expected to be a battle between Netflix's "The Power of the Dog" and Apple TV+'s "CODA," marking the first time the industry's top honor is likely to go to a film distributed primarily online and not in theaters. The ceremony, which returns to its regular home at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles, will be broadcast on ABC, with three female comedians presiding over the ceremony. The event comes as the film industry continues to adapt to the pandemic, with studios releasing movies for home viewing to compete with streaming services.

images.alt_text: The race for this year's best-picture Oscar is shaping up to be a battle between Netflix and Apple. Either way, it's likely to mark the first time the industry's top honour has gone to a film distributed primarily online and not in theatres.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Infra Trust, Frasers Property, Singtel, CICT, Viking Offshore
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies saw new developments that may impact trading on Monday. Keppel Infra Trust proposed new base and performance fee structures to align with unitholders' interests. Frasers Property's subsidiaries entered into strategic alliances and provided bridging loans. Singtel monetized a 1.6% stake in Airtel Africa through a market placement, raising S$150 million. CICT and CapitaLand acquired a Grade A office building for S$1.3 billion. Viking Offshore and Marine plans to diversify and rebrand, while Excelpoint Technology is in talks with a potential third-party transaction. TalkMed Group received in-principle approval to transfer to the mainboard.

site_title: A novel approach to startup recruiting: lower the stock price
summary: Instacart, a grocery-delivery startup, lowered its valuation by 40% to around $24 billion in an effort to boost recruiting and retention. This move, uncommon in the tech industry, aims to provide new employees with more room for upside as the company grows and market conditions improve. By reducing the valuation, Instacart will offer more shares to new hires for the same dollar grant, potentially attracting seasoned candidates. However, long-time and former employees, as well as investors, will take a hit from the reduced valuation.

site_title: Foreign worker levy rebate for construction, marine shipyard sectors extended
summary: Singapore has extended foreign worker levy rebates for construction, marine shipyard, and process sectors until June 2022, with rebates of S$250 for April and May, and S$200 for June. The move aims to address continued manpower shortages and elevated business costs caused by the pandemic. The Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act Part 10A will also be extended until June 30, allowing contractors to adjust contract sums to account for increased foreign manpower costs. The government will permanently remove a minimum employment period requirement for construction work permit holders.

site_title: Canada beat Jamaica 4-0 to reach first World Cup in 36 years
summary: Canada secured its first World Cup qualification in 36 years with a 4-0 victory over Jamaica in Toronto, advancing to the 2022 World Cup. Goals from Cyle Larin, Tajon Buchanan, Junior Hoilett, and an own goal by Adrian Mariappa secured the win. The match, played in front of a sell-out crowd, marked Canada's second World Cup appearance, with their last being in 1986.

images.alt_text: Canada qualified for the World Cup for the first time in 36 years on Sunday with an emphatic 4-0 victory over Jamaica in Toronto.

site_title: Temasek said to push for removal of Bayer CEO Baumann
summary: Temasek Holdings, a major investor in Bayer, is pushing for the removal of CEO Werner Baumann due to concerns over the company's operating performance and lack of succession planning. The Singapore state investor has communicated its dissatisfaction to the company and supervisory board, considering options such as a no-confidence vote or voting against the management's performance. This move comes as Bayer's shares have rebounded in recent months, but the company still faces significant challenges, including ongoing litigation over its Monsanto acquisition.

images.alt_text: Baumann is one of the primary architects of Bayer's controversial mega-takeover of Monsanto. He survived the past 3 annual meetings, including in 2019 when he actually lost a shareholder confidence vote.

site_title: Shanghai overtakes Jilin to be China's biggest Covid-19 hotspot
summary: Shanghai surpassed Jilin as China's biggest Covid-19 hotspot, reporting 2,676 new daily infections, a 18% increase from the previous day. The city will perform a fresh round of testing and lock down residents in two batches between March 28 and April 5. Most cases are asymptomatic, with a vast majority showing no symptoms.

site_title: WealthBT: How social factors can make your healthcare investments (Ep 12)
summary: WealthBT podcast discusses sustainable healthcare investing, highlighting the importance of social factors, such as clinical benefits and cost savings, in determining a therapy's viability. Nathalie Flury, co-head of Sustainable Healthcare Equity at HSBC Asset Management, shares insights on how companies conduct health economic assessments to set acceptable prices. The conversation emphasizes innovation's role in sustainable healthcare, citing Singapore's trend towards medical cost control. The podcast aims to educate affluent individuals on protecting and growing their wealth through sustainable healthcare investments.

site_title: Dollar edges up, heads for third day of gains
summary: The US dollar edged higher against major currencies, poised for a third day of gains, as crude prices rebounded following a missile attack in Saudi Arabia. The dollar index rose 0.071% and the euro fell 0.11% to US$1.0984, driven by inflation concerns and expectations of a more aggressive US Federal Reserve. Analysts predict the dollar will lead rate hikes, with Bank of America and Citi revising their Fed policy paths to include 50 basis point hikes.

site_title: Navigating digital and green economy the way forward for Asean
summary: Singapore is prioritizing its position in the digital and green economies, aiming to seize emerging opportunities. The city-state has signed digital economy agreements with countries such as Chile, New Zealand, and the UK, and is working on a green economy agreement with Australia. Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong emphasized the importance of developing digital agreements with major trading partners to facilitate digital transactions and interoperability. Singapore is also focusing on supply chain connectivity and free trade agreements to build resiliency, with the goal of becoming a hub for businesses in the region.

site_title: Singapore stocks start the week lower; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares started the week lower, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% at 3,410.98. Gainers outnumbered losers 78 to 37, with oil and gas company S51 rising 4.3% and cultural tourism developer E27 gaining 8%. Banks were mixed, with D05 down 0.5% and U11 rising 0.1%. Globally, the Dow and S&P 500 closed in positive territory, while the Nasdaq fell. European shares also ended slightly higher, despite a 0.2% decline on the week due to concerns over the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

site_title: Aramco cleans up Bendera Bay
summary: Aramco, in partnership with the National Parks Board, collected 41kg of marine litter at Bendera Bay on St John's Island, aiming to protect Singapore's marine biodiversity. The initiative is part of Aramco's sustainability efforts, which align with the City in Nature vision and Singapore Green Plan 2030. The company has donated S$260,000 to NParks' Garden City Fund, supporting marine biodiversity conservation and educational programs.

site_title: Ukrainian civilian death toll reaches 1,119: UN
summary: The United Nations reported that 1,119 Ukrainian civilians have been killed and 1,790 wounded since Russia's attack on Ukraine began on February 24. The true casualty figures are expected to be higher due to delayed and unverified reports, particularly from areas like Mariupol and Volnovakha. The majority of civilian casualties were caused by explosive weapons, including shelling and missile strikes.

site_title: NFT collection failures begin to mount in flashback to ICO bust
summary: NFT collections are experiencing failures, with about 1 in 3 having "essentially expired" or trading below their minting cost, according to blockchain analytics firm Nansen. This trend mirrors the 2018 ICO bust, where thousands of digital tokens became worthless. Despite celebrity purchases, overall NFT sales have declined 40% over the past month, with trading volume on OpenSea down 67%. Industry participants attribute the decline to cooling demand rather than a bubble bursting, but some collections, like EL by Reza Milani, have seen virtually no trading activity.

site_title: Key ESG-related developments
summary: Singapore's Energy 2050 committee has deemed it "realistic" for the country's power sector to aim for net-zero emissions by 2050, despite transformational changes required to achieve this goal. The committee identified strategies for decarbonization, diversification, and advanced power grid management to position Singapore for the transition. Meanwhile, the IFRS Foundation and Global Reporting Initiative are collaborating to harmonize sustainability reporting standards, reducing the reporting burden for companies. The Singapore Exchange Regulation is also offering sustainability training for directors of listed companies to meet enhanced sustainability reporting rules.

site_title: Trading halts loom with HK firms set to delay earnings filings
summary: At least 73 Hong Kong-listed firms will delay their annual earnings filings past the March 31 deadline due to the Covid outbreak or auditor changes, raising concerns about a possible trading halt. This includes several distressed developers, such as China Evergrande Group and Kaisa Group Holdings. The situation has already weighed on affected stocks, with some firms experiencing significant declines. Analysts warn that delayed results may indicate financial stress, particularly for Chinese property firms struggling with the Covid outbreak and auditor resignations.

site_title: New world order? War and pandemic rattle globalisation
summary: Globalisation is being tested by the ongoing pandemic and war, particularly the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which has raised concerns about supply chain disruptions and food shortages. Companies are struggling to cope with bottlenecks, and some experts, like Larry Fink, argue that the globalisation model has come to an end. However, US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen disagrees, stating that the global economy will remain deeply involved. The conflict has prompted a shift towards "friend-shoring" and strategic autonomy, with the European Union and US seeking to reduce reliance on Russia and China.

site_title: Temasek said to push for removal of Bayer CEO Baumann
summary: Temasek Holdings Pte, a major shareholder of Bayer AG, is pushing for the removal of CEO Werner Baumann amid concerns over the company's operating performance and lack of succession planning. The Singapore state investor has communicated its displeasure to the company and supervisory board chairman, considering options such as a no-confidence vote or voting against the management team's performance. This move comes as Bayer reverses a years-long stock slump, with shares up 29% this year. Temasek's actions may raise pressure on the supervisory board to reshuffle leadership, potentially leading to Baumann's ouster.

site_title: Biotech Valneva eyes growth inflection with Covid vaccine
summary: French biotech Valneva is poised for growth with its Covid-19 vaccine, VLA2001, after the European Medicines Agency is expected to recommend its approval in April. The vaccine has shown potential superiority to the Oxford-AstraZeneca jab in Phase 3 results and has neutralized the Omicron variant. Valneva's CEO Thomas Lingelbach is confident of European approval, despite the company's share price fluctuations. The company expects to deliver up to 60 million doses to European countries in Q2 if approved, with annual vaccination requirements expected in the post-pandemic phase.

site_title: Crude palm oil rally taking a breather
summary: Crude palm oil prices experienced significant volatility in March 2022 due to geopolitical uncertainty, particularly the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The conflict disrupted global edible oil markets, with Russia and Ukraine being the top two sunflower oil producers. As a result, traders scrambled for alternative supplies, driving palm oil prices up. The market has since entered a consolidation phase, with prices showing signs of stabilization.

site_title: Ukraine says Russia wants to split nation, calls for more arms from West
summary: Russia aims to split Ukraine into two, similar to North and South Korea, according to Ukraine's military intelligence chief. President Volodymyr Zelensky urged the West to provide tanks, planes, and missiles to counter Russian forces. Despite failing to seize major Ukrainian cities, Russia scaled back ambitions to focus on the Donbass region. Ukraine's army is preparing for "total guerrilla warfare" to prevent a split, while a local leader in the self-proclaimed Luhansk People's Republic announced plans for a potential referendum on joining Russia.

site_title: Retail, hotel, office S-Reits gain with relaxed Covid rules
summary: Singapore announced the easing of Covid-19 measures on March 24, 2022, allowing up to 75% of office workers to return to workplaces, doubling the group size for social gatherings, and easing cross-border travel restrictions. This led to a 1.1% gain in the Straits Times Index and a 1% increase in the iEdge S-Reit Index, with hospitality and retail S-Reits gaining 3.5% and 1.5% respectively. Diversified S-Reits also gained an average of 1.8%, with top performers including Lendlease Global Commercial Reit and CDL Hospitality Trusts.

site_title: Shanghai overtakes Jilin to be China's biggest Covid hotspot
summary: Shanghai has become China's biggest coronavirus hotspot after reporting 2,676 new Covid-19 infections, a 18% increase from the previous day. This surpasses Jilin province, which reported 2,078 cases. Shanghai's cases have been hitting records over the past week, with most being asymptomatic. To avoid economic damage, officials are determined to avoid a full lockdown.

site_title: 4,848 Covid-19 cases in Singapore on Sunday, lowest since Feb 3
summary: Singapore reported 4,848 Covid-19 cases on Sunday, the lowest since February 3. Hospitalizations decreased to 694, with 4 deaths reported. The Covid-19 week-on-week infection ratio remained below 1 for the 26th consecutive day at 0.75. Of the local cases, 4,221 were detected through antigen rapid tests, and 526 through polymerase chain reaction tests. The total number of deaths in Singapore stands at 1,250, and the total number of cases is 1,072,005.

site_title: Bitcoin rises 4.4% to US$46,499
summary: Bitcoin surged 4.41% to $46,499.29, adding $1,963.64 to its previous close, marking a 41.1% gain from its year-low on January 24. The cryptocurrency is now up 1.4% for the year, surpassing the US$45,000 level for the first time since early January. Analysts predict further upside momentum, with some predicting a 20% run higher, driven by reduced stimulus measures and growing demand.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin surged 4.41 per cent to US$46,499.29 at 22:07 GMT on Sunday, adding US$1,963.64 to its previous close.

site_title: Chelsea FC bidders to submit final bids on Apr 11
summary: Contenders for the takeover of Chelsea Football Club are set to submit their final bids on April 11, according to Sky News. The bidders, who have pledged £1 billion in future investment, must also provide contractual guarantees for additional funding to support stadium development. The move comes after Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich put the club up for sale due to sanctions linked to the war in Ukraine. The Raine Group, a New York-based merchant bank, is handling the sale and has notified the 4 bidders of the deadline.

site_title: Shaken by spiking commodities, trading houses adapt to survive
summary: Trading houses are adapting to survive amid a commodity crisis fueled by the war in Ukraine. Companies such as Glencore, Trafigura, and Gunvor are seeking extra cash and new investors to keep their businesses going. Smaller traders risk not surviving, with liquidity sapping volatility and threatening to make markets more volatile. Trading houses are reducing activity, and some are considering raising equity from outside investors to address huge cash requirements. The crisis has led to a 30% jump in commodities prices, forcing companies to cover increased trading costs and ship cargoes, with some seeking backup funding and revolving credit facilities.

images.alt_text: Trafigura has held talks with private equity groups for additional financing, people familiar with the matter say.

site_title: US homebuyers hit with mortgage rates surging most since 1994
summary: US homebuyers face a surge in mortgage rates, the largest three-month increase since 1994, with the average 30-year loan rising to 4.42%, the highest since January 2019. This is forcing borrowers to recalibrate their budgets and pause their home searches. Americans are losing purchasing power as borrowing costs rise, inflation erodes savings, and home prices outpace income growth. Experts warn that this may lead to a surge in renters, with only a few select individuals owning property, as the competition for affordable homes intensifies.

images.alt_text: New homes under construction in California. The problem is compounded for people shopping in the tightest markets who are struggling to find anything they can afford. A panel of housing experts surveyed by Zillow said they expect listings nationwide to rebound to pre-pandemic norms, but not until 2024.

site_title: China's Sinopec plans its biggest capital expenditure in history
summary: China Petroleum & Chemical Corp (Sinopec) plans its largest capital investment in history, with a 198 billion yuan (S$42.2 billion) budget for 2022, an 18% increase from last year. The company aims to boost production, particularly in crude oil and natural gas fields, amid recovering energy demand and volatile oil prices. Sinopec also warned of potential impacts from geopolitical challenges and sanctions, particularly in Russia, where it had suspended talks on major investments.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for March 25, 2022, reveals volatile market trends in the tanker and dry bulk sectors. Capesize vessels faced a $5,956 decline in value, while Atlantic owners experienced a 40% drop in basin value. The Pacific basin saw increased timecharter rates, but the transpacific C10 lost 20% of its value. Panamax vessels benefited from increased demand, with rates climbing dramatically in the Atlantic. The Ultramax/Supramax sector saw a strong week, but some areas showed signs of slowing down. Handysize vessels gained ground in East Coast South America, while the US Gulf region strengthened. The VLCC market saw rates fall, while the Suezmax sector declined due to limited activity. The Aframax market experienced a 2.5-point drop in the 80,000mt Ceyhan/Mediterranean market.

site_title: Telegram joins programme from Brazil's Electoral Court to fight fake news
summary: Telegram has partnered with Brazil's Electoral Court to combat misinformation ahead of the country's presidential election in October. This is the app's first major partnership with the court, following its suspension last week for non-compliance. The partnership aims to fight fake content related to the electoral process and actors involved. Telegram has committed to fighting "fake news" and will deliver a proposal to its executives.

site_title: Foreign worker levy rebate for construction, marine shipyard sectors extended till June
summary: Singapore has extended the Foreign Worker Levy rebate for construction, marine shipyard, and process sectors until June 2022, providing companies with S$250 per month in April and May, and S$200 in June. The rebate was initially set to expire in March 2022 due to manpower shortages and elevated business costs caused by the pandemic. The extension aims to support companies in these sectors and monitor the situation to decide on further extensions.

site_title: Kaspersky first Russian company on US security risk list
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) added Russian cybersecurity company AO Kaspersky Lab to its list of companies deemed a threat to national security, marking the first time a Russian entity is on the list. Kaspersky, known for its anti-virus software, was added following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, citing concerns about national security threats. The FCC's action restricts federal subsidies for Kaspersky equipment and services, following a 2017 US ban on Kaspersky software in federal information systems.

site_title: CGS-CIMB embraces disruption to chart its course
summary: CGS-CIMB Securities, a prominent brokerage firm in Singapore, has undergone a strategic push to broaden its offerings and tap into a wider pool of clients, generating stickier recurring revenue. The company, with an established position, has focused on expanding its services to stay competitive. By doing so, CGS-CIMB aims to increase its client base and revenue streams, positioning itself for long-term success in the market.

site_title: Climate crisis more acute than feared: How will this impact businesses?
summary: The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) warns that the climate crisis is more acute than feared, with unavoidable multiple climate hazards over the next two decades even if global warming is kept to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. Urgent and bolder action is needed from governments, businesses, and individuals to address climate risks. Scaling up investment in adaptation efforts is crucial to build climate resilience, with the IPCC estimating that adaptation costs will rise to $140-500 billion annually by 2030-2050. The IPCC's report emphasizes the importance of immediate and ambitious action, with businesses needing to "walk the talk" in addressing climate change and governments taking the lead in implementing policies and funding adaptation strategies.

site_title: China finds second black box of crashed plane
summary: China's recovery crews found the second black box, a flight data recorder, from the wreckage of a crashed China Eastern Airlines Boeing 737-800 jet on March 27. The plane, carrying 132 people, crashed into a mountainside in southern China on March 21. Initially, there was little hope of finding survivors, and officials confirmed all on board, including 9 crew members, were deceased. The discovery of the second black box increases the chances of determining the cause of the crash.

site_title: Shanghai won't lock down despite Covid spike: official
summary: Shanghai reported a sharp rise in Covid-19 cases, with 2,269 new local transmissions, but officials aim to avoid a full lockdown due to its economic impact. The city has implemented targeted 48-hour lockdowns and large-scale testing to contain the outbreak. China's National Health Commission has also begun distributing rapid-antigen kits to residents, expanding its pandemic response. The government is balancing anti-virus measures with maintaining "normal life" amid growing concerns over economic impact and public fatigue.

site_title: Chinese minister seeks normal India ties, Delhi says ease border tension first
summary: India and China's foreign ministers met in New Delhi, where China expressed a desire for normal relations, but India said normal ties couldn't be achieved until troops were pulled back from the disputed border. China's Wang Yi said the two nations should work together for global peace and stability, while India's Subrahmanyam Jaishankar emphasized the need for a resolution to border tensions. Both countries agreed to speed up resolving remaining issues and avoiding misunderstandings.

site_title: Japan's regional lenders face glitches at ATMs
summary: Japanese regional lenders, including Hyakujushi Bank, Joyo Bank, and Yamaguchi Bank, experienced system glitches at their ATMs and internet banking services on Saturday, suspending operations. Lawson Bank, operated by convenience store chain Lawson, also reported system failures. This is the latest in a series of technical issues for Mizuho Financial Group's main banking unit, Mizuho Bank, which has faced major system failures in the past, prompting a new CEO. The cause of the glitches is not specified.

site_title: Chinese stock rally in US stalls on growth, delisting concerns
summary: US-listed Chinese stocks fell on Friday, extending losses from a recent rally, due to concerns over the tech sector's earnings and the risk of local firms being delisted from US exchanges. The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index dropped 4.7% and Alibaba Group Holding slid 1.9%. Earnings from Meituan and Nio also raised concerns, with Meituan's sales growth slowing and Nio reporting worse-than-expected results. Heightened concerns over China's relationship with Russia and the risk of delistings have weighed on the market, with investors seeking clarity on the future of Chinese stocks on US exchanges.

site_title: Healthcare stocks looking cheaper, but fund managers flag need for technical expertise
summary: Healthcare stocks have been underperforming this year due to geopolitical tensions and inflationary pressures, but fund managers see the sector as undervalued. The MSCI World Health Care Index has fallen 4.9% this year, but many experts believe it's a good time to invest in long-term growth potential. Companies like Moderna, BioNTech, and Pfizer have driven huge inflows into the biotech segment, and the industry has historically rebounded after significant corrections. Fund managers require deep expertise to identify winners, and most rely on specialized teams to guide their investment theses.

site_title: Hong Kong halves Covid-rule ban time for airlines
summary: Hong Kong has reduced the airline ban time for carrying excessive Covid-positive passengers from 2 weeks to 7 days. The revised rules, effective April 1, keep most existing triggers, including bans for 3 or more Covid cases on the same flight or 1 confirmed infection and another non-compliant one. The city's flagship carrier Cathay Pacific Airways will schedule only one flight per route every 14 days for 9 countries whose flight bans were lifted.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong has cut the time airlines are banned for carrying excessive numbers of Covid-positive passengers to 7 days from 2 weeks.

site_title: Bumper dividends from pandemic winners in FY21
summary: Singapore's largest listed companies paid out at least as much in dividends per share for FY2021 as they did in FY19, with some companies paying the largest dividends in their listed history. Analysts expect dividends for FY22 to be even stronger, driven by a solid financial performance and easing of Covid-19 restrictions. The aggregate level of dividends for FY21 was US$13.6 billion, up 17% from FY20, and expected to surpass FY19's US$14.9 billion. Banks, Reits, and logistics sectors are expected to benefit from the economic recovery and rising interest rate environment.

site_title: Thousands flee after Philippine volcano erupts
summary: Thousands of people fled their homes near the Philippine volcano Taal after an eruption on Saturday, sending ash and steam hundreds of meters into the sky. The Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology raised the alert level to three, warning of further eruptions that could trigger dangerous flows and a tsunami. Over 12,000 people live in the affected area, and police have been deployed to stop people from entering high-risk zones. The eruption occurred after a "short-lived" burst, followed by nearly continuous phreatomagmatic activity, and ash emissions have since quietened.

site_title: Western sanctions won't sway Kremlin: Russia's former president Medvedev
summary: Russian ex-president Dmitry Medvedev stated that Western sanctions against Russian businesses are "foolish" and will not sway the Kremlin, instead consolidating Russian society. Medvedev downplayed the economic impact of sanctions, saying the Russian government will find its own solutions to develop key industries. He also criticized those who speak out against the Kremlin's actions, labeling them as "treason." Medvedev's comments come as the West has imposed sanctions on Russian businesses and individuals, particularly those close to President Vladimir Putin, amid Russia's ongoing invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Retail, hotel, office S-Reits gain with relaxed Covid rules
summary: Singapore announced the easing of Covid-19 measures on March 24, allowing for relaxed rules, including optional mask-wearing outdoors and doubling the maximum group size for social gatherings. This move is expected to boost businesses, particularly the tourism sector, and help Singapore reclaim its position as a business and aviation hub. As a result, S-Reits recorded gains, with hospitality S-Reits leading the way, and the Straits Times Index rose 1.1% during the trading session.

site_title: 3.8 million people flee Ukraine: UN
summary: More than 3.8 million people, mostly women and children, have fled Ukraine since Russia's invasion a month ago, according to UN figures. The UN refugee agency reported a 48,450 increase from the previous day's numbers. The flow of refugees has slowed down significantly, marking a shift in the crisis.

site_title: Elon Musk giving 'serious thought' to build a new social media platform
summary: Elon Musk is considering building a new social media platform with an open-source algorithm and prioritizing free speech, following a Twitter poll where 70% of users voted "no" on whether Twitter adheres to free speech principles. Musk has been critical of Twitter's policies and believes the company is undermining democracy. If he proceeds, he would join a growing list of tech companies positioning themselves as champions of free speech, including Truth Social, Gettr, and Parler, but none have matched the reach and popularity of mainstream platforms like Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube.

images.alt_text: Tesla CEO Elon Musk is giving "serious thought" to building a new social media platform.

site_title: US judge approves SEC payout from Elon Musk, Tesla settlements
summary: A US federal judge authorized the Securities and Exchange Commission to distribute $40 million from its 2018 settlements with Tesla and CEO Elon Musk, following Musk's claim that the SEC had delayed making the payout for nearly 3.5 years. The distribution plan was proposed by the SEC on March 9 and was approved by Judge Alison Nathan in Manhattan. The SEC had agreed to the settlements with Tesla in 2018 over Musk's tweets about the company's stock price.

site_title: Fitch withdraws Russia's ratings to comply with EU sanctions
summary: Fitch has withdrawn Russia's ratings to comply with EU sanctions, downgrading the country's rating to "junk" territory earlier this month. The move follows aggressive sanctions against Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, crippling the country's economy and prompting the Russian rouble's free fall. Investors and experts are concerned Russia could be plunged into a debt default due to the unprecedented sanctions. Fitch plans to withdraw ratings on all Russian entities and their subsidiaries by April 15.

site_title: Oil rises to over US$120/barrel after attack on Saudi facilities
summary: Oil prices surged to over $120 a barrel after a missile attack on an oil distribution facility in Saudi Arabia, with Brent crude up 1.4% and US WTI crude up 1.4%. The attack, attributed to Yemen's Houthi movement, has raised concerns about supply disruptions. The US is considering a larger oil release from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve to mitigate the impact, amid already-low global stockpiles.

site_title: Biden compares Russian invasion to Tiananmen Square
summary: US President Joe Biden compared Russia's invasion of Ukraine to China's suppression of protests in Tiananmen Square in 1989, labeling Russian President Vladimir Putin as "a war criminal." Biden praised Ukrainians for their resistance and said he would defend "every inch" of NATO territory. He also stated that the situation is "Tiananmen Square squared," emphasizing the severity of the conflict. Biden visited Poland near the border with Ukraine, meeting with US soldiers and aid workers, and will deliver a major speech on Saturday.

site_title: 'We have nothing but grief', says father of China Eastern crash victim
summary: A grieving father described his emotional state after learning of the death of his daughter, Shujun, who was a passenger on the China Eastern Airlines flight MU5735 that crashed in Guangxi region. Qin Haitao, a migrant worker from Hunan province, said he and his family received no official confirmation before finding out the truth, and has since visited the crash site where he burned incense and prayed, asking for his daughter's body to be found and brought home. Qin expressed his only request is for his daughter's body to be recovered as soon as possible.

site_title: First Sponsor and Ho Bee Land chairmen build stakes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 2.3% in the 5 trading sessions from Mar 18 to 24, driven by institutional net buying of S$20 million. Net institutional outflows were reported by UOB, OCBC, and Geo Energy Resources. Share buybacks totaled S$15.7 million, with OCBC, Keppel Corporation, and Raffles Medical Group leading the way. Notable director and substantial shareholder transactions included First Sponsor Group chairman Calvin Ho Han Leong increasing his stake in the company, Ho Bee Land executive chairman Chua Thian Poh acquiring more shares, and Oxley Holdings deputy CEO Eric Low See Ching acquiring shares in Hafary Holdings.

site_title: US FCC adds Russia's Kaspersky, China telecom firms to national security threat list
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) added Russia's Kaspersky Lab, China Telecom (Americas) Corp, and China Mobile International USA to its list of communications equipment and service providers deemed threats to US national security. The designations, mandated under a 2019 law, aim to secure US networks from espionage and harm. Kaspersky has denied being a tool of the Russian government, while China's companies have criticized the FCC's actions. The move restricts the use of funds from the FCC's $8 billion Universal Service Fund for these companies.

site_title: Saudi Arabian F1 Grand Prix continues 'as planned' despite rebel attack on oil facility
summary: Saudi Arabia's Formula One Grand Prix will continue as planned despite a rebel attack on an oil facility near the Jeddah circuit, which caused a huge fire. The attack occurred during the opening practice session, but drivers and team bosses were assured of safety. The F1 boss, Stefano Domenicali, confirmed that the weekend will proceed as scheduled, prioritizing safety. The incident is part of a wave of attacks ahead of the seventh anniversary of a Saudi-led coalition's military intervention in Yemen.

site_title: Macron dismisses Putin demand for gas payments in roubles
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron dismissed Russian President Vladimir Putin's demand for gas payments in roubles, calling it a mechanism to circumvent EU sanctions. Macron stated that European players must pay for gas in euros, as per signed contracts, and that the move is "not in line" with agreements. Russia is struggling to prop up its economy due to debilitating sanctions over its war on Ukraine. Germany has also denounced the move, and the EU is scrambling to reduce its reliance on Russian gas.

site_title: War has shattered illusions of the West
summary: The article argues that the West's post-1945 order, based on the United Nations and NATO, has been shattered by Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine. Three illusions have been shattered: the democratic power of the UN, the European illusion of universal peace, and the US's sole superpower status. The collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the Ottoman Empire created an illusion of a globalized, liberal world order, but the US's response to 9/11 and the ongoing conflicts in the Middle East have revealed unfinished business. The article concludes that the world is heading towards a new era of division, stagflation, and uncertainty, with the US dollar's monopoly status on global reserve currency set to be challenged by China.

site_title: Diana musical and 'Space Jam' snag the most Razzie awards
summary: Diana: The Musical and Space Jam: A New Legacy won the most Razzie awards, with Diana taking home five prizes, including worst picture, worst actress, and worst director. Space Jam won three Razzies for worst actor, worst rip-off or sequel, and worst screen couple. Jared Leto received the worst supporting actor award for his performance in House of Gucci, while Bruce Willis received the "Worst Performance by Bruce Willis in a 2021 Movie" award. Will Smith received a redeemer award for his role in King Richard.

images.alt_text: The Razzies gave Bruce Willis his own special category, nominating him eight times for "Worst Performance by Bruce Willis in a 2021 Movie", in eight forgettable films.

site_title: Russia using 'old methods of warfare': Ukraine intel chief
summary: Russia's military in Ukraine is using informers and "old methods of warfare" against Ukrainian forces, according to Ukraine's defense intelligence agency head Brigadier General Kyrylo Budanov. Despite Ukrainian forces holding out for a month, the situation remains "very difficult" with large Russian forces encircling cities. Budanov credited Ukrainian success to "miscalculations" by the Russians, citing effective use of informers within the Russian army and Chechen forces. He warned that Russian forces would face insurgents in Ukrainian forests, potentially escalating the conflict.

site_title: Huge fire near Saudi F1 track as Yemen rebels attack oil facilities
summary: A Yemeni rebel attack on a Saudi oil plant near Jeddah's Formula One circuit sparked a huge fire, part of a wave of assaults on Aramco facilities. The attack, one of 16 by Iran-backed rebels, delayed the second practice session for the F1 Grand Prix. The Saudi-led coalition condemned the attack, saying it had no impact on life in Jeddah, while the US State Department called it "unacceptable." The attacks pose a "direct threat" to global oil supplies, prompting Saudi Arabia to warn of potential shortages.

site_title: Jordan king hosts UAE, Egypt, Iraq leaders
summary: Jordan's King Abdullah II hosted leaders from Egypt, Iraq, and the UAE for "consultative" talks in Aqaba, focusing on recent international and regional developments. The meeting came ahead of US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's trip to Israel, the West Bank, and other countries to discuss the Ukraine war and Iran. The gathering marked the latest effort by Arab states to strengthen ties with Israel, following a historic summit in Egypt and a planned US-Arab summit. Analysts see the talks as a demonstration of the region's efforts to balance ties with Washington and Moscow.

images.alt_text: Jordan's King Abdullah II hosted leaders from Egypt, Iraq and the United Arab Emirates on Friday for "consultative" talks, state media said.

site_title: UK to fund £2m of food supplies for encircled Ukrainian cities
summary: The UK has pledged £2 million in food supplies for encircled Ukrainian cities, responding to a direct request from the Ukrainian government. The aid, including dried food, tinned goods, and water, will be transported to the most at-risk areas by road and rail from Poland and Slovakia. The supplies will help alleviate the crisis in cities like Mariupol, where tens of thousands of people are trapped without access to food, power, or heating, according to the British Foreign Office's Humanitarian Adviser.

site_title: British maritime agency detains P&O ferry, says crew not trained
summary: The British Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA) has detained a P&O ferry, the European Causeway, in Northern Ireland due to crew training and vessel documentation issues. The ferry, which operates between Scotland and Northern Ireland, will remain under detention until the company resolves the problems. This comes amid scrutiny over P&O's sacking of 800 seafarers without consulting unions, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson vowing to take legal action. P&O's CEO has admitted to breaking the law and will compensate the affected workers.

site_title: Six things to watch for at the Oscars
summary: The Oscars ceremony is set to address the ongoing war in Ukraine, with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky potentially speaking via video. The show will also introduce two new prizes chosen by popular vote, including a "fan favourite" film and an "Oscars cheer moment" from any movie in history. The ceremony will honor timeless classics like "The Godfather" and the 60th anniversary of the James Bond franchise. Jane Campion is expected to become the third female best director in Oscars history, while Ariana DeBose is widely expected to win for best supporting actress. The show will also feature performances, including Billie Eilish's theme song for the latest Bond flick and a live performance of the viral sensation "We Don't Talk About Bruno."

site_title: Kiwi homeowners grapple with rising mortgage rates
summary: New Zealand homeowners face rising mortgage rates, with economists predicting a 2-year fixed mortgage rate of up to 5.5% by the end of the year, more than doubling from last year's lows. This increase will further reduce spending power and exacerbate the downward pressure on the cooling housing market, which is already being squeezed by record-high living costs. Economists warn that this could lead to a slowdown in the economy and a decline in house prices, with some predicting a 10% drop this year.

site_title: Critics raise privacy fears over EU message app rule
summary: The European Union has agreed on a law to curb market dominance of US tech firms, including Meta, Google, Amazon, and Apple, by requiring them to drop barriers between their messaging services. Critics warn this could compromise user privacy, citing concerns over encryption and interoperability. The Digital Markets Act demands communications remain encrypted, but critics argue it's impossible to achieve end-to-end encryption across multiple platforms. The law, set to be published in October, could impose fines of up to 20% of a company's annual global sales for non-compliance.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 eke out positive finish to uncertain week
summary: US stocks closed in positive territory on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.4% and the S&P 500 gaining 0.5%, despite uncertainty amid high inflation and the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The Nasdaq fell 0.2% as investors grappled with the gap between long- and short-term US Treasury bonds. Markets await the release of earnings and the impact of the Ukraine conflict on the economy, with interest rate increases from the Federal Reserve expected to continue.

site_title: Singapore must stay competitive in 'dangerous world': PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need to protect the country's competitive advantages in attracting investments amid worsening external economic conditions. The announcement of a S$1.5 billion investment by Dyson in the Republic highlights the opportunity for Singapore to remain competitive. The ongoing war in Ukraine and intensifying competition for investments pose significant challenges to the global economy.

site_title: North Korea has 'likely more in store' after missile test: US
summary: North Korea successfully test-fired its largest-ever intercontinental ballistic missile, dubbed the Hwasong-17, with a range of 6,200 km, surpassing its previous record set in 2017. The US calls for tougher international sanctions at the UN Security Council, citing the missile's "increasingly dangerous provocations." The test is seen as part of a pattern of testing and provocation from North Korea, with the US National Security Advisor stating that "there is likely more in store" from the country.

images.alt_text: North Korea likely has "more in store" after successfully test-firing its largest-ever intercontinental ballistic missile, a top US official said on Friday, as Washington called for tougher international sanctions at the UN Security Council.

site_title: PM Lee to visit Washington DC in first US visit under Biden administration
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will visit Washington DC from March 26 to April 2, marking his first US visit under the Biden administration and his first to Washington DC. During the trip, Lee will meet with President Joe Biden, Vice-President Kamala Harris, and other US officials to discuss ways to advance cooperation between the two countries. Foreign Affairs Minister Vivian Balakrishnan and other officials will accompany Lee on the trip.

site_title: GoTo's offering is pricier than peers Bukalapak, Bank Neo Commerce: UOBKH
summary: Indonesia's largest tech firm GoTo's offering price is valued significantly higher than its peers, with a valuation of 9.8 times FY2023 price-to-sales estimates, according to UOB Kay Hian. This makes GoTo's offering pricier than peers Bukalapak and Bank Neo Commerce.

site_title: Air crash disaster risks an even wider rift for Boeing and China
summary: A US-made Boeing plane operated by China Eastern Airlines crashed in southern China, killing all 132 people on board. The investigation into the March 21 crash has complicated relations between the US and China, with both sides risking damage if the probe becomes politicized. The US National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is participating in the probe, despite China's Covid-19 restrictions, and Boeing has offered full support to the investigation. China is seeking to maintain international stature and demonstrate its commitment to aviation safety, but its desire for self-sufficiency and influence may undermine the probe.

site_title: Rebound in factory output in February could moderate this month, say economists
summary: Singapore's factory output rebounded 17.6% year-on-year in February, exceeding economists' projections of 6.3% growth. The surge was driven by electronics production, particularly semiconductors, which rose 32.4% and pharmaceuticals output, which increased 46.7%. However, production in most other sectors eased. Economists believe growth may moderate in the coming months due to external uncertainty, geopolitical tensions, and supply chain disruptions. Despite this, some economists, such as Maybank's Barnabas Gan, remain optimistic about growth prospects, citing ongoing global economic momentum and a strong global trade backdrop.

site_title: Amazon union vote gets underway in New York
summary: Amazon workers in New York began voting on whether to establish the company's first US labor union, with a six-day election running from Friday to Wednesday. The Amazon Labor Union (ALU), led by former and current workers, qualified for the vote after obtaining signatures from 30% of the 5,000 workers at the JFK8 warehouse. The outcome is uncertain, with some workers expressing skepticism about the union's unproven track record and others calling for better pay, benefits, and working conditions. The vote count is expected to start on March 31.

site_title: Europe: Shares caught between soaring commodity sector and war worries
summary: European shares ended slightly higher on Friday but down on the week due to concerns over the Russia-Ukraine conflict and soaring commodity prices. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1% despite losses in banks and defensive stocks, with gains in energy and basic materials sectors offsetting declines. The US plans to supply liquefied natural gas to the EU to reduce reliance on Russian energy, while Germany has made progress in reducing its exposure to Russian imports.

site_title: How to use economic sanctions wisely
summary: The US and its allies have imposed unprecedented economic sanctions on Russia in response to its invasion of Ukraine, targeting its economy with trade and financial measures. However, the effectiveness of these sanctions is uncertain, with concerns about their ability to coerce Russia into changing its behavior. Historically, sanctions have had limited success, and their impact can be mitigated by targeted countries that evade sanctions or find alternative trade routes. The true extent of the damage to the Russian economy depends on the European Union's response, which could exacerbate the crisis and have far-reaching consequences for the global energy market.

site_title: DBS sees upside to DPU of hospitality S-Reits from 2022 as borders reopen
summary: DBS Group Research expects Singapore hospitality real estate investment trusts (Reits) to deliver a convincing recovery trajectory from 2022 as borders reopen. Reits have seen improvements in revenue per available room (RevPAR) and guided for a brighter outlook in 2022, leading to potential upside surprises to their distribution per unit (DPU). This positive outlook is driven by the reopening of borders in Singapore and Asia, which is expected to boost the sector's recovery.

site_title: Why foreign investors are feeling jittery about China
summary: Foreign investors are feeling jittery about China due to geopolitical concerns, including the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war and concerns over Taiwan. State meddling in the private sector and tech companies, as well as the potential for sanctions on Chinese firms, are also contributing to the outflows. China's weakening control over the Covid-19 pandemic and a struggling property market are exacerbating the issue. In response, China's government is taking steps to regain investors' confidence, including increasing lending and easing regulations. However, investors remain skeptical, and a quick turnaround is unlikely until structural changes are made.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng tech index, which tracks many Chinese big tech groups listed in Hong Kong, is down by 45% against a year ago.

site_title: Domestic, border reopenings could further push up consumer prices amid scramble for labour
summary: Singapore's domestic and border reopenings could further strain the labor market, exacerbating local cost conditions amid a tight labor market. Employers are struggling to fill vacancies, and upward pressure on wages could worsen consumer price inflation. Foreign workers are expected to return, but the limited foreign labor policy may not fully resolve the labor shortage. To mitigate the issue, some employers are exploring non-traditional sources, such as partnering organizations for people with special needs. Rising wages and inflation are expected to weigh on policy considerations at the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Multiple free trade agreements can support supply chain resilience: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations, S Iswaran, stated that a lattice of multiple free trade agreements (FTAs) can provide resilience in supply chains disrupted by geopolitical tensions and the Covid-19 pandemic. He emphasized the importance of a multiplicity of bonds, rather than relying on a single platform. This comes as global supply chains face challenges, with the US imposing higher tariffs on Asian garment imports and other economic news unfolding.

site_title: Yellen sees no weakness in US economy, even with global growth dented
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen expressed confidence in the US economy's resilience despite higher energy and commodity costs due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine affecting global growth. She noted a strong job market and consumer spending, citing the US as a net exporter, which may offset the impact of higher energy prices on spending. Yellen also stated that sanctions against China over its partnership with Russia are not necessary at this point, as she does not see China attempting to evade sanctions.

images.alt_text: "When you look at the balance sheet of the typical American family, it is in very good shape. Consumer spending is strong and tax revenues have frankly been surprising to the upside," said US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen.

site_title: Sound asleep - not quite
summary: Sleep disordered breathing encompasses a range of medical conditions, from simple snoring to severe obstructive sleep apnea, which can lead to heart failure, stroke, and death. Conditions like sleepwalking, insomnia, and sleep-related parasomnias also exist. Diagnosis typically involves a fibreoptic evaluation, sleep study, and examination of the upper airway. Treatment options include lifestyle changes, CPAP therapy, or surgery, with CPAP being the gold standard for moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea. In children, adenotonsillar hypertrophy is a common cause of sleep apnea, which can be managed with surgery, resulting in excellent outcomes.

site_title: The Fed takes the red pill
summary: The US Federal Reserve has acknowledged the severity of the inflation problem, raising rates by 25 basis points and indicating 7 rate hikes this year.
