The collaboration aims to accelerate the voluntary carbon market and support large-scale emissions reductions to keep global warming under 2 deg C by 2030.

site_title: Man of steel sets up Mah maison, to score a lifestyle Triumph
summary: Triumph, Britain's largest motorcycle brand, has set up a new showroom in Singapore with Didi Lifestyle Pte Ltd, a company backed by Malaysia's Goh Brothers Group. The dealership change marks a clean break from Mah Pte Ltd, the largest motorcycle retailer in Singapore, and goes to another Mah. The new 40,000 sq ft venue aims to create a lifestyle destination, not just a showroom, to attract families, cycling enthusiasts, and foodies, shifting the focus from sales to aftersales and experiences.

site_title: 2021 current account deficit biggest on record; initial jobless claims fall to lowest since 1969
summary: The US current account deficit narrowed in the fourth quarter to $217.9 billion, a 0.9% decrease from the previous quarter. For 2021, the deficit reached an all-time high of $821.6 billion, a 33.4% increase from the previous year. Meanwhile, initial jobless claims fell to 187,000, the lowest since 1969, as employers try to retain workers amid strong job openings and low labor-force participation.

site_title: Touareg: Return of a Volks legend
summary: The Volkswagen Touareg has returned to the Singapore market after a half-year absence due to supply issues. The 5-seat SUV now comes with new features, including an above-view parking camera, Park Assist Plus, and a radar setup that monitors pedestrians and obstacles. The Touareg's 340 horsepower engine and sporty styling elements make it a competitive option in the crowded large SUV market. The R-Line pack adds 4-wheel steering, air suspension, and ventilated massage chairs, but at a higher price point of S$399,900. Supply issues are now resolved, and demand will drive Touareg sales.

site_title: Buyout boom drives record European corporate real estate sales
summary: A record 29 billion euros worth of European corporate real estate was sold in 2021, driven by a surge in mergers and acquisitions. Private equity firms, accounting for nearly a quarter of global M&A deals, cashed in on property portfolios of acquired companies. This led to a boom in disposals as acquiring entities released capital tied up in property portfolios through direct sales or leasebacks. The high levels of disposals reflect frenetic M&A activity last year, with the majority of the sales taking place in the UK.

site_title: Trends shaping South-east Asia's startup ecosystem growth
summary: South-east Asia's startup ecosystem is expected to continue its growth trajectory, with funding doubling in 2021. The region's accelerated digitalisation has inspired entrepreneurs and industries to create new business models and disrupt traditional categories. As investors seek areas of growth, understanding the trends in South-east Asia is crucial, particularly in catering to the region's booming consumer market. The region's growth potential is brimming, with no clear indication that the upward trend will slow down, making it an attractive destination for investors.

site_title: S&P downgrades ST Engineering on higher debt levels following TransCore deal
summary: S&P Global Ratings downgraded ST Engineering's credit rating to "AA+" from "AAA" due to the company's elevated debt levels following its S$3.6 billion acquisition of TransCore Partners and TLP Holdings. The deal is expected to nearly triple ST Engineering's debt to S$5.3 billion in 2022, with analysts estimating a debt-to-Ebitda ratio of 4. The downgrade reflects concerns over the company's ability to manage its debt burden, with earnings growth expected to be gradual over several years.

site_title: Mask rules, group size cap, border curbs eased as Singapore reaches 'turning point'
summary: Singapore has eased COVID-19 restrictions, including mask mandates, social gathering limits, and quarantine requirements, marking a "major step towards living with Covid-19". From March 29, masks will be optional outdoors, and fully vaccinated individuals can dine out in groups of up to 10. International borders with Malaysia will reopen to all fully vaccinated travelers on April 1, with quarantine-free entry for air and sea travelers also allowed. The changes are seen as a pivot towards normalcy, but policymakers acknowledge the need for ongoing vigilance against new variants.

site_title: Is it time to say RIP to ESG?
summary: Key proponents of the environmental, social and governance (ESG) movement suggest it's time to move beyond ESG, integrating it into mainstream investment practices. However, a debate over standards and a misguided focus on transport threaten its progress. The Ukraine crisis may further hinder East-West cooperation on climate issues. Attendees at a dinner hosted by OMFIF at the House of Lords expressed concerns about the movement's contradictions and potential irreconcilable differences. The future of ESG remains uncertain as it faces challenges from conflicting priorities and external factors.

site_title: Biden seeks more military aid to Ukraine as West showcases unity against Russian war
summary: Western leaders showcased unity against Russia's war in Ukraine, with US President Joe Biden seeking more military aid to Ukraine. Nato Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg announced increased troop deployments to the eastern flank, while Britain imposed fresh sanctions against Moscow. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy called for more support, including tanks and anti-missile systems. Nato rejected Ukraine's request to defend its skies, and Russia denies targeting civilians. The G7 and EU are set to meet to discuss sanctions and energy cooperation, with the EU considering a joint gas purchase and the US providing additional liquefied natural gas supplies.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden (left) and French President Emmanuel Macron (middle) arriving for a roundtable meeting during an extraordinary Nato Summit at the Alliance's headquarters in Brussels, on Mar 24.

site_title: Greenback firms; yen holds near lowest since 2015
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the Japanese yen, reaching its lowest since 2015, amid the Russia-Ukraine conflict and expectations of central bank tightening. The dollar rose 0.4% against the yen, while the euro fell 0.2% against the US dollar. Western leaders agreed to strengthen military aid to Ukraine and Western leaders meeting in Brussels will also discuss increasing military aid to Ukraine.

site_title: Outbound travel to trump inbound travel in the short term with reopening
summary: Singapore's travel and tourism industry expects a boost with the reopening of the Vaccinated Travel Framework (VTF) on April 1, allowing fully vaccinated travelers to enter the country quarantine-free. Outbound travel may pick up faster than inbound travel, with top destinations including the US, UK, and Australia. Travel agencies report increased interest, with some expecting a 60-70% increase in inbound travel demand. However, inbound travel may not see significant growth immediately, with some experts attributing this to ongoing concerns about COVID-19 and inflation.

site_title: Race towards sustainability
summary: The Singapore Grand Prix is set to return this year with a focus on sustainability. The event aims to reduce carbon emissions by implementing greener and cleaner practices, such as electric or hybrid vehicles, and minimizing waste. This initiative aligns with broader efforts by Formula One and the Republic of Singapore to reduce their carbon footprint. The event will take place at the Marina Bay Street Circuit in October, marking a significant step towards a more environmentally friendly motorsport event.

site_title: Nearly 50% of foreign firms in Hong Kong plan to relocate staff
summary: Nearly half of European companies in Hong Kong plan to relocate staff or operations, with 25% planning to fully relocate and 24% partially relocating, according to a survey by the European Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong. The move is attributed to the city's Covid-19 travel and quarantine restrictions, eroding its appeal as a finance hub. This decline in business confidence is a result of over 2 years of increased isolation from the world.

site_title: Palm oil stocks book strong performance but face volatility, demand destruction ahead
summary: Palm oil stocks have seen strong performance in the recent quarter, with prices up 43% year-to-date. However, analysts warn that prices may correct soon due to increased supply and favorable weather conditions. Integrated players like Sime Darby Plantation and IOI Corporation have seen better earnings figures, while upstream plantation companies like First Resources and Bumitama Agri have performed relatively better. Analysts predict CPO prices will remain high, but demand and supply dynamics may not hold this year, with potential demand destruction and rising inventory levels expected to cause prices to ease.

site_title: Dubai's biggest IPO in 15 years seeks to raise US$2.2 billion
summary: Dubai Electricity & Water Authority (Dewa) is set to raise up to $2.2 billion in its initial public offering (IPO), the largest in 15 years, valuing the firm at $33.8 billion. The company plans to sell 3.25 billion shares between $2.25 and $2.48 apiece. The listing will make Dewa the largest company on Dubai's bourse, marking the first step in reinvigorating the emirate's capital markets.

site_title: Coinbase teams up with Alviere for lineup of crypto offerings
summary: Coinbase is partnering with fintech startup Alviere to offer a lineup of crypto products, including custody and exchange services. The partnership will initially roll out in the US and later expand to international markets. Alviere, which provides financial products to businesses, aims to allow its customers to buy and sell crypto, mirroring the services of challenger banks. The partnership is part of Coinbase's goal to make crypto a mainstream financial option. Alviere, backed by $70 million in funding, plans to expand its operations and acquire new customers.

site_title: Ford creates unit to develop autonomous vehicles, new technology
summary: Ford Motor Co. has created a new unit, Ford Next, to accelerate development of autonomous vehicles and foster new technology businesses. Led by Franck Louis-Victor, the unit will focus on mobility services and startups, including a joint venture with ADT. This move is part of CEO Jim Farley's effort to restructure the company into more agile and nimble pieces to compete with startups and tech giants.

site_title: Stagflation and why it occurs
summary: Singapore's economy may face recession or stagflation if the Russia-led war in Ukraine is prolonged, warned Finance Minister Lawrence Wong, despite limited links to Russia and Ukraine. Stagflation occurs when stagnation, high unemployment, and rising inflation co-occur, a combination previously thought impossible. The 1970s saw stagflation triggered by the 1973 oil crisis and post-war economic boom in the US. A prolonged war could lead to supply shocks, reducing global production capacity, and raise inflation, potentially affecting Singapore's economy, which is projected to grow 3-5% in 2022.

images.alt_text: The global economy faces the risk of recession or stagflation if the Russia-led war in Ukraine is prolonged, and Singapore could be adversely affected in these scenarios, despite its limited links to Russia and Ukraine, warned Finance Minister Lawrence Wong at an event on Tuesday (Mar 22).

site_title: Slower property auctions in March; sole sale is a freehold retail shop in Sim Lim Tower transacted at S$1.455m
summary: Knight Frank's March auction in Singapore saw only one property sold, a freehold retail shop at Sim Lim Tower for S$1.455 million. Two other units, including a 4-bedroom duplex penthouse at Marina Bay Residences, remained unsold despite being auctioned off at lower prices. Four properties were withdrawn, and auctions were postponed due to unanticipated situations. The slow pace in property auctions contrasts with the previous month's surge in interest.

site_title: SoftBank backs startup for interactive accounting tools
summary: SoftBank Vision Fund led a $65 million funding round for Digits Financial, a finance and accounting platform. The funding brings the startup's valuation to $565 million. Digits Reports provides interactive, auto-generated financial reports with features such as drag-and-drop charts and Excel-style formulas, saving accountants 4 hours per client on monthly reports. The company aims to develop a "living model" to understand and respond to business finance changes, applicable to SoftBank's other portfolio companies.

site_title: Malaysia's Time Dotcom weighs sale of data centres unit
summary: Malaysia's telecommunications provider Time Dotcom is considering selling its data centers business, Aims Data Centre, in a strategic review. The company may raise $500-600 million in a stake sale, with potential bidders including industry players and infrastructure funds. Time could retain a minority interest in the business. The move comes amid increasing investor appetite for digital infrastructure assets, following recent acquisitions of data centers by companies like DigitalBridge Group.

site_title: Biodiversity loss threatens economic stability: central banks report
summary: Central banks report that biodiversity loss poses a significant threat to economic stability, with the natural assets that financial institutions depend on being destroyed at a rapid pace. The report, compiled with input from dozens of central banks, highlights the impact of financial system choices on biodiversity and warns that dependent economic and financial systems are at risk when natural processes are damaged. A global deal to protect nature up to mid-century is being negotiated, with 200 nations set to sign off on a biodiversity framework that includes a proposal to protect 30% of the world's habitats.

site_title: CIX partners Carbonplace to lower entry barriers to voluntary carbon market
summary: CIX, a Temasek-backed carbon exchange, has partnered with Carbonplace, a platform developed by 7 major banks, to lower entry barriers to the voluntary carbon market. The partnership aims to simplify carbon credit transactions and provide a record of ownership, addressing existing issues of access, trust, and transparency. With Carbonplace's settlement system, corporations and financial institutions can buy and trade high-quality carbon credits, enabling large-scale emissions reductions. This collaboration is seen as a key accelerator for scaling up the voluntary carbon market, with CIX CEO Mikkel Larsen calling it "precisely the type of accelerator we need".

site_title: Europol seizes 5 million unsafe fake toys
summary: Europol seized over 5 million counterfeit toys worth more than 18 million euros, including hazardous items like puzzle games, dolls, and clothing from famous brands. The majority of the toys were imported from East Asia to the EU, UK, and US. The operation, Operation Ludus II, involved law enforcement authorities from 21 countries and resulted in the shutdown of 30 websites, the reporting of 99 individuals, and the seizure of hazardous toys. The counterfeit goods posed risks such as chemical exposure, strangulation, and electric shock, highlighting the need for stricter safety regulations.

images.alt_text: Europol seized more than 5 million potentially hazardous counterfeit toys worth more than 18 million euros (S$27 million) between October 2021 and January 2022, the European Union police agency said on Thursday (Mar 24).

site_title: Daily new Covid-19 cases in Singapore falls to 8,478
summary: Daily new Covid-19 cases in Singapore fell to 8,478, a decrease from 8,940 on Wednesday. Hospital cases dropped to 873, the second consecutive day below 1,000. Six deaths were reported, and the weekly infection growth rate remained below one for 23 consecutive days at 0.79. Of the local cases, 6,975 were mild, and 24 patients were in the intensive care unit. The total number of cases stands at 1,053,139, and 95% of the eligible population has completed their full vaccination regimen.

site_title: F&B operators cheer doubling of dining limits but fret over labour crunch
summary: Singapore is set to double its dining limits to 10 vaccinated individuals per table, with eateries allowed to seat groups of up to 5 without COVID-19 checks. However, F&B operators are concerned about a labour crunch, with many struggling to find staff due to quotas on work permits. The reopening of the Singapore-Malaysia land border on April 1 may help alleviate the issue, but nightlife operators, including bars and karaoke establishments, will have to wait longer to reopen. Despite these challenges, the industry is optimistic about the boost to consumer confidence and the potential for a recovery.

images.alt_text: With dining limits soon to be doubled to 10 vaccinated persons in Singapore, food and beverage (F&B) operators, although overjoyed, are finding themselves in another pickle: labour crunch.

site_title: Indonesia's GoTo IPO books covered, to raise at least US$1b: sources
summary: Indonesia's GoTo Group has received sufficient investor orders for its initial public offering (IPO), which could raise at least $1.1 billion within its targeted price band. Long-term investors such as Schroders and Eastspring Investments have supported the offering. GoTo, formed by the merger of Gojek and Tokopedia, launched its IPO process despite global equities market turbulence. The IPO has garnered interest from long-term investors, indicating a potential rebound in the company's shares following a $2.2 billion sell-off.

site_title: Indonesia's export levy among factors that will heavily influence CPO prices, producers in 2022
summary: Indonesia has increased its crude palm oil export levy to US$675 per tonne, from US$375 per tonne, in an effort to control domestic cooking oil prices. The move is expected to affect CPO prices, with analysts predicting lower producer earnings if prices rise above US$1,000 per tonne. The removal of Indonesia's domestic market obligation will also lead to increased global palm oil supply, potentially softening international CPO pricing.

site_title: Blockchain funds face ESG risks in data privacy, security, human capital: report
summary: A recent report by Morningstar Sustainalytics highlights material ESG (environmental, social, and governance) risks in the blockchain ETF market, particularly in the financial and tech sectors. The report notes that 22 of 46 financial sector companies have high unmanaged risk scores related to product governance and business ethics, and 41% have faced significant business ethics controversies. Companies in the tech sector face material data security risks, while those in the financial sector face risks related to product governance and business ethics. Despite these risks, the report suggests that investors in the blockchain market face slightly less overall ESG risk than those in the broader global equities market.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on tech boost, investors watch Nato summit
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Thursday, driven by a tech boost, as investors watched a NATO summit. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite opened higher, with gains of 0.14%, 0.31%, and 0.57% respectively. The moves come as the Ukraine crisis enters its second month, with investors closely tracking Western leaders' meeting.

site_title: Bank of England questions tighter bank capital rules after Ukraine invasion
summary: The Bank of England is reconsidering plans to raise banks' capital requirements due to economic uncertainty following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Despite major British lenders having strong capital and liquidity positions, the BOE may not proceed with the planned increase, citing volatile commodity markets and uncertainty over the economic outlook. The BOE will continue to monitor the situation and adjust its capital buffer rate accordingly. The decision will be reassessed once new economic forecasts are published in May.

site_title: Food Empire's auditors highlight impact of Russia-Ukraine crisis on company
summary: Food Empire's auditors have flagged the Russia-Ukraine crisis as a major concern, citing its impact on the company's revenue and financial performance. The conflict affects 45% of Food Empire's revenue, primarily from Russia and Ukraine, and is expected to have a negative effect on its financial position. Despite the food and beverage industry not being restricted, the auditors expect a decline in financial performance due to the war's uncertainty. The issue is highlighted as an "emphasis of matter" in the auditor's report.

site_title: Salary of UOB chief executive Wee Ee Cheong up 11.5% to S$10.9m in 2021
summary: UOB's CEO Wee Ee Cheong saw his annual salary increase by 11.5% to S$10.9 million in 2021, driven by strong profits amid an improved economic outlook. The bank posted a 40% on-year increase in net profit to S$4.1 billion, while its total income rose 7% on year to S$9.8 billion. Wee's pay includes a base salary, bonus, and benefits-in-kind, with 60% of his variable pay deferred over the next 3 years. The bank also announced plans to acquire Citi's consumer units in 4 Asean markets, doubling its retail base in the region.

site_title: US initial jobless claims decline to lowest since 1969
summary: US initial jobless claims fell to 187,000 in the week ended Mar 19, the lowest since 1969, as employers try to retain workers amid near-record job openings and low labor-force participation. Continuing claims for state benefits dropped to 1.35 million, also the lowest since 1970. This drop is consistent with a labor market where employers are desperate to hang onto workers, and applications are expected to remain low due to dwindling savings and high inflation. The jobs market is considered "tight to an unhealthy level" by Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell.

site_title: Russia stocks jump as trade resumes after month-long break
summary: Russia's stock market surged 11% on its first day of trading in a month, driven by gains in commodity stocks and sovereign wealth fund support. Energy firms like Novatek, Rosneft, and Lukoil rose 10-20%, while shares in mining giant Nornickel also gained 10%. However, shares in VTB, a bank subject to Western sanctions, fell 5%. The rouble strengthened 2% to hover near 96 against the US dollar, and trading of US dollar-denominated stocks remained suspended.

site_title: China Life profit misses estimates as economy drags on sales
summary: China Life Insurance, the nation's largest life insurer, reported annual profit of 50.9 billion yuan, missing estimates by 1.3%. The slowdown in China's economy and lower interest rates have eroded demand for life insurance, leading to a 9% drop in new policies and a 23% decline in new business value. Investment income rose 15% but net realised gains on financial assets slumped 77%. The company's shares fell 0.5% in Hong Kong, widening this year's loss to 5.1%. The economic slowdown also affects rival Ping An Insurance, which reported a 29% drop in net income last week.

site_title: Thai finance minister says fiscal, monetary policy to underpin recovery
summary: Thailand's finance minister, Arkhom Termpittayapaisith, stated that the country's fiscal and monetary policies will support its recovery, despite various challenges. The government's fiscal position remains stable, and liquidity in the banking system is ample. This year's growth will be driven by government spending and exports, expected to rise 5-10%. The government will monitor the Russia-Ukraine conflict and sanctions, which may impact inflation. Despite potential slight misses in forecasts, Thailand's economy is expected to grow at least 3% this year.

site_title: Indonesia inviting Putin to G-20 despite pressure to exclude him
summary: Indonesia plans to invite Russian President Vladimir Putin to the G-20 summit in Bali despite pressure to exclude him due to Russia's war in Ukraine. Foreign Ministry official Triansyah Djani stated that Indonesia will remain impartial and invite all members in accordance with established procedures. This decision has been met with criticism from Australia, which may boycott the summit if Putin attends, and concerns from US President Joe Biden about unspecified consequences if China supports Russia.

site_title: UK private sector reports record price hikes, confidence down
summary: Britain's private sector reported a record price hike, with the S&P Global/CIPS composite PMI for March at 59.7, down from 59.9 in February. Confidence in the sector is at its lowest in almost a year and a half, following a historically high reading in February. The manufacturing sector saw its lowest output in 5 months, while the services sector reached its highest in 9 months. The UK economy also contracted for the second month, dealing a fresh blow to Prime Minister Starmer's government.

site_title: Trade associations and chambers key in companies adapting to changing consumer trends
summary: Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling emphasized the importance of trade associations and chambers (TACs) supporting member companies as they adapt to changing consumer trends, particularly in the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic. The government aims to collaborate with TACs to identify opportunities for sectoral and industry standards, with initiatives including sustainability and decarbonisation blueprints. This collaboration will aid TACs in finding ways to raise industry standards and aid companies in transforming and adapting to the changing external environment.

site_title: US core capital goods orders fall in February
summary: US core capital goods orders fell 0.3% in February, surprising economists who predicted a 0.5% increase. Shipments of core capital goods rose 0.5% after a 2.1% gain in January. Demand for goods remains strong, but manufacturing faces supply bottlenecks. Orders for durable goods, including transportation equipment and motor vehicles, also declined, with transportation equipment orders dropping 5.6% and motor vehicle orders falling 0.5%. The sector's growth is expected to continue despite supply chain improvements, but may be impacted by Russia's war in Ukraine.

site_title: Roberta's Pizza doesn't rise to expectations
summary: Roberta's Pizza, a Brooklyn-based restaurant, has opened at Marina Bay Sands in Singapore, offering a unique dining experience with its manufactured Americana and bright pop art decor. Despite a bare-bones self-service setup and high pricing, the restaurant's pizza dough is a standout, with a 15-year-old starter that adds a mellow tanginess. However, the pizzas are thin and overpriced, with limited toppings, making it a mixed experience. The house bread and straciatella cheese are a highlight, but overall, the restaurant falls short of expectations. Rating: 6/10.

Roberta's Bee Sting pizza
Roberta's house bread with straciatella cheese and smashed cucumbers
Maui Wowee pizza with pineapple and speck

site_title: Malaysia's major telcos mull equity stakes in state 5G agency
summary: Malaysia's four major telecommunications firms, Axiata Group's Celcom, DiGi, Maxis, and U-Mobile, are exploring a government offer of up to 70% equity stake in state 5G agency Digital Nasional Berhad (DNB). The firms had initially raised concerns over pricing and transparency. The telcos have requested details on the offer and asked the government to refrain from major deals or hires during negotiations. They will finalize the shareholding structure before signing an agreement. The move aims to give telcos more say in the 5G rollout process.

site_title: Rhino bond is offered by World Bank in first issuance of its kind
summary: The World Bank has issued the world's first wildlife bond, raising $150 million to conserve black rhinos in South Africa. The 5-year bond pays returns based on the growth of rhino populations in two reserves, with the goal of increasing numbers. If successful, the program could be expanded to protect other wildlife species. The bond was sold at 94.8% of its nominal value, with a maximum success payment of $13.8 million, and will be used to fund conservation efforts.

images.alt_text: The World Bank says it has priced the world's first wildlife bond, raising US$150 million that will be partly used for the conservation of black rhinos in South Africa.

site_title: UBS, China Life asset management venture plan in limbo as talks stall: sources
summary: UBS and China Life Insurance Group's joint venture to set up an asset management company in China is in limbo due to a corruption investigation and curbs on the scope of the business. Talks stalled after the then chairman of China Life was put under investigation and the scope of the business was overestimated. UBS had hoped to hold a majority stake in the venture, but progress is behind expectations. The development highlights challenges for Western financial firms expanding in China's 100 trillion yuan asset management sector.

site_title: Swiss National Bank sticks to loose policy despite inflation pickup
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) has doubled its inflation forecast for 2022 to 2.1% despite rising prices, citing tensions from the Ukrainian war. However, the bank stuck to its expansive monetary policy, keeping interest rates at -0.75% and its commitment to currency interventions. Analysts see this as a sign of a shift in tone, with some predicting a rate hike in June 2023. The SNB also downgraded its economic forecasts, but remains relatively relaxed about the recent rise in the Swiss franc's value.

site_title: Asian outbound real estate investment mostly from Singapore in 2021
summary: Singapore accounted for the majority of Asia's $54.6 billion in outbound commercial real estate investment in 2021, with $32 billion spent overseas, largely in the US and logistics assets. Outbound flows from Asia rebounded 69% year-over-year, exceeding pre-pandemic volumes. Hong Kong was the second most active source of capital, with $6.7 billion invested in retail and office assets in China. Asian investors focused on the Asia-Pacific, with North America and regional gateway markets drawing the most attention, and expect to deploy more capital in 2022.

site_title: Wynn Resorts' new CEO likes his odds, despite Macau troubles
summary: Wynn Resorts' new CEO, Craig Billings, is optimistic about the company's future despite Macau's challenges. The Macau casinos, once the main breadwinners, lost money in the final months of 2021. Billings plans to expand Wynn into new businesses, focusing on younger, affluent guests, and exploring new markets. He announced plans for a new casino in the UAE, and is considering traditional casino expansion opportunities in the US, including New York City. Billings aims to build a more global player, diversifying from its traditional gaming business, and is open to investing in non-casino attractions to attract new customers.

site_title: Slower property auctions in March; freehold retail shop sold under guide price at S$1.455 million
summary: Knight Frank's March property auction saw only one property sell, a freehold retail shop at Sim Lim Tower for S$1.455 million, below the original guide price. Two other properties, including a 4-bedroom duplex penthouse at Marina Bay Residences, remained unsold after being put up for auction at lower prices. Four out of nine listed properties were withdrawn, with auctions postponed due to unanticipated situations.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore relaxes COVID-19 restrictions, doubling group size to 10 for social gatherings and lifting mask mandates outdoors starting March 29. Fully vaccinated travelers can enter Singapore quarantine-free without VTLs from April 1, and travel between Singapore and Malaysia by land will also be allowed without tests or quarantine. The country also lifts restrictions on large-scale social events, live performances, and alcohol consumption beyond 10:30pm. Meanwhile, S&P Global Ratings downgraded ST Engineering's credit rating due to elevated debt levels following a recent deal.

site_title: STI up 1.1% on further easing of Covid-19 restrictions
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.1% on Thursday, March 24, after the government announced loosened Covid-19 restrictions. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed 35.44 to close at 3,399.70, with gains beating losses 297 to 165. Analysts note that mobility, leisure, tourism, commercial, and Reit plays could see stronger investor interest. Stocks like Singapore Airlines, SATS, and Genting Singapore gained, while banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.09 points or 0.07% to 1,598.97 on Thursday, with 482 winners and 428 losers. The index was supported by a volume of 2.7 billion lots worth RM2.11 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with deep losses on Thursday, following a sell-off on Wall Street and a strong rally over the past week. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.94%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The losses were attributed to traders focusing on the Ukraine war and US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Clock runs out on Russian steelmaker Severstal's bond interest deadline as Citi blocks payment
summary: Russian steelmaker Severstal missed a US$12.6 million interest payment deadline for its US$800 million loan participation notes due to US Treasury's refusal to clear the payment without express permission. The company is seeking a solution, but a default would leave international operations covering only 16% of its foreign debt. This is the first time a Russian company has failed to meet a foreign-currency debt deadline since the Ukraine war began, exacerbating investor anxiety about Russian firms' debt obligations under sanctions.

site_title: Top steel city Tangshan set to cut output amid Covid disruptions: sources
summary: China's steel city Tangshan is expected to cut or suspend production due to Covid disruptions and transportation constraints. The city, which produced 13% of China's steel last year, has implemented a temporary lockdown, hindering steel mills from replenishing raw materials and causing a backlog of steel products at warehouses. Producers, mostly privately owned, face difficulties maintaining cash flow and have already seen a 36% drop in molten iron output this week. The lockdown is the latest in a series of measures to control Covid cases in northern China, adding to production woes that began in June due to environmental curbs and the Winter Olympics.

images.alt_text: Steel producers in China's northern city of Tangshan are likely to have to cut or suspend production in the coming days because of the difficulties getting raw materials, sources said, as transportation comes to a standstill following fresh Covid curbs.

site_title: Art Basel promises French focus for new Paris fair
summary: Art Basel has announced its new Paris fair, "Paris + by Art Basel", which will have a French team and aims to ease tensions over replacing France's FIAC fair. The decision follows a shock announcement in January that Art Basel would replace FIAC this autumn. The new fair will be part-owned by billionaire investor James Murdoch and will operate alongside Art Basel's existing fairs in Basel, Miami, and Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Paris + by Art Basel will be held at the Grand Palais near the Champs-Elysees in October.

site_title: US mortgage rates surge to 4.42%, highest since January 2019
summary: US mortgage rates surged to 4.42%, the highest since January 2019, according to Freddie Mac. This marks the latest jump in borrowing costs, driven by rising 10-year Treasury yields and the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. Home-loan costs are expected to rise further by the end of the year, affecting homebuyers' ability to keep up with the market. The increase in mortgage rates, combined with house price appreciation, is reducing buying power and increasing monthly mortgage payments.

site_title: Thai crypto curbs to 'ring-fence' banks from unforeseen risks
summary: Thailand's central bank, Bank of Thailand, plans to restrict commercial banks' investment in digital assets to 3% of their capital to protect them from unforeseen risks. The move aims to ring-fence banks from risks associated with cryptocurrencies and other digital assets. The bank also plans to issue guidelines for digital banks by June, allowing existing and new applicants to seek licenses. The restrictions come as the popularity of cryptocurrencies has driven banks to invest in digital asset platforms, with the value of digital assets held by Thais increasing to 114.5 billion baht.

images.alt_text: Thailand, which has banned the use of cryptocurrencies for payments, will restrict the role of commercial banks in the digital-assets business to protect them from unforeseen risks, a central bank official said.

site_title: Current income cap to own BTO flats still reasonable for now: analysts
summary: The current income ceiling for buying a build-to-order (BTO) flat in Singapore remains reasonable, according to analysts. The ceiling, currently set at S$14,000 per month, is unlikely to be raised too quickly, as it may price out many Singaporeans. Analysts suggest that raising the income cap should be done in conjunction with monitoring median household income and ensuring that BTO flats remain accessible to those who need affordable housing. Alternative options, such as HDB resale flats, executive condominiums, and private housing, are also available for families who exceed the income cap.

site_title: N Korea fires possible ICBM in largest test since 2017
summary: North Korea launched a possible intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) off its east coast, its largest test since 2017. The missile, believed to be a new type, flew for 71 minutes and landed in Japan's exclusive economic zone, 1,100 km away from its launch site. This marks a significant escalation in North Korea's development of ICBMs capable of delivering nuclear warheads to the US mainland. The launch poses a new national security headache for US President Joe Biden and challenges South Korea's incoming conservative administration, amid ongoing tensions over Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on March 24, 2022, with the DAX and CAC 40 indices gaining 0.3% each. In contrast, Britain's FTSE 100 and midcap indexes were muted, with the blue-chip index up 0.1% and the midcap index down 0.1%. The gains were driven by steady oil prices and a mixed Asian market. Concerns about the Ukraine crisis and earnings forecasts weighed on sentiment, particularly for the UK's Next clothing retailer.

site_title: Is it time to say RIP to ESG?
summary: Key proponents of the environmental, social, and governance (ESG) movement, including Anne Simpson, are questioning the effectiveness of ESG, suggesting it may be "time to say RIP" due to contradictory debates on standards and a misguided focus on transport. Simpson emphasized the need for mainstreaming ESG across investments and capital allocation. However, the increasing complexity of ESG standards, regulation, and reporting frameworks highlights the need for a common language to support the movement of assets towards sustainability.

site_title: Philippine central bank holds rate, but sends hawkish signal
summary: The Philippine central bank maintained interest rates steady at 2.0% for an 11th consecutive meeting, citing global uncertainties and domestic economic risks. Despite keeping rates unchanged, the bank raised inflation forecasts to 4.3% in 2022, higher than the previous forecast of 3.7%. BSP governor Benjamin Diokno signaled the bank's readiness to temper price pressures, with average inflation expected to breach the 2-4% target range in 2022.

site_title: 10 grapes worth knowing better
summary: A writer discovered a new grape variety, servadou, while tasting a wine from the Aveyron region of France. The writer had previously been unfamiliar with the grape but found the wine to be delightful. This encounter served as a reminder that there is always more to learn about wine, even for those well-versed in its intricacies. The writer's experience highlights the potential for discovery and joy in exploring new grape varieties.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks retreat from 3-week high on inflation fears, Ukraine crisis
summary: South Korean stocks retreated from a 3-week high due to inflation fears and the ongoing Ukraine crisis. The Kospi index closed down 0.2% at 2,729.66, with chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading the declines. Oil prices jumped, and Western leaders gathered in Brussels to discuss measures to pressure Russia. The Korean won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield rose. Foreigners sold 473.5 billion won worth of shares, and US$1.1 billion worth of Samsung Electronics shares were sold in a block deal.

site_title: STI up 1.1% after further easing of Covid-19 restrictions
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.1% on Thursday, driven by the easing of Covid-19 restrictions. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed 35.44 to close at 3,399.70, with major gainers including SATS, Singapore Airlines, and DBS. Analysts predict stronger investor interest in "reopening plays" such as mobility, leisure, and commercial real estate investment trusts. The market rally comes ahead of GDP data, with the US-EU tariffs and healthcare sector also in focus.

site_title: New York widens lead over London in top finance centres index
summary: New York has extended its lead as the world's top financial centre, ranking first with 759 points, down 3 from 6 months ago. London, ranked second with 726 points, is losing ground to rivals in the US and Asia. The Global Financial Centres Index (GFCI) attributes London's decline to increased competitiveness from US and Asian cities. Russia's invasion of Ukraine is expected to affect future rankings for Moscow and St Petersburg, which are currently 50th and 110th respectively. London's ranking has been closely watched since Brexit, with the UK finance ministry planning to give regulators a formal competitiveness remit.

site_title: US goods risk being late as China's lockdowns worsen shipping port jams
summary: Congestion at Chinese ports, particularly Shenzhen and Hong Kong, has reached its highest level in 5 months due to Covid-19 lockdowns. Over 174 vessels are anchored or loading, posing a risk of delays to US-bound goods this summer. The situation is expected to worsen if lockdowns continue, potentially causing a ripple effect on global supply chains.

site_title: Room to experiment
summary: Architect Ivan Soh, co-founder of PI Architects, designed his 123-square-metre apartment in Bedok South with complete freedom, allowing him to experiment with unconventional design ideas and finishes. The unit, which faces a playground, was chosen for its peaceful atmosphere. Soh's home showcases his ability to balance personal taste with professional expertise, as he would typically follow a client's brief in his work. The article highlights Soh's creative freedom and ability to bring his personal style to a residential project.

site_title: Singapore-Malaysia land travel: No test, quarantine for the vaccinated from Apr 1
summary: Singapore and Malaysia will allow fully vaccinated travelers to enter either country without a COVID-19 test or quarantine starting April 1. This applies to all categories of travelers and modes of transport via the land border. Non-fully vaccinated children under 12 will also be exempt from testing and quarantine. Fully vaccinated travelers must still have valid documents, such as passports and Vehicle Entry Permits, and may submit digital vaccination certificates in advance. The move aims to facilitate recovery efforts and contribute to the economies and livelihoods of both countries.

site_title: Lloyd's sees major claims this year from Ukraine conflict
summary: Lloyd's of London anticipates significant claims this year due to the ongoing Ukraine conflict, but the commercial insurance market remains solvent. The aviation insurance market, in particular, is vulnerable to the impact of Russia's invasion and subsequent sanctions. Lloyd's has around 100 member syndicates that underwrite complex risks, with business in Ukraine, Russia, and Belarus accounting for less than 1% of the market's total business. The company's pre-tax profit for 2021 was £2.3 billion, following a £900 million loss in 2020.

site_title: Trends shaping South-east Asia's startup ecosystem growth
summary: South-east Asia's startup ecosystem is experiencing rapid growth, driven by a maturing market with a large, young, and tech-savvy population. The region's unique features, such as a growing consumer market and a trend of people coming online for the first time, are creating opportunities for startups to expand. Investors are expected to focus on fintech, e-commerce, and education sectors, with a growing interest in emerging sectors like crypto and blockchain. The region's regulatory landscape is still evolving, but investors who understand the unique potential of South-east Asia can benefit from the ecosystem's growth.

site_title: Eurozone business growth stronger than expected in March
summary: Eurozone business activity grew stronger than expected in March, with the S&P Global Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index reaching 54.5, above the median forecast of 53.9. However, prices rose at a record pace, likely adding to pressure on the European Central Bank to raise interest rates. The growth was partly driven by a rebound following Covid restrictions being lifted, but supply chain issues worsened following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, casting a murky outlook for the economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rebound to close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, rebounding from earlier losses, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.25% to 28,110.39. The gains were attributed to end-of-financial-year factors such as dividend purchases and buying back shares to hedge losses. The market's eighth consecutive gain, its best performance since September, was driven by the soaring price of natural resources. Despite this, analysts noted that market sentiment has not improved due to ongoing uncertainties over Ukraine.

site_title: Fashion NFTs take to the runway in world's first Metaverse Fashion Week
summary: The world's first Metaverse Fashion Week (MFW) took place from March 24 to 27 on the Decentraland platform, featuring runway shows and events showcasing digital garments from top brands like Dolce & Gabbana, Etro, and Elie Saab. The event highlights the growing trend of fashion NFTs, with thousands of digital-only or digital-first brands creating clothes for virtual avatars. The Metaverse offers unique possibilities for fashion, allowing users to customize and style their digital avatars with clothes that can change colors, shapes, and even sprout flowers or diamonds.

site_title: ANZ becomes first Australian bank to mint stablecoin
summary: ANZ, Australia's third-largest bank, has become the first Australian lender to mint a stablecoin, dubbed A$DC, which is linked to the country's currency. The bank, in collaboration with Zerocap, created 30 million A$DC using a smart contract and transferred them between parties before redeeming them back into fiat currency. This move comes after the Reserve Bank of Australia expressed interest in the growth of digital wallets and the potential for central banks to back digital currencies.

site_title: The cult of the disruptor: New TV shows chart the rise and fall of startup founders
summary: Two new TV series, "WeCrashed" and "The Dropout," chronicle the rise and fall of startup founders Adam Neumann and Elizabeth Holmes, respectively. "WeCrashed" dramatizes Neumann's transformation from a small-time salesman to a co-working mogul, while "The Dropout" delves into Holmes' struggles to build Theranos into a successful company. Both series highlight the cult-like cultures and narcissistic tendencies of their subjects, as well as the challenges faced by women in the tech industry. The shows offer cautionary tales about the dangers of hubris and greed, with Neumann walking away with millions and Holmes marrying a hotel heir despite her troubled past.

site_title: Hong Kong can open up to world once wave subsides, Lam says
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam expressed optimism that the city can reopen to the world once the current COVID-19 wave subsides. The government plans to halve hotel quarantine to 7 days and lift flight bans on some countries. However, business groups say the government isn't going far enough, amid a significant exodus of residents and economic hardship. The city has seen a net 144,000 people leave this year, with tourism severely impacted, and analysts downgrading growth forecasts for the year.

site_title: Fully-vaccinated Singapore residents, long-term pass holders no longer need to pay for Covid-19 treatment post-travel
summary: Singapore has revised its Covid-19 treatment policy for fully-vaccinated residents and long-term pass holders. Starting now, they will no longer need to pay for Covid-related medical bills after traveling, with the charging policy aligned to local community cases. This change applies to fully-vaccinated travelers returning from all countries and regions under the General Travel Category, as well as medically exempted individuals and children under 12. Short-term pass holders remain responsible for their medical bills.

site_title: Shangri-La pares FY21 loss to US$290.6m as revenue rises
summary: Shangri-La Asia reported a narrowed FY21 net loss to US$290.6 million, down from US$460.2 million the previous year. Revenue improved 20.1% to US$1.2 billion, driven by domestic demand in mainland China and Hong Kong. The loss per share decreased to 8.13 US cents, compared to 12.89 US cents the previous year.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, the company's hotel occupancy was at 37 per cent for the full year, down 45 per cent from the year before.

site_title: Mask on: Face coverings from designers around the world
summary: A virtual exhibition, "Clothing the Pandemic: A Virtual Exhibition of Covid-19 Face Masks from Around the World," is now available, showcasing over 100 face masks collected by museum curators from 2020 to 2021. Organized by the International Committee for Museums and Collections of Costume and spearheaded by the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto, Canada, the exhibition highlights the material culture of the pandemic and the iconic symbol of face masks. Participating museums include the British Museum, Victoria & Albert Museum, and the Asian Civilisations Museum in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Butterfly people mask by Indian designer Rahul Mishra

site_title: Invesco drops plan to shake up India's Zee, citing Sony merger plan
summary: US investment firm Invesco dropped its plan to oust India's Zee Entertainment CEO, citing support for a planned merger with Sony Group. Invesco, which owns 18% of Zee, had pursued a shareholder meeting to appoint new independent board members over alleged corporate governance issues. However, the firm decided not to pursue the matter, citing the merger, which will substantially reconstitute the board. Zee shares rose over 16% following the news, as the planned merger is expected to strengthen board oversight.

site_title: A widening ban on Russian oil products will put heat on Putin to negotiate
summary: The West's initial response to Russia's invasion, including sanctions on energy exports, has been deemed insufficient, allowing Russia to withstand the sanctions with energy exports remaining excluded. The rouble's exchange rate has appreciated, government bond yields have fallen, and Russia's GDP growth forecast for 2022 stands at minus 8%. A widening ban on Russian oil products could pressure President Putin to negotiate, with a "ladder of sanctions" being proposed to gradually increase pressure on Russia.

images.alt_text: A Ukrainian refugee takes part in a protest against the Russian invasion of Ukraine in Brussels, Belgium, on Tuesday (Mar 22). Europe's dependence on Russia's oil and oil products is funding Vladimir Putin's war machine. The reality is that the continent is unable to wean itself from these energy products. A scheduled, widening ban on Russian oil will give parties time to find alternative sources and choke off Putin's source of funds.

site_title: BT podcast: 5 steps to pivot to e-commerce
summary: A podcast by The Business Times explores how businesses can rethink their e-commerce strategies to stay resilient amidst global supply chain issues. Lalamove's managing director, Alex Lin, shares a 5-step plan to pivot to e-commerce, emphasizing the importance of choosing the right logistics partner and partner enablement. The conversation highlights the dangers of overlooking any step in the process, and the need for businesses to adapt to the changing market landscape.

site_title: Oil sees further gains on sanctions talk, while equities slip
summary: Oil prices surged further on Thursday as investors feared additional Russia sanctions, boosting prices above $120, while most equity markets declined due to surging inflation and interest rate hikes. The US Federal Reserve has signaled a potential half-point rate hike, and the European Union is debating a possible Russian oil embargo. The ongoing Ukraine war and Iran nuclear deal developments also contributed to market uncertainty, fueling inflation concerns and putting pressure on central banks to tighten monetary policy.

site_title: S&P downgrades ST Engineering on higher debt levels following TransCore deal
summary: S&P Global Ratings downgraded ST Engineering's credit rating to "AA+" from "AAA" due to elevated debt levels resulting from its $3.6 billion acquisition of TransCore Partners and TLP Holdings. The acquisition is expected to triple ST Engineering's debt to $5.3 billion in 2022, with a debt-to-Ebitda ratio estimated to increase to 4. The downgrade notes that the company's ability to bid for large overseas contracts is limited, and the slow recovery in the aviation industry will hinder debt reduction.

site_title: A dotcom era pioneer in India readies second startup for an IPO
summary: Rajesh Jain, a pioneer of India's Internet industry, is preparing his second startup, Netcore Cloud, for an initial public offer (IPO) within 9-12 months. Netcore, a software-as-a-service company, specializes in customer communication and engagement solutions, and has recently acquired Unbxd for $100 million. The acquisition is expected to boost subscription revenues to $150 million annually, and Jain believes the company is "profitable and dominates India and emerging markets." Netcore has over 5,000 clients globally and sends 15 billion marketing emails monthly, making it an attractive IPO candidate.

site_title: EY startup incubator programme expands to more Asean countries
summary: EY's startup incubator programme, EY Foundry, expands to Cambodia, Guam, Thailand, and Vietnam, marking its first expansion outside of Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Sri Lanka, Australia, and New Zealand. The programme, launched in 2018, aims to support early-stage tech startups by offering tailored learnings, pilot sessions, and Microsoft Azure credits. EY seeks collaborations with startups to enhance its tax practice and develop innovative solutions for clients. The programme is open for application until April 15.

site_title: Vaccinated travellers to enter Singapore quarantine-free without need for VTLs from April
summary: Singapore to allow fully vaccinated travelers to enter quarantine-free starting April 1, without the need for Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) or related passes. Fully vaccinated travelers will still need a pre-departure test, but not an antigen rapid test upon arrival. The simplified regime applies to travelers from countries in the General Travel Category, excluding those from the Restricted Category. The move aims to boost the travel and tourism sector, with the goal of reaching 50% of pre-Covid passenger volumes by the end of 2022.

site_title: Buyout boom drives record European corporate real estate sales
summary: A record 29 billion euros of European corporate real estate was sold in 2021, driven by a surge in mergers and acquisitions. Private equity firms, which accounted for nearly a quarter of global mergers and acquisitions, cashed in on property portfolios of acquired companies. This led to a boom in private equity firms loading their targets with leverage, resulting in increased disposals of corporate real estate. The high levels of disposals reflect the frenetic levels of mergers and acquisitions last year, with acquiring entities seeking to release capital tied up in property portfolios.

site_title: Singapore to 'drastically streamline' testing, quarantine rules with Vaccinated Travel Framework
summary: Singapore will "drastically streamline" testing and quarantine requirements for travelers under the Vaccinated Travel Framework, allowing for easier travel abroad and lifting most restrictions for fully vaccinated visitors entering the country. This comes after the Omicron variant is now well under control, and the government believes it's safe to open up borders. The changes will take effect on March 29, with more details to be provided by the multi-ministry taskforce.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher as miners, energy stocks ride commodity rally
summary: Australian shares rose 0.1% to 7,387.1 points, driven by gains in miners and energy stocks as commodity prices surged amid ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine. The metals and mining index rose 1.1% on iron ore and base metal price increases, with sector majors Rio Tinto and BHP Group up 2.1% and 1.8%, respectively.

site_title: IEA fears climate goals may fall victim to 'Russia's aggression'
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) expressed concern that Russia's war in Ukraine may hinder efforts to combat climate change. IEA executive director Fatih Birol stated that governments must balance energy security with climate goals, warning that climate change could be another victim of Russia's aggression.

site_title: Epstein's Caribbean islands list for US$125m: WSJ
summary: Two private Caribbean islands, Great St James and Little St James, once owned by late financier Jeffrey Epstein, are on sale for US$125 million. The islands, spanning 230 acres, feature luxury homes, a helipad, and untouched marine preserves. Epstein, accused of trafficking and abusing young women, purchased the islands in 1998 and 2016. The sale proceeds will go towards resolving lawsuits and estate costs, according to the Wall Street Journal.

site_title: Australia strikes deal with Moderna to manufacture mRNA vaccines
summary: Australia has partnered with Moderna to manufacture mRNA vaccines domestically, worth A$2 billion, to bolster pharmaceutical supply lines. The facility, expected to produce 100 million vaccine doses annually, will start operations in 2024 and will include research collaborations. This deal aims to improve Australia's pandemic preparedness and support domestic manufacturing. The agreement is seen as a major part of Prime Minister Scott Morrison's election pitch, addressing the country's past criticism of failing to secure medical supplies quickly enough during the pandemic.

site_title: Group size to double to 10 pax; masks no longer needed outdoors from Mar 29
summary: Singapore to relax COVID-19 restrictions starting March 29, with the maximum group size doubling to 10 people, and mask-wearing outdoors becoming optional. The percentage of employees allowed to return to work will rise to 75% and the capacity limit for larger events will increase to 75%. However, mask-wearing will remain mandatory indoors and safe-distancing measures will still be in place. The move is seen as a "decisive step" towards living with the virus, with the number of daily new infections declining over the past two weeks.

site_title: Dubai's biggest IPO in 15 years seeks to raise US$2.2 billion
summary: Dubai Electricity & Water Authority (Dewa) plans to raise up to $2.2 billion in its initial public offering (IPO), valuing the company at up to $33.8 billion. The 6.5% stake sale, at 2.25-2.48 dirhams per share, will make Dewa the largest company on Dubai's bourse. The listing aims to boost the emirate's flagging capital markets, despite global market volatility. The IPO drew in 6 cornerstone investors, including Emirates Investment Authority, and is expected to start trading on April 12.

images.alt_text: The Dewa listing, which will make it the biggest company on the emirate's bourse, marks the first step in Dubai's ambitious plan to reinvigorate its flagging capital markets.

site_title: Singapore urges second booster shot for seniors aged 80 and up, other at-risk groups
summary: Singapore's expert committee recommends a second booster dose of the Covid-19 vaccine for seniors aged 80 and up, as well as other at-risk groups, to be administered around 5 months after the first booster. This move aims to maintain high protection levels as activities resume normally. Eligible individuals can obtain the second booster dose without affecting their eligibility for vaccination-differentiated safe management measures. Younger, healthy individuals are not recommended for a second booster dose.

site_title: Trump 'guilty' of felonies, says prosecutor who resigned: NYT
summary: A former prosecutor in the New York investigation into Donald Trump's business practices has resigned, stating that Trump is "guilty of numerous felony violations." The prosecutor, Mark Pomerantz, quit after Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg decided not to prosecute Trump over allegations of fraudulently overvaluing assets to secure loans and undervaluing them to minimize taxes. Pomerantz's resignation letter claims the decision is "contrary to the public interest" and will "doom any future prospects" of Trump being prosecuted. Trump has not been charged and maintains that the case is a "political witch hunt."

site_title: Hot stock: Olam Group tumbles 8% after announcing delay in OFI listing plans
summary: Olam Group shares fell 8% after its food ingredients unit OFI delayed plans for an initial public offering (IPO) in Q2 2022, citing current market conditions due to the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. The company remains committed to pursuing a public listing and will evaluate the timing based on prevailing market conditions.

site_title: Credit Suisse flags potential hit from Bermuda court ruling
summary: Credit Suisse Group warned that a potential court ruling in Bermuda could be worth over $500 million, stemming from a former client adviser's conviction for defrauding customers. The bank has been fighting claims and previously took reserves against this matter. Credit Suisse plans to pursue all available legal actions and will reassess reserves for its first-quarter results.

site_title: Thai Feb exports rise 16.2% yoy, beats forecast
summary: Thailand's exports rose 16.2% year-over-year in February, exceeding forecasts of a 10.2% increase. This follows January's 8% increase. Imports also rose 16.8% year-over-year, resulting in a trade surplus of $123 million.

site_title: Singapore lifts Covid restrictions on social events, live performances and alcohol past 10.30pm
summary: Singapore lifts Covid restrictions on social events, live performances, and alcohol consumption beyond 10.30pm starting March 29, marking a "decisive move" to live with Covid-19. Social group sizes increase to 10, and food and beverage establishments can serve up to 10 fully vaccinated customers. Restrictions on alcohol sales and consumption after 10.30pm, as well as live performances, are lifted. Live broadcasts and recorded entertainment can also resume at F&B establishments.

site_title: Chinese search for second black box from crashed China Eastern jet
summary: Chinese authorities are searching for a second black box from a crashed China Eastern Airlines passenger plane that killed 132 people. The first black box, a cockpit voice recorder, was found and appears to have survived the impact relatively intact. The plane, a Boeing 737-800, plunged from cruising altitude in southern China on Monday, with pilots not responding to repeated calls from air traffic controllers. The cause of the crash is unknown, but experts say it's likely due to a combination of factors. The investigation, led by China, also involves the US National Transportation Safety Board.

site_title: Samsung Electronics shares worth US$1.1b sold in block deal
summary: Samsung Electronics sold approximately US$1.1 billion worth of shares in a block deal, with about 19.9 million shares sold at a discounted price. The sale was attributed to the company's controlling family raising funds to meet a large tax bill, with shares to be used to pay over US$10 billion in inheritance tax. The sale came as the trust agreement period for shares held by Hong Ra-hee, mother of Samsung vice-chairman Jay Lee, was set to end on April 25.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics shares worth about US$1.1 billion were sold in a block deal on Thursday (Mar 24), which some analysts attributed to the conglomerate's controlling family raising cash to meet a big tax bill.

site_title: Hot stocks: Aviation, tourism-linked counters rise on easing of Covid-19 measures
summary: Singapore's easing of Covid-19 measures has boosted aviation and tourism-linked stocks, with shares of companies such as C6L, S59, and S58 rising 2.9%, 2.2%, and 3.8% respectively. The easing of travel requirements and increased social gatherings are expected to drive increased mobility, benefiting transport stocks like ComfortDelGro and coffee shop operators. DBS analysts predict that simplified travel requirements could also boost occupancies and activity for hospitality and tourism plays, while medical tourism is expected to make a comeback.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines planes sit on the tarmac at Changi Airport in Singapore December 8, 2020.

site_title: Australia: Shares set for worst day in over 1 week on tech slump
summary: Australian shares are set for their worst day in over a week, down 0.1% as technology stocks follow US peers lower amid broadening inflationary pressures and reassessed global growth outlook. Financials slipped 0.9% and the "Big Four" banks fell between 0.6% and 1.3%. Technology stocks dropped 1.8%, with Block Inc falling 4.7%, while commodities rose, led by oil, as Western leaders consider more sanctions on Russia.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday, following losses on Wall Street after Federal Reserve officials signaled the need for aggressive monetary policy to contain inflation. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.71%, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.48%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 1.01%. The losses follow a similar trend on Wall Street, where stocks fell amid concerns over US-EU trade talks and inflation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened flat on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.02% to 1,598.17 points. The trading volume reached 261.12 million lots worth RM128.41 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 200 to 153.

site_title: Gold flat as stronger dollar counters Ukraine worries
summary: Gold prices remained unchanged at US$1,943.75 per ounce on March 24, despite an escalation in the Ukraine crisis, as a stronger US dollar offset support from the crisis. The dollar index gained, making gold less attractive for other currency holders, while oil prices rose. The benchmark 10-year Treasury yield hovered near multi-year peaks, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Russian President Vladimir Putin's threat to switch gas sales to roubles also sent European futures soaring.

site_title: Keppel Infra Trust undertakes strategic review of Ixom business
summary: Keppel Infra Trust is undertaking a strategic review of its wholly-owned Ixom business, a leading manufacturer of water treatment chemicals and industrial chemicals in Australia and New Zealand. The review aims to unlock value from the asset and further the trust's growth, with no assurance that a transaction will materialise. The trustee-manager has appointed a financial adviser and may enter preliminary discussions with various parties to evaluate options. The review is part of the trust's regular asset review process, with units closing 0.9% higher on the news.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 1.27% and the Topix index 1.01% lower. The declines follow falls on Wall Street amid growing concerns over inflation and surging oil prices.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust proposes to acquire Panvel warehouse for 2.2b rupees
summary: Ascendas India Trust has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire a 330,000 square foot warehouse in Panvel, Navi Mumbai, for 2.2 billion rupees. The acquisition, valued at S$38.7 million, is part of a forward purchase agreement executed in 2019. The company will lease the property back for 6 years, with an option to pay an additional 210 million rupees over the next 4 years. The warehouse's open market value is estimated at 2.5 billion rupees.

site_title: Occidental plans 70 plants to capture carbon from air by 2035
summary: Occidental Petroleum plans to build 70 carbon capture facilities by 2035, removing 1 million tons of greenhouse gas per year from the atmosphere. The first facility, valued at $1 billion, is expected to start construction in the second half of this year and begin operations in 2024. This project aims to offset emissions from operations and fossil fuels, with CEO Vicki Hollub stating that the low-carbon business will become as big as the legacy chemicals business. The move is seen as a step to mitigate climate change, with Occidental investing $100 million this year to develop 3 carbon sequestration hubs.

site_title: Bank of Japan policymakers saw chance of inflation overshoot in January: minutes
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers believe consumer inflation may temporarily hit 1.5% in January due to companies passing on rising costs to households. Some members project a brief rise near the central bank's 2% target as companies adjust price-setting behavior. Rising raw material costs and stock prices for companies that hike prices are concerns. Policymakers are watching wages closely, with one member stating that nominal wage growth must exceed 2% for Japan to meet the BOJ's price target. The BOJ maintains ultra-loose monetary policy to support a fragile economic recovery.

site_title: Salary of UOB chief executive Wee Ee Cheong up 11.5% to S$10.9m in 2021
summary: UOB's CEO Wee Ee Cheong saw an 11.5% increase in his annual salary to S$10.9 million in 2021, driven by strong profits and an improved economic outlook. His pay includes a base salary of S$1.2 million, a bonus of S$9.7 million, and benefits-in-kind. The bank reported a 40% on-year increase in net profit to S$4.1 billion and a 7% rise in total income to S$9.8 billion. This comes as UOB expands its retail franchise in ASEAN, with a deal to acquire Citi's consumer units in four markets.

site_title: Data privacy, security, human capital present material ESG risks for blockchain funds
summary: A recent report by Morningstar Sustainalytics highlights material ESG (environmental, social, and governance) risks in the blockchain ETF market, including data privacy and security, human capital, and business ethics. The report found 22 of 46 financial sector companies have high unmanaged risk scores related to product governance and business ethics, and 41% have experienced significant business ethics controversies. While blockchain offers benefits, companies must make disclosures on product features and risks to ensure client awareness and protection.

site_title: Toshiba's spin-off plan up against much opposition at Thursday's shareholder vote
summary: Toshiba's proposed spin-off of its devices business faces significant opposition at a shareholder vote, with top shareholders and proxy advisory firms opposing the plan. The proposal, backed by Singapore-based 3D Investment Partners, aims to solicit buyout offers from private equity firms, but lacks support from ISS and Glass Lewis. Toshiba management argues the spin-off would maximize shareholder value, but hopes a successful vote would entice activist shareholders to leave. The outcome represents another battle in a four-year scandal-filled war between Toshiba and activist shareholders over the company's direction.

site_title: Olam Group's OFI to delay IPO and listing due to Russia-Ukraine conflict
summary: Olam Group's food ingredients unit, OFI, has delayed its planned initial public offering (IPO) and listing due to the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict. The company, which had previously anticipated the IPO for Q2 2022, now plans to evaluate the timing of a public listing on an ongoing basis, considering prevailing market conditions.

images.alt_text: Olam Group's co-founder and group chief executive Sunny Verghese is 1 of 3 non-executive directors appointed to OFI's board.

site_title: Google tests letting apps like Spotify offer own billing
summary: Google is testing a new system that allows apps like Spotify to bill users directly, bypassing Google's 15% fee. The move comes amid antitrust concerns over app store fees and follows a similar change in South Korea, where Google reduced fees by 4%. Spotify, which has been installed nearly 1 billion times on the Google Play store, will no longer have to give Google its entire 15% fee if users choose to pay directly. The system, seen as a significant milestone, is expected to work across the globe and could potentially influence Apple's approach to app store fees.

site_title: US reinstates tariff exemptions on some Chinese products
summary: The US government announced it will reinstate tariff exemptions for 352 Chinese products, which lapsed in late 2020, and extend them through the end of 2022. The decision comes after President Joe Biden's administration received public comments and consulted with other US agencies. The exemptions, which were first introduced in 2018, aim to alleviate the tariff burden on businesses and drive down prices amid a record wave of inflation. The move is seen as a step towards easing tensions in the trade conflict between the US and China.

site_title: DeFi app promising 20% interest on stablecoin deposits raises concerns
summary: A DeFi app called Anchor Protocol is promising 19.45% interest on stablecoin UST deposits, significantly higher than traditional banks. The high rate aims to create demand for UST, but experts question its sustainability. A sudden drop could test the cryptocurrency's peg to the US dollar, potentially causing a crash. Anchor's creator, Do Kwon, believes the rate is justified by DeFi's potential for high returns, but critics warn of the risks. The Terra blockchain, which powers Anchor and UST, is facing skepticism, with some calling it a Ponzi scheme.

site_title: General insurance sector posts underwriting profit of S$262.7m despite more claims paid out
summary: The General Insurance Association of Singapore reported an underwriting profit of S$262.7 million for 2021, a 2.7% increase from the previous year, despite a 8.3% rise in total claims paid out. The sector saw an 8% increase in overall gross written premiums to S$4.4 billion, driven by strong uptake in top business segments. The association expects a continued upward trend in the property insurance segment and will focus on addressing emerging risks such as cyber threats and sustainability.

site_title: US: Wall Street retreats at the close amid economic uncertainty
summary: US stocks retreated at the close on Wednesday amid concerns over a "soft landing" and aggressive rate hikes to combat inflation, echoing comments from Federal Reserve officials. Investors are skeptical about the risk of a recession despite officials downplaying it. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, reflecting a choppy trading week.

site_title: YouTube offers thousands of free television episodes - with ads
summary: YouTube has started streaming over 4,000 free television episodes, including shows like Hell's Kitchen and Heartland, with ads, to US viewers. This move aims to compete with other streaming platforms. The content is available on YouTube through smart televisions, mobile devices, or web browsers. This expansion follows YouTube's history as a pioneer in video-on-demand services, starting with user-uploaded clips. The platform's goal is to provide a wider range of content to its users.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, Olam, Keppel Infrastructure Trust
summary: ST Engineering's shares rose 0.2% following a downgrade of its credit rating to AA+ from AAA due to elevated debt levels after a $3.6 billion deal. Olam Group's food ingredients unit OFI postponed its IPO and appointed new directors, including Sunny Verghese, after citing market conditions. Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Ixom business is undergoing a strategic review to potentially unlock value.

site_title: Instant noodle store an unlikely hit with Thai youth
summary: A store in Bangkok, Thailand, called Good Noodle has become a hit among local teenagers, offering over 70 types of instant noodles from across Asia. Since its opening in October, the store has attracted thousands of young customers who can cook and eat their meals immediately, with prices ranging from $0.24 to $10.10. The store's managing director scoured Bangkok's convenience stores for over 350 types of instant noodles, seeing an opportunity to offer a unique experience. The store's success highlights the popularity of instant noodles in Asia, despite health experts warning against excessive consumption.

images.alt_text: In Thailand, a country famous for its flavourful, spicy cuisine and street food, instant noodles may seem an unlikely culinary hit.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall slightly at Thursday's open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened slightly lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% to 3,360 points. The decline follows losses on Wall Street, where rising concerns about a US "soft landing" amid aggressive Federal Reserve comments sent stocks lower. European shares also fell 1% on Wednesday, and Tokyo stocks opened lower after a similar decline on Wall Street.

site_title: SPH seeks to buy back outstanding S$500m of 3.2% notes due 2030
summary: SPH, a Singaporean media company, has launched a consent solicitation to buy back its outstanding S$500m 3.2% notes due 2030. Noteholders can sell back their notes at 100.75% of the principal amount until April 18.
