site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 8.47 points or 0.53% to 1,594.28. The market saw 251.69 million lots traded worth RM124.39 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 259 to 94.

site_title: Hot stock: Lendlease Reit hits 9-month low on S$648.8m equity fundraising
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit's units fell 5% on resuming trading after a private placement and preferential offering to finance its S$2.1 billion Jem mall acquisition. The counter dropped to S$0.755, its lowest level since May 31, 2021.

images.alt_text: Lendlease Reit, which is looking to take a full stake in Jem mall, counts 313@somerset (pictured) in its investment portfolio.
Vivienne Tay

site_title: Private equity company Actis weighs sale of Indonesian private school firm
summary: Private equity firm Actis is considering the sale of its Indonesian private education company, the Singapore Intercultural School (SIS) Group, valued at around US$100 million. Actis acquired the asset when it took over funds formerly managed by Abraaj Group. Discussions are at an early stage, and the sale could launch as early as the end of March. SIS Group operates 7 schools in Indonesia and plans to add 4 more facilities, teaching curricula such as Singapore, Cambridge, and International Baccalaureate. The sale is part of the growing demand for private education assets in South-east Asia.

site_title: Apple services including App Store resume after outage for second straight day
summary: Apple services, including App Store, Apple Music, and Podcasts, resumed on Tuesday after a second consecutive day of outage. The outage also affected Mac App Store, Apple Card, and other services. The cause of the outages was not immediately clear, but it was reportedly related to a domain name system (DNS) issue. Apple did not comment on the outage. The company's services had been unavailable since Monday, affecting 11 of its services, including Arcade and Maps.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.3% to 3,361.67. Oceanus and Sembcorp Marine were among the top gainers, while Lendlease Reit's private placement was 3.3 times subscribed. In the US, Wall Street stocks regained their momentum, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.7% and the S&P 500 winning 1.1%. European shares rose, boosted by gains in banks, and Asian markets, including Tokyo and Nikkei 225, also opened higher.

site_title: Ant Group names new regional general manager for South-east Asia
summary: Ant Group, a Chinese fintech giant, has appointed Jia Hang as its new regional general manager for South-east Asia, based in Singapore. This role is part of Ant's strategy to target SMEs in the region with fintech services. Jia has over 20 years of experience in fintech, previously overseeing WorldFirst's payments solution team. Ant's growth in South-east Asia comes as other Chinese tech giants, including Alibaba and Tencent, are restructuring and cutting jobs amid China's crackdown.

site_title: President Halimah approves draw of S$6b from past reserves to fund Singapore's Covid-19 expenditure
summary: President Halimah Yacob has approved the government's plan to draw S$6 billion from past reserves to fund Singapore's ongoing Covid-19 public health expenditure. This is the third consecutive financial year the country is drawing on past reserves to combat the pandemic. The move aims to support areas such as testing, vaccination, and therapeutics, despite preparations to transition to the "new normal".

site_title: IMF downgrades Indonesia's 2022 GDP growth to 5.4%
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has downgraded Indonesia's 2022 GDP growth forecast to 5.4%, down from 5.6% previously. The IMF maintains its 2023 growth forecast at 6% and praised Indonesia's pandemic policy response. The downgrade did not explain the change, citing favourable global commodity prices and easing of Covid-19 restrictions. Indonesia's economy grew 3.7% in 2021, and the IMF urged the central bank to end bond purchases to limit government interest costs on debt.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend gains after Wall Street rally
summary: Asian markets extended gains on Wednesday, following a rally in New York, as investors bet on consumer resilience amid concerns about inflation. The Federal Reserve's plan to hike interest rates to bring inflation under control gave confidence to traders. Analysts, including Seema Shah, said the US economy is strong enough to withstand higher interest rates, which could help reduce inflation. Despite recession risks, equities were seen as positive for the year, with the Nasdaq rallying 2% on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Asian markets extended gains on Wednesday, tracking a rally in New York, on optimism that the Federal Reserve's plan to hike interest rates will help bring inflation under control.

site_title: Core inflation cools to 2.2% in February; price growth mainly driven by cost of cars
summary: Singapore's core inflation cooled to 2.2% in February, below analysts' expectations of 2.6%. The overall consumer price index (CPI) rose 4.3% year-on-year, driven mainly by higher transport costs. However, core inflation is expected to remain stable at 2% to 3% in 2022, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry. Global inflation is forecast to stay high before easing in the second half of the year due to supply-demand mismatches and labor shortages in major trading partners.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks started with gains on March 23, 2022, following a strong performance on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.91% to 22,088.79, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also gained. Tech firms led the advances.

site_title: Mandatory CPF, job stigma keep food delivery riders up at night: study
summary: A study by Blackbox Research found that 93% of Singapore's food delivery riders believe their work is misunderstood, with 93% also stating that the stress and challenges of their work are underestimated by the public. Despite job satisfaction, 45% of riders are not contributing to their CPF Medisave account, citing concerns about mandatory contributions and reduced cash flow. The study suggests that riders value flexibility, control, and earnings, and are concerned about the impact of regulations and policies on their livelihoods, with 44% considering joining a union or association to address these issues.

site_title: Indonesian tycoon's firm to spend US$500m on Canada LNG
summary: Indonesian tycoon Sukanto Tanoto's energy company, Pacific Energy, plans to spend $500 million on a liquefied natural gas (LNG) project in Canada, marking a significant investment in the country's west coast. The project, backed by Woodfibre LNG, aims to export 2.1 million metric tons of gas per year, with completion expected in 2027. This move follows Shell's $40 billion LNG Canada project and comes as European countries seek alternatives to Russian gas due to the ongoing Ukraine conflict.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, following gains on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.49% to 27,629.13, while the Topix index advanced 1.22% to 1,957.34. Investors are monitoring developments in Ukraine.

site_title: Sembmarine unit secures wind turbine installation vessel project
summary: Sembcorp Marine has secured a contract to construct a wind turbine installation vessel, valued but undisclosed, with completion expected in early 2025. The project will be designed in-house in collaboration with the customer, with the company highlighting its focus on sustainability. The contract is not expected to have a material impact on the company's net tangible assets and earnings per share for its 2022 financial year. This project validates Sembmarine's strategy to transform into an innovative engineering solutions provider in the offshore, marine, and energy industries.

site_title: US threat to sanction China is spooking other nations in Asia
summary: US President Joe Biden has warned China that unspecified consequences will follow if China supports Russia in the war. This has raised concerns among smaller Asian nations, including Indonesia and Thailand, which will host the upcoming Group of 20 and Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summits. Indonesian Foreign Minister Retno Marsudi has expressed concern about US threats of secondary sanctions against China, which Jakarta sees as a neutral stance on the war. The summits are months away, but the US-China tensions have created uncertainty for host countries.

site_title: Platform workers caught between autonomy and security in retirement planning
summary: Platform workers in Singapore are facing concerns over retirement planning and security, with 84% of respondents worried about having enough retirement savings. A study found that half of private hire drivers did not contribute to their Central Provident Fund (CPF) and 21% contributed less than 5% of their income. Meanwhile, a Malaysian platform, GoGet, has integrated with the Employee Provident Fund (EPF), allowing workers to contribute a portion of their net income. Platforms in Singapore are collaborating with the Advisory Committee on Platform Workers to address the issue, while emphasizing the importance of flexibility and autonomy. Policymakers must balance the needs of platform workers, consumers, and merchants to create sustainable solutions.

site_title: Katie Haun's crypto VC fund raises US$1.5b to target Web3 startups
summary: Katie Haun's venture capital firm, Haun Ventures, has raised $1.5 billion to invest in Web3 startups, including those focused on blockchain technology, cryptocurrencies, and non-fungible tokens. The firm's early-stage fund is $500 million, while its more mature fund is $1 billion. Haun, a former federal prosecutor, aims to support crypto efforts with everything from hiring to governance, and plans to deploy the funds over at least two years. Despite challenges in the cryptocurrency industry, Haun believes it's a good time to deploy a crypto fund, citing the need for more diverse voices in the space.

site_title: Nomura to book group pre-tax profit of 43m yen from NRI share sale
summary: Nomura Holdings plans to record a group pretax profit of 43 billion yen (S$481.4 million) from the sale of a portion of its stake in affiliate Nomura Research Institute, resulting in the company owning 24.6% of the research affiliate.

site_title: SpaceX president says Ukraine war opened door to Starlink
summary: SpaceX president Gwynne Shotwell says the Ukraine war accelerated the company's plans to offer its Starlink internet service in the war-torn country. Initially close to offering service, the documents weren't signed until Russia's invasion. The company now offers consumer connections in Ukraine, with France and Poland funding shipments. SpaceX also helps deploy a rival satellite constellation from OneWeb, which was forced to end its relationship with Russia's space agency. The company plans to launch tens of thousands of Starlink satellites for low-cost internet services.

site_title: CapitaLand's The Ascott acquires 2 properties for S$190m
summary: CapitaLand's The Ascott Limited has acquired two properties for S$190 million through its private equity fund, Ascott Serviced Residence Global Fund (ASRGF). The first property, a 206-unit serviced residence in Ningbo, China, is expected to open in 2025, while the second property, a 93-unit serviced residence in Amsterdam, is due to be refurbished and relaunched in 2023. The acquisitions bring the fund's total funds under management to S$9 billion, with 10 properties and over 2,000 units held under the fund.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker's 1MDB loot bought 6-carat diamond, gold-plated hourglass
summary: An FBI agent testified at the foreign-bribery trial of ex-Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng, revealing how $35 million siphoned from 1MDB was used to buy a $20,000 gold-plated hourglass and $300,000 in diamond jewelry. The funds were part of a global scheme to steal billions from 1MDB, allegedly masterminded by fugitive financier Jho Low. The US is wrapping up its case after 5 weeks of testimony, with prosecutors seeking to hold Ng accountable for his role in the scheme.

site_title: Expense management firm Jeeves raises US$180m from investors including Tencent, GIC
summary: Expense management firm Jeeves has raised US$180 million in a funding round led by Tencent and GIC, valuing it at US$2.1 billion. The platform, launched through Y Combinator, helps high-growth startups manage expenses, including payroll and vendor payments, and offers credit lines in its operating countries. Jeeves aims to help startups improve their financial structures, with the funding round expected to support the company's expansion plans.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Investment, SPH, SPH Reit, Sembmarine, Lendlease Reit
summary:
Stocks to watch include CapitaLand Investment, SPH, SPH Reit, Sembmarine, and Lendlease Reit. Key developments include: 

- 9CI's lodging business unit, Ascott, acquired 2 properties in China and Netherlands for S$190 million, increasing funds under management to S$9 billion.
- SPH shareholders voted in favor of the Cuscaden Peak takeover offer and proposed distribution of SPH Reit units.
- Sembmarine secured a contract to construct a wind turbine installation vessel.
- Lendlease Reit's private placement was 3.3 times subscribed and priced at S$0.725 per unit.
- EB7 clarified its non-executive chairman's involvement in 18 civil suits, stating no basis for suspicion of fraud or dishonesty.

site_title: Yen slides as Powell sees possibility of 50 bps rate hike
summary: The US dollar rose on Tuesday as Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell suggested a possible half-percentage-point interest rate hike, while the yen fell to a 6-year low due to rising US yields and a deteriorating trade balance. The yen crossed suffered losses, with the euro making a 5-month high against it. US Treasury yields reached multi-year highs, contrasting with the Bank of Japan's ultra-loose monetary policy stance.

site_title: Federal Reserve policymakers call for bigger rate hikes to fight inflation
summary: Federal Reserve officials, including St. Louis Fed President James Bullard and Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester, are calling for bigger interest rate hikes to combat inflation, with some predicting rates could reach 3% this year. Fed Chair Jerome Powell also urged the central bank to raise rates "expeditiously" to control inflation, which has hit a 40-year high. The comments have sparked market expectations of half-point rate hikes in May and June, with traders now betting on a federal funds rate range of 2.25-2.5% by year-end.

site_title: Nato invites Zelensky to address summit via videolink
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has been invited to address a special Nato summit via video link on Thursday to discuss the Russian invasion of his country. Zelensky's spokesman confirmed the invitation, stating the Ukraine leader will seek help in ending the Russian invasion, possibly through providing Ukraine with powerful air defense systems and aviation. The Nato official stated members will examine ways to reinforce their support for Ukraine, coinciding with a G-7 and EU summit also being held in Brussels.

site_title: Hackers hit authentication firm Okta, customers 'may have been impacted'
summary: Okta, a leading authentication firm, reported a security breach in mid-January when a hacker accessed a customer support engineer's computer for five days. The breach's impact on Okta customers is still unclear, but the company believes it is limited to the support engineer's access. Okta is in the process of identifying and contacting potentially affected customers, and some have already taken corrective action to review their security. The incident has raised concerns among experts, with one group, Lapsus$, claiming responsibility and saying its focus was on Okta customers.

site_title: Michelin fetes 'resilient' French cuisine but calls for more women
summary: The Michelin Guide launched its 2022 edition, celebrating the resilience of the French food industry after two difficult years of the pandemic. Two restaurants, Plenitude in Paris and La Villa Madie in Cassis, were awarded three stars, while 87 restaurants received the 'green star' for sustainable cooking. The guide's director called for more women chefs, citing an imbalance in the industry. Despite controversies and challenges, the guide continues to motivate chefs and bring attention to French cuisine, which is experiencing a golden age after a period of stagnation.

site_title: Bored Apes NFT creator Yuga raises US$450m from Andreessen, Animoca
summary: Yuga Labs, creator of Bored Apes Yacht Club NFTs, has raised US$450 million in a funding round led by Andreessen Horowitz and Animoca Brands, valuing the firm at US$4 billion. The funding will support expansion of the development team and joint ventures. This marks the latest development in the growing NFT market, following the debut of ApeCoin, a Bored Apes-related cryptocurrency. The funds will also be used to acquire the intellectual property of other NFT collections, further solidifying Yuga's position in the market.

site_title: US announces deal with UK to end steel, aluminium tariffs
summary: The US and UK have agreed to end tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, which were imposed by former President Donald Trump in 2018. The US Commerce Secretary, Gina Raimondo, stated that the deal eases supply and demand gaps for these products in the US, and reopens the British market to American goods. This move comes after years of trade tensions between the two nations, and is seen as a positive development for the US economy.

site_title: Ordinary Ukrainians do their bit to support the war effort
summary: Ordinary Ukrainians in the city of Mykolaiv are contributing to the war effort by cleaning up debris from Russian bombardments and preparing for the next attack. Residents, staff, and volunteers are using available resources to support the Ukrainian forces fighting against the Russian push towards Odessa.

site_title: US: Indices rebound as Nike lifts consumer stocks
summary: US stocks rebounded on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.7% and the S&P 500 gaining 1.1%, following a strong performance from Nike, which rose 2.2% after beating analyst expectations. Consumer discretionary stocks led the gains, while the yield on the 10-year US Treasury note continued to rise. Meanwhile, markets monitored ongoing developments in Ukraine, with President Volodymyr Zelensky renewing his offer of direct talks with Vladimir Putin.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend gains to two-month high on banking, tech boost
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to a two-month high on Wednesday, driven by gains in banking and technology stocks. Investors weighed US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments on swift interest rate hikes, while a commodity slump capped gains. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 7,380.40 points, its highest level since January 19. Financials and technology stocks led the gains, while metals and mining fell due to weak iron ore prices.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose on Wednesday, led by banking and technology stocks, as investors assess the increased possibility of swift interest rate hikes following hawkish comments from the US Federal Reserve, though a commodity slump capped gains.

site_title: Lendlease Reit private placement 3.3 times subscribed; priced at S$0.725 per unit
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit's private placement to raise at least S$325 million was 3.3 times subscribed, exceeding the manager's target. The private placement, priced at S$0.725 per unit, raised a total of S$400 million for the issue of 551.7 million new units. The funds will be used to partially finance the Reit's S$2.1 billion acquisition of the remaining stake in Jem, with 98.4% of the proceeds allocated to this purpose.

site_title: Fortress Kyiv holds breath ahead of feared Russian assault
summary: Kyiv, Ukraine, remains under curfew as Russia's 27-day invasion stalls, with residents taking advantage of the break to prepare and catch their breath. Despite fears of a Russian assault, morale remains high among the city's defenders, including soldiers and volunteer fighters. Many residents, mostly women and children, have fled, but those remaining are mostly the elderly and those determined to defend the city. The city's streets are filled with sandbags, anti-tank hedgehogs, and checkpoints, with residents expressing hope that the Russians will not be able to take the city.

site_title: Oil edges lower as EU looks less likely to ban Russian oil
summary: Oil prices edged lower on Tuesday as European Union nations appeared unlikely to agree to join the US in a Russian oil embargo. EU foreign ministers were split on the ban, with some countries, including Germany, citing dependence on Russian fossil fuels. The move would likely have a significant impact on the German economy, leading the EU to back away from the ban.

site_title: FDA probe of US Abbott facility finds quality control issues
summary: The US FDA has found quality control issues at an Abbott Laboratories facility in Michigan, where powdered baby formula was produced. The inspection revealed Cronobacter sakazakii, a bacteria that can cause severe foodborne illness in infants, on surfaces in some areas of the facility. The FDA probe was prompted by complaints that Abbott's products had caused bacterial infections, leading to a recall of certain formulas last month. The facility lacks a control system to prevent microbe contamination and personnel did not wear necessary protective apparel. Abbott can address the issues, according to the FDA.

images.alt_text: An inspection at the Abbott Laboratories facility in Sturgis, Michigan found a harmful bacteria on surfaces in some areas of its powdered baby formula production, the US health regulator said on on Tuesday.

site_title: To counter China influence, US names envoy to lead Pacific Island talks
summary: The US has appointed former senior diplomat Joseph Yun as Special Presidential Envoy for Compact Negotiations to lead talks with three Pacific Island countries - the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, and Palau - amid concerns of China's growing influence in the region. Renewal talks on the Compacts of Free Association, which govern US economic assistance, have stalled since 2020. Yun's appointment signals the US's commitment to countering China's efforts in the Pacific Islands, where the US maintains a significant military foothold.

site_title: Singapore GDP likely to grow but recession, stagflation not ruled out: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow but a recession or stagflation cannot be ruled out due to uncertainties from the Ukraine crisis. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated the country's baseline assumption is to continue growing, but an escalation in the war could affect supply chains, inflation, and global growth. Singapore President Halimah Yacob also warned that the country's earlier projection of 3-5% economic growth may be affected. Wong emphasized the need for Singapore to transform its economy into a more connected, innovative, and resilient one to prepare for future challenges.

site_title: Putin keeps loyalty of Russian political elite despite outcry
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is maintaining the loyalty of the country's political elite despite international outcry over the Ukraine invasion. Despite criticism from artists, oligarchs, and even some billionaires, Putin's inner circle and key political figures remain united. Experts attribute this to Putin's cultivated system of super-loyalists who share his world view, as well as fear of dissent. There has been no apparent split within the ruling class, with only a few exceptions, including a former Kremlin aide who spoke out against the war.

site_title: Validus acquires Citi's small-business unit loan portfolio
summary: Validus, a Singapore-based fintech, has acquired Citi's small-business unit loan portfolio, marking the first time a South-east Asian fintech has acquired an established bank's loan portfolio and customer base. The deal is expected to bolster Validus' top line revenue and customer base, and expand its growing loan book. The acquisition follows Citi's closure of its CitiBusiness unit last August, and Validus plans to double its loan disbursements to US$2 billion in the next year.

site_title: SPH shareholders vote in favour of Cuscaden takeover offer
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) shareholders have voted overwhelmingly in favour of a takeover offer from consortium Cuscaden Peak, with 89.19% voting in favour. The offer includes an all-cash consideration of S$2.36 per share and a distribution-in-specie of SPH Reit units. Following court sanction, shareholders will choose between the all-cash consideration or the cash and Reit units consideration, with a mandatory general offer for SPH Reit expected to be triggered if Cuscaden owns more than 30% of the Reit.

site_title: Cryptocurrency failing to take advantage of crisis
summary: Cryptocurrency has largely failed to capitalize on the current global crisis, despite being touted as a potential solution for liberation from fiat currencies and state-controlled financial infrastructures. True believers, speculators, and pragmatists are all disappointed, as Bitcoin's artificially controlled scarcity and immunity to inflation have not led to its prosperity. The war in Ukraine, which could have been a test bed for cryptocurrencies, has instead shown crypto's limitations, leaving many to question its potential as a borderless and politically neutral payments instrument.

site_title: 6.6-magnitude earthquake strikes off Taiwan: USGS
summary: A 6.6-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of Taiwan early Wednesday, according to the US Geological Survey. The quake, which occurred 70 km south of Hualien City, had a depth of 10 km and was followed by a 6.1-magnitude aftershock. Despite initial reports, there were no immediate fatalities or injuries, and no major damage was reported. The USGS gave a "green" ranking to the threat posed by the quake, predicting a low likelihood of casualties or damage.

site_title: Banks not a one-way bet; look at the big picture
summary: Banks are often viewed as a reliable investment option, but they can be cyclical businesses tied to the economic cycle, making them vulnerable to downturns. Banks' solvency is based on perceived solvency, and a sudden withdrawal of funds can lead to collapse. Despite this, well-managed banks can be a good long-term bet. Key metrics to consider when evaluating bank shares include the price-to-book multiple and dividend yield. Currently, some well-known banks in Singapore are trading at a discount to their book values and offer favorable dividend yields, making them potentially attractive investment opportunities, but it's essential to consider the outlook for the global economy.

site_title: NWP Property, CRE Asia form JV to develop big-box logistics in Indonesia
summary: NWP Property and CRE Asia have formed a joint venture to develop a big-box logistics platform in Indonesia, with a secured warehouse in Jakarta. Construction is expected to start in the second half of 2022. The partnership aims to address the undersupply of modern logistics real estate in Indonesia, with experts citing a significant gap between Indonesia's warehouse space and that of its industrial peers. The joint venture is backed by global private equity firm Warburg Pincus, led by Indonesia entrepreneur Bonny Setiawan.

images.alt_text: NWP Property's chief executive officer Timothy Daly said the supply of warehouse space in Indonesia is "meaningfully behind" its industrial peers. China and Japan, for example, have 10 to 40 times the warehouse space per capita compared to Indonesia.

site_title: Nvidia unveils data-centre chips aimed at stretching its lead in AI
summary: Nvidia unveiled new data-center chips aimed at expanding its lead in artificial intelligence. The company's focus is on growth through new products rather than aggressive stock buybacks, according to CFO Colette Kress. Nvidia has bought back $2 billion in stock this quarter, but hasn't increased its budget for repurchases. The company has $5 billion of buyback authorization left. This move comes after Nvidia walked away from a $40 billion Arm acquisition plan in February due to regulatory opposition.

images.alt_text: Nvidia told investors it's focused on maintaining growth with new products, including speedier data-centre chips, rather than embarking on more aggressive stock-buyback plans as some shareholders had hoped.

site_title: Russia-Ukraine conflict: Limited impact on SGD bonds
summary: The Russia-Ukraine conflict has had a limited impact on Singapore-dollar (SGD) bond markets, with most banks having a manageable exposure to Russia. Societe Generale's exposure to Russia is estimated to have a 50 basis point impact on its CET1 ratio, but the bank remains above regulatory levels. Agribusinesses, such as Olam International, also have exposure to Russia and Ukraine but have diversified sourcing and are able to substitute contracts with other countries, making the impact manageable. Bond prices of sectors affected by the conflict have come down due to negative sentiment, but the analyst maintains a positive view on Additional Tier 1 notes.

site_title: Most central banks not doing enough to curb inflation: survey
summary: Most central banks in developed markets are not doing enough to combat inflation, according to a survey of 886 investors. 73% of respondents believe that monetary authorities haven't adequately addressed inflation, with value stocks emerging as the top hedge against rising prices, garnering 35% of the vote. Inflation-linked bonds and gold were distant runners-up. The survey also found that European investors are less likely to prefer value stocks, with a preference for gold and oil instead.

site_title: Singapore's net zero emissions target by 2050 for power sector 'realistic': report
summary: Singapore's net-zero emissions target by 2050 for the power sector is deemed "realistic" by a report commissioned by the Energy Market Authority. The report suggests the country can achieve this goal through a diversified supply mix, including electricity imports and low-carbon hydrogen. The committee recommends prioritizing renewable imports, developing a hydrogen supply chain, and creating a multi-layered grid to manage distributed energy resources. The report acknowledges that the energy transition will be complex and uncertain, requiring Singapore to stay nimble and manage trade-offs to achieve sustainable and secure energy.

images.alt_text: As an "alternative energy-disadvantaged" country, Singapore is expected to bank on electricity imports and low-carbon hydrogen as it embarks on the path to decarbonise and hit net-zero emissions by mid century, showed a latest energy market report.

site_title: China to push back monetary easing to next quarter: survey
summary: China is unlikely to cut its reserve requirement ratio (RRR) in the first quarter, with only 9 of 21 economists surveyed by Bloomberg predicting a reduction. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) is expected to lower the key policy interest rate on its 1-year medium-term lending facility by 10 basis points in the second quarter, and forecast a reduction in the de facto benchmark lending rate by the same magnitude. Analysts attribute the slowdown in China's economy to regional lockdowns and a persistent slump in the housing market.

images.alt_text: Analysts continue to expect the People's Bank of China to lower the key policy interest rate on its 1-year medium-term lending facility by 10 basis points in the second quarter.

site_title: Pakistan's economic prospects looking up
summary: Pakistan's economic growth outlook is improving, with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) projecting a 4% GDP growth rate for the current fiscal year, according to Pakistan's High Commissioner in Singapore, Rukhsana Afzaal. The country's domestic demand is expected to rise, driven by investment and expenditure reform, while inflationary pressures will be tempered by government measures. Export growth is also expected to accelerate, driven by a recovery in economic activity and trade with major partners. Remittances are likely to remain high, helping to narrow the current account deficit.

site_title: Surbana Jurong unit bags new projects
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singapore-based business, has secured two new hydropower projects in Pakistan's Swat district, funded by the World Bank. The estimated cost is US$600 million, with the projects expected to provide clean energy and contribute to Pakistan's energy mix. This marks a significant expansion of Surbana Jurong's presence in Pakistan, with the company having a strong presence in the country's infrastructure development. The projects are part of Pakistan's efforts to reduce reliance on fossil fuels and increase renewable energy production.

images.alt_text: Hari Poologasundram, CEO SMEC and CEO International, Surbana Jurong, says: "SMEC has been working in Pakistan for over 40 years, primarily on projects funded by international funding agencies."

site_title: Europe: Banks lift shares after lacklustre start to week
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Tuesday, boosted by gains in banks amid hawkish comments from US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, who suggested aggressive interest rate hikes to combat inflation. European banks jumped 2.5%, while insurers and autos rose 2.0% and 1.6% respectively. Money markets now price around 50 basis points of ECB rate hikes by the end of the year. The Stoxx 600 index has fallen 6% this year, but the FTSE 100 has outperformed with a 1.1% gain.

images.alt_text: European shares rose on Tuesday, boosted by gains in banks on prospect of aggressive interest rate hikes following hawkish comments by US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell.

site_title: Russia-Ukraine war: Taking heed of geopolitical risks and potential hotspots
summary: The ongoing Russia-Ukraine war is expected to have far-reaching indirect effects, including disruptions to global grain supply and food inflation. Ukraine, known as the "bread basket of Europe," supplies wheat to developing countries across Africa, the Middle East, and Central Asia. The war may lead to a failed Ukrainian wheat harvest, causing food shortages and higher prices in countries reliant on Russian and Ukrainian grain imports, such as Benin, Congo, Egypt, Qatar, and Lebanon. This could compound existing food inflation, potentially leading to civil unrest and social instability in vulnerable nations.

site_title: China Eastern crash could set back Boeing's China recovery, return of MAX aircraft
summary: China's deadly crash of a China Eastern Airlines 737-800, which occurred on March 21, could set back Boeing's efforts to regain ground in China's aircraft market. The 737-800 does not have the 737 MAX crash equipment, but Chinese passengers and a national regulator known for strict safety requirements may still be deterred. This could impact Boeing's delivery of over 140 737 MAX jets to Chinese customers, potentially hindering the company's recovery in the world's largest aircraft market.

site_title: Steep oil price, widening yield gap flash more weakness for yen
summary: Japan's currency, the yen, has breached 120 per US dollar for the first time in 6 years, with a 4.5% fall in less than 3 weeks. Analysts predict the yen could reach 123 per dollar by September. A widening yield gap between Japan and US bonds, as well as high oil prices, are contributing to the yen's decline. The Bank of Japan's ultra-loose monetary policy is also limiting the currency's ability to recover.

site_title: Asia's retail industry is eclipsing the rest of the world's, thanks to e-commerce
summary: Asia's retail industry is rapidly growing, driven by e-commerce, with the region accounting for 3/4 of worldwide retail growth and 30% of online growth. Between 2014 and 2019, Asia's retail sales growth was 4 times higher than the rest of the world. The pandemic accelerated this transformation, and the region's digital economy is expected to continue growing. Omnichannel retailing is becoming the norm, with physical stores evolving to support e-commerce operations. Reliable connectivity is crucial for the region's retail ecosystem, as it enables seamless digital experiences and maximizes opportunities opened up by e-commerce.

site_title: Japan land prices rebound in 2021 amid Covid economic recovery
summary: Japan's land prices rebounded 0.6% in 2021, following a 0.5% drop in 2020, as the country's economy recovered from the COVID-19 pandemic. Residential land prices rose 0.5%, driven by a recovery in consumer sentiment and low interest rates. Commercial land prices increased 0.4%, while industrial land prices rose 2.0%, marking the sixth year of growth. The rebound was led by demand for condominiums in suburban areas, particularly in major regional cities.

site_title: After impressive IPO debut, Malaysia's Farm Fresh eyes regional expansion
summary: Malaysia's dairy producer Farm Fresh made an impressive debut on Bursa Malaysia, raising RM1 billion and surging 38% in its first day of trading. The company's CEO, Loi Tuan Ee, announced plans to expand the business to Hong Kong, Indonesia, and the Philippines within the next year, with a focus on partnerships and exports. Farm Fresh operates 5 dairy farms and 2 processing facilities, producing 137 million litres of finished products annually. Analysts predict the company's regional expansion will drive growth, with a 3-year earnings compound annual growth rate of 16.9%.

site_title: GoTo casts wider net for investors as it extends IPO deadline
summary: GoTo, a merger between Gojek and Tokopedia, has extended its IPO deadline to March 24, allowing 600,000 Indonesian drivers to become shareholders. The move has received a mixed response from market players, who are concerned the IPO may not be as exciting as initially anticipated. The company's shares are expected to rebound after a recent $2.2 billion sell-off.

site_title: Mariupol being pounded into 'ashes of a dead land': council
summary: Russia is pounding the Ukrainian port city of Mariupol into "ashes of a dead land," according to the city's council, with hundreds of thousands trapped and no access to basic necessities. The city, home to 400,000 before the war, has been sealed off for weeks, with daily shelling and no independent journalists allowed in. Ukraine denies Russia's claims of targeting civilians, while the US accuses Moscow of planning to use chemical and biological weapons. The conflict has displaced nearly a quarter of Ukraine's population, with global food prices soaring due to Ukraine's significant grain exports.

site_title: Singapore mortgages may rise as much as 0.75% this year following Fed hikes
summary: Mortgage rates in Singapore may rise 3 times this year, with projections suggesting a 0.8% 3-month Sora by July and possibly crossing 1% by end-2022. The US Federal Reserve's commitment to double down on inflation has influenced Singapore's interest rates, with DBS senior rates strategist Eugene Leow predicting significant increases in floating mortgage rates. Local banks have not confirmed specific interest rate hikes, but expect increases in the coming quarters. Mortgage advisers advise consumers to review affordability of home purchases given rising rates.

site_title: Sanctions on Russia are different this time
summary: The US has imposed severe sanctions on Russia, exceeding previous multilateral sanctions' potency. Despite Russia's military advances in Ukraine, the sanctions are expected to ultimately harm the Russian economy. US President Joe Biden warned Russian President Vladimir Putin in December that severe sanctions would impose a "terrible price". The sanctions' effectiveness remains to be seen, but they mark a significant escalation in the global response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Tuan Sing, Mitsubishi Estate to develop first phase of Indonesia mall for S$90m
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings and Mitsubishi Estate have partnered to develop the first phase of a luxury outlet mall in Karawang, Indonesia, valued at S$90 million. Construction will begin in Q2 2022, with a target opening date in Q4 2023. The 9-hectare site, The Grand Outlet - East Jakarta, will feature 180 shops, 1,000 car park spaces, and a leasable area of 26,000 sq m. Indonesian retail giant Mitra Adiperkasa is among the interested parties to occupy the development, which aims to tap into Indonesia's rising affluent consumer population.

site_title: Singapore could potentially include nuclear in energy supply mix
summary: Singapore may consider nuclear energy as part of its path to net-zero emissions by 2050, according to a report commissioned by the Energy Market Authority. The report highlights geothermal energy as a possible focus, and in one scenario, low-carbon hydrogen dominates Singapore's energy supply mix. Nuclear energy could emerge as a long-term option, with newer designs being safer and more efficient. However, more research is needed to determine its viability in Singapore. The report recommends monitoring developments in new supply technologies to support the country's decarbonization efforts.

site_title: Sri Lanka deploys troops as fuel shortage sparks protests
summary: Sri Lanka has deployed troops to petrol stations amid a severe fuel shortage, sparking sporadic protests. Thousands of motorists are queuing daily for scarce fuel, leading to rolling electricity blackouts and shortages of essential goods. The deployment follows a stabbing murder and reports of fuel hoarding. Sri Lanka is grappling with its worst economic meltdown in over 7 decades, with the government seeking a bailout from the International Monetary Fund. The country's financial crisis stems from a critical shortfall of foreign currency, leaving traders unable to finance imports.

site_title: Putin wants a decisive victory, unlikely to compromise on Ukraine: experts
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is unlikely to compromise on Ukraine, aiming for a decisive victory in the ongoing conflict. Experts believe Putin's priority is regime stability, making it difficult for him to accept a defeat. China is caught in a delicate position, trying to balance its relationship with Putin while maintaining its own economic interests. Despite the negative impact on Asian stock markets, China has opportunities to invest in sectors such as consumption upgrades, research & development, and renewable energy.

site_title: Rare copy of first Marvel comic sells for US$2.4m
summary: A rare copy of the first Marvel comic book, Marvel Comics No 1, published in 1939, sold for $2.4 million at auction. The "pay copy" version, annotated by the publisher with payments owed to illustrators, is highly valuable due to its rarity and historical significance. The comic book features early Marvel characters, including Namor the Sub-Mariner and the Human Torch, and is in remarkable condition considering its age. The buyer, a comic collector in his 40s, purchased the book to add to his collection.

site_title: Businessman from Pakistan thrives here
summary: Shamsher Zaman, managing director of Linkers (Far East) Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based company, has been thriving in the country for over four decades since immigrating from Pakistan. Zaman attributes Singapore's strategic location, business-friendly environment, and innovative technology to the company's success. LFE has expanded globally, doing business with over 40 countries, and Zaman holds various public positions, including Ambassador to Jordan and chairman of the Singapore Business Federation's Middle East Business Group. He emphasizes the potential for economic growth between Singapore and Pakistan, citing the country's growing middle class and strategic location.

site_title: Do we really need a decarbonisation R&D bunker levy?
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) is considering a proposal for a levy on bunker purchases to fund research and development (R&D) for decarbonization of the shipping sector. The proposal, supported by 30 IMO member states, aims to establish an International Maritime Research and Development Fund (IMRF) to support GHG reduction projects in developing and climate-vulnerable countries. The levy would allocate $50 million annually to support these projects. The IMO's Marine Environment Protection Committee (MEPC) is expected to make a final decision in June.

site_title: Avoid commodity price volatility by buying into Indonesia's 'immune' stocks: UOBKH
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) is recommending investors to avoid commodity price volatility by buying into Indonesia's finance, retail, healthcare, and technology sectors. The research house notes that commodities such as wheat, coal, and oil have risen by over 50% since the Russia-Ukraine conflict, affecting companies in these sectors. Analyst Stevanus Juanda suggests investing in banks, healthcare companies like Kalbe Farma, and telcos like Telkom Indonesia, as they are less exposed to commodity price fluctuations. Juanda expects high commodity prices to persist throughout 2022 due to supply delays.

site_title: China Pakistan Economic Corridor on track despite pandemic
summary: Pakistan's China Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) project is on track despite the pandemic, with over $25 billion invested and 75,000 jobs created. Work is progressing on motorways, transit, and transmission lines. Completed components include the Rashakai and Dhabeji Special Economic Zones, which have created 200,000 jobs, and 10 power projects with a total installed capacity of 5,320 MW. China is supporting Pakistan in attracting international investors, with the Gwadar Port and Free Zone showing satisfactory progress. The project has also contributed significantly to Pakistan's power supply.

site_title: Russian artist and Ukrainian in Bali collaborate on message of unity
summary: A Russian artist and a Ukrainian villa owner in Bali have collaborated on a massive 960 sq m calligraphy piece promoting unity and peace. The artwork, titled "United World," is written in six languages and spans across the rooftops of nine buildings. The project was conceived before the war in Ukraine, but its message has taken on greater significance. Both artists, Pokras Lampas and Alex Shtefan, expressed shock and concern over the conflict, emphasizing the need for unity and peaceful negotiation. The artwork serves as a cultural statement about people coming together.

images.alt_text: Russian artist Pokras Lampas (right) and Ukrainian Alex Shtefan pose with one of nine of Pokras' calligraphy artwork on the rooftop of Shtefan's villas in Bali.

site_title: S&P downgrades 4 Thai banks on structural issues, fragile economic recovery
summary: S&P Global Ratings downgraded the credit ratings of four Thai banks, Siam Commercial Bank, Kasikornbank, Krung Thai Bank, and TMBThanachart Bank, due to increased systematic risks and fragile economic recovery. The ratings were lowered to "BBB" or "BBB-" from "BBB+" or "BBB", respectively. The agency expects high leverage among borrowers to persist and regulatory relaxation to delay resolving structural issues, with non-performing loans rising to 5% over the next 24 months.

site_title: Repercussions of the Russia-Ukraine conflict for asset allocation
summary: The Russia-Ukraine conflict has led to a rise in raw material prices, potentially causing temporary spikes in Brent oil to US$140. The conflict has impacted the euro area's economic outlook, with higher inflation and lower growth expected, particularly in the energy sector. The European Central Bank and Federal Reserve have decided to raise interest rates to combat inflation, while Asian economies, especially India, the Philippines, and Thailand, are vulnerable to higher oil and food prices and a stronger US dollar. The conflict has also led to a shift in the equity market, with defensive growth stocks such as healthcare and energy sectors performing well, while valuations are under pressure.

site_title: Ho Bee should inject its investment properties into a Reit
summary: Ho Bee Land, a Singaporean property group, has invested £718 million (S$1.3 billion) in London's office tower, The Scalpel, despite market predictions of office tower hollowing out due to remote work and Brexit. The investment brings Ho Bee's total London investment to over £2 billion. The Scalpel has a secure 10-year income with a yield of 4%. Ho Bee's net asset value has risen 6.2% annually, but the company trades at a 51% discount to its end-2021 net asset value, raising questions about its value. Injecting its properties into a Reit may be a strategic move to grow its business and benefit shareholders.

site_title: Beijing could emerge as a winner from the war
summary: US officials criticize China for not joining a diplomatic and economic campaign against Russia over Ukraine. However, China has no incentives to join the US against Russia, as the US approach has weakened relations between Beijing and Moscow. China has denounced international sanctions imposed on Russia and has called for an end to the war, similar to India. China's economy is exposed to the fallout of the war, including rising food and energy prices, but Beijing recognizes the importance of trade and investment ties with Western economies. China's interest lies in a military stalemate, allowing it to emerge as a winner in the crisis.

site_title: Japan's record budget clears parliament, paves way for debate on fresh stimulus
summary: Japan's record $900 billion budget for the next fiscal year has cleared parliament, paving the way for Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's administration to consider another stimulus package to address rising household bills. The government had previously approved a $1.2 trillion package for fiscal 2022, and lawmakers have voiced few complaints about the huge spending to combat the economic strain from the Covid-19 pandemic. Analysts expect the government to openly debate the likelihood of another spending package, with opposition parties calling for a fresh stimulus worth $20 trillion yen.

site_title: China Evergrande to announce restructuring proposal by end-July
summary: China Evergrande Group, the world's most indebted property developer, plans to announce a debt restructuring proposal by the end of July. The proposal aims to address Evergrande's over $300 billion in liabilities and has drawn state intervention to quell market concern over a disorderly collapse. The plan involves returning land used as collateral to the Guangzhou government and has the potential to be replicated for other indebted Chinese property firms. The move is seen as a model for local government and creditors working together to resolve Evergrande's debt repayment issue.

site_title: Manchester City top Deloitte Money League for first time
summary: Manchester City has topped the Deloitte Football Money League for the first time, becoming the world's highest revenue-generating club in the 2020-21 season. This marks a significant shift, as previous leaders Barcelona have dropped to fourth place, their lowest position since 2013-14. The COVID-19 pandemic had a notable impact on the 2020-21 season, affecting revenue for many clubs. Manchester City's achievement is a testament to the club's strong financial performance.

images.alt_text: Manchester City, the English Premier League (EPL) champions and current leaders, are only the fourth club to top the Money League after Barcelona, Real Madrid and Manchester United.

site_title: Alibaba's upscaled buyback may be a sign of things to come
summary: Alibaba's $25 billion share buyback program may spark a wave of similar moves by other cash-rich Chinese internet firms, boosting investor confidence. The move comes as the sector faces challenges, with shares nearly halving in value since their peak. Analysts predict Tencent and Xiaomi may follow suit, with some companies looking to reduce cash positions to boost stock value. The news could be a sign of a turnaround in the battered sector, which has seen investors buy up dips in US technology stocks despite rising bond yields.

site_title: Rising lithium prices won't hurt EV momentum: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse analysts believe rising lithium prices won't hinder electric vehicle (EV) momentum, as automakers will lower prices to maintain growth. The bank forecasts 73% of global EVs by 2030 and 28% CAGR in global battery demand. To combat cost inflation, automakers are switching to cheaper lithium iron phosphate (LFP) batteries, expected to increase LFP market share to 67% in China by 2025. Companies with strong cost control, such as Contemporary Amperex Technology Co Limited (CATL), are preferred, as they can defend margins amidst rising raw material costs.

site_title: Lagarde says cryptos being used to evade Russian sanctions
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde stated that there are signs Russians are using cryptocurrencies and stablecoins to bypass sanctions over the war in Ukraine. She noted that this is the highest level of such transactions since 2021. The US and European Union have imposed penalties on major banks and restrictions on Russia's elite to limit its ability to do business in dollars and other international currencies. Industry experts and regulators warn that cryptocurrencies could represent a "major loophole" in the financial system and be used for sanctions evasion.

site_title: Two years on, Covid pandemic needs a greater global response
summary: Two years after the World Health Organization declared Covid-19 a pandemic, critics argue that key policy mistakes, such as vaccine inequality, contributed to the crisis' length. Former UK PM Gordon Brown and Tony Blair have called for greater global response, including sharing vaccine doses with developing nations, to tackle the ongoing crisis. The WHO warns that the pandemic is likely at its mid-point and urges policymakers to act on the lesson that no one is safe until everyone is safe to reverse the crisis' trajectory.

site_title: Japanese turn down heat, lights to avoid power cut after quake
summary: Japan temporarily reduced energy consumption after a magnitude 7.4 earthquake last week, turning off neon signs, dimming lights, and lowering thermostats to avoid power cuts. The government warned that up to 3 million households could lose power if usage rates didn't come down. However, the country is likely to avoid blackouts, with temperatures expected to rise and more solar power generation added. Residents responded to the call, with many businesses and individuals taking steps to conserve energy.

images.alt_text: Neon signs were turned off, lights dimmed and thermostats dialled down in Japan on Tuesday (Mar 22) after the government issued an urgent call to save energy, warning of blackouts after an earthquake last week caused a serious power shortage.

site_title: Streaming drives 2021 recorded music sales to record US$26b
summary: Global recorded music revenues reached a record US$25.9 billion in 2021, driven by a 18.5% increase in paid subscription streaming to US$12.3 billion, accounting for 65% of total revenues. Physical format revenues rose 16.1% to US$5 billion, marking the first growth in 20 years. Streaming growth was highest in the Middle East and North Africa, with Latin America, US, and Canada also seeing significant increases. The report attributed the growth to record companies engaging locally to support music cultures and emerging music ecosystems.

site_title: Nordic Group bags S$151.6m worth of contracts
summary: Nordic Group secured S$151.6 million in contracts through its divisions and newly-acquired Starburst Holdings subsidiary. The contracts were won from new and repeat customers in Singapore, Malaysia, China, and the Middle East. This marks a significant achievement for the systems integration solutions provider.

site_title: China developers to miss earnings deadlines
summary: China's Hong Kong-listed property developers, including Evergrande Group, Sunac China Holdings, and Shimao Group Holdings, are likely to miss their earnings deadlines due to audit delays caused by the latest Covid-19 wave. The firms face a March 31 deadline to file audited 2021 results, with shares at risk of being halted if they fail to meet the deadline. Evergrande will hold a global investor call to brief on its restructuring framework, and Shimao and Sunac plan to release unaudited results on March 31. The delays raise concerns about transparency and governance.

site_title: Europe is heading for a diesel shortage
summary: Europe is facing a potential diesel shortage due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with exports of crude oil and petroleum products decreasing by 2-2.5 million barrels a day. European diesel stockpiles are expected to fall to their lowest level since 2018, and 500,000 tons of Russian diesel exports are at risk in March. Diesel prices in Europe have surged, and suppliers are shying away from dealing with Russian energy products, leading to potential cutbacks in Russian production and further tightening of the market.

site_title: No survivors found after China plane crash: Aviation authority
summary: Chinese authorities have found no survivors from a China Eastern jet crash that killed all 132 people on board. The Boeing 737-800 NG plane crashed into a mountainside in southern China on Monday, with pilots failing to respond to air-traffic controller calls. The cause of the crash is still under investigation, with Chinese officials ordering a two-week safety review. This is China's first fatal commercial airliner crash since 2010 and the deadliest in nearly three decades. The incident has led to a grounding of China Eastern's 737-800 fleet and cancellations of thousands of domestic flights.

images.alt_text: People making offerings to victims in a field close to the entrance of Simen village, near the site where a China Eastern Airlines Boeing 737-800 plane flying from Kunming to Guangzhou crashed.

site_title: IHH Healthcare offers to buy Ramsay-Sime Darby JV for RM 5.7b
summary: Malaysian hospital group Ramsay-Sime Darby Health Care (RSDHC) is being offered RM5.67 billion (S$1.83 billion) by IHH Healthcare on a cash-free, debt-free basis. The acquisition is a 50:50 joint venture between Australian Ramsay Health Care and Malaysian Sime Darby Holdings. IHH has submitted a preliminary proposal, with discussions ongoing. Analysts see the deal as complementary to both companies' portfolios, with potential synergies and growth opportunities. The acquisition would mark IHH's first foray into Indonesia and drive medical tourism referrals.

site_title: Asean poised for rebound, but growth fragile due to uncertainties, risks: OECD
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is expected to experience economic growth of 5.2% in 2022 and 2023, despite uncertainties and risks from the Russia-Ukraine invasion, Covid-19, inflation, and supply chain disruptions. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) projects varying growth rates across Asean member countries, ranging from -0.3% in Myanmar to 7.0% in the Philippines. The OECD's report emphasizes the fragility of Asean's economic recovery due to these external factors.

site_title: STI declines 0.2 per cent, bucking Asia rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.2% to 3,350.17, bucking the Asia-wide rally. Despite regional gains, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 3.2%, Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 1.5%, and South Korea's Kospi rose 0.9%. Local bank stocks, however, fell, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC down 0.5%, 0.2%, and 0.3% respectively. Jardine Cycle & Carriage was the top gainer, while Jardine Matheson Holdings was the biggest loser, closing 1.4% lower.

site_title: Singapore's productivity grew 3.9% per annum from 2019 to 2021 despite Covid-19: DPM Heng
summary: Singapore's productivity grew 3.9% per annum from 2019 to 2021, driven by economic transformation efforts, despite disruptions from Covid-19. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat attributed this growth to the effectiveness of Industry Transformation Maps (ITMs), which enabled businesses to adapt and respond to the changing operating environment. Heng emphasized the need to strengthen resilience with openness, innovation, sustainability, and trust, outlining four key attributes to achieve this.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as bank stocks, Nike gain
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Tuesday, with bank shares rising due to bets of aggressive interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve, and Nike gaining after upbeat quarterly results. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.09%, the S&P 500 gained 0.18%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.20%.

site_title: Second Abramovich superyacht docks in sanctions-free Turkey
summary: Roman Abramovich's second superyacht has docked in a sanctions-free Turkish resort, amid efforts by the billionaire to invest in Turkey due to Western sanctions. The move comes as Turkey opposes sanctions imposed by Nato allies, potentially setting it up as a safe haven for Russians seeking to preserve assets. Abramovich's investment plans follow Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with Western governments targeting Russian oligarchs with sanctions.

site_title: Daily new Covid-19 cases in Singapore at 13,166, down from 15,851 last Tuesday
summary: Singapore reported 13,166 new Covid-19 cases on Tuesday, down from 15,851 last Tuesday. Hospitalizations fell to 1,023 cases, and 6 deaths were reported. The Covid-19 weekly infection growth rate remained below one for the 21st consecutive day at 0.74. Of the local cases, 11,323 were detected through antigen rapid tests, and 1,602 through PCR tests. The total number of deaths is now 1,214, and 95% of the eligible population has completed the full vaccination regimen.

site_title: Philippines to allow full foreign ownership in telecoms, airlines, shipping
summary: Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte has approved an amendment to a 1935 law allowing full foreign ownership in key sectors such as telecoms, airlines, shipping, and railways. The move aims to boost competition, create jobs, and expand the economy. Foreign ownership caps will be removed in sectors like telecoms and shipping, while remaining in areas like power transmission and water pipelines. Lawmakers estimate the move will attract around $5.7 billion in foreign direct investment over the next five years, benefiting consumers and promoting economic recovery.

site_title: Caviar off menu as Kyiv chefs serve free meals
summary: In response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, several restaurants in Kyiv are serving free meals to those struggling to access food, including dozens of elderly individuals. Chernomorka fish restaurant, a downtown eatery, has been serving hearty chicken and rice meals instead of its usual menu items, which were previously off the menu due to the invasion. The initiative aims to contribute to Ukraine's war effort and provide assistance to those affected by the ongoing conflict.

site_title: Lendlease Reit to raise at least S$573.8m to fund Jem acquisition
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit (Lendlease Reit) is proposing to raise at least S$573.8 million through a private placement and non-renounceable preferential offering to partly finance the acquisition of the remaining interest in Jem mall. The deal will provide a 10.5% distribution per unit accretion and significantly increase the Reit's portfolio net lettable area by 70%. The transaction, valued at S$2.1 billion, has been approved by Lendlease Corporation, which has given an irrevocable undertaking to subscribe to the preferential offering units.

site_title: Robinhood ups fintech competition with new debit card launch
summary: Robinhood launched a debit card allowing users to invest spare change and receive weekly bonuses. The cash card, offered by Robinhood Money, lets users round up change to invest in assets of their choice. The feature, similar to Chime and Acorns Grow, aims to capitalize on the younger generation's preference for debit cards and digital spending. Users can keep separate accounts for investing and spending, and the service is free of charge. The move expands Robinhood's consumer finance offerings and heats up competition with fintech giants.

site_title: Ukraine makes plea as bombs hit Mariupol, turning it into 'ashes of a dead land'
summary: Russia has intensified its bombing campaign on the Ukrainian port city of Mariupol, leaving it in a state of "ashes of a dead land" according to the city council. Hundreds of thousands of residents are trapped under near-constant shelling, with no access to basic necessities. Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky has denounced Russia's actions as a "special military operation" to disarm Ukraine, while the West calls it a false pretext for war. The conflict has displaced nearly a quarter of Ukraine's population and caused global food prices to surge.

site_title: Xiaomi beats profit estimates after holiday quarter sales gain
summary: Xiaomi surpassed profit estimates by 40% with adjusted net income reaching 4.47 billion yuan in the last quarter of 2021, driven by increased sales of smartphones with upgraded features. The company's global smartphone shipments rose 3.9% despite component shortages and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Xiaomi's premium smartphone lineup and expansion into emerging markets are expected to fuel growth. The company is also investing in electric vehicles, with a $10 billion project in China.

site_title: Putin keeps loyalty of Russian political elite despite outcry
summary: President Vladimir Putin is maintaining the loyalty of Russia's political elite despite international outcry over the Ukraine invasion and sanctions. Russian artists and billionaire oligarchs have publicly criticized the war, but no dissent has been reported from within Putin's inner circle or among key political figures in the country. This suggests Putin's grip on power remains strong, with many high-ranking officials choosing to remain silent or supportive of his actions.

site_title: Maserati unveils new SUV Grecale, full electric version expected next year
summary: Maserati unveiled its new SUV Grecale, initially planned for November 2021, with deliveries expected in the second half of 2022 in three versions: two hybrid and a high-performance petrol V6. The Grecale will compete with luxury SUVs like Porsche's Cayenne and Mercedes' GLE. A full-electric version is expected next year, with Maserati aiming to offer full-electric models by 2025 and be entirely electric by 2030.

site_title: Asean poised for rebound, but growth fragile as Ukraine war adds to list of risks: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) projects Asean economies to grow by 5.2% in 2022 and 2023, despite uncertainties from the Ukraine war, rising inflation, and supply chain disruptions. The pandemic has inflicted substantial damage on labour markets, particularly in the Philippines and Vietnam, with micro-, small-, and medium-sized enterprises being heavily impacted. Real GDP growth for Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam is projected to be 5.2%, 6%, 7%, 3.8%, and 6.5% respectively in 2022, with some countries facing potential headwinds due to the ongoing pandemic and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Sri Lanka deploys troops as fuel shortage sparks protests
summary: Sri Lanka has deployed troops to petrol stations amid a severe fuel shortage, sparking sporadic protests. Thousands of motorists have been queuing daily for scarce fuel, with angry crowds blocking major arteries and holding up traffic. The government has also announced a summit to discuss the economic crisis, but opposition groups plan to boycott the meeting. The country is grappling with its worst economic meltdown in over 7 decades, caused by a critical shortfall of foreign currency and rolling electricity blackouts.

site_title: Japan's central bank renews powerful easing pledge after hawkish Fed signal
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has renewed its pledge to maintain ultra-loose monetary policy, citing concerns that cost-push inflation could hurt the economy. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that consumer inflation is expected to accelerate, potentially harming households' purchasing power. This stance contrasts with the US Federal Reserve's aggressive tightening plan, which has led to a weaker yen and increased import costs for Japan. The BOJ will continue to hold huge assets on its balance sheet, with Kuroda warning against premature discussions of exiting easy policy until inflation reaches its 2% target.

site_title: Crisis-hit Sri Lanka sends troops to fuel stations, aims to restructure debt
summary: Sri Lanka deploys troops to state-run gas stations to distribute fuel amid a foreign exchange crisis, which has led to a currency devaluation and shortages of essential imports. The nation is struggling to repay $4 billion in debt, including a $1 billion international sovereign bond, and has turned to the International Monetary Fund for help. The military's deployment comes after three elderly people died waiting in long fuel queues, and the government aims to restructure debt through technical assistance from a global law firm.

site_title: Traders sleep in offices to keep working amid Shanghai lockdowns
summary: Traders in Shanghai and Shenzhen are camping out in offices to avoid potential lockdowns amid China's worst Covid outbreaks. To prepare for possible quarantines, employers are providing traders with essential provisions, such as airbeds, instant noodles, and emergency kits. This measure aims to ensure workers have enough supplies in case they are forced to stay in the office for an extended period. The move reflects the volatility in Chinese capital markets and the uncertainty surrounding the pandemic's impact on the economy.

site_title: Oceanus announces placement, issue of convertible digital bonds to repay loans
summary: Oceanus Group plans to issue US$6 million in digital convertible bonds and place 29.2 million new shares to repay bridging loans. The bonds will bear a 4% coupon and be held by HydraX Digital Assets. The placement shares will be priced at S$0.023 per share, a 9.5% premium to the weighted average price. The move aims to repay loans and fund growth plans. The bonds and new shares will be issued to substantial shareholder Alacrity Investment Group, which owns 14.6% of the company.

site_title: Thai central bank backs top lenders after S&P downgrades ratings
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, has backed top lenders after S&P Global Ratings downgraded their ratings due to increased systemic risks. The banking system has a 20% capital adequacy ratio and high levels of provisioning against bad loans. The central bank stated that the financial positions of the Thai banking system remain resilient with a high level of buffer. S&P's base case scenario projects a bad loans ratio of 5% for Thai banks over the next 24 months, but the central bank's stress tests found the system to be resilient.

images.alt_text: The capital adequacy ratio of Thai banking system stands at 20 per cent and lenders have increased provisioning against bad loans by 430 billion baht (S$17.4 billion) in the past 2 years, the Bank of Thailand (BOT) said in a statement.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 1.35 points lower to 1,585.81 on Tuesday, March 22, 2022. Volume was 3.090 billion lots worth RM2.843 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 504 to 402 in the broader market.

site_title: Bitcoin climbs to highest in almost 3 weeks
summary: Bitcoin surged to its highest level in almost three weeks, reaching US$43,337, a 5.6% gain. The increase follows Russia's invasion of Ukraine, adding over 26% to its value since February 24. Ether, the second-largest digital coin, also rose 5.4% to its highest since February 17. Analysts attribute the gains to a tentative appetite for riskier assets, despite net outflows from crypto investment products and funds for the second consecutive week.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin climbed as much as 5.6 per cent to US$43,337, its highest since Mar 3, and was last up 3.6 per cent.

site_title: Hong Kong Covid shift won't move China, Xi's virus czar says
summary: China's top Covid-19 expert, Liang Wannian, advises the country to stick to its strict Covid Zero strategy despite signals of a potential shift to ease economic pain. Liang says measures can be fine-tuned to be more targeted and deployed quicker to combat the easily transmissible Omicron variant. China and Hong Kong are among the last places pursuing Covid Zero, with the strategy facing unprecedented challenges after Omicron breached the defences that had kept the virus at bay. Officials aim to balance control with economic disruption.

site_title: Signs of Ukrainian forces 'going after' Russians: Pentagon
summary: The US Pentagon reported that Ukrainian forces have begun to shift the battlefield momentum, reclaiming ground from Russian forces in some areas despite heavy bombardment. This development comes as Moscow's indiscriminate attacks have devastated Ukrainian cities and displaced over 10 million people. Analysts remain uncertain about a clear path out of the conflict, with the situation continuing to deteriorate.

images.alt_text: (Top) Ukrainian servicemen drive off in a Russian tank they captured after fighting with Russian troops.Ukraine's resistance - backed by millions in Western military aid - has been unexpectedly fierce, and now the Ukrainians are "in places and at times going on an offensive.

site_title: Ferrari gets more than 100m euros in Italian public funds
summary: Ferrari has secured up to €106 million in Italian public funds for investments in technology and production in its Emilia-Romagna region, creating 250 jobs. The funding is part of a memorandum of understanding with the Economy Ministry, Invitalia, and the regional government. The investment will be used for industrial projects, research and development, and aims to increase digitalization and reduce environmental impact. The project will benefit the towns of Maranello and Modena, and Ferrari's CEO Benedetto Vigna expressed commitment to enhancing the region's social and environmental benefits.

site_title: Tesla rolls out first vehicles as German gigafactory goes live
summary: Tesla has successfully launched its first European production hub at its 5 billion euro Gruenheide plant in Germany, delivering 30 Model Y cars to customers. The event marks the biggest investment in a German car factory in recent history, with the plant expected to produce 500,000 cars annually. Despite initial delays, Tesla has hired over 3,000 workers and has received the final go-ahead from local authorities to begin production. The move is seen as a significant milestone for the company, which aims to localize production within a continent and reduce logistics costs.

site_title: Steep oil and sunken yields flash more weakness for Japan's yen
summary: Japan's yen has fallen to a six-year low of 120 per dollar after a surge in oil prices and a widening gap between Japanese and US yields. Analysts predict the yen could reach 123 per dollar by September, citing a lack of demand and potential supply from the university fund's foreign investments. The country's trade deficit has also widened due to high energy prices, exacerbating the yen's decline. The Bank of Japan has maintained ultra-loose monetary policy, and while some experts expect a quick recovery, others believe the yen's weakness may be more persistent.

site_title: Chinese automakers see Thailand EV boost from government incentives
summary: Chinese automaker Great Wall Motor has signed an agreement with Thailand's government to slash retail prices of its electric vehicles, aiming to boost domestic EV sales and production. The agreement includes a government subsidy and reduced value-added tax, saving customers up to 160,000 baht (S$6,486) per unit. Similar agreements have been signed with rival automaker SAIC-CP Motor, as Thailand targets 725,000 EV units a year by 2030, accounting for 30% of output.

site_title: London nickel trading shows signs of recovery after 2 weeks of chaos
summary: The London Metal Exchange's (LME) benchmark nickel contract fell 10% to US$28,300 a tonne, marking the first time since March 16 that it didn't hit its downside limit. Trading resumed after a 6-day suspension due to a price surge and technical glitches. The market is showing signs of recovery, with around 6,000 contracts changing hands, compared to an average of 9,000 contracts per day. Analysts say the turbulence has led to investor frustration, but there are no quick alternatives for those seeking to shift their business elsewhere.

site_title: Thailand approves support measures to cope with high energy prices
summary: Thailand's Cabinet approved measures to cope with high energy prices caused by the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The measures include fuel subsidies, a monthly 100 baht ($4.05) subsidy for 3.6 million welfare card holders and 250 baht ($12.75) for 157,000 motorcycle taxi drivers. Diesel prices will be capped until April and subsidised thereafter. The government also agreed to suspend half of 9.3 billion baht debt owed by farmers to state banks, with the rest to be restructured within 15 years.

site_title: Cryptocurrency failing to take advantage of crisis
summary: Cryptocurrencies have failed to capitalize on the current crisis in Ukraine, despite being touted as a potential alternative to fiat currencies. The country, known for its cyber-literacy and openness to cryptocurrency, has seen significant use of digital payments to support the resistance effort, but trust in traditional currencies remains high. Russian citizens have turned to cryptocurrency to preserve wealth, but the government's response to this trend remains unclear. As a result, the price of bitcoin has barely budged, and gold has seen a 12% increase, indicating that fiat currency architecture remains dominant.

site_title: Credit Suisse wants SoftBank subpoena before it files UK suit over Greensill collapse
summary: Credit Suisse is seeking a US subpoena before filing a lawsuit in the UK against SoftBank Group over the collapse of Greensill Capital. The bank wants information from SoftBank, including internal records from a US-based construction company, to recover losses of $2.7 billion. SoftBank has argued the information is irrelevant and is trying to block the subpoena, claiming Credit Suisse is deflecting responsibility for the Greensill collapse. Credit Suisse has cut ties with SoftBank and repaid $6.7 billion to investors affected by Greensill's failure.
