site_title: Private securities marketplace Forge Global goes public via SPAC merger
summary: Forge Global, a private securities marketplace, has gone public via a merger with special purpose acquisition company Motive Capital Corp. The new company, Forge Global Holdings, will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange under tickers "FRGE" and "FRGE WS". The platform, which trades shares of private companies, saw 75% year-over-year revenue growth and a 71% increase in trading volume to $3.2 billion in 2021. True Global Ventures, a backer of Forge, expressed confidence in the company's future growth.

site_title: Sanctions on Russia are different this time
summary: The international community has imposed a comprehensive and multilateral set of sanctions on Russia in response to its invasion of Ukraine, exceeding expectations. The sanctions include restrictions on Russian oil and gas exports, penalties on non-oil exports, embargoes on key products, withdrawal of foreign investors, and financial sanctions targeting Russian banks and elites. The measures are expected to severely impact the Russian economy, potentially reducing its GDP ranking and diminishing its standard of living. As a result, the Kremlin is likely to lose significant economic and geopolitical leverage, potentially leading to a withdrawal from the invasion.

site_title: Rising lithium prices will not hurt electric vehicle momentum: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse analysts believe rising lithium prices, which have surged due to cost inflation in electric vehicle (EV) battery materials, will not hinder the accelerating EV momentum. Despite projected elevated prices until 2024, automakers are expected to lower prices to maintain growth, sacrificing margins to offset the impact. The bank forecasts 73% global xEV penetration by 2030, with a compound annual growth rate of 28% in global battery demand. Companies with stronger cost control, such as Contemporary Amperex Technology Co Limited (CATL), are preferred, while lithium stocks like Tianqi and Ganfeng are expected to benefit from rising prices.

images.alt_text: Technicians work in the assembly line of German carmaker Volkswagen's electric ID. 3 car in Dresden, Germany, June 8, 2021.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow in 2022, but with uncertainties due to the Ukraine crisis, recession or stagflation cannot be ruled out, according to Finance Minister Lawrence Wong. Mortgage rates may rise by up to 0.75% this year, while nuclear energy could be considered in Singapore's energy supply mix to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. The STI declined 0.2% on Tuesday, bucking an Asia-wide rally. Shareholders of Singapore Press Holdings voted in favor of a takeover offer from Cuscaden Peak, while banks are no longer a guaranteed investment bet due to market fluctuations.

site_title: Europe: Stocks climb at open after Asian gains
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on March 22, 2022, following strong gains in Asia. The FTSE 100 index in London climbed 0.2% to 7,459.49 points, while the DAX index in Frankfurt rose 0.6% to 14,412.34 points, and the CAC 40 in Paris grew 0.3% to 6,602.36 points. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: Singapore could potentially include nuclear in energy supply mix: report
summary: Singapore may consider including nuclear energy in its energy supply mix as the country charts a path to net-zero emissions by 2050. A report commissioned by the Energy Market Authority suggests that next-generation nuclear technologies and geothermal energy could play a role in Singapore's future energy supply. The report highlights the potential of newer nuclear power plant designs to provide a scalable and carbon-free baseload source of electricity, but notes that more research is needed before their viability can be confirmed.

site_title: Fintech Validus acquires Citi's small-business banking unit loan portfolio
summary: Fintech Validus has acquired Citi Singapore's CitiBusiness loan portfolio, serving small businesses, marking the first time a South-east Asian fintech has acquired an established bank's loan portfolio and customer base. The deal follows Citi's closure of its CitiBusiness unit in August, with the bank re-allocating resources to support other growth areas. The acquisition value was undisclosed, with Validus noting the deal's significance in expanding its presence in the region.

site_title: SPH shareholders vote in favour of Cuscaden takeover offer
summary: SPH shareholders have voted in favour of the takeover offer from consortium Cuscaden Peak, with 89.2% of 2,728 shareholders approving the deal. The offer includes an all-cash option of S$2.36 per share and a cash and SPH Reit units consideration. The consortium, backed by Hotel Properties, Ong Beng Seng, and Temasek-linked entities, will proceed to apply to the court to sanction the deal on April 5. Shareholders will have until April 26 to elect their preferred consideration option, with payment expected by May 11. SPH is expected to be delisted on May 13.

site_title: China locks down city of 9 million as Covid-19 ripples across country
summary: China has locked down an industrial city of 9 million people, Shenyang, amid an Omicron wave, with 4,770 new infections reported nationwide. The city's lockdown, combined with mass testing and closures, marks a significant escalation of the country's "zero-Covid" strategy. Authorities have warned of the economic impact, with Chinese President Xi Jinping urging officials to balance health and economic growth. The lockdowns come as China faces a shortage of hospital beds and a low vaccination rate among the elderly, with only around half of those over 80 fully vaccinated.

site_title: Beijing could emerge as a winner from the war
summary: US diplomacy, particularly under President Joe Biden, has inadvertently strengthened the relationship between Beijing and Moscow, exacerbating tensions with the West. The Biden administration's criticism of China for not joining the US-led campaign against Russia has backfired, as China has refused to back Russia, citing its own national interests. The US's focus on containing China has led to a self-fulfilling prophecy, where China is now refusing to toe the Western line. This dynamic has created an emerging China-Russia axis, which may ultimately benefit China as a result of the US's costly diplomatic-military mission in Europe.

site_title: Asia's retail industry beating the rest of the world's, thanks to e-commerce
summary: Asia's retail industry is leading the world in growth, accounting for three-quarters of global retail growth and over 30% of online growth. The region's e-commerce market has accelerated due to the pandemic, with consumers increasingly shopping online and purchasing more frequently. Key drivers of this growth include mobile-first adoption, cash-on-delivery payments, and the popularity of "buy now, pay later" schemes. The region's digital maturity will determine its retail sector's health, but barriers to growth remain, including the need for reliable connectivity to support seamless omnichannel operations and the integration of emerging technologies such as AR/VR and IoT.

site_title: After impressive IPO debut, Malaysia's Farm Fresh eyes regional expansion
summary: Malaysia's Farm Fresh, a dairy producer, made an impressive debut on Bursa Malaysia with its shares rising 27.4% to RM1.72. The company, led by Loi Tuan Ee, plans to expand its presence in the region, targeting Hong Kong, Indonesia, and the Philippines, with a goal to export products within 7-8 months. Farm Fresh aims to capitalize on Indonesia's large population and low dairy consumption, as well as the lack of fresh milk products in the Philippines.

site_title: Two years in, Covid pandemic needs a greater global response
summary: Two years into the Covid-19 pandemic, former UK Prime Minister Gordon Brown and Tony Blair have criticized key policy mistakes, including vaccine inequality, that may have extended the crisis. The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned that a greater global response is needed, urging industrialized countries to share vaccine doses with the rest of the world. The WHO believes the pandemic is likely at its mid-point, but a coordinated effort to tackle the crisis is still urgently required.

site_title: Japan's land prices rebound in 2021 as economy recovers from Covid hit
summary: Japan's land prices rebounded in 2021, rising 0.6% after a 0.5% drop in 2020, driven by a recovery in consumer sentiment and low interest rates. Residential land prices increased 0.5%, while commercial land prices rose 0.4%, with industrial land prices increasing 2.0% due to growing e-commerce demand. The rebound was modest compared to other economies, with Tokyo's housing land prices rising 0.6% and Osaka's commercial property prices remaining flat.

site_title: Japan's Suzuki, SkyDrive sign deal to develop, market 'flying cars'
summary: Suzuki Motor and SkyDrive, a Japanese flying car firm, signed a deal to develop and market electric, vertical takeoff and landing aircraft. The partnership aims to open new markets, with an initial focus on India, where Suzuki has a significant presence. Suzuki plans to invest 104.4 billion rupees in its India factory to produce electric vehicles and batteries. The companies did not disclose details of investments or production timelines. SkyDrive is developing a compact, two-seating electric-powered flying car with plans for full-scale production by 2025.

site_title: BNP Paribas stops new business in Russia, joins European peers
summary: BNP Paribas has stopped all new business in Russia, joining European peers in winding down its local operations after the country's invasion of Ukraine. The bank will no longer process transactions from its local unit starting March 31. With a total gross exposure of 1.3 billion euros, BNP Paribas is the latest lender to cut ties with Russia amid sanctions. This move follows similar steps taken by Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, and Commerzbank.

site_title: NWP Property, CRE Asia form JV to develop big-box logistics in Indonesia
summary: NWP Property and CRE Asia have formed a joint venture to develop a big-box logistics platform in Indonesia. The venture, led by entrepreneur Bonny Setiawan, aims to address the undersupply of modern logistics real estate in the country. With the backing of global private equity firm Warburg Pincus, the joint venture plans to secure its first warehouse in Jakarta and start construction in the second half of this year. The move is seen as an opportunity to develop high-quality logistics assets to serve the growing demand from e-commerce and FMCG companies.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound despite hawkish Fed view, higher oil prices
summary: South Korean shares rebounded on Tuesday, defying overnight weakness on Wall Street, as investors sought bargains despite Federal Reserve Chief Jerome Powell's hawkish remarks. The Kospi index rose 0.89% to its highest close since March 4, driven by gains in chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. Oil prices also rose amid concerns over sanctions on Russian oil. Despite a weakened won and higher bond yields, investors seemed to have priced in Powell's remarks, with analysts noting limited impact on the Kospi.

site_title: Australia launches Space Command to counter China's ambitions
summary: Australia has launched Space Command, a new defense agency aimed at countering China's growing space ambitions. The agency, led by Air Vice-Marshal Cath Roberts, will initially be modest but is expected to grow into a full-fledged Space Force in the future. The move is part of Australia's efforts to secure its place in space amid increasing competition from China and Russia. The launch comes just months after Australia signed a military partnership with the US and UK, and follows the country's commitment to increase its defense force to 80,000 troops by 2040.

site_title: Asset allocation at a time of war: Brace for inflation and lower growth
summary: The Russia-Ukraine conflict has led to concerns over inflation and lower economic growth, particularly in the euro area. The European Central Bank and Federal Reserve have raised interest rates to combat inflation, while the euro area's high dependence on Russian gas makes it more vulnerable to the conflict. The conflict is also affecting Asian economies, with India, the Philippines, and Thailand likely to be the most vulnerable. The article concludes that defensive-growth companies, such as healthcare and energy sectors, are expected to perform well in the current high-volatility regime.

site_title: Russia-Ukraine war: Taking heed of geopolitical risks and potential hotspots
summary: The ongoing Russia-Ukraine war is causing significant indirect geopolitical risks, particularly in the global grain supply and food inflation. Ukraine's abandonment of its fields and Russia's diversion of grain exports for domestic use may lead to a complete or near-complete failure of the 2022 Ukrainian wheat harvest, affecting countries reliant on Russian and Ukrainian grain imports. This, combined with spiking energy prices, could propel food prices higher, exacerbating food insecurity in developing nations, potentially leading to civil unrest and geopolitical tensions. Countries at high risk include Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Egypt, Congo, and Turkey.

site_title: Record breaking auction items in 2021
summary: In 2021, luxury collectibles saw record-breaking auction items, with watches and wines taking center stage. Meanwhile, the cryptocurrency market experienced significant growth, with Bitcoin breaking the $112,000 mark and extending a record run. The NFT market, however, declined for the fifth consecutive quarter, with trading volumes plummeting. In related news, Shanghai regulators are considering policy responses to stablecoins and cryptocurrencies, while China's tech giants explore offshore renminbi stablecoins. Additionally, Schroders has chosen Singapore as a global hub for digital assets.

site_title: STI declines 0.2 per cent, bucking Asia rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.2% to 3,350.17, bucking an Asia-wide rally. The decline followed a more hawkish outlook for US interest rates, which could have supported local bank stocks. DBS, UOB, and OCBC fell, with DBS down 0.5%, UOB down 0.2%, and OCBC down 0.3%. Jardine Cycle & Carriage topped the STI, while Jardine Matheson Holdings was at the bottom, down 1.4%.

site_title: Russia-Ukraine war: Limited impact on SGD bonds
summary: The Russia-Ukraine war has had a limited impact on Singapore-dollar (SGD) bonds, with most banks and agri-businesses having manageable exposure to the affected markets. Russia's finance ministry has fulfilled its debt obligation to US$117 million in coupon payments, avoiding a default. Despite the negative sentiment, bond prices of sectors affected by the conflict have come down, mainly due to the conflict's limited impact on SGD issuances. Analysts maintain a positive view on Additional Tier 1 notes, citing robust earnings and potential benefits from rising interest rates in the European Union.

site_title: Beijing tells Chinese in Russia to help fill economic void
summary: China's top envoy in Russia, Ambassador Zhang Hanhui, urged Chinese businesspeople in Moscow to capitalize on economic opportunities created by the crisis, including filling the void in the local market. This strategy aims to soften the impact of international sanctions. The Chinese government is finding ways to adapt to logistics and payment challenges, but smaller businesses may be reluctant to participate due to the sanctions. The move is seen as a way for China to maintain economic ties with Russia despite international pressure.

site_title: S&P downgrades 4 Thai banks on structural issues, fragile economic recovery
summary: S&P Global Ratings downgraded the credit ratings of four Thai banks, Siam Commercial Bank, Kasikornbank, Krung Thai Bank, and TMBThanachart Bank, to "BBB-" and "BBB-" respectively, citing increased systematic risks and fragile economic recovery. The downgrade is attributed to high leverage among borrowers and regulatory relaxation, which may prolong structural issues. Non-performing loans in the Thai banking sector are expected to rise to 5% over the next 24 months, with economic recovery remaining fragile and uneven across sectors.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei extends gains to sixth session as energy, financial stocks rise
summary: Japan's Nikkei stock index rose for a sixth consecutive session, posting its best winning streak since September, driven by stronger oil prices lifting energy shares and financials gaining on higher global bond yields. The Nikkei closed 1.48% higher at 27,224.11, with oil explorers leading the advance, followed by the insurance and banking sectors. Mitsubishi and Mitsui & Co were the top gainers, with oil and gas company Inpex rising 8.63%. The broader Topix also gained 1.28% to 1,933.74, marking a sixth straight winning session.

site_title: Japan issues first-ever power supply warning amid shortage
summary: Japan issued its first-ever power supply warning on March 22, 2022, due to a power shortage caused by an earthquake that shut several plants and technical troubles affecting Tokyo Electric Power Company (Tepco). The government called on citizens to reduce energy consumption to meet heating needs as temperatures dropped, with a request for power savings unlikely to extend beyond Tuesday. Industry Minister Koichi Hagiuda said some thermal power plants could take weeks or months to return to operation, prompting Tepco to request regional utilities to provide electricity supply of up to 1.42 million kilowatts.

site_title: Russian artist and Ukrainian in Bali collaborate on message of unity
summary: A Russian artist and a Ukrainian villa owner in Bali collaborated on a 960 sq m calligraphy piece promoting unity, with the message "United World" in 6 languages. The artwork, created over 3 weeks, was a cultural statement rather than a political one, according to artist Pokras Lampas. The piece reflects the values of its creators, who were shocked by the war in Ukraine and hope it can inspire unity. The artwork is a symbol of the close relationship between Russia and Ukraine, despite their cultural differences.

site_title: Malaysia companies to partially pass on higher wage costs to consumers: CGS-CIMB
summary: Malaysia's minimum wage is set to increase to RM1,500 (S$483) per month, a 25% rise from the current RM1,200, effective May 1. Analysts from CGS-CIMB predict that companies will partially pass on the higher costs to consumers in the second half of the year, potentially affecting sectors like travel, food, and retail. The move is expected to boost the purchasing power of the low-income group and help them cope with rising costs of living, but may also lead to weak demand and tumbling profit margins for companies unable to absorb the costs.

site_title: Singapore economy likely to grow in 2022 but don't rule out recession, stagflation: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to grow 3-5% in 2022, but Finance Minister Lawrence Wong cautioned that a recession or stagflation cannot be ruled out due to uncertainties from the Ukraine crisis. The economy's resilience depends on factors such as connectivity, innovation, and talent, with Wong emphasizing the importance of retaining an open mindset and investing in science and research and development. The government is committed to addressing challenges, including a tight labor market and carbon constraints, through targeted policies and initiatives.

site_title: Authentication firm Okta probes report of digital breach
summary: Okta, a leading authentication services provider, is investigating a reported digital breach after hackers posted screenshots of its internal company environment on Telegram. The screenshots, attributed to the ransom-seeking group LAPSUS$, appear to be authentic, according to security experts. The breach could have significant consequences, as thousands of companies rely on Okta to manage access to their networks and applications. Okta officials confirmed the reports and urged customers to be vigilant.

site_title: Singapore's net zero emissions target by 2050 for power sector 'technically viable', 'realistic': report
summary: Singapore's net-zero emissions target by 2050 for its power sector is considered "technically viable" and "realistic" according to a report by the Energy 2050 Committee, commissioned by the Energy Market Authority. The report highlights three trends that will impact the sector's green transition, including rising electricity demand, cheaper solar power, and the proliferation of distributed energy resources. The committee recommends a diversified supply mix, prioritizing importing renewable electricity, developing a national hydrogen strategy, and creating a multi-layered grid to manage the growth of distributed energy resources.

site_title: UK watchdog ramps up 'red alert' over crypto advertising
summary: The UK's Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) has sent enforcement notices to over 50 companies promoting cryptocurrencies, warning them to review and clean up their ads by May 2. The ASA will monitor compliance and introduce tougher measures after that date, including reporting repeat offenders to the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) and Trading Standards. The regulator is concerned that people may be enticed into investing money they can't afford to lose due to misleading ads, and aims to prevent crypto ads from being misleading and irresponsible.

site_title: Oil extends rally on Russia embargo talk
summary: Oil prices rallied by over 7% on Monday and extended the gain by 2% on Tuesday, driven by supply worries amid European discussions of banning Russian energy imports due to the Ukraine conflict. EU nations are divided on imposing sanctions, with some pushing for more pressure on Vladimir Putin and others, like Germany, resisting targeting key sectors. The US interest rate hike prospect also weighed on equities, despite a tepid Wall Street lead.

site_title: Debt-ridden Evergrande urges investor 'caution' as audit result delayed
summary: Evergrande, a Chinese property developer, has warned investors to "exercise caution" amid the delay of its 2021 audit results. The company halted trading in Hong Kong a day earlier due to drastic changes in its operational environment and Covid-19 outbreak. The suspension is the second this year and comes ahead of two major repayment obligations. Evergrande has faced operational and financial challenges, including debt pressure, and its struggles have had knock-on effects on China's property sector.

site_title: Most central banks not doing enough to curb inflation: global investor survey
summary: Most central banks, according to a global investor survey of 886 participants, are not doing enough to combat inflation. 73% of respondents believe that either "all" or "most" monetary authorities in developed markets have failed to quell inflation. Investors attribute this to the fact that many central banks have not raised interest rates aggressively enough to curb price increases.

site_title: Banks not a one-way bet; look at the big picture
summary: Banks are often viewed as one-way bets, but they can be cyclical businesses tied to the economic cycle. While banks can make significant profits during good times, they can also incur massive losses during bad times. Trust in banks is crucial for an economy to function, and their solvency is based on perceived solvency. Investors should look beyond short-term performance and consider metrics like price-to-book multiple and dividend yield to make informed decisions. With the global economy recovering from the pandemic, now may be a good time to invest in well-performing banks, particularly those trading at a discount to their book values.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Tuesday, adding 0.46% to 21,319.19, following a tepid lead from Wall Street. This comes as Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell sounded a hawkish note on monetary policy. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.13% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.22%. The market is closely watching the Ukraine war and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Singapore likely sees mild impact from China's Covid-19 situation: UOBKH
summary: Singapore companies are likely to experience a mild impact from China's resurging Covid-19 situation, according to UOB Kay Hian. The research team has maintained its earnings forecasts for Singapore companies with substantial exposure to China, citing mild impact. However, the outlook remains cloudy due to the Russia-Ukraine conflict and worsening domestic pandemic. The Straits Times Index's valuations are undemanding, and share prices have underperformed amid market uncertainty. UOBKH has selected several Singapore companies with positive outlooks, including Ascott Residence Trust and Singtel.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with hefty gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose sharply, with the Hang Seng Index climbing 3.15% to 21,889.28, driven by optimism that a tech crackdown was nearing its end. Beijing reiterated its pledge to support the stock market and provide stability, following a meeting chaired by Vice Premier Liu He. The Shanghai Composite Index also rose, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined. Alibaba's 11% advance fueled the rally, with tech giants such as JD.com, Tencent, and Meituan also seeing significant gains.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares finished sharply higher on Tuesday (Mar 22), resuming last week's rally sparked by China's pledge to support the country's markets and indicated a tech crackdown was nearing an end.

site_title: Evergrande unit discovers US$2.1b of its cash can be seized by banks
summary: China Evergrande Group's property-services unit has discovered that US$2.1 billion of its deposits can be seized by banks, raising concerns over corporate governance. The unit is investigating how the funds were used as security for pledge guarantees. This development may heighten scrutiny of Evergrande, the world's most indebted developer with over US$300 billion in liabilities, which has been in financial distress. The company's shares have been suspended in Hong Kong, and its financial statements are coming under increased scrutiny amid credit-market turmoil.

site_title: No country met WHO air quality standards in 2021: data
summary: Not a single country met the World Health Organization's (WHO) air quality standard in 2021, according to a survey of 6,475 cities. The standard recommends no more than 5 micrograms per cubic meter of small and hazardous airborne particles. Only 3.4% of surveyed cities met the standard, indicating significant health risks from poor air quality globally.

site_title: Asia: Equities remain resilient on Tuesday
summary: Asia's stock markets remained resilient on Tuesday, with Hong Kong and Tokyo rising over 1% after Chinese authorities reiterated their support for the markets and economy. Other key markets, including Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, and Manila, also saw gains, while Singapore and Taipei struggled. China Eastern Airlines fell 6% after one of its planes crashed in China, killing 132 people.

site_title: Singapore mortgage rates may rise up to 0.75 point this year following Fed hikes, consultants say
summary: Singapore mortgage rates may rise by up to 0.75 points this year due to US Federal Reserve hikes, according to mortgage advisors. The US Fed has already raised interest rates for the first time since 2018, and Singapore's domestic interest rates are largely influenced by global market movements. Experts expect the 3-month compounded Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) to reach 0.8-1% by July and possibly cross 1% by the end of 2022, while floating mortgage rates could see "meaningful increases" in the coming quarters.

site_title: Avoid commodity price volatility by buying into Indonesia's 'immune' stocks: UOBKH
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) recommends investors to buy into Indonesia's finance, retail, healthcare, and technology sectors to avoid commodity price volatility. The research house notes that commodity prices, such as wheat, coal, and oil, have risen by over 50% since the Russia-Ukraine conflict. UOBKH downgraded its consumer sector to "underweight" due to high exposure to raw materials and potential margin pressure. This shift is aimed at protecting investors from fluctuations in commodity prices.

site_title: S$840m in wage credits to be disbursed to over 99,000 employers by end-March
summary: The Ministry of Finance and Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore announced that the final tranche of payouts under the Wage Credit Scheme (WCS) will be disbursed by end-March 2022. Over 99,000 employers in Singapore will receive S$840 million in wage credits, with eligible employees earning up to S$5,000 receiving co-funded wage increases for 2021, 2020, and 2019. The payouts will be credited directly to employer accounts through PayNow Corporate or GIRO, with appeals due by June 30.

site_title: Telemedicine booms in South Korea amid Covid, President-elect Yoon backs practice
summary: South Korea sees a surge in telemedicine usage amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with 2 million people under home care and 2.3 million users since December 2020. Despite being technically illegal, telemedicine has become an "inevitable reality" under emergency measures, and President-elect Yoon Suk-yeol supports its expansion. Local telemedicine players have seen a 40-fold jump in users, with some reporting long virtual queues, but many patients, like Kim Jin-woo, praise its convenience and accessibility. Yoon aims to make telemedicine a permanent part of the healthcare system, which could bring significant growth to the industry.

site_title: Alibaba increases share buyback to US$25b from US$15b
summary: Alibaba Group has increased its share buyback program to US$25 billion, up from US$15 billion. The move is aimed at returning capital to shareholders. Additionally, the company appointed Weijian Shan, executive chairman of investment group PAG, as an independent director to its board. This expansion and new appointment signal Alibaba's focus on capital allocation and strategic governance.

site_title: Sony Entertainment to buy industry veteran's Haven gaming studio
summary: Sony Entertainment has acquired Montreal-based video game development studio Haven Entertainment Studios, led by industry veteran Jade Raymond, for undisclosed terms. Haven, founded last year with Sony's initial investment, is working on a live experience for PlayStation 5. The acquisition marks Sony's 18th studio addition to the PlayStation Studios family, expanding its diverse gaming catalogue. This deal follows recent industry consolidations, including Sony's $3.6 billion purchase of Bungie and Microsoft's $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard.

site_title: 'Perfect storm': Europe Covid-19 cases rise due to fewer curbs, subvariant
summary: Covid-19 cases in Western Europe are surging due to a "perfect storm" of governments lifting restrictions, waning immunity, and the more contagious BA.2 Omicron subvariant. Cases have risen in countries like France, Germany, and Italy, with some maintaining restrictions despite the government's decision to end them. Experts attribute the surge to the combination of these factors, with BA.2 being 30% more contagious than its predecessor. Some nations, like France, are rolling out fourth vaccine doses to bolster immunity, while the World Health Organization warns against prioritizing booster shots over sharing vaccines with countries in need.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Tuesday, climbing 0.98% or 263.89 points to 27,091.32, despite US stock falls due to oil price drops and the Federal Reserve's hawkish comments on inflation.

site_title: Chinese air travel faces mass cancellations after plane crash
summary: Chinese air travel has faced mass cancellations, with 74% of scheduled flights cancelled on March 22, including the majority of flights between Beijing and Shanghai. This rate is the highest this year and double the number at the start of the month. The cancellations come after a Boeing 737-800 operated by China Eastern Airlines crashed in Guangxi province on Monday, killing all 132 people on board. It was China's first fatal air crash since 2010, further exacerbating existing Covid-related travel restrictions.

images.alt_text: About 74 per cent of the 11,800 flights scheduled in China on Tuesday (Mar 22) have been cancelled, including the majority due between Beijing and Shanghai, typically one of the world's busiest domestic routes, according to VariFlight.

site_title: IHH Healthcare confirms offer to buy Ramsay-Sime Darby JV for RM5.67b
summary: IHH Healthcare is offering to buy Ramsay-Sime Darby JV, a 50:50 joint venture operating hospitals in Indonesia and Malaysia, for RM5.67 billion on a cash-free and debt-free basis. The deal, if agreed, would mark IHH's first foray into Indonesia and potentially drive medical tourism referrals to Malaysia and Singapore. The acquisition is in line with IHH's strategy to strengthen its presence in the Klang Valley area, and analysts see it as a reasonable transaction price at 20-30 times the company's enterprise value to earnings.

site_title: Locofy.ai joins low-code movement with backing from Accel and startup founders
summary: Locofy.ai, a Singapore-based startup, has secured US$3 million in funding from Accel and other investors to develop a low-code platform that converts designs to production-ready code and live prototypes. The company aims to automate the work of engineers and allow them to focus on complex tasks. The low-code movement is gaining ground amid the global shortage of software developers, with companies such as Airtable and OutSystems also raising significant funding. Locofy.ai's platform is expected to compete with tech giants and startups in the market, with investors predicting it could become a leading low-code platform used globally.

images.alt_text: Locofy.ai's co-founders Honey Mittal and Sohaib Muhammad.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.38 points to 1,587.54. The market saw 181 losers and 154 gainers, with a total trading volume of 237.96 million lots worth RM258.36 million.

site_title: Dairy producer Farm Fresh surges in Kuala Lumpur trading debut
summary: Malaysian dairy producer Farm Fresh made its trading debut in Kuala Lumpur, raising about RM1 billion (S$322 million) in its IPO. The shares jumped to RM1.81, after being sold at RM1.35 each, with cornerstone investors including Abrdn and Franklin Templeton Asset Management. The company plans to use the funds to build a manufacturing hub, dairy farm, and processing facility, and boost production in Australia and South-east Asia. This is the third company to list in Bursa Malaysia this year, reviving the IPO market amid rising interest rates and market volatility.

site_title: Lendlease Reit to raise at least S$573.8m to fund Jem acquisition
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit (Lendlease Reit) plans to raise at least S$573.8 million through a private placement and non-renounceable preferential offering to partly finance its acquisition of the remaining interest in Jem mall. The acquisition, valued at S$2.1 billion, will increase Lendlease Reit's portfolio net lettable area by 70% and provide a 10.5% distribution per unit accretion. The private placement and preferential offering will be priced between S$0.725 and S$0.74 and S$0.72 per unit, respectively, representing discounts of 7.1% to 9.6% to the Reit's volume-weighted average price.

site_title: UK pay settlements hold at highest since 2008: XpertHR
summary: UK pay settlements remain at 3% since 2008, the joint highest, but still lag behind inflation, which rose 5.5% in the past year. This raises concerns for the Bank of England, which fears accelerating prices will drive up pay, making it hard to return to its 2% target. Only 3.5% of settlements saw a wage freeze, down from 34% last year, as employers try to react to inflation and labor shortages.

site_title: Boeing CEO offers 'full support' for China Eastern crash probe
summary: Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun has offered "full support" for the investigation into the China Eastern Airlines 737-800 crash, stating the company will provide technical expertise while respecting the investigation's lead by the Civil Aviation Administration of China. Calhoun emphasized Boeing's commitment to safety, transparency, and integrity in the process.

site_title: Gold eases as yields climb higher on aggressive Fed stance
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,931.84 per ounce, as US Treasury yields hit fresh multi-year highs following Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's aggressive inflation stance. Spot silver and platinum also declined, while palladium fell 0.5% due to supply concerns from Russia. The escalation of the Ukraine crisis and potential risk of an economic downturn are underpinning gold prices.

images.alt_text: Gold prices fell on Tuesday (Mar 22) as US Treasury yields hit fresh multi-year highs following Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's aggressive inflation stance, while safe-haven bullion remained underpinned by escalation in the Ukraine crisis.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda renews powerful easing pledge in wake of hawkish Federal Reserve signal
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda renewed the pledge for powerful monetary easing to combat cost-push inflation, citing the widening gap with the US Federal Reserve's tightening plan. Consumer inflation is expected to accelerate due to rising energy and food costs, potentially hurting the economy. Kuroda emphasized the need to maintain ultra-loose policy, warning that cost-push inflation could weigh on households' purchasing power and corporate profits. The yen fell against the dollar, widening the policy gap between the Fed and the BOJ.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan must maintain ultra-loose monetary policy as recent cost-push inflation could hurt the economy, Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said on Tuesday, highlighting the widening gap with the US Federal Reserve's aggressive tightening plan.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MCT, MNACT, Keppel DC Reit, ESR-Reit, Ara Logos Logistics
summary: Several Singaporean stocks saw developments on Tuesday, March 22, 2022. MCT and MNACT Reits announced merger details, with MNACT's unitholders opting for cash-only consideration. Keppel DC Reit initiated legal proceedings against tenant DXC Technology Services Singapore over disputed payments. ESR-Logos Reit (E-Log Reit) received approval to merge from its unitholders. Ara Logos Logistics acquired Malaysian industrial lands, while T24 teamed up with Mitsubishi Estate to develop an outlet mall in Indonesia. Nordic secured S$151.6 million worth of contracts, and NutryFarm's executive director Levin Lee resigned.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Business City Phase 2 spans 40, 50, 60, 70 and 80 Pasir Panjang Road.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit over two-month high on energy, miners boost
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% to a two-month high, driven by miners' gains in iron ore and energy stocks, as crude prices surged 7% overnight. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 7,367.40, with sector leaders like Rio Tinto, Fortescue Metals Group, and BHP Group up between 1.7% and 4.3%. The move was influenced by the US Federal Reserve's plan to raise interest rates and the ongoing energy market volatility.

site_title: Tencent-backed startup that helps hire staff raises US$120m
summary: Omnipresent, a Tencent-backed startup, has raised $120 million in funding to support its business model helping companies hire and support staff abroad. The company's revenue increased 25 times in 2021, driven by the shift to remote work during the pandemic. Omnipresent plans to use the funds to hire hundreds more employees to meet surging demand. Co-founders Guenther Eisinger and Matthew Wilson believe that companies have realized the benefits of working with globally distributed teams, making international employment problems more manageable.

site_title: Singapore's productivity grew 3.9% per annum from 2019 to 2021 despite Covid-19: DPM Heng
summary: Singapore's productivity grew 3.9% per annum from 2019 to 2021, despite disruptions from Covid-19, according to Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat. This increase is higher than pre-pandemic growth rates, driven by economic transformation efforts. Prior to the introduction of Industry Transformation Maps, Singapore's productivity growth averaged 2.3% per annum, outpacing most other advanced economies.

images.alt_text: The increase in productivity levels during the pandemic is also higher than that in the years before, Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat revealed in a keynote address at the Singapore Apex Business Summit 2022.
Sharon See

site_title: The dark side of using AI to design drugs
summary: A team at Collaborations Pharmaceuticals used AI to design potential biochemical weapons by training a molecule-generating model with toxins and scoring them for lethality. Within 6 hours, the model produced 40,000 deadly molecules, including VX, a banned nerve agent. The company has deleted its library and plans to restrict its technology, recommending a reporting hotline and code of conduct for AI-focused drug discovery. Experts warn that state-sponsored groups and national militaries could exploit this technology, increasing the capacity for malicious intent, and that the potential for misuse has been amplified by AI.

site_title: S&P Global to withdraw all outstanding ratings on Russian entities
summary: S&P Global Ratings has announced its decision to withdraw all outstanding ratings for Russian entities before April 15. This move comes as the company suspends commercial operations in Russia, following other credit rating agencies like Moody's and Fitch, due to tightening economic sanctions over Moscow's invasion of Ukraine. Western sanctions have frozen assets, barred banks from global payments, and sent the rouble into free fall, prompting the corporate boycott of Russia.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% at Tuesday's open, tracking overnight losses on Wall Street amid expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped to 3,346.59, with Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust and Sembcorp Marine seeing notable trading activity. US stocks also retreated, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.6% and the S&P 500 slipping less than 0.1%. European shares were subdued, while Tokyo shares opened higher on Tuesday.

site_title: NutryFarm exec director resigns; new non-exec director appointed
summary: NutryFarm International's executive director Levin Lee has resigned, effective April 19, to pursue other business interests. Lee's resignation is due to the delay in the release of the company's financial results, which hindered his fundraising activities. The company will appoint Ng Fang Yao, a lawyer, as a new non-executive director, who will also serve on the audit, remuneration, and nominating committees. This change comes after another non-executive director's resignation.

site_title: Biden says Putin is weighing use of chemical weapons in Ukraine
summary: US President Joe Biden stated that Russian President Vladimir Putin is considering using chemical and biological weapons in Ukraine, citing Putin's "false flags" as a sign of desperation. Biden described Putin's claims that the US has these weapons as "simply not true." This comes as Putin's forces face challenges in their war against Ukraine. The US President's comments highlight the escalating tensions between Russia and the West.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker's wife created shell entity after 1MDB deal
summary: Former Goldman Sachs banker Roger Ng's wife, Hwee Bin Lim, created a shell company and opened a bank account to help launder tens of millions of dollars in illicit kickbacks from Malaysian financier Jho Low. Prosecutors say Lim played a central role in helping her husband launder the payments from bond deals engineered by Goldman Sachs for 1MDB. Lim wasn't charged, while Ng is accused of conspiring with his former boss, Tim Leissner, who has pleaded guilty and is cooperating with the government against Ng.

images.alt_text: Former Goldman Sachs Group banker Roger Ng's wife created a shell company and opened a bank account that prosecutors say she used to help launder tens of millions of dollars in illegal kickbacks from Malaysian financier Jho Low.

site_title: Europe: Shares muted in choppy trade
summary: European shares were subdued at close on Monday due to investor concerns over the war in Ukraine and the possibility of an oil embargo on Russia. The Stoxx 600 was flat after posting its biggest weekly percentage gain since November 2020. European Union governments are gathering with US President Joe Biden to harden their stance against Moscow, amid tensions over US-EU trade talks and tariffs.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat on oil price jump, hawkish Federal Reserve
summary: US stocks retreated on Monday, ending a week-long rally, due to a surge in oil prices and hawkish comments from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. Oil prices jumped above $100 a barrel as some buyers began to "self-sanction" Russian oil, while Powell stated the Fed is prepared to raise interest rates by larger steps to combat high inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.6%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.1% and 0.4%, respectively.

site_title: Tuan Sing, Mitsubishi Estate to develop first phase of Indonesia mall for S$90m
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings and Mitsubishi Estate have partnered to develop the first phase of a luxury outlet mall in Karawang, Indonesia, with an initial investment of S$90 million. Construction is set to commence in Q2 2022 with a target opening date in Q4 2023. The 9-hectare mall, named The Grand Outlet - East Jakarta, will feature 180 shops, car park space for 1,000 cars, and 180 motorcycles. Indonesian retail giant Mitra Adiperkasa is interested in being a major tenant. The project aims to tap into Indonesia's rising affluent consumer population.

site_title: Russia bans Instagram and Facebook as 'extremist'
summary: Russia's Tverskoi district court has banned Facebook and Instagram as "extremist" platforms, citing their alleged tolerance of "Russophobia" since Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The ban follows earlier blocks of access to Twitter and euronews.com. Meta's WhatsApp messenger service remains accessible. Experts say it remains unclear if ordinary Russians can post on the banned platforms, but using them "carefully" may be safe. The Russian authorities have accused Meta of working against Russia's interests during the conflict.

site_title: India bans offsetting loss on one crypto with gain from another
summary: India has tightened its crypto regulations by disallowing tax breaks on losses incurred in one crypto asset against income from another. Junior Finance Minister Pankaj Chaudhary clarified that infrastructure costs incurred while mining crypto assets will not be treated as cost of acquisition. This move is seen as a setback for the industry, which is already facing a steep tax rate. The tax regime will gradually roll out in the financial year starting April 1, with 30% tax on profits and 1% TDS from July 1, 2022.

site_title: Washington and London resume trade talks in Baltimore
summary: The US and UK resumed trade talks in Baltimore, aiming to deepen their economic relationship and address challenges such as global supply chain bottlenecks, carbon use, and digital trade. The two-day meeting, led by US Trade Representative Katherine Tai and UK International Trade Secretary Anne-Marie Trevelyan, focused on promoting labor rights and supporting workers. The countries have made progress in removing trade friction, including ending a dispute over steel and aluminum tariffs. A major bilateral trade agreement is not expected, but the talks will pave the way for future negotiations.

site_title: Federal Reserve will raise rates more aggressively if needed: Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled an urgency to address inflation, stating that the central bank must move "expeditiously" to raise rates and possibly "more aggressively" to keep an upward price spiral from getting entrenched. Powell repeated that the Fed's goal is to return monetary policy to a neutral level and then to more restrictive levels if necessary to restore price stability. The Fed's interest rate hikes are expected to be more aggressive, potentially lifting the short-term policy rate to 2.25-2.5% by the end of the year, and balance sheet reductions could start by May.

site_title: Crude settles up more than 7% as EU mulls Russian oil ban
summary: The European Union is debating a potential Russian oil embargo, which has led to a surge in oil prices, with Brent futures rising above $115 a barrel. The US has already imposed an embargo on Russian oil imports. Analysts warn that such an embargo could disrupt global oil supplies. Oil prices rose over 7% on Monday, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures reaching $112.12 a barrel. The EU's decision on the embargo is expected to have significant implications for the global energy market.

site_title: China stocks slip as absence of policy measures add to worries
summary: China's stock market declined 0.2% on Monday as lenders left borrowing costs unchanged, disappointing traders seeking policy support to spur growth. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index fell 1.7% after a recent rally, while a gauge tracking real estate developers dropped 3.7%. Economists expect a possible cut in the reserve requirement ratio and a rate reduction in the second quarter. Speculation of policy easing increased after Vice-Premier Liu He's vow to boost the economy and stabilize financial markets.

site_title: Lakeside Apartments to go up for collective sale again at S$240m
summary: Lakeside Apartments, a 99-year leasehold development, will be put up for collective sale again on March 22 at a reserve price of S$240 million. The 120-unit complex, located near Jurong Lake Gardens, has a gross plot ratio of 2.1 and potential for redevelopment into a 24-storey building. The collective sale tender will close on May 25. The reserve price is the same as its 2019 en bloc launch price, despite a proposed reduction by the collective sale committee.

images.alt_text: Lakeside Apartments comprises 120 residential units and has a 99-year leasehold land tenure commencing from March 1977.

site_title: Temasek-backed health insurance startup raising funds at 2.5b euro valuation: sources
summary: Alan, a Temasek-backed health insurance startup, is in talks to raise new funding with a valuation of approximately 2.5 billion euros. The company, which operates in France, Spain, and Belgium, has annualized sales of 161 million euros. Alan last raised 185 million euros in 2021 at a 1.4 billion-euro valuation. The funding round is not yet finalized, and the details are subject to change.

site_title: New US rule requires publicly-listed firms to disclose emissions
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has approved a rule requiring publicly-listed firms to disclose greenhouse gas emissions and climate change risks. The measure aims to standardize emissions reporting, following similar steps by regulators in Japan and Europe. SEC Chair Gary Gensler stated that climate risks can pose significant financial risks to companies, highlighting the need for transparency and management of climate-related risks. The proposed rule now goes for public comment.

site_title: Strong pricing boosts Nike results despite China hit
summary: Nike reported better-than-expected quarterly profits despite a 5% revenue drop in China due to the country's "zero tolerance" policy on Covid-19. The company's gross profit margin increased due to full-priced sales, offset by elevated logistics costs. Nike's total profits rose 5% to US$1.4 billion, driven by strong sales in Asia Pacific/Latin America and North America. The company's shares jumped 5.9% in after-hours trading.

site_title: Credit Suisse vice- chairman to leave in board shakeup
summary: Credit Suisse vice-chairman Severin Schwan is stepping down from his role, along with two other board members, amid the bank's efforts to renew its top supervisory body following scandals. Christian Gellerstad will become vice-chairman, while Richard Meddings and Mirko Bianchi will oversee the risk and audit committees, respectively. Schwan's departure comes amid criticism of his dual mandates, and follows the ouster of former Chairman Antonio Horta-Osorio. The bank's chairman, Axel P Lehmann, praised Schwan's dedication but noted the need for change.

site_title: Rare copy of first Marvel comic sells for US$2.4m
summary: A rare copy of the first Marvel comic book, Marvel Comics No. 1, published in 1939, sold at auction for US$2.4 million. The book is a "pay copy," which includes the publisher's annotated payments to the illustrators. The buyer, a 40-year-old comic collector, remains anonymous. The sale highlights the value of rare comic books, particularly those with historical significance. The comic book's rarity and condition contributed to its high price, making it a significant addition to the collector's collection.

site_title: Dollar steady as investors look to Powell for clues
summary: The US dollar remained steady against major currencies on Monday, awaiting remarks from US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell for monetary policy clues. The dollar index edged up 0.1% to 98.376, while the euro and British pound declined 0.1% and 0.3% respectively. The yen remains near six-year lows due to the Bank of Japan's dovish policy, which contrasts with the Fed's interest rate hikes. Powell's remarks and speeches by other Fed policymakers this week are expected to provide insights into future rate hikes.

site_title: Ether outperforms Bitcoin as excitement builds for software upgrade
summary: Ether has outperformed Bitcoin by nearly 9% in the past week, with a 14% rally, as anticipation builds for the Ethereum Merge, a software upgrade expected to reduce the network's carbon footprint and make it more energy-efficient. The upgrade, which is expected to occur within months, will shift from miners to stakers to order transactions, potentially reducing the supply of Ether in circulation and making it more attractive to environmentally-conscious investors.

site_title: MNACT unitholders appeased by all-cash option in proposed MCT merger
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) are proposing a merger, with MNACT unitholders now offered the option to receive the entire scheme consideration of S$1.1949 per unit in cash. The merger, which was initially met with criticism, has been revised to include a cash-only option, which will also fund additional cash requirements of up to S$2.2 billion. MCT will make a preferential offering of S$2.0039 per unit to fund this requirement. The merger is expected to create a significantly larger and more diversified Reit.

site_title: Zelensky insists on need for 'meeting' with Putin
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky reiterated the need for a meeting with Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine. Zelensky emphasized that without negotiations, it's impossible to stop the conflict, and he has previously called for a summit with Putin. His comments were particularly insistent, highlighting the importance of a dialogue to resolve the ongoing war.

site_title: South Korea's soaring energy import costs raise trade deficit risk
summary: South Korea's trade deficit risk increases due to rising energy import costs, driven by global demand decline and soaring energy prices. Exports rose 10.1% in the first 20 days of March, led by semiconductors and oil products, while imports climbed 18.9% and resulted in a $2.1 billion deficit. The Bank of Korea has raised its inflation forecast, and analysts warn that the country may not see a surplus until oil prices drop. A trade deficit is expected, with exports to China, the US, and Japan increasing, while shipments to the European Union fell.

site_title: Apple suffers widespread outage hitting music, maps and iCloud
summary: Apple experienced a widespread network outage on March 21, 2022, affecting services such as Apple Music, iCloud, and the App Store. The outage hindered corporate employees' work-from-home capabilities, retail workers' tasks, and limited internal communication. The issue was attributed to DNS problems, which are often caused by human errors. The outage also impacted product repairs, swaps, and item pickups, causing frustration for customers and employees. Apple resolved the issue, but the incident highlighted the importance of robust network infrastructure and error prevention measures.

site_title: British royals dance, make chocolate in Belize as tour overcomes awkward start
summary: Prince William and Kate, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, completed a smooth second day of their Caribbean tour in Belize, following an awkward start. The visit coincides with Queen Elizabeth's 70th year on the throne and comes amid growing scrutiny of past British conduct in the Caribbean. The royal couple danced with villagers, made traditional chocolate, and planted a tree, after a local protest forced a change in their itinerary. The visit aims to promote understanding and comes as debates over colonial-era abuses and reparations for slavery in Jamaica gain momentum.

site_title: Crypto laws loom for Australia as government seeks market views
summary: Australia's government is seeking feedback on plans to overhaul licensing and custody arrangements for digital assets, aiming to ensure consumer trust in crypto exchanges. The proposals include breach reporting obligations, anti-money laundering compliance, and a classification strategy for crypto assets. Minister for the Digital Economy Jane Hume said the government wants to create a regulatory framework that is "better, safer and more secure" for Australian players in the crypto ecosystem. The feedback is due ahead of the regime's finalization later this year, as the digital asset economy is expected to grow to A$64 billion by the decade's end.

site_title: Diversity of Singapore boards approaching a momentous milestone
summary: Singapore's boards are approaching a milestone in diversity, with progress on gender showing a path for multi-dimensional diversity ambitions. As of January 2022, women held 19.7% of board seats among the 100 largest listed companies on the Singapore Exchange. Women's share rose to 29.7% among statutory boards and 28.4% among top Institutions of a Public Character. This progress indicates a holistic approach to board diversity, moving beyond numerical targets and box-ticking, and sets a course for further ambitious goals in diversity.

site_title: ESR-Reit, ALog Trust investors say 'aye' to union
summary: Singapore's ESR-Reit and ALog Trust have received approval from their respective unitholders to merge and form ESR-Logos Reit. At an EGM, 98.6% of ESR-Reit unitholders voted in favor of the merger, while 94.8% of ALog Trust unitholders approved the scheme resolution. The merger aims to create a larger entity with $5.4 billion in total assets under management and rank among the 10 largest Singapore-listed Reits. The deal is expected to become effective by the end of April 2022, with ALog Trust to be delisted from the Singapore Exchange around May 2022.

site_title: War threatens to undermine ESG-oriented investing
summary: A war in Ukraine has led to a shift in investor sentiment, with traditional fossil fuel companies experiencing a surge in popularity, while ESG-oriented investing appears to be losing momentum. The Singapore Exchange and OCBC unveiled a new index to promote low-carbon investing, but investors are increasingly prioritizing energy security and national security over environmental concerns. The article suggests that the widespread commitment to ESG investing was based on a low opportunity cost, and that investors may now be willing to overlook the incompatibility of certain companies with ESG principles in favor of higher returns.

site_title: Hong Kong to lift ban on flights, ease quarantine measures
summary: Hong Kong is set to relax its COVID-19 measures, lifting a ban on flights from 9 countries and reducing quarantine time for arrivals from abroad. Starting April 1, flights will resume, and hotel quarantine for arrivals could be cut to 7 days if residents test negative. Schools will also resume face-to-face classes from April 19, and public venues, including sports facilities, will reopen from April 21. The measures aim to ease the city's stringent measures, which have been in place for over 2 years, and address criticism from residents.

site_title: Lack of data challenges rising Apac sustainable investing: Robeco
summary: A survey by Robeco found that sustainable investing in Asia-Pacific is catching up with Europe, but implementation of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) strategies remains challenged by data, internal expertise, and resources. 75% of global investors view climate change as a significant issue, with Asian investors increasing their focus on climate change, but lagging behind European counterparts in including biodiversity in their investment approach. Despite challenges, nearly half of investors have made a public commitment to achieving net-zero emissions by 2050, and thematic and impact investing are increasingly adopted.

site_title: STI advances 0.8% led by Wall Street's exuberance
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.8% on Monday, led by Wall Street's exuberance, to close at 3,355.51 points, extending gains from last Friday. The Straits Times Index climbed 24.88 points, driven by an exuberant session on Wall Street and a possible Russia-Ukraine peace pact. Key gauges in Asia-Pacific fared mixed, with turnover reaching S$1.55 billion. Gainers outpaced losers, with Mapletree Commercial Trust and Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust seeing significant gains.

site_title: Grab vs Gojek: Is there really no room for more than one?
summary: Grab and Gojek, two rival ride-hailing companies in South-east Asia, continue to battle for market share despite financial losses. Grab, listed on Nasdaq, holds a 75% market share in Singapore and 80% in Thailand, while Gojek is targeting a valuation of $26.2 billion. However, Gojek's valuation might be too high for the market, and it's unlikely to withdraw from Singapore and other markets, which would allow Grab to monopolize. Instead, Gojek will likely stay the course to provide competition, with Gojek's CEO signaling the company's commitment to expanding its regional presence.

site_title: Nordic Group obtains S$151.6m worth of contracts
summary: Nordic Group MR7 has secured S$151.6 million in contracts through its divisions and newly-acquired Starburst Holdings subsidiary. The contracts come from new and repeat customers in Singapore, Malaysia, China, and the Middle East. Starburst Holdings has remaining capital projects worth S$32.6 million and maintenance contracts worth S$57.5 million, set to be completed in Q1 2023 and spanning 1-11 years respectively.

images.alt_text: The contracts come from new and repeat customers in Singapore, Malaysia, China and the Middle East.

site_title: Biden doubles down on transatlantic ties
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to present a unified front to Moscow during his European trip, focusing on Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Biden will meet with Western leaders at NATO and European Council summits, unveiling a package of new measures to punish Russia and help Ukraine. Options include sanctions, energy restrictions, and military assistance. Biden aims to rebuild transatlantic ties after the Trump presidency, which was marked by division and Brexit-related tensions. The trip also highlights the contrast between Biden's approach and Trump's more isolationist stance.

site_title: Philippines allows foreign ownership of telcos, airlines
summary: The Philippines has eased restrictions to allow foreign ownership in airline, telecommunications, and shipping operators, aiming to boost jobs and stimulate the virus-hit economy. The Public Service Act amendments, signed by outgoing President Rodrigo Duterte, ease foreign equity restrictions in several sectors, including telecommunications, shipping, and airlines. However, foreign ownership in public utilities such as water and electricity distribution remains capped at 40%. Experts welcome the move, but caution that more needs to be done to improve the country's investment environment.

site_title: The smartest EU sanction on Russia - a targeted energy tariff
summary: The European Union can impose a targeted energy tariff on Russian gas imports, which would minimize economic disruption. This approach is considered a smarter alternative to a complete ban, which could harm Russia's war effort but also cause significant economic damage in Europe. The tariff would allow the EU to exert pressure on Russia while avoiding a catastrophic economic impact.

site_title: China Eastern Airlines plane with 132 on board crashes in China
summary: A China Eastern Airlines Boeing 737-800 aircraft with 132 people on board crashed in the mountains of southern China on March 21, 2022, while en route from Kunming to Guangzhou. The cause of the crash is unknown, and rescue services are on the scene. The plane completely disintegrated, and a fire was reported. China Eastern Airlines has grounded all its Boeing 737-800 jets and set up an emergency hotline for relatives of those on board. The incident is under investigation, and the number of casualties is not yet known.

site_title: Asean banks not equally ready to meet climate goals: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service reports that ASEAN banks are not equally ready to meet their carbon neutrality targets due to insufficient data and disclosures. The region's limited green and sustainability-linked bond supply hinders banks' efforts to incorporate climate risks into loan underwriting. ASEAN banks have large exposures to companies with high carbon-transition risks, and insufficient data hinders their ability to assess climate risks of clients. Despite the benefits of a low-carbon economy, the region's progress in meeting net-zero targets is hindered by these challenges.

site_title: Cathay rallies as Hong Kong plans to ease air travel curbs
summary: Cathay Pacific shares surged 4.9% on Monday after Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced the lift of a flight ban on 9 countries and easing of mandatory quarantine to 7 days from 14. The airline, which has been operating at 2% capacity since the pandemic, expects to see a significant increase in bookings. Hong Kong's easing of restrictions comes after other regions in the Asia-Pacific have started reopening their borders and adapting to living with Covid-19.

site_title: The Batman rules again, crosses US$300m in North America
summary: The Batman has crossed US$300 million in North America, becoming the second pandemic-era movie to achieve this milestone. Despite relatively light competition, the film maintained impressive week-to-week holds, collecting US$36.8 million from 4,302 theaters. The Batman remains at the top of the box office charts for the third consecutive weekend, while Jujutsu Kaisen 0: The Movie and X took second and fourth place, respectively.

site_title: Russia's invasion is accelerating 'splinternet', says French envoy
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine is accelerating the creation of a "splinternet," a forced division of cyberspace under the control of competing political blocs. French digital affairs envoy Henri Verdier warns that Russia's acceleration of domestic online censorship and Ukraine's calls for Russia to be taken offline could lead to devastating cyberattacks and the fragmentation of the internet. Experts say Russia's suspected intention to establish a sovereign internet is likely to be hindered by new US-led export controls, but the risk of a splintered internet remains, with authoritarian countries seeking to replicate China's "Great Firewall" model.

site_title: Turning positive on China equities
summary: China's regulatory environment is expected to stabilize, potentially boosting the domestic equity market. The Financial Stability and Development Committee's announcement on March 16 signaled a pause in further regulatory interventions for the rest of the year. Key government bodies have pledged to maintain economic growth and ease regulatory restrictions, giving investors confidence to turn overweight on China equities. The MSCI China Index is trading at a 12-month forward P/E multiple of 10 times, below its 5-year average, and analysts have raised 2022 earnings estimates for the MXCN by 3%.

site_title: Keppel DC Singapore 1 starts legal suit against DXC over payment default
summary: Keppel DC Singapore 1, a data centre operated by Keppel DC Reit, has initiated a lawsuit against DXC Technology Services Singapore over a disputed payment of approximately S$14.8 million for co-location services from April 2021 to March 2025. DXC disputes its liability, citing the amount as non-existent. The dispute is believed to have a minimal impact on Keppel DC Reit's financial performance. The case will be updated as necessary.

site_title: Hotels to start tracking carbon emissions in 2023, aim to have net-zero emissions by 2050
summary: Singapore's Hotel Association and Tourism Board launched a sustainability road map, aiming for hotels to track carbon emissions by 2023 and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. The industry aims for 60% of hotel room stock to attain internationally recognized sustainability certification by 2025. The road map outlines four strategies: developing sustainable hotel concepts, promoting sustainable habits among guests, sourcing sustainable solutions, and focusing on water conservation, waste management, and energy conservation. The goals align with Singapore's Green Plan 2030 and aim to drive business competitiveness and growth through sustainability.

site_title: More women and fewer long-serving IDs on Singapore listed companies' boards: report
summary: Singapore's largest listed companies saw improvements in women's participation on boards in 2021, with women making up 19.7% of directors at the largest companies by market capitalization. The number of long-serving independent directors fell to 10% as of end-2021. First-time directors accounted for 59% of board appointments, the highest since tracking began in 2015. Women also took on more board chair positions, with 46 SGX-listed companies having a female board chair. Despite progress, 17 companies among the 100 largest had no women on their boards.

site_title: China Huarong returned to profit in 2021 after state bailout
summary: China Huarong Asset Management reported a preliminary net income of 370 million yuan (S$79 million) for 2021, reversing a record loss of 102.9 billion yuan in 2020. The state bad-debt manager attributed the turnaround to a revamped business strategy and accelerated cash recovery. A US$6.6 billion government bailout helped the company pare back its sprawling empire, but its shares remain volatile amid concerns over the industry's long-term growth prospects. Huarong's audited full-year results are scheduled for release next week.

site_title: Malaysia logistics firms may have to pass on cost of Covid-19 tests to Singapore customers
summary: Malaysia's logistics firms may be forced to pass on the cost of COVID-19 tests to their Singapore customers after Singapore stopped offering on-arrival tests at land checkpoints starting Thursday. The new requirement for pre-departure tests, which must be conducted in Malaysia, will increase costs for logistics companies, with estimates suggesting they may charge customers an additional RM20,000 per day. This could exacerbate existing price hikes in the industry, which have seen increases in daily consumables and fuel prices.

site_title: Daily Covid-19 cases in Singapore continue on downward trend, 7,538 new infections
summary: Singapore reported 7,538 new Covid-19 cases on Monday, marking a downward trend for the second consecutive day. The weekly infection growth rate remained below one for the 20th day at 0.72, indicating a decrease in new cases. This follows a similar drop from 7,859 cases on Sunday. The trend suggests a slowing pace of the virus's spread in the city-state.

site_title: Singapore's Q2 net employment outlook strongest in a decade but lower than global average: survey
summary: Singapore's Q2 net employment outlook is at its strongest level in a decade, with 42% of employers expecting to increase headcount, up from 39% in Q1. The seasonally adjusted net employment outlook score is +25%, compared to the global average of +29%. The survey found that digital roles, particularly in the tech, telecoms, and media sector, are in high demand, with 38% of employers expecting hiring growth. The manufacturing sector also reported strong hiring intentions, with 26% of employers expecting an increase in headcount.

images.alt_text: Large organisations with over 250 staff reported the strongest hiring intentions, while medium-sized ones with 50-249 employees had the lowest intention to do so.

site_title: At least 144 victims lost S$190,000 this year from latest rental scam: SPF
summary: The Singapore Police Force (SPF) has reported a resurgence of a rental scam variant, resulting in losses of at least S$190,000 and affecting 144 victims since January 2022. The scam involves scammers posing as landlords or property managers, taking deposits from victims and failing to provide rental properties. Authorities are urging the public to be cautious and report any suspicious activities to prevent further losses.

site_title: Goldman Sachs to offer over-the-counter crypto options trading
summary: Goldman Sachs executed its first over-the-counter (OTC) crypto options trade, trading a non-deliverable Bitcoin option facilitated by Galaxy Digital Holdings. This marks the first major US bank to engage in OTC crypto options trading, which is used to hedge risks or boost yields. The move aims to expand digital-asset offerings to Wall Street investors and could pave the way for other banks to consider OTC trading as a conduit for digital assets.

site_title: Volkswagen China joins with 2 firms to battle runaway costs for EV batteries
summary: Volkswagen China has formed joint ventures with Huayou Cobalt and Tsingshan Group to secure nickel and cobalt supplies for electric vehicle (EV) batteries, amid surging raw material prices. The partnerships aim to control costs, secure supply, and achieve a transparent and sustainable supply chain, targeting a 30-50% cost reduction on each battery. The move follows rising nickel prices due to the Ukraine crisis, with prices doubling to $100,000 per tonne in March. Volkswagen plans to set up six large battery factories in Europe to overtake Tesla as the world's top EV seller by 2025.

site_title: Christie's to auction Warhol portrait of Marilyn Monroe estimated at US$200m
summary: Christie's will auction Andy Warhol's 1964 "Shot Sage Blue Marilyn" portrait of Marilyn Monroe for an estimated US$200 million, expected to become the most expensive 20th-century artwork. The silk-screen work is one of four known "Shot Marilyns" and features Monroe with pink face, ruby lips, and blue eye shadow on a sage-blue backdrop. The painting is described as "one of the rarest and most transcendent images in existence" and will benefit the Zurich-based Thomas and Doris Ammann Foundation, which works to improve children's lives worldwide.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as oil climbs, Boeing slips after 737 crash
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, March 21, 2022, due to a Boeing share slump after a 737-800 jet crash in China and rising oil prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.24% to 34,669.85, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped 0.02% and 0.24%, respectively. The decline came amid ongoing concerns over the Russia-Ukraine conflict and US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: DXC Technology Services faces legal action over alleged payment default at Keppel DC Reit property
summary: Keppel DC Reit's master lessee, Keppel DC Singapore Ltd, has commenced legal proceedings against tenant DXC Technology Services Singapore for approximately S$14.8 million in unpaid colocation services at its data centre in Serangoon North. DXC has disputed their liability, but the dispute is not expected to significantly impact Keppel DC Reit's overall financial performance. The parties have engaged in commercial discussions and mediations, but a mutually acceptable resolution has not been reached.

site_title: Usurping US dollar's dominance an impossible task, fund giants say
summary: US dollar dominance is unlikely to be usurped, according to fund giants, following Washington's freeze of Russia's dollar holdings. The move has sparked speculation about countries like China exploring alternatives to greenback-denominated financial systems. Central bankers are rethinking foreign-exchange reserve security, but investors do not expect a shift away from the US dollar. Instead, Asia is poised to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification, with retail investors in the region expected to drive massive ETF growth. De-dollarization efforts are emerging, but the US dollar's dominance appears secure.

site_title: High Point back on the market after HK-listed buyer pulled out of deal
summary: High Point, a 22-storey condominium in Singapore, is relaunching a collective sale with a reserve price of S$550 million, after Hong Kong-listed developer Shun Tak Holdings pulled out of the deal in December due to cooling measures. The tender period will allow developers more time to evaluate the opportunity, with Savills expecting demand from foreign buyers to resume later this year. The site can be redeveloped into an ultra-luxurious development of up to 98 units, with an average size of about 200 sq m per unit.

images.alt_text: Freehold condominium High Point is taking another shot at a collective sale with a reserve price of S$550 million after Hong Konglisted developer Shun Tak Holdings called off the en bloc deal in December.

site_title: Ukraine rejects Putin's ultimatum to surrender besieged Mariupol
summary: Ukraine has rejected a Russian ultimatum to surrender the besieged city of Mariupol, where nearly 350,000 people are trapped without water and electricity. The ultimatum, which included demands for surrender and recognition of Russian control, was rejected by Ukrainian officials, who urged Europe to significantly increase pressure on Moscow to halt its invasion.
