summary: A restriction on strata subdivision for commercial properties in Singapore may lead to a loss of security for individual owners. Strata owners of commercial space, such as those who house their own business operations, value long-term capital gain and security of tenure. The sale of the freehold strata-owned Tanglin Shopping Centre for S$868 million in February demonstrates the potential for significant returns. However, a restriction could limit opportunities for strata owners, potentially affecting their long-term financial goals.

site_title: North Korea fires multiple-rocket launcher, South says
summary: North Korea fired multiple rocket launcher shots towards its west coast on March 20, South Korea's military reported, amid heightened tensions. The incident occurred around 7:20 am local time and lasted about an hour. South Korea's National Security Council held an emergency meeting in response. The launch comes after North Korea's high-pace missile launches this year, with the US and South Korea warning that the North could resume testing its largest ICBMs.

site_title: Malaysia truck drivers must show negative Covid-19 test results from March 24 as on-arrival tests end
summary: Singapore will stop conducting Covid-19 on-arrival tests at land checkpoints for cargo drivers from Malaysia starting March 24. Instead, drivers must present a negative Covid-19 test result or proof of recent recovery, which can be used for multiple entries. All truck drivers must be fully vaccinated, and those who have recently recovered can enter without a test result if they show documentary proof of infection within the last 90 days.

site_title: China locks down millions more as Covid spreads
summary: China has imposed stay-at-home orders on approximately 4.5 million people in Jilin province, its second-biggest city, as the country battles its largest Covid-19 outbreak in 2 years. The Omicron strain has spread to multiple cities, with over 4,000 new infections reported on Sunday. The lockdowns come after China recorded its first Covid deaths in over a year and amid concerns about the healthcare system's ability to cope with the outbreak. The measures are part of a nationwide effort to contain the spread of the virus.

site_title: TADA follows in Gojek's footsteps with temporary 'driver fee' as operating costs spike
summary: TADA, a ride-hailing operator in Singapore, will implement a temporary driver fee starting April 4 to help drivers with rising fuel costs. The fee will range from S$0.50 to S$0.80 per trip, with the entire amount going to drivers. The company will also roll out a driver campaign offering fuel rebates and S$1 vouchers to passengers. The measures come as petrol prices in Singapore have spiked amid the Russia-Ukraine war. The temporary fee will be reviewed in May if fuel prices drop.

site_title: HK finance chief says monitoring markets to ensure stability
summary: Hong Kong authorities closely monitored last week's stock market volatility, with equities experiencing a historic 4.2% gain, the largest since 2008. Financial Secretary Paul Chan stated there was no excessive accumulation of derivatives positions and brokerages can cope with market risks. Chan also warned of deteriorating unemployment and negative economic growth in the first quarter, with the unemployment rate rising to 4.5%. Despite this, Chan reassured that markets are stable and Hong Kong authorities are monitoring the situation to ensure orderly operations.

images.alt_text: Equities in Hong Kong and China went on a roller coaster ride last week, with a historic rout in the first 2 sessions quickly reversing on Wednesday (Mar15) as China made a sweeping set of promises to stabilise markets and support the economy.

site_title: Pure-play China S-Reits record strong 2021 growth
summary: Five Singapore-listed Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) with pure exposure to China recorded strong growth in 2021. CapitaLand China Trust (CLCT) and Sasseur Reit (CRPU) saw 37.5% and 8.5% increases in distribution per unit, respectively. EC World Reit (ECW) reported 12.7% growth in net property income, while BHG Retail Reit (BMGU) and Dasin Retail Trust (CEDU) saw 14.9% and 10.9% increases in net property income, respectively. The REITs attributed their growth to resilient portfolio occupancy rates, recovery in shopper footfalls, and contributions from acquisitions despite Covid-19 disruptions.

site_title: South Korea's president-elect ditches 'imperial' Blue House office
summary: South Korea's president-elect, Yoon Suk-yeol, has announced plans to relocate his office from the "imperial" Blue House, citing a desire to make the president more accessible and approachable. The move, which is expected to be completed after his inauguration on May 10, has raised concerns about its reported cost of around 50 billion won (S$55 million) and logistical hurdles. Yoon's decision is linked to his belief in shamanistic spiritual practices, including feng shui, which he has denied.

site_title: Google is accused in lawsuit of systemic bias against Black employees
summary: Google is accused in a lawsuit of systemic racial bias against Black employees, alleging the company steers them to lower-level jobs, pays them less, and denies advancement opportunities due to their race. The lawsuit claims Google maintains a "racially biased corporate culture" that favors white men, with Black employees making up only 4.4% of the workforce and 3% of leadership positions. The plaintiff, April Curley, also alleges a hostile work environment, including security checks and ID requirements, at Google's Mountain View, California campus.

site_title: Uber, Lyft drivers consider quitting as pain at the gas pump grows
summary: Uber and Lyft drivers are considering quitting the ride-hailing platforms due to a 55-US cent per-ride surcharge to offset record gas prices. The surcharge, announced in response to the Ukraine crisis, would be paid directly to drivers, but many feel it's "insulting" as they typically pay for their own gas. The move has sparked discontent among drivers who form a significant part of the gig economy.

site_title: Telegram booms as Russia's digital landscape shrinks
summary: Telegram has seen significant growth since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, becoming a popular platform for mass messaging due to the blocking of Facebook and Instagram. The app provides a key window into Russia while also serving as an open channel to report on Ukraine's struggles. Despite concerns over data security and misinformation, Telegram has become a go-to platform for users seeking to stay informed.

site_title: Saudi Aramco 2021 profit more than doubles to U$110b
summary: Saudi Aramco reported a 124% increase in 2021 net profit to $110 billion, driven by higher crude prices and a global economic recovery from the pandemic. The company's president and CEO, Amin Nasser, attributed the results to financial discipline and a long-term growth strategy, despite uncertain economic conditions due to macroeconomic and geopolitical factors. The announcement comes after Yemen's Huthi rebels targeted Aramco facilities in cross-border drone attacks.

images.alt_text: Saudi Aramco on Sunday (Mar 20) has reported that its 2021 net profit soared by more than 120 per cent, due to higher crude prices.

site_title: NYSE owner to remove Russian, Belarusian debt from indexes
summary: Intercontinental Exchange (ICE), owner of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE), will remove Russian and Belarusian debt from its fixed-income indexes on March 31 due to the invasion of Ukraine and sanctions. The move follows similar decisions by other major index providers, including JPMorgan Chase & Co and S&P Dow Jones Indices. The removal aims to address liquidity issues for Russia-related securities and will be subject to applicable laws and regulations. This decision is a long-term hurdle for Russia's assets, potentially undoing decades of financial integration.

site_title: US booking sites seeing strong demand for 2022 travel
summary: US booking sites are seeing strong demand for spring and summer leisure travel as COVID-19 restrictions ease, despite rising fuel prices. Booking activity is 49% higher than last year and 26% higher than pre-pandemic levels. Vacation rental platforms like Vrbo and Airbnb report increased demand, with bookings already outpacing last summer by 15%. Airlines, including Delta, United, and American, expect strong demand to offset rising fuel costs. International travel to Europe has dropped, but bookings to Mexico, Central America, and the Caribbean are increasing.

site_title: Rising mortgage rates won't be enough to end US housing boom
summary: US mortgage rates have surpassed 4% for the first time in nearly 3 years, but economists predict it won't curb the US housing boom. Rising borrowing costs will modestly cool price increases in some markets, but the severe housing shortage and pent-up demand will continue to drive housing costs higher. The intense demand from both traditional buyers and investors will keep housing costs elevated, despite the higher mortgage rates.

site_title: Hong Kong plans to review Covid restrictions on Monday as cases ease
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam plans to review Covid-19 restrictions on Monday, amid growing concerns from residents and businesses about the city's strict policies. The city has seen a net outflow of 50,000 people this month, with cases easing to 14,149 new cases. Lam acknowledged that people are "losing patience" with the city's coronavirus policies, which include a ban on flights from 9 countries and hotel quarantine of up to 2 weeks. The review aims to ease restrictions and allow the city to move towards a "live with the virus" approach.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust signs MOU for potential divestment of 2 malls
summary: Dasin Retail Trust has signed a non-binding MOU for the potential divestment of two malls, Shiqi Metro Mall and Xiaolan Metro Mall, valued at 2.81 billion yuan and 2.02 billion yuan respectively. The sale proceeds will be used to repay existing loans and boost working capital. Sino-Ocean Capital, a substantial unitholder, will jointly manage the purchaser, Wuhu Yuanche Bisheng Investment Center, with GSUM Real Estate Fund Management Co. The MOU does not restrict the trustee-manager from exploring other offers.

site_title: Marquez out after horror crash as Indonesian MotoGP start delayed
summary: Six-time world champion Marc Marquez was ruled out of the Indonesian MotoGP due to a concussion after a horror warm-up crash. Marquez was catapulted from his bike at 180 kmh and appeared to land heavily on his left arm. The race was delayed by heavy rain and reduced to 20 laps due to tyre safety concerns. Current world champion Fabio Quartararo will start from pole position. MotoGP has returned to Indonesia for the first time since 1997, with organisers citing extreme heat and safety concerns as reasons for the changes.

site_title: UK's sky-high house prices are still more affordable than rent
summary: UK house prices have reached an all-time high, but buying a home remains more affordable than renting. The average monthly cost of purchasing a 3-bedroom property (£759) is lower than the £874 rental payment for a similar property, resulting in a £1,378 yearly difference. This gap has widened to the widest since 2015, largely due to record-low mortgage costs. Despite high house prices, buyers in London can save £4,181 a year over renters, who pay £1,700 a month on average.

site_title: P&O told to explain mass firings to angry UK cabinet ministers
summary: UK cabinet ministers have demanded explanations from P&O Ferries over the mass firing of 800 workers, citing a lack of consultation and notification. Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng and Transport Secretary Grant Shapps expressed strong disappointment, warning the company could face prosecution if it breaches employment law. P&O has offered enhanced severance terms but justified the move as a last resort due to financial struggles. The government is investigating the situation, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson's office saying it does not believe P&O exhausted all avenues before dismissing staff.

site_title: Suzuki to invest US$1.3b in India electric car production
summary: Suzuki Motor Corporation plans to invest $1.3 billion in electric vehicle and battery production in India, aiming to increase production capacity for electric vehicle manufacturing in the state of Gujarat by 2025. The company will also build an EV battery plant and a vehicle recycling facility, as part of its long-term plan to achieve carbon neutrality. This move follows similar announcements from major carmakers such as Ford and Sony, which are stepping up production of emission-free vehicles to reduce emissions.

site_title: Brazil bans Telegram in crackdown on 'fake news'
summary: Brazil's Supreme Court banned Telegram, a popular messaging service, in a crackdown on fake news and hate speech ahead of presidential elections later this year. The ban follows repeated attempts by federal police to remove content deemed objectionable. Telegram is known for not cooperating with authorities, and its users have been accused of spreading conspiracy theories and vitriol. President Jair Bolsonaro has used the platform, despite its association with misinformation, and critics say it has become a safe haven for his supporters.

site_title: EU officials mull using sanctioned Russians' assets for Ukraine
summary: EU officials are exploring the possibility of using assets of sanctioned Russian tycoons to fund Ukraine's war recovery efforts. The idea is in its early stages, with no decision made, and would need to be approved by member states. The assets are currently frozen, and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen has not asked for this to be explored, according to spokesman Eric Mamer. This potential move could involve using assets for war reparations.

site_title: Ramos-Horta, Guterres early frontrunners in East Timor election
summary: East Timor's presidential election has seen Jose Ramos-Horta and Francisco Guterres emerge as early frontrunners. Ramos-Horta holds 44.5% of the vote, while Guterres has 24.1%, according to official data. The election, held on March 20, comes as East Timor approaches 20 years of independence and grapples with political instability and economic diversification. If no candidate wins a majority, a second-round runoff will take place on April 19 between the top two candidates.

site_title: EU proposes to create solidarity fund for Ukraine's basic needs
summary: The European Union is considering a solidarity fund for Ukraine to provide basic services and meet citizens' immediate needs. European Council President Charles Michel proposed the fund, which would give liquidity to authorities and serve as a backbone for Ukraine's reconstruction once hostilities stop. The fund could be contributed to through an international donors conference, with partners including the EU.

site_title: MAS and non-profit CDP ink MOU to promote access to ESG data
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and non-profit CDP have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to promote access to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) data and climate disclosures across the financial sector and real economy. The partnership aims to enhance financial institutions' access to ESG data and implement capacity-building programmes for corporates and financial institutions. The collaboration also has "significant synergies" with MAS' Project Greenprint, supporting sustainable finance and investment decisions.

site_title: UK's Johnson gets political lift as Ukraine overshadows 'partygate'
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's leadership appears to be back on track after reports of law-breaking parties in Downing Street overshadowed by Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Senior aides and MPs, including David Davis and Andrew Bridgen, have withdrawn their calls for Johnson's resignation, citing the international crisis as the priority. The Metropolitan Police investigation into alleged gatherings remains ongoing, but the appetite for a leadership challenge is waning ahead of a 2024 general election. Johnson's leadership is expected to continue, despite ongoing scrutiny over lockdown laws.

site_title: Amazon antitrust lawsuit in Washington, DC dismissed by judge
summary: A Washington DC Superior Court judge dismissed a lawsuit against Amazon accusing the e-commerce giant of anticompetitive behavior. The lawsuit, filed by Attorney General Karl Racine, alleged Amazon inflated prices for consumers through policies guaranteeing a minimum profit. The judge found no evidence to support the claim, dismissing the lawsuit. Amazon is among big tech companies facing antitrust scrutiny, following a similar lawsuit proceeding in Seattle and a settlement in Washington state.

site_title: Shell is pushing to build offshore wind farms along Brazil's coast
summary: Energy giant Shell is seeking environmental permits to develop its first offshore wind farms along Brazil's coast, aiming to speed its transition away from fossil fuels. The company proposes 6 projects with a combined capacity of 17 gigawatts, rivaling the output of 15 nuclear reactors. Shell, aiming for net-zero emissions by 2050, has over 8 gigawatts of wind projects in operation and under development globally. Environmental studies for the Brazilian projects are expected to begin later this year, with the company planning to bid into future power auctions and sell electricity to the country's nascent hydrogen industry.

site_title: Oil settles up but posts second consecutive weekly decline
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, with Brent crude futures increasing 1.2% to $107.93 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures rising 1.7% to $104.70 a barrel. Despite the gains, oil prices posted a second consecutive weekly decline, down around 4% for the week. The volatile trading week was driven by concerns over Russian oil supply and the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, with prices hitting 14-year highs nearly two weeks ago.

site_title: Oil pares gain near US$104 to end another volatile week
summary: Oil prices surged 8.4% on Thursday, but pared gains near $104 a barrel on Friday, ending a volatile week. The International Energy Agency warned of a significant price increase in the coming months due to a potential oil supply shortage. A renewed Covid-19 outbreak in China and conflicting news on Russia's peace negotiations with Ukraine contributed to the volatility. The oil market is facing an emergency, with Russia's oil output expected to slump by a quarter next month, and diesel prices also experiencing significant fluctuations.

site_title: Bitcoin to the rescue: cryptocurrencies' role in Ukraine
summary: Cryptocurrencies have played a significant role in Ukraine's war effort, with the government raising over $100 million in cryptocurrency donations since the start of the conflict. The majority of donations came from Bitcoin, Ethereum, and Tether, and have been used to fund aid and military efforts. The use of cryptocurrencies has helped attract younger donors and has been less influenced by geopolitical factors, with faster transfer times compared to traditional bank wires. However, the industry has faced challenges, including the proliferation of fake cryptocurrencies and concerns about its role in the shadow economy.

site_title: From lab to table
summary: Singapore's cultivated meat industry is gaining momentum, with 8 startups developing cell-grown meats since 2018. Companies like Shiok Meats and Eat Just are working to make cultivated meat more affordable, with prices ranging from $4 to $50 per kg. However, the industry faces challenges, including high production costs and regulatory hurdles. To overcome these obstacles, startups are focusing on reducing costs, such as developing low-cost growth media and scaling up production. The industry is expected to grow, with global funding reaching $1.3 billion in 2021, and Singapore's government supporting the sector with $144 million in funding.

site_title: Pure-play China S-Reits record strong 2021 growth
summary: Pure-play China S-Reits recorded strong 2021 growth, with all 5 trusts experiencing increases in rental income and distributions to unitholders. Resilient portfolio occupancy rates, recovery in shopper footfalls, and contributions from acquisitions were key factors. CapitaLand China Trust reported a 37.5% increase in FY2021 distribution per unit and 85.2% higher annual net property income, driven by new acquisitions in logistics and business parks. This growth is attributed to the trusts' diversified portfolios and recovery in the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: CLCT is diversified across 11 retail assets, 5 business parks and 4 logistics properties.

site_title: Bosch curbs Russia activities over military vehicle claims
summary: Bosch, the world's largest auto supplier, has halted deliveries of truck parts to Russian customers following Ukrainian claims that its components were found in Russian military vehicles. The move comes amid European Union sanctions on Russia over its 2014 annexation of Crimea. Bosch stated it took the allegations "very seriously" and initiated a comprehensive review, despite stressing it had not directly supplied components to Russian military vehicle manufacturers. The company has also suspended work at several Russian plants.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes higher after Biden-Xi talks end, oil steadies
summary: US stocks closed higher on Friday, March 18, after talks between US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping over the Ukraine crisis ended without significant surprises. Investors were relieved by stabilizing oil prices and the Federal Reserve's interest rate increase, which was seen as a clear roadmap for monetary policy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.8%, the S&P 500 gained 1.17%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 2.05%, with technology stocks leading the gains.

site_title: Russia's biggest cargo airline to suspend all Boeing flights
summary: Russia's biggest cargo airline, Volga-Dnepr Group, has suspended all flights using Boeing aircraft due to Western sanctions. The airline stopped operations of two subsidiaries, AirBridgeCargo and Atran, that use 18 Boeing 747 and 6 Boeing 737 airplanes. Volga-Dnepr continues to operate Russian-made aircraft, including An-124 and Il-76 cargo jets. The decision follows sanctions imposed by the US and Europe, which have cut off aircraft supply and closed airspace to Russian airlines. Volga-Dnepr is exploring alternative solutions with partners and state regulators.

site_title: KKR eyes raising US$5b to invest in mid-size companies: sources
summary: KKR plans to launch its first mid-size company investment fund, called Ascendant, with a potential raise of up to $5 billion. The fund will focus on North American investments across various sectors. This move is part of KKR's expansion into new strategies to boost assets under management and fee revenue. The firm has indicated it will fundraise across at least 30 strategies this year, including real estate products and a social good fund. The plan is in its early stages, and the fund's details are expected to be revealed soon.

site_title: Xi says improper handling of Taiwan issues will hit China-US ties
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping warned US President Joe Biden that improper handling of Taiwan issues could negatively impact Sino-US relations. Xi emphasized that the Taiwan issue is a sensitive and important matter for China, and US actions could be seen as supporting pro-independence forces. The US reiterated its opposition to unilateral changes to the status quo, while China urged the US to pay attention to the issue. The two leaders also discussed the war in Ukraine, with Xi calling for an end to the conflict as soon as possible and joint support for the Russia-Ukraine dialogue.

site_title: Russia's US$117m debt coupon payout leaves clearing houses
summary: Russia's US$117 million bond coupon payment has been processed through European and US clearing houses, bringing the funds closer to bondholders. The payment was facilitated by JPMorgan Chase & Co as the correspondent bank, Citigroup as the paying agent, and clearing houses. The funds were denominated in dollars and have traveled through the financial system, awaiting delivery to bondholders. This marks a significant step in resolving the debt.

site_title: New Russian cosmonaut team welcomed aboard International Space Station
summary: Three Russian cosmonauts, Oleg Artemyev, Denis Matveev, and Sergey Korsakov, safely docked their Soyuz capsule with the International Space Station (ISS) on March 18, marking the start of a 6.5-month mission. The arrival comes amid heightened tensions between Russia and the US over Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with the US imposing economic sanctions on Russia's space program. The ISS, a 20-year shared Russian-US presence in orbit, continues to operate despite these tensions, with a diverse crew of 7, including Americans, Russians, and a German.

site_title: Swiss banks hold more than US$200b in stashed Russian cash
summary: Swiss banks are estimated to hold more than $200 billion in stashed Russian cash, according to the Swiss Bankers Association. This wealth is stored in offshore accounts, with some estimates suggesting that rich Russians have up to $300 billion stashed away across Swiss lenders. The Swiss government has implemented EU sanctions against Russian companies and individuals, but it is unclear how much cash has been frozen to date. This revelation highlights the extent of Russian wealth stored in overseas vaults, particularly in Switzerland, which has long been attractive to wealthy Russians due to its discretion and light-touch regulation.

site_title: Bank of Japan maintains huge stimulus, warns of growth risks from Ukraine crisis
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its massive stimulus package, warning of risks to the economy from the Ukraine crisis, which is destabilizing financial markets and pushing up raw material costs. Despite inflation approaching its 2% target, the BOJ is not tightening monetary policy, citing the recent energy-driven price rise as transitory. The central bank's dovish tone contrasts with the US Federal Reserve and Bank of England, which raised interest rates this week. Japan's economy is expected to stall in the current quarter due to supply disruptions and Covid-19 curbs.

site_title: Football: Three bids submitted for Chelsea as deadline passes
summary: Three groups have submitted bids to purchase Chelsea FC, a Premier League club, as the deadline passed. The bids are led by British property developer Nick Candy (£2 billion), Chicago Cubs owners the Ricketts family, and a pairing of Martin Broughton and Sebastian Coe. Other potential bidders include Swiss billionaire Hansjoerg Wyss and British businessman Jonathan Goldstein. The sale process was initiated by Chelsea's owner Roman Abramovich due to sanctions imposed by the British government following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Requisitioning shareholders of ecoWise say EGM postponed only because of injunction application
summary: Eight shareholders of ecoWise Holdings, holding an 11.3% stake, have clarified that a previously requisitioned extraordinary general meeting (EGM) was not voluntarily postponed by the company, contrary to its statement. The EGM was postponed due to a temporary injunction obtained by ecoWise's director, Cao Shixuan, and will now take place on April 14 to remove Cao from all roles and appoint new directors. The shareholders claim ecoWise's statement diminishes the credibility of the upcoming EGM and express concerns over undisclosed developments in litigations involving Cao and other directors.

site_title: Biden warned Xi of 'consequences' for backing Russia in war
summary: US President Joe Biden warned Chinese President Xi Jinping of "implications and consequences" for China supporting Russia in the war, amid escalating tensions. The call came after China's refusal to condemn Russia's invasion of Ukraine and amid reports of China's potential military and financial aid to Russia. Xi expressed concern about the global economic crisis and warned the US and NATO to engage in dialogue with Russia to ease security concerns. Biden reiterated US opposition to any unilateral changes to Taiwan's status and warned of consequences for China if it supports Russia.

site_title: Is this the beginning of the end of China's techlash?
summary: The Chinese Communist Party appears to be softening its stance on the tech industry, with a high-ranking official stating that the "rectification" of large tech companies is coming to an end. This comes after a series of regulatory actions against major tech firms, including Didi Global and Tencent, which shaved a third off Chinese tech stocks in March. However, a recent report from the central government suggests that the tech crackdown is nearing its end, with regulators urging transparency and caution in implementing new rules. This shift in tone has led to a surge in Chinese tech stocks, with the Hang Seng Tech Index soaring 22% on March 16.

site_title: China hikes fuel prices to highest levels in more than a decade
summary: China has increased fuel prices to their highest levels in over a decade, with retail petrol prices rising by 750 yuan (S$160) a tonne and diesel prices by 720 yuan a tonne. The hikes, effective March 18, are the largest since China's current pricing mechanism was introduced in 2013. The price increases follow a surge in global oil benchmarks amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The move aims to curb demand and stabilize the economy amidst rising inflation and economic pressure.

site_title: South-east Asia's tourist hubs easing travel restrictions
summary: South-east Asia's tourist hubs are easing travel restrictions to attract more visitors and boost growth in their economies. Starting April 1, Thailand will no longer require a Covid-free certificate for vaccinated visitors, while Vietnam has waived quarantine rules for all international travellers. The Philippines and Malaysia will also allow quarantine-free entry to all fully vaccinated travellers from April 1. This move aims to restore passenger volumes and support the region's tourism-reliant economies, which were severely impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: GIC-backed software startup Grafana seeks funds at US$5b valuation: sources
summary: Grafana Labs, a software startup backed by the Government of Canada's GIC, is in talks to raise new funding at a valuation of at least $5 billion, a significant increase from its $3 billion valuation seven months ago. Existing investors including Sequoia Capital and Coatue Management are involved in the capital raise, which could total $250-275 million. The funds may be used for mergers and acquisitions. Grafana, which provides data visualization tools for enterprise customers, competes with companies like Datadog and Splunk.

site_title: GM buying out SoftBank's US$2.1b stake in Cruise self-driving cars
summary: General Motors announced it is acquiring SoftBank's US$2.1 billion stake in its autonomous car venture Cruise. Additionally, GM will invest US$1.35 billion to cover a commitment made by SoftBank's Vision Fund in 2018. This deal aims to ramp up GM's investments in autonomous technology and electric vehicle capacity, competing with Tesla and other self-driving ventures.

site_title: Rejuvenated Real ready for Barcelona in El Clasico battle
summary: Real Madrid is set to face Barcelona in a highly anticipated El Clasico match at the Santiago Bernabeu. La Liga leaders Real Madrid, 15 points ahead of Barcelona, are expected to secure a win despite coach Carlo Ancelotti's injury concerns over striker Karim Benzema. The match is a must-watch, with Real likely to come out on top, but Barcelona's new-look attack may pose a challenge.

site_title: SMRT appoints ex-LTA chief Ngien Hoon Ping as new group CEO
summary: SMRT appoints Ngien Hoon Ping, former LTA chief, as its new group CEO, effective August 1. Ngien will also join SMRT's board as a director on May 1. He previously led supply chain digitalization and infrastructure projects at NTUC FairPrice and LTA. SMRT's chairman, Seah Moon Ming, expects Ngien's leadership to capitalize on new growth opportunities in the digital age. Ngien succeeds Neo Kian Hong, who will step down and serve as adviser to Ngien until October 31.

site_title: IEA urges 'emergency measures' to cut oil use over supply fears
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has urged governments to implement emergency measures to cut global oil consumption due to supply fears stemming from Russia's invasion of Ukraine. A 10-point plan aims to reduce oil consumption among advanced economies by 2.7 million barrels a day within four months. The measures include increasing working from home, reducing speed limits, and car-free Sundays, targeting the majority of oil demand. The IEA warns that a tightening of supplies could lead to significant oil price escalations, affecting the world's peak demand season.

site_title: PSA International 2021 net profit up 18.2%
summary: PSA International, a Singapore-based port operator, reported a 18.2% increase in net profit to S$1.4 billion in 2021, driven by 11.7% revenue growth to S$4.7 billion. The company handled 91.5 million TEUs, with higher throughput and storage revenue contributing to the increase. Despite supply chain disruptions, PSA's balance sheet remains strong, and the company aims to accelerate sustainable trade through technological and digital capabilities.

site_title: Europe: Stocks post their best week since November 2020
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Friday, marking their best weekly performance since November 2020, driven by optimism over Russia-Ukraine peace negotiations and talks between US President Joe Biden and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping. Technology stocks led the gains, as investors focused on the potential for a peaceful resolution to the Ukraine conflict. The Stoxx 600 index was headed for its best weekly performance since 2020, with the benchmark index closing 0.9% higher.

site_title: F&B outlets starting to pass on costs from utilities bill spike
summary: Electricity costs for food and beverage (F&B) operators in Singapore have risen by 80-300% since late last year due to the exit of independent power retailers from the open electricity market. This has forced operators to switch to pricier plans, with some passing on costs to stall tenants. According to a Restaurant Association of Singapore poll, respondents reported an average rise of 130% in costs, with increases ranging from 38.5-471.8%. The Singapore government has extended a support scheme to protect businesses from volatility in wholesale electricity prices, but many operators are still facing significant price increases, with some expected to pass on costs to consumers.

site_title: Prolonged lockdown in China will exacerbate already volatile supply chains
summary: China's prolonged lockdown will exacerbate supply chain disruptions, with potential price hikes and delays. Manpower shortages due to residents being confined to quarantine facilities or homes are a key concern. Ports are operating, but ports cannot function without workers and truck drivers to move products out of warehouses. Some factories are closed, and those that remain operational may have limited capacity due to restrictions on third-party truckers. Companies like Foxconn and Maersk foresee longer delivery times and increased transport costs.

site_title: Infra funds circle Vodafone for 15 billion euro Vantage Towers deal
summary: Global infrastructure funds, including Brookfield and Global Infrastructure Partners, have submitted proposals to invest in Vodafone's US$16 billion mast company Vantage Towers, valuing it at 15 billion euros. However, Vodafone prefers to seek an industry merger, with sources indicating a potential deal with either Deutsche Telekom's towers unit DFMG or Orange's Totem, due to antitrust concerns. The move aims to align with activist fund Cevian Capital's demands to simplify the portfolio and boost returns, amid pressure to reduce competition and increase profitability in the telecoms market.

site_title: Xi says conflicts like Ukraine crisis in no one's interests
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping told US President Joe Biden that conflicts like the Ukraine crisis are in no one's interests, urging bilateral relations to guide towards world peace. Xi expressed concerns over the Ukraine crisis, while Biden will pressure him to join Western pressure against Russia. The video call aims to persuade Xi to avoid supporting Russia or sending military assistance, warning of "costs" if Beijing aids Russia.

site_title: China's local land sales plunge nearly 30% in first 2 months
summary: China's local land sales plummeted nearly 30% in the first two months of the year, with revenue from state-owned land sales down 29.5% from last year to 792.2 billion yuan. This marks the largest slump since 2015 and highlights the impact of the housing slump on government finances. The decline is attributed to reduced demand from housing developers, leading to a slowdown in property market growth. China's local authorities face pressure to boost economic growth, with the central government promising to transfer more funds to regions.

site_title: Missiles strike Lviv as Biden pressures Xi to abandon Moscow
summary: Missiles struck an airport near Lviv, Ukraine, as Russia attempts to regain the initiative in its campaign against Ukraine. US President Joe Biden is pressuring Chinese President Xi Jinping to condemn Russia's assault, aiming to isolate Moscow from its only major ally. This move is part of a broader effort to starve Russia's war machine by limiting its diplomatic support. The attacks on Lviv, a city hosting hundreds of thousands of refugees, have raised concerns about the humanitarian situation in Ukraine.

site_title: Why private credit's time has come in Asia
summary: Australia is leading the growth of the private credit market in the Asia-Pacific region, with assets under management increasing from A$35 billion in 2015 to A$109 billion in 2020. This growth complements traditional bank lending, offering financing options for underserved companies and sectors. Private credit funds raised a record US$195 billion globally in 2021, and the market is expected to continue growing, potentially becoming a valuable source of capital for Asian businesses. As banks become more selective in lending, private credit is poised to fill the funding gap, particularly for smaller companies.

site_title: STI gains 0.24% amid mixed regional showing
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.24% or 7.92 points to 3,330.63, ending the week higher despite a mixed regional market showing. The best-performing counters were Keppel Corp and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, while Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust fell 2.1%. Analysts attribute the market's cautious optimism to the Federal Reserve's dovish rate hike and unclear Ukraine-Russia talks, which have influenced market sentiment.

site_title: Work-life integration is key
summary: Guillermo Frydman, a Johnson & Johnson executive, attributes his success to a focus on fitness and diet, which he believes is essential for work-life integration and overall well-being. He discovered Thai boxing as a way to stay active during the pandemic and found that the sport requires both physical and mental resilience. Frydman's experience highlights the importance of balancing physical and mental health for individuals to lead a fulfilling life and achieve their goals. His approach serves as an example of the value of prioritizing purpose and joy in one's life.

site_title: PropertyGuru starts trading on NYSE
summary: PropertyGuru, a Singapore-based property listing platform, debuted on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at US$8.61, then fell 9.5% to US$7.79 within an hour. The listing valued the company at US$1.4 billion and secured US$254 million in gross proceeds from private investments. Despite a challenging tech environment, PropertyGuru reported a 22.7% revenue increase in FY2021 and is on track to return to positive adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) in 2022.

site_title: Musings over miles
summary: The author reflects on the meditative benefits of her morning runs, which she calls "dawn patrol." As a runner and journalist, she finds that the early morning hours allow her to process life beyond headlines, clear her mind, and gain perspective. She shares her running experiences and how they influence her writing and journalism, including the importance of patience, trust-building, and taking the time to tell a good story. Her column aims to prompt discussions on various issues and share her thoughts gathered during her morning runs.

images.alt_text: Sunrise by the MacRitchie Reservoir in Singapore.

site_title: Quarz seeks MAS intervention, says MNACT manager has fiduciary duty to seek better price
summary: Activist fund manager Quarz Capital Management has urged the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) to intervene in the proposed merger of Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) and Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT). Quarz claims that the merger undervalues MNACT's assets and questions the fiduciary duty of MNACT's manager to seek a better price. The proposed deal, which would see MNACT unitholders receive a scheme consideration of S$1.1949, is seen as undervaluing MNACT's assets, with the offer price at a 11-13% discount to its net asset value.

site_title: Vickers Venture SPAC to merge with subsidiary of Sorrento Therapeutics
summary: Vickers Venture Partners' special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) Vickers Vantage Corp I is merging with Scilex Holding Company, a commercial biopharmaceutical company focused on developing non-opioid pain management therapies. The merged entity, expected to be named Scilex, will have up to $140 million in funds and is expected to complete by the third quarter of 2022. Scilex's existing equity holders will roll over their equity, owning approximately 88% of the combined entity, and Vickers Vantage Corp I's sponsors will cancel 40% of their private warrants if redemptions exceed 75%.

images.alt_text: Scilex Holding is a subsidiary of pharma giant Sorrento Therapeutics, which is also listed on the Nasdaq.

site_title: Regional security in Asia will require energy cooperation
summary: Government leaders in the Asia-Pacific region emphasized the importance of energy security in maintaining regional stability and security. At the CERAWeek conference, they recognized the need for collaboration and cooperation among governments, finance sectors, industries, and technologies to achieve shared objectives. The region's economies are projected to account for 50% of the world's GDP by 2050, and a reliable energy supply is crucial for growth. Policymakers must balance affordability, reliability, and environmental concerns in energy policy. Energy cooperation will be essential for regional security in Asia.

site_title: Shenzhen lockdown eases as Xi seeks to soften Covid impact
summary: Shenzhen, China, partially eases its strict lockdown on Friday, March 18, 2022, allowing factories and public transport in several districts to resume operations. The move is part of President Xi Jinping's efforts to soften the economic impact of his Covid-fighting measures. Five districts will reopen, with train and bus services resuming, while the rest of the city remains subject to movement restrictions. The decision comes as Covid cases surge in China, with over 4,000 new infections reported, and the government seeks to balance its zero-tolerance strategy with economic concerns.

site_title: Russia's war is creating corporate winners and losers
summary: Russia's ongoing war in Ukraine is causing significant disruptions to global supply chains, creating corporate winners and losers. The war has led to a surge in commodity prices, particularly for steel, nickel, and palladium, benefiting firms like mining and steel companies. However, many companies, especially those with business in Russia, are struggling to manage the fallout, with over 400 announcing their withdrawal from Russia. The conflict is also affecting industries such as airlines, carmakers, and food firms, which are facing rising costs and potential price increases for consumers.

images.alt_text: A few industries are benefitting from the turmoil, from armsmakers to cable news and the lawyers who help firms comply with sanctions. The biggest winners are commodities firms, especially outside Russia.

site_title: UBS sells Japan real-estate venture to KKR for 230 billion yen
summary: UBS is selling its Japanese real-estate venture, valued at 230 billion yen (S$2.6 billion), to private-equity firm KKR & Co. Mitsubishi is selling its 51% stake in the venture to KKR for 116 billion yen. The deal marks UBS' exit from the Japanese real-estate market.

site_title: First Hong Kong-listed SPAC has slow start in trading debut
summary: Aquila Acquisition, Hong Kong's first listed SPAC, had a slow debut on March 18, closing 3.2% lower at HK$9.68 due to limited trading activity. Only a few qualified investors were able to trade the shares, and the firm raised US$128 million in its IPO. This marks a challenging start for the newcomer, with Hong Kong's strict rules for SPACs and global listings slowing down due to investor interest and regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: Myanmar junta approves sale of Telenor subsidiary to Lebanon's M1
summary: Myanmar's junta has approved the sale of Telenor's Myanmar subsidiary to Lebanese conglomerate M1 Group, following months of stalled negotiations. The sale, which includes local consortium Shwe Byain Phyu, has raised concerns among activist groups about the potential transfer of sensitive customer data to the military. The move comes as Myanmar remains in chaos since a coup last year, with over 1,600 people killed and 11,000 arrested. Telenor had cited junta demands for monitoring equipment as a reason for leaving the country, and the sale is expected to put further pressure on the human rights situation.

site_title: Singapore introduces 2 new tax frameworks for companies to strengthen tax compliance
summary: Singapore has introduced two new tax frameworks for companies to enhance tax compliance. The frameworks complement the existing Goods and Services Tax Assisted Compliance Assurance Programme (GST ACAP) and offer benefits such as longer grace periods and waivers for voluntarily disclosing tax errors. The move aims to strengthen tax compliance and support companies in adhering to tax regulations.

site_title: CGS-CIMB shaves Razer target price to HK$2.88 on challenges in hardware segment
summary: CGS-CIMB lowered its target price on Razer to HK$2.88 due to slowing demand in the hardware segment and supply chain constraints. The analyst cut his earnings per share estimates by 27% for FY2022 and 29% for FY2023. Razer's revenue rose 33.3% in FY2021, but gross profit margins for the second half fell 21.4% due to surging logistics costs. The analyst expects Razer's gaming peripherals sales to decelerate to 8% in FY2022 and expects the company to increase investment in its software and services segment.

site_title: Can the finance sector step up as an agent of change in sustainability?
summary: The finance sector is shifting towards a more proactive role in driving sustainability, moving beyond the concept of "finance is neutral." Environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investments are booming, but a more significant opportunity lies in realising the potential of investing in the wider health of a system. The finance sector can influence change at a system level by intentionally investing for the health of the economy, environment, and society. Three key trends – impact investing, judging investments based on thresholds, and influencing the rules of the game – are driving this shift, but a fundamental remodelling of the financial architecture is needed to truly shape a different future.

site_title: Rising rates support a long-term approach to cash management
summary: Rising interest rates and volatile market conditions require corporate treasurers to adopt a long-term approach to cash management, working closely with financial institutions. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes aim to contain inflation, but the ongoing pandemic, rising costs, and uncertain global economy pose challenges. To mitigate these risks, treasurers must find more productive uses for their cash, such as repaying loans, investing in businesses, or increasing shareholder value. Banks must also adapt by offering sustainable solutions and structuring end-to-end services to support long-term corporate treasury relationships.

site_title: BMW X3: A mild improvement
summary: BMW's 2022 X3 facelift features a new front end with a bigger grille and slimmer headlamps, as well as a revamped rear design. The interior now boasts a 12.3-inch touchscreen and a mild hybrid drive system, which improves acceleration and reduces fuel consumption. The X3's driving experience is also enhanced, with a taut steering feel and decent ride quality. The xDrive all-wheel drive system and 48-volt mild hybrid technology make it a strong contender in its class, but the basic xDrive20i version may be the more comfortable and engaging option.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after 3-day rally
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, March 18, after a 3-day rally, amid concerns over peace talks to end the war in Ukraine and the first US interest rate hike since 2018. The Dow Jones fell 0.04%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.10%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.37%. The market's decline follows a week of little progress in peace talks and a rise in interest rates.

site_title: UN says Ukraine food supply 'falling apart'
summary: The United Nations reports that Ukraine's food supply system is deteriorating due to Russia's invasion, with infrastructure destroyed and shops and warehouses empty. Movements of goods have slowed down due to insecurity and driver reluctance. In "encircled cities" like Mariupol, food and water supplies are running out, and convoys have been unable to enter the city, sparking concern about the humanitarian situation.

site_title: Universal Music label acquires ape NFT to lead virtual music group
summary: Universal Music Group acquired Bored Ape #5537, a female character, for $360,817 to lead its virtual music group, Kingship. The group, launched in November, will produce new music and perform in the metaverse. All members of Kingship are NFTs, including 3 Bored Apes and a Mutant Ape on loan from collector Jim McNelis. This move aims to explore the metaverse and create characters that generate excitement, with Universal Music viewing it as a laboratory for experimenting with new forms of entertainment.

site_title: MAS issues 10-year prohibition order to former DBS wealth manager for fraud
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued a 10-year prohibition order against Marcus Loh Thim Mun, a former DBS wealth manager, for cheating clients out of S$490,000. Loh was convicted of forgery and cheating in 2021 and sentenced to 33 months' imprisonment. The MAS prohibits Loh from providing financial advice or participating in the management of any financial advisory or capital markets firm to safeguard the integrity of Singapore's financial sector.

site_title: Australia: Shares record best week in 13 months on boost from mining, energy sectors
summary: Australia's shares rose for a third consecutive day, reaching their best week in 13 months, driven by gains in mining and energy sectors. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.6% to 7,294.4 points, with energy stocks leading the gains, and miners rising 1.8% after iron ore prices climbed. Despite geopolitical tensions and inflationary concerns, investors were buoyed by diminishing concerns over a Russian default and easing concerns over China's Covid cases.

site_title: Russia keeps rates at 19-year high as war stokes inflation surge
summary: Russia's central bank maintained interest rates at 20% for the first time in nearly two decades, following an emergency hike amid the ongoing war with Ukraine. The decision aims to combat inflation, which has surged to 12.54% and is expected to reach 20% in the coming weeks. Despite economic sanctions, the Bank of Russia has taken measures to stabilize markets and maintain confidence in the banking system. The central bank's decision reflects the need to maintain elevated borrowing costs to address the economic fallout and avoid a bank run.

site_title: Aiming to Entrance
summary: The Entrance, a speakeasy-style bar in Singapore, is a mysterious and unique drinking experience. Founder Qyo aims to entrance patrons with molecular gastronomy techniques in her playful cocktails, such as foams and belljars of smoke. The bar's menu features Japanese-European fusion dishes, including nori-shell salmon tacos and arancini with miso butter and shiitake mushrooms. With a 10:30pm cut-off, Entrance hopes to be a one-stop destination for customers looking for a late-night experience, offering a combination of food and drinks that will engage all senses.

site_title: Toyota pauses most Japan production after quake
summary: Toyota has paused operations on 17 of its 28 domestic production lines in Japan for three days due to a parts shortage caused by a 7.4-magnitude earthquake that struck east Japan on Wednesday. The quake, which also affected two million homes, has linked three deaths to the disaster. The halt will impact 11 factories and affect the production of approximately 20,000 vehicles, with Toyota citing ongoing pandemic-related supply chain issues and the global chip shortage.

images.alt_text: The 7.4-magnitude quake jolted east Japan on Wednesday night, derailing a bullet train and initially cutting power to over two million homes.

site_title: US existing home sales plunge in February: NAR
summary: US existing home sales dropped 7.2% in February to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.02 million units, surpassing pre-pandemic levels. Rising mortgage rates, which averaged 4.16% in February, and a prolonged housing shortage priced out first-time buyers, leading to a 2.4% year-on-year decline in home resales. The median existing house price increased 15% to $357,300, while the typical monthly mortgage payment surged 28% from a year ago, a burden for first-time buyers who accounted for 29% of sales.

images.alt_text: US home sales fell more than expected in February as rising mortgage rates and a perennial shortage of houses priced out first-time buyers from the market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore introduces two new tax frameworks for companies to strengthen tax compliance. Koufu Group will charge its stallholders an additional $200-$300 in monthly fees to cover rising electricity costs. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has prohibited a former DBS wealth manager from providing financial advice due to fraud. MAS has also signed a memorandum of understanding with CDP to promote access to quality ESG data and strengthen sustainability disclosures. Singapore shares ended the week higher, gaining 0.24% amid mixed regional market performance.

site_title: Swiss banks hold more than US$200b in stashed Russian cash
summary: Swiss banks are estimated to hold over $200 billion in stashed Russian cash, according to the Swiss Bankers Association. This amount is likely between $150 billion and $200 billion in offshore accounts, with some estimates suggesting it could be as high as $300 billion. The country's long-standing neutrality and light-touch regulation have made it an attractive destination for wealthy Russians. Swiss banks are now facing pressure to report and potentially freeze sanctioned Russian assets, following the country's decision to implement EU sanctions against Russian companies and individuals.

site_title: Porsche to broaden electric lineup with 718 Boxster
summary: Porsche plans to convert the 718 Boxster into an exclusively electric model by 2025, as part of its goal to have half of its sales be battery-only or plug-in hybrid models by 2025. The company expects electric models to be profitable in 2-3 years, with a target of 80% of sales being electric by 2030. This move comes as Volkswagen, Porsche's parent, prepares for an initial public offering of the brand, valued at up to $96 billion.

images.alt_text: Porsche will turn the 718 Boxster into an exclusively electric model from 2025 as the sports-car maker's returns on the successful Taycan improve.

site_title: Singapore's Covid-19 weekly infection growth rate dips to 0.70; below one for 17th day in a row
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 weekly infection growth rate dropped to 0.70, below one for the 17th consecutive day, on March 18, 2022. The Ministry of Health reported 10,594 new cases, a decrease from the previous week's total of 15,345. Hospitalizations also decreased, with 1,175 cases as of Friday noon. Nine deaths were reported, down from 12 the day before. This marks the 17th consecutive day of a growth rate below one, indicating a slowing rise in cases.

site_title: Japan steps up rhetoric against sharp yen falls
summary: Japan's government is warning against sharp yen falls, calling them "undesirable" as they inflate fuel and raw material costs, threatening Japan's fragile economic recovery. Chief Cabinet Secretary Hirokazu Matsuno stated that exchange-rate stability is crucial, while Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda believes a weak yen is generally positive for Japan's economy. The yen has lost over 3% to the dollar this month, with the BOJ maintaining ultra-easy policy despite rising fuel costs and potential inflation.

site_title: Australia sanctions Russian billionaires with mining industry links
summary: Australia has imposed sanctions on two Russian oligarchs, Oleg Deripaska and Viktor Vekselberg, with links to its mining industry, including Rio Tinto's Gladstone alumina refinery joint venture. The sanctions are part of Australia's efforts to increase pressure on oligarchs close to Russian President Vladimir Putin over the invasion of Ukraine. The measures are in addition to existing curbs on 41 oligarchs and immediate family members.

site_title: Requisitioning shareholders of ecoWise say EGM was postponed only because of injunction application
summary: A group of 8 shareholders, collectively owning 11.3% of ecoWise Holdings, claim the company's extraordinary general meeting (EGM) was not voluntarily postponed, but due to a temporary injunction obtained by director Cao Shixuan. The EGM was initially scheduled for Nov 26, but was postponed due to a court hearing. The shareholders intend to convene the EGM on Apr 14 to remove Cao from all roles and appoint new directors. They dispute ecoWise's statement that the EGM was postponed voluntarily, which they claim diminishes the credibility of the upcoming meeting.

site_title: CAS upholds FIFA ban on Russian teams while court deliberates
summary: The Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) has upheld FIFA's ban on Russian teams and clubs from participating in its competitions until further notice, citing the ongoing invasion of Ukraine. The decision prevents Russia from participating in World Cup qualifying playoffs scheduled for March 24. The CAS also upheld UEFA's ban on Russian teams participating in its competitions. No CAS hearing has been scheduled, and Russian teams remain suspended from FIFA competitions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.38 points to 1,591.26, closing higher on Friday. The index saw a trading volume of 3.329 billion lots worth RM5.709 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 468 to 424.

site_title: Singapore introduces 2 new tax frameworks for companies to strengthen tax compliance
summary: Singapore has introduced two new tax frameworks to strengthen tax compliance among companies. The Tax Governance Framework (TGF) and Tax Risk Management and Control Framework for Corporate Income Tax (CTRM) offer benefits such as extended grace periods and waivers for voluntary disclosure of tax errors. The TGF focuses on strengthening tax governance standards, while the CTRM is targeted at large companies with complex structures. Companies that adopt both frameworks are encouraged to ensure proper internal controls and systems to manage tax risks.

site_title: Fortunes of US oil tycoons surge as war sparks chaos in crude
summary: US oil and gas tycoons have seen their fortunes surge due to soaring oil prices sparked by the Russia-Ukraine war. The collective net worth of American oil and gas industrialists on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index has jumped 10% to $239 billion, with some individuals, such as Harold Hamm and Richard Kinder, increasing their wealth by billions. The war has fueled near-record high energy prices, benefiting companies that produce, sell, or transport fossil fuels, including private companies that have taken advantage of the pandemic-driven consolidation of publicly traded companies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up as fears of Russia default ease
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, March 18, as fears of a Russian default on its bonds eased. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.7% and the Topix index added 0.5%. The gains followed a decline in global markets, with European stocks down due to bank and healthcare concerns, and US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: Thailand to scrap pre-travel Covid-19 test to boost tourism
summary: Thailand plans to scrap the pre-travel Covid-19 test requirement for travelers starting April 1, aiming to boost its tourism sector. The new policy, announced by the country's Covid-19 task force, will replace the 72-hour negative test requirement with on-arrival testing. This move follows efforts to reboot the tourism industry, which was severely impacted by the pandemic. The change is expected to help limit the spread of the virus while supporting the country's economy.

site_title: China's low elderly vaccination rate reveals key vulnerability
summary: China's elderly vaccination rate against Covid-19 is concerning, with only half of those 80 and older fully vaccinated. About 51% of over 80-year-olds have received two shots, and 20% have gotten boosters. This contrasts with other countries, such as South Korea, where over 90% of those 80 and over are fully vaccinated. China's reluctance to ease its strict Covid Zero strategy is partly due to this vulnerability, which has led to a significant number of elderly deaths in the current outbreak.

site_title: IEA urges 'emergency measures' to cut oil use over supply fears
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has urged governments to implement emergency measures to cut global oil consumption within months due to supply fears stemming from Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The IEA proposes 10 measures, which could reduce oil consumption among advanced economies by 2.7 million barrels a day within 4 months. These measures include increasing working from home and reducing speed limits to mitigate the impact of rising oil prices.

site_title: Asean envoy to seek favourable conditions for Myanmar peace process
summary: Asean envoy Prak Sokhonn to visit Myanmar next week to lay groundwork for a peace process, amid allegations the junta has delayed negotiations while consolidating power. The envoy aims to hold Myanmar's military boss Min Aung Hlaing to his commitment to end hostilities. Asean has barred the generals from regional summits and insists they must remain sidelined until progress is made, including granting the envoy access to all parties. The visit comes after a UN report accused the military of systematic abuses, including war crimes and crimes against humanity.

site_title: Malaysia will not entertain any territorial claim over Sabah
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob stated the country will not entertain any territorial claims over Sabah, a Borneo state. The claims come after a French arbitration court ordered Malaysia to pay RM62.59 billion to the Sulu Sultanate's descendants, who leased Sabah to a British company in 1878. The Malaysian government has filed to cancel the award, citing the claims as "illegal and in violation of the law." The United Nations and international community have recognized Sabah as part of the Malaysian Federation since 1963.

site_title: AI startup Aibee becomes unicorn with fresh funds from Xiaomi
summary: Chinese AI startup Aibee has become a unicorn after receiving fresh funding from Xiaomi, valuing it at over $1 billion. Aibee was planning to raise $100 million but received additional funds from Xiaomi and China Merchants Capital Management. The firm develops AI technologies such as speech recognition and natural language processing, and has partnerships with major Chinese airports and companies like Lenovo and Sequoia Capital China. Xiaomi's investment is part of its exploration of AI areas, including electric vehicles and the Internet of Things.

site_title: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments eyes RTO with US$161.7m acquisition of MoneySmart
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments has entered a non-binding heads of agreement to acquire MoneySmart, a South-east Asian personal financial portal, for US$161.7 million. The deal is expected to result in a reverse takeover of the company, pending approval from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) and shareholders. MoneySmart offers customers a platform to compare financial products across various categories.

site_title: Japan to revoke Hino's engine certification over false emissions data
summary: Japan's transport ministry will revoke Hino Motors' certification for 4 engines due to false emissions data submitted by Toyota Motor Corp unit Hino. The move affects approximately 115,000 vehicles, including those from Toyota Motor and Isuzu Motors. Hino admitted to falsifying data for 3 engines and found performance issues with a fourth. This is part of a string of improper emissions tests by Japanese automakers, including Mazda, Suzuki, and Yamaha, following Volkswagen's 2015 emissions cheating scandal. The certification revocation will be formally announced on March 25.

site_title: Chelsea sale to galvanise Manchester United stock, Crimson says
summary: Chelsea's impending sale, valued at £3 billion, could prompt investors to reassess Manchester United's value after its 29% decline in the past 6 months. Canadian fund manager Crimson Asset Management believes Manchester United's shares will rise due to shifts in sports broadcasting rights as technology giants bid for live events. Crimson founder Ken Jesudian sees Manchester United as a unique asset with significant revenue growth potential. He expects the Chelsea sale to surprise investors and potentially boost Manchester United's stock value.

site_title: STI gains 0.24% amid mixed regional showing
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.24% on Friday, ending at 3,330.63, as regional markets showed mixed performances. Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi gained 0.65% and 0.46%, respectively, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index slipped 0.41%. Analysts attribute the market's performance to uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's rate hike and the unclear outcome of Ukraine-Russia talks, with the STI being driven by advancers like Keppel Corp and Yangzijiang Shipbuilding.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish with small loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day 0.41% lower, closing at 21,412.40, after a 16% gain in the previous two days following China's pledge of support to markets. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.12% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.56%. The losses were attributed to profit-takers entering the market.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks finished on Friday (Mar 18) slightly lower as profit-takers moved in after ratcheting up more than 16 per cent in gains in the previous 2 days following China's pledge of support to markets.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets steadied at the open on Friday, March 18, 2022, following wild swings the previous week. London's FTSE 100 opened flat at 7,386.47 points, while Frankfurt's DAX index and Paris CAC 40 dipped 0.1% and 0.2%, respectively. The market reaction was driven by developments surrounding the Ukraine war and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: South-east Asia's tourist hubs easing travel restrictions
summary: South-east Asia's tourist hubs are easing travel restrictions to attract visitors and boost their economies. Starting April 1, Thailand will remove Covid-19 certificate requirements for vaccinated visitors, while Vietnam has waived quarantine rules for all international travelers. The Philippines and Malaysia will also allow quarantine-free entry to fully vaccinated travelers. These moves follow improving vaccination rates and easing of Covid infections in the region, with tourism accounting for 12.1% of South-east Asia's economic output in 2019. The goal is to restore passenger volumes to at least 50% of pre-Covid levels this year.

site_title: MAS and non-profit firm CDP ink MOU to promote access to quality ESG data
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and non-profit organization CDP have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to promote access to quality Environmental, Social and Governance (ESG) data. The collaboration aims to enhance financial institutions' access to ESG data through the exchange of information between CDP's disclosure system and MAS' Project Greenprint. The goal is to implement capacity-building programs for corporates and financial institutions on climate disclosures, supporting sustainable finance.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post biggest weekly gain in 6
summary: South Korea's stock market posted its biggest weekly gain in six weeks, with the Kospi index rising 1.72% to 2,707.02. The benchmark bond yield rose, while the Korean won strengthened. Investors assessed the Russia-Ukraine situation and the Federal Reserve's tightening cycle. US President Joe Biden will hold a call with Chinese leader Xi Jinping, amid Washington's warning of potential Chinese military support for Russia's invasion. Foreigners were net sellers of 101.8 billion won worth of shares, but the won gained 2.02% for the week, its largest jump since mid-September 2020.

site_title: Moderna seeks FDA authorisation for second Covid booster for all adults
summary: Moderna is seeking FDA authorization for a second Covid-19 booster shot for all adults over 18, following a surge in cases worldwide. The request, filed on March 17, aims to determine the use of an additional booster dose for those at higher risk of Covid-19. This move comes as US health officials consider the possibility of a fourth shot, particularly for older people, to prepare for another surge in cases. The decision follows data showing vaccine efficacy wanes over time and a third shot helps restore it.

site_title: PropertyGuru closes at US$8.46, down 1.7% on its NYSE debut
summary: PropertyGuru's shares closed at US$8.46 on its first day of trading on the NYSE, down 1.7% from its debut price of US$8.61. The company, a Singapore unicorn, listed via a business combination with special-purpose acquisition company Bridgetown 2, backed by billionaires Peter Thiel and Richard Li. PropertyGuru received US$254 million in gross proceeds from investors, including US$100 million in private investment in public equity (PIPE). The platform's valuation is US$1.4 billion, with its equity value at US$1.6 billion.

images.alt_text: PropertyGuru's NYSE listing event on Mar 18 took place with around 250 employees, investors and guests present. The bell-ringing at NYSE was livestreamed at Suntec Singapore Convention and Exhibition Centre Hybrid Experience.

site_title: Port operator PSA International 2021 net profit up 18.2% to S$1.4b
summary: PSA International, a Temasek-owned port operator, reported a 18.2% increase in 2021 net profit to S$1.4 billion, driven by higher throughput and storage revenue. Revenue rose 11.7% to S$4.7 billion, and the company handled 91.5 million TEUs, up 5.6% from 2020. Despite supply chain disruptions and congestion, the company's balance sheet remains strong, with a gross debt equity ratio of 0.4 times. CEO Tan Chong Meng attributed the success to building up physical, technological, and digital capabilities to provide sustainable trade solutions.

site_title: First Hong Kong-listed SPAC has slow start in trading debut
summary: Aquila Acquisition, Hong Kong's first SPAC to list, had a slow trading debut with only 2 trades registered as of 12:55 pm local time, unchanged from its offer price of HK$10 each. The firm raised about US$128 million in its IPO, which is being closely watched by 9 other blank-check firms. The slow start is attributed to limited qualified investors and stringent rules in Hong Kong, which restrict transactions to professional investors and have a minimum fund-raising threshold of HK$1 billion.

site_title: China cuts income tax for some small firms to 20%: finance ministry
summary: China has cut income tax for some small firms to 20% from 25% as part of efforts to ease burdens on businesses and support the slowing economy. The tax cut applies to small firms with annual taxable income below 3 million yuan, assets below 50 million yuan, and fewer than 300 employees. This move follows Premier Li Keqiang's pledge to deliver 2.5 trillion yuan in tax cuts and rebates this year. The measure aims to cushion the economy's slowdown, which affects about 80% of urban employment in China.

images.alt_text: China will cut income tax for some small firms to 20 per cent from 25 per cent, the finance ministry said on Friday (Mar 18), as part of steps to ease burdens on small businesses to support the slowing economy.

site_title: Meet Thailand's 'Chicano' community
summary: In Thailand, a "Chicano" gang has emerged, blending Mexican-American culture with Thai aesthetics. The group, led by Chalakorn "Leng" Arttanasiri, celebrates Chicano clothing and tattoos, but with a focus on aesthetics rather than violence. Members, including former gang members and entrepreneurs, have created a "Thaino" culture that combines blue-collar values with a love for Chicano style. The group has become a tight-knit community, with members embracing their shared lifestyle and rejecting the negative stereotypes associated with the Chicano subculture.

site_title: Russian missiles strike airport near Ukraine's Lviv
summary: Russian missiles struck an area near Lviv's airport in western Ukraine, causing at least three blasts and destroying buildings, but no casualties. The assault is part of Russia's ongoing invasion, which has faltered despite initial expectations of a swift victory. The US and Japan imposed new sanctions on Russian entities, while China declined to condemn Russia's action. The UN reported 2,032 civilian casualties, and 3.2 million civilians have fled to neighboring countries. Talks between Russian and Ukrainian negotiators continued, with no agreement yet reached.

site_title: Surge in US Treasury rates suggests the bond market expects the Fed to slam brakes
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, citing inflation concerns, with Powell promising six more hikes this year. This move sent the Dow Jones soaring over 500 points as stock traders, initially battered by the statement, responded by buying stocks. Treasury yields hit their highest levels since 2019, suggesting the bond market expects the Fed to slow the economy to combat inflation. Despite Powell's reassurances about the economy, the market remains uncertain, with many experts warning of a possible recession due to rising inflation and global economic concerns.

site_title: Shenzhen lockdown eases as Xi seeks to soften Covid impact
summary: Shenzhen, a major Chinese city, has partially eased its strict lockdown, allowing factories and public transport to resume operations in several areas. The move comes as President Xi Jinping seeks to soften the economic impact of his Covid-fighting measures. Five districts will reopen, with train and bus services resuming, while the rest of the city remains under movement restrictions. This easing signals a shift towards a more open policy, with China allowing Pfizer's antiviral pill, rapid-antigen tests, and quarantine facilities for mild and asymptomatic patients.

site_title: Shanghai pushes ahead with mass Covid tests as new cases spike
summary: Shanghai, China, has launched a mass testing initiative to curb a new spike in Covid-19 infections, with symptomatic cases reaching 57 and asymptomatic cases increasing to 203. The city has sealed off dozens of residential compounds for at least 48 hours and plans to test residents on a neighborhood basis. Despite easing some lockdown rules, officials remain committed to the "zero-Covid" policy, with President Xi Jinping signaling that the dynamic clearance policy will not be ditched. The city has ramped up testing capacity to 3 million per day, but shortages of qualified personnel have been reported.

site_title: Koufu to charge stallholders at least S$200 more in monthly fees on higher electricity costs
summary: Koufu Group, a food court operator, will charge its stallholders an additional S$200 to S$300 in monthly miscellaneous fees to cover rising electricity costs, which have increased by 80% to S$500,000. The fees will cover 30% of the increase in electricity costs, with the remaining 70% borne by Koufu. The company has secured a new fixed price electricity contract from July 1, priced 30% higher than the regulated tariff, amid volatility in the wholesale electricity market.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks retreat after biggest two-day rally since 1998
summary: Hong Kong stocks retreated 2.7% on Friday after a two-day surge of 21% since 1998, amid concerns over Beijing's pledge to stabilize financial markets and risks from its ties with Russia. Investors are cautious ahead of a meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Joe Biden, which may provide cues on Sino-US relations and market sentiment. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index fell, while shares on the mainland fared relatively better, losing 0.5%. Economists expect the People's Bank of China to ease monetary policy, which may aid market sentiment.

site_title: SMRT appoints ex-LTA chief Ngien Hoon Ping as new group CEO
summary: SMRT appoints Ngien Hoon Ping as its new group CEO, effective August 1. Ngien, formerly CEO of NTUC FairPrice Group's supply chain business, will also join SMRT's board as a director on May 1. This appointment aims to implement digitalisation and process enhancements in SMRT's operations.

site_title: China weighs Tencent payments overhaul, new licence requirement
summary: China's regulatory authorities are considering requiring Tencent to include WeChat Pay in a newly created financial holding company, part of an overhaul that may necessitate a new licence for the ubiquitous mobile payments service.
