The move aims to separate financial services from Tencent's main business, subjecting WeChat Pay to direct scrutiny of new regulatory bodies like the central bank. This could add uncertainty to Tencent's restructuring and potentially revive investor angst about Beijing's crackdown on technology companies. The overhaul would also subject WeChat Pay to stricter regulations, potentially impacting its convenience and user data.

site_title: Russian risks 'manageable' for Bumi Armada despite significant de-rating: CGS-CIMB
summary: Malaysia-listed oilfield services company Bumi Armada's share price has seen a significant de-rating due to concerns over its exposure to Russia, but analysts at CGS-CIMB believe the risks are manageable. The company has assets in the Caspian Sea that have worked for Lukoil, a Russian vertically integrated oil company, and has secured a new contract for pipelay work. CGS-CIMB has upgraded its rating on Bumi Armada to "add" from "hold" with an unchanged price target of 55 sen, citing potential upside from the company's ongoing bid for TotalEnergies' Cameia FPSO project in Angola.

site_title: Brokers' take: SAC Capital upgrades Grand Venture to 'buy' but trims target price
summary: SAC Capital has upgraded its "buy" call on Grand Venture Tech to "hold" and trimmed its target price to S$1.195 from S$1.30 due to expected higher debt costs and market risks. However, the analyst expects Grand Venture to take on more debt to fund expansion, citing production capacity no longer being a limiting factor. The company's development in front-end capabilities is seen as a key growth catalyst, with significant progress expected from FY2023 to 2024.

images.alt_text: Grand Venture executive chairman Ricky Lee.

site_title: Quarz seeks MAS intervention; says MNACT manager has fiduciary duty to seek better price
summary: Quarz Capital Management has sent a letter to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) expressing concerns over the proposed merger of Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) and Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT). Quarz believes the merger undervalues MNACT's assets and calls for the manager to conduct a more transparent sale process to obtain a better price. The proposed deal offers a scheme consideration of S$1.1949 per MNACT unit, significantly lower than MNACT's net asset value, and could lock in permanent discounts for retirees and retail investors.

site_title: Japan to speed up wind farm projects in wake of Ukraine crisis
summary: Japan plans to accelerate offshore wind farm projects to reduce dependence on oil amid rising prices and potential disruptions in energy supply due to the Ukraine crisis. Industry Minister Koichi Hagiuda announced a revamp of the public tender process to consider not only prices but also the speed of installation. The move aims to increase the country's renewable energy capacity and mitigate the impact of global events on its economy.

site_title: Asia: Traders take breather; Hong Kong slips after huge surge
summary: Asian equities were mixed on Friday, with Hong Kong dropping 1% after a 16% surge in the previous two days due to China's support pledge. Investors took a breather from the rally, while unease over the Ukraine war and oil prices above $100 continued to impact markets. The Federal Reserve announced interest rate hikes, but traders have largely accounted for the impact. Talks between the US and China on the Ukraine conflict will be closely followed, with concerns over Russia's nuclear threats and ongoing volatility in the global economy.

site_title: Temasek's Pavilion Energy appoints Alan Heng as group CEO
summary: Temasek-owned Pavilion Energy has appointed Alan Heng as its group CEO, effective April 1. Heng, who has been interim CEO since August 2021, previously held the managing director for Asia role. With over 34 years of energy industry experience, Heng joined Pavilion Energy in 2013. Chairman Tan Sri Mohd Hassan Marican expressed confidence in Heng's ability to drive progress towards the company's vision as Singapore's global energy merchant.

site_title: Gold eases, set for worst week since late Nov
summary: Gold prices eased, falling 0.2% to $1,938.29 per ounce, as hopes for Russia-Ukraine peace talks diminished the metal's safe-haven appeal. This marks the metal's biggest weekly drop since late November. The US dollar index rose, and US Treasury yields held near three-year highs, raising interest rates and making gold less attractive. Russian troops stalled in their advance on Ukrainian cities, and officials from the two countries met for peace talks but remained far apart.

site_title: War handcuffs Russian central bankers watching demise of economy
summary: Russia's central bank is facing significant limitations due to the devastating economic impact of the war and international sanctions. The Bank of Russia will have limited influence, as its US$643 billion in foreign reserves have been seized. Governor Elvira Nabiullina will review interest rates for the first time since the invasion of Ukraine, amidst widespread household wealth destruction, food shortages, and foreign companies' exit from Russia. The central bank's policymaking role has been significantly curtailed, marking a shift in its 3-decade history.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ho Bee Land, DHLT, CLI, Frasers Property, QT Vascular, Banyan Tree
summary:

site_title: Australia: Shares boosted by energy, mining stocks; set for best week in 13 months
summary: Australian shares rose for a third consecutive session, setting the benchmark index on course for its best week in 13 months. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.3% to 7,270.50, driven by gains in mining and energy stocks, particularly iron ore prices. Energy stocks rose nearly 3% on surging oil prices amid supply concerns, while technology stocks also advanced. Financials slipped but were on track for their best week since February last year.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index opened flat on Friday, with investors cautious after recent gains ahead of a long weekend. The index hovered in a narrow range, up 0.01% or 2.63 points at 26,655.52. The broader Topix index added 0.31% or 5.93 points to 1,904.94. The flat opening follows recent market movements, with investors monitoring US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: Vickers Venture SPAC to merge with subsidiary of Sorrento Therapeutics
summary: Vickers Venture Partners' SPAC, Vickers Vantage Corp I, is merging with Scilex Holding Company, a commercial biopharmaceutical company focused on non-opioid pain therapies. Scilex Holding is a subsidiary of Sorrento Therapeutics. The merged entity is expected to have up to $140 million in funds. The merger aims to develop and commercialize non-opioid therapies for patients with acute and chronic pain.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.67 points or 0.29% to 1,586.21. The market saw 225 losers and 169 gainers, with a total volume of 210.27 million lots worth RM157.95 million.

site_title: Bank of Japan maintains huge stimulus, warns of growth risks from Ukraine crisis
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its massive stimulus package, keeping short-term interest rates at -0.1% and 10-year bond yields around 0%, as the economy shows signs of a fragile recovery. The central bank warned of risks to growth from the Ukraine crisis, which is destabilizing financial markets and pushing up raw material costs. Despite inflation approaching its 2% target, the BOJ is committed to sustaining its stimulus until wage growth is strong, citing the transitory nature of recent energy-driven price rises.

site_title: Micron asks some employees in China to work from home amid Covid-19 resurgence
summary: Micron Technology is encouraging employees at its engineering and customer sites in Shenzhen and Shanghai to work from home amid China's Covid-19 resurgence. Operations in Xian remain normal without restrictive measures. This decision comes as another US chip firm, ON Semiconductor, closed its Shenzhen facility from March 14 to March 20. Chinese factories, including Foxconn, have adopted isolation bubbles to maintain production.

site_title: Europe: Shares higher after Federal Reserve hike, eyes on Ukraine peace talks
summary: European stocks rose 0.5% in choppy trading, driven by commodity stocks and gains in the energy sector, following the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. Investors also eyed Russia-Ukraine peace talks, with Western officials saying the two sides remain far apart. The European Central Bank is expected to hike rates, with investors pricing in a 50-basis-point increase this year.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend gains at Friday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% or 3.36 points to 3,326.07 at open on Friday, tracking global market rallies. Oil and gas firms led gains, with T13 and 5WH shares jumping 6.8% and 5.9%, respectively. The market was influenced by overnight US market rallies, amid hopes for peace negotiations and monetary tightening moves by central banks.

site_title: S&P cuts Russia's ratings to 'CC' on debt default risk
summary: S&P lowered Russia's rating to 'CC' from 'CCC-' due to difficulties meeting debt payments on dollar-denominated Eurobonds. The country's payment difficulties stem from international sanctions restricting its access to the global financial system. The agency believes debt service payments on Russia's Eurobonds due in the next few weeks may face technical difficulties, despite public statements suggesting the government will transfer payments to bondholders. This move reflects the increasing debt default risk for Russia.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB shaves Razer target price to HK$2.88 on challenges in hardware segment
summary: Analyst Ray Kwok of CGS-CIMB lowered his target price on Razer to HK$2.88, citing challenges in the company's hardware segment due to slowing demand and supply chain constraints. Despite a net profit of US$46.2 million in FY2021, Kwok expects Razer's gaming peripherals sales growth to decelerate to 8% in FY2022. The analyst also expects the company's gross profit margins to be negatively affected by surging logistics costs. Meanwhile, Razer is set to focus on its software and services business, which is expected to boost gamer activity in its ecosystem.

site_title: UK cuts tax accord with Russia over Ukraine war
summary: The UK has suspended accords on sharing tax information with Russia, following the country's invasion of Ukraine. The move aims to prevent Russia from benefiting financially from the information. This is part of a series of economic sanctions targeting Russia, including asset freezes, travel bans, and tariffs on imports. The UK has also announced plans to cut out Russian oil imports by the end of the year.

site_title: Malaysia PM warns against undermining king in call for election
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob has warned against undermining the king's authority as pressure mounts within his party to call for a general election. Ismail stated that parliament's dissolution, a precursor to a nationwide vote, must be discussed with the monarch first. His party, the United Malays National Organisation, has called for an early election, but Ismail has indicated that his party will wait, stating "we will wait" and avoiding usurping the king's power.

site_title: Investors cheer China's pledge to support bruised property sector
summary: China's Vice-Premier Liu He pledged support for the battered real estate sector, proposing measures to reduce risks and facilitate a new development model. This move sparked a rally in property shares, with the Hang Seng Mainland Properties Index jumping 14.8% midday Thursday. Top developers such as Sunac China, Country Garden, and China Evergrande rose 47.5%, 22%, and 22% respectively. The government also announced plans to stabilize land and home prices, and encourage mergers and acquisitions to purchase distressed assets.

site_title: Nasa rolls out its mega Moon rocket
summary: NASA has unveiled its massive new Moon rocket, the Space Launch System (SLS) Block 1, which stands 98m tall and will produce 8.8 million pounds of thrust, making it the world's most powerful rocket. The rocket is set to make its first journey to a launchpad on Thursday and will undergo a series of tests before a planned uncrewed lunar mission, Artemis-1, in May. The mission will test the rocket's capabilities and pave the way for future crewed missions to the Moon, with NASA aiming to establish a sustainable presence on the lunar surface by the 2030s.

site_title: Biden to press Xi to get in line over condemnation of Russia
summary: US President Joe Biden will warn Chinese President Xi Jinping that China will face "costs" if Beijing rescues Russia from Western sanctions over its invasion of Ukraine. The call comes as the US leads a pressure campaign on Russia, with Biden seeking to gauge Xi's stance on the issue. China has refused to condemn Russia, sparking concerns that Beijing may provide military or financial support, potentially forcing Western sanctions on China. Biden aims to persuade Xi to use "leverage" to compel Moscow to end the war, but the US is prepared to impose costs on China if it does not.

site_title: Russia scraps UN vote on Ukraine resolution over lack of support
summary: Russia cancelled a UN Security Council vote on a Ukraine resolution due to lack of support from key allies China and India. The resolution, which condemned attacks on civilians, was scheduled for a vote on Friday but Russia's ambassador confirmed it would not happen. The move was seen as an attempt to show Russia still has support on the world stage, but the resolution was doomed to fail due to a veto from western powers.

site_title: Quarz has a case for opposing appointment of director, but other objections not as clear-cut
summary: Quarz Capital has raised concerns about Sabana Reit's proposed appointments of Chan Wai Kheong as an independent director and the issuance of new units. Quarz argues that Chan's substantial payment from ESR Cayman and his stake in a competitor Reit raise questions about his independence. The company also objects to granting the manager leeway to issue new units, citing Sabana's low leverage and potential for borrowing instead. Additionally, Quarz opposes a distribution reinvestment plan, which could dilute its holdings and reduce its voting power.

site_title: US lawmakers vote to end normal trade ties with Russia
summary: US lawmakers voted to suspend Russia's "most favoured nation" trade status, tightening economic pressure on Moscow over its Ukraine invasion. The bill, expected to be quickly passed by the Senate, will allow President Joe Biden to raise tariffs on imports from Russia and Belarus. The sanctions, which include a ban on Russian energy imports, are predicted to lead to a "deep recession" in Russia this year, according to the IMF. The move is seen as a significant escalation of Western pressure on Russia, with Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer calling it a "clear message" to Russian President Putin.

site_title: Shell, Esso lower fuel prices below S$3 mark
summary: Esso and Shell have lowered fuel prices below S$3 per liter, with Esso's 92-octane and 95-octane fuel at S$2.95 and S$2.99, and Shell's 95-octane fuel at S$2.99. The price cuts follow a week of declining oil prices, with Brent crude rising to US$100.11 per barrel. The move comes after Second Minister for Trade and Industry Tan See Leng's remarks about monitoring petrol companies to prevent profiteering.

site_title: Singapore hotel market poised for steady rebound as border curbs ease: CBRE
summary: Singapore's hotel market is expected to experience a steady rebound in 2022 as border curbs ease and visitor arrivals increase, driven by the Vaccinated Travel Lane (VTL) scheme. According to CBRE, the average occupancy for the second half of 2021 grew to 65.3%, with luxury hotels posting the strongest RevPAR increases. The company is "upbeat" yet "cautiously optimistic" on the market's outlook for 2022, citing the release of pent-up travel demand and new initiatives from the Singapore Tourism Board.

site_title: White House discussing new dates for summit with South-east Asian leaders
summary: The White House is discussing new dates for a Washington summit with Southeast Asian leaders after Cambodia postponed the event due to insufficient attendance. The original March 28-29 dates were announced by US President Joe Biden last month. A spokesperson stated Biden looks forward to welcoming Asean leaders, indicating the summit is still planned. No new dates have been confirmed, but the White House is exploring alternative options.

images.alt_text: The White House said on Thursday it is discussing new dates for a Washington summit with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations after Asean chair Cambodia said it had been postponed because not all leaders could attend later this month.

site_title: SocGen, UBS permanently suspend DLCs of various Chinese tech companies after violent price swings
summary: SocGen and UBS have permanently suspended trading of daily leverage certificates (DLCs) for several Chinese tech companies, including JD.com, Alibaba, NetEase, and others, after their underlying stocks surged more than 20% in intraday share prices, triggering the airbag mechanism. This move aims to protect investors from potential losses. The suspension affects DLCs with 3-7 times leverage and is part of a broader market response to recent lockdowns and regulatory crackdowns in China.

site_title: Australia watchdog sues Meta over 'false' cryptocurrency ads
summary: The Australian Competition & Consumer Commission (ACCC) has sued Meta Platforms over alleged false or misleading cryptocurrency advertisements in the country. Meta published ads featuring Australian public figures promoting cryptocurrency schemes, which the regulator claims were "scams" that misled users. The ACCC alleges Meta was aware of the issue but failed to take sufficient steps to address it. Meta is accused of engaging in deceptive marketing practices, potentially harming Australian consumers.

images.alt_text: The Australian competition watchdog has begun proceedings against Facebook owner Meta Platforms, alleging the social media company engaged in false or misleading cryptocurrency advertisements in the country, it said on Friday (Mar 18).

site_title: Oil surges 8% amid warnings of Russian supply shortages
summary: Oil prices surged 8% on Thursday, with benchmark Brent crude futures rising 8.79% to $106.64 a barrel, amid warnings of Russian supply shortages due to sanctions. The price rebound follows several days of losses, with US West Texas Intermediate crude rising 8.35% to $102.98 a barrel. Analysts predict Russian oil production will drop by 1 million barrels per day from April, outweighing a 600,000 bpd decline in global demand. Morgan Stanley raised its Brent price forecast to $120 a barrel, citing a supply squeeze.

site_title: Jho Low was US$87m Vegas whale at late-night baccarat table
summary: Jho Low, a Malaysian financier and fugitive, lost nearly $87 million at the Venetian in Las Vegas, primarily at a baccarat table. Over a 90-minute stint, he wagered $1.75 million and lost $1.75 million. Low's extravagant lifestyle included requests for disco balls, dance floors, and DJs, and he spent over $50,000 at the Venetian. His lavish spending was part of the 1MDB scam, in which he allegedly stole billions of dollars from Goldman Sachs. Prosecutors may use this testimony to refute Ng's claims of meeting Low only once.

images.alt_text: Jho Low was a big man in Vegas. He sported gold lame suits, traveled with an entourage and lost tens of millions of dollars, a New York jury was told.

site_title: Bank of Japan to maintain huge stimulus as Ukraine crisis adds to economic woes
summary: The Bank of Japan is set to maintain its massive stimulus package, focusing on risks to its fragile economic recovery due to the Ukraine crisis. Despite inflation approaching its 2% target, the BOJ will sustain huge monetary support, viewing recent energy-driven price rise as transitory. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda is likely to stress the need for strong wage growth to accompany inflation, ensuring a prolonged period of stimulus. This move reinforces the BOJ's stance as an outlier in a global shift towards tighter monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan is set to maintain its massive stimulus on Friday and focus on risks to a fragile economic recovery from the Ukraine crisis, reinforcing expectations it will remain an outlier amid a global shift towards tighter monetary policy.

site_title: Euro edges up as investors focus on Ukraine talks
summary: The euro rose 0.2% to $1.106, driven by investor interest in Ukraine talks between Russia and Ukraine. The Russian rouble fell 16% to 105.18 versus the dollar after hitting its highest since February 24. The Federal Reserve's monetary policy decision failed to affect the market, with investors already pricing in a hawkish cycle. Other currencies, including the dollar, yen, and pound, also saw fluctuations, while the Australian dollar rose 0.6% after employment data beat expectations.

site_title: JPMorgan Chase has received debt payment from Russia: source
summary: JPMorgan Chase received a debt payment from Russia, a move that alleviated concerns about a potential debt default. The payment, made in a foreign currency, was reportedly $117.2 million, which was sent to Citigroup after US authorities were consulted. The Russian finance ministry had announced the payment on Thursday, following a completed interest payment to foreign debt holders, amid sanctions that have crippled the Russian banking sector. The payment was made after a payment order was sent to a bank on Monday, and the government stated that there were no issues with servicing state debt.

site_title: US: Stocks rally despite rebound in oil prices
summary: US stocks rallied for a third straight session, despite a 8% jump in oil prices, driven by hopes for peace negotiations and planned talks between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.2%, the S&P 500 climbed 1.2%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.3%. Individual companies like Williams-Sonoma and Dollar General also saw gains. The Bank of England raised interest rates to 0.75%, following the Federal Reserve's first rate hike since 2018, amid concerns about inflation.

site_title: SGX RegCo launches sustainability courses; board directors must attend
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has launched 8 sustainability courses for directors of listed companies to meet the new sustainability reporting rules. The courses, offered by various providers, are designed to train directors in sustainability issues and are required for all board directors of equity issuers listed on the exchange. The courses will be conducted virtually or in-person and will start in March, May, July, October, and the second quarter of this year. Directors must attend one of the courses to meet the requirement.

site_title: Oil's typical buying buzz pauses in Asia as Russia upends market
summary: Asian oil buyers are pausing spot purchases amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine, disrupting the trading cycle in the world's biggest crude-consuming region. Typically, a flurry of trades would have occurred by now, but buyers are navigating wildly fluctuating prices and a changing supply picture, with many shunning Russian crude. Middle Eastern suppliers are in high demand, driving up spot differentials, but Opec+ nations have resisted calls to pump more oil, contributing to the volatility.

site_title: CLI, Frasers Hospitality don't see big hit to their businesses in Shenzhen
summary: China's tech hub Shenzhen has been locked down due to a spike in Covid-19 cases, prompting the suspension of non-essential economic activity. However, businesses like CapitaLand Investment (CLI) and Frasers Hospitality, which operate in the area, do not expect a major impact on their businesses. CLI's integrated development Raffles City Shenzhen continues to operate with some adjustments, and Frasers Hospitality's occupancy remains high due to its long-stay guests. The Chinese government has allowed companies to resume work in an orderly manner, but no timeline has been given for the resumption.

site_title: HK leader to review Covid-19 restrictions in coming days
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam announced she will review Covid-19 restrictions in the coming days, amid growing frustration from residents and businesses. The review will include social distancing measures, border restrictions, and a proposal for mass testing. The city has been under a "Zero-Covid" strategy, but daily cases have been hovering around 20,000-30,000, with an estimated half of the population likely infected. The review aims to address concerns from financial institutions and residents, who have been isolated and affected by the restrictions.

site_title: Fear of overpaying replaces Fomo in cooling Kiwi housing market
summary: New Zealand's housing market is experiencing a shift from a frenzied price increase to a cooling trend, driven by a credit squeeze and rising interest rates. The fear of overpaying has replaced the fear of missing out (Fomo) as buyers become less willing to pay record-high prices. Economists predict house prices could fall by as much as 10% this year, with some attributing this to the recent introduction of stricter lending regulations and interest rate hikes.

site_title: Hong Kong raises benchmark interest rate
summary: Hong Kong raised its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 0.75% following the US Federal Reserve's 25 basis point hike. The move aims to maintain financial system stability amid market volatility. Despite this, Hong Kong banks, including HSBC and Standard Chartered, announced they would not change their best lending rates, providing the economy with some breathing room. Economists have downgraded Hong Kong's growth forecasts due to the pandemic's impact, and the HKMA warned of an uncertain global outlook.

site_title: Fertiliser prices to stay high amid supply holdups from Russia-Ukraine war: analysts
summary: Fertiliser prices are expected to remain high due to supply disruptions caused by the Russia-Ukraine war, which affects major fertiliser component producers. The prolonged conflict may also limit global food production, driving up food prices. This is amidst existing pressure from pandemic-related supply-chain problems and demand shifts. Analysts predict that these factors will continue to impact the global market, leading to sustained high prices for fertiliser and food.

site_title: Japan's core consumer prices rise 0.6% in February
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 0.6% in February, the sixth consecutive monthly gain, driven by higher energy and food costs. The tepid increase met market expectations but fell short of the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation goal. Despite this, Japan's consumer prices excluding fresh food and energy prices declined 1.0% for the 11th straight month. Economists expect further price rises due to high energy costs, with some citing the ongoing Ukraine war as a factor.

images.alt_text: Japan's core consumer prices rose 0.6 per cent in February from a year earlier, data showed on Friday, the sixth straight monthly gain as global energy and food prices soar.

site_title: Breaking up SPH is hard to do, says CEO Ng Yat Chung
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) CEO Ng Yat Chung stated that the company is not in divestment mode despite shareholders questioning the value of the sale of sgCarMart. Ng emphasized that the sale price of S$150 million is "above average" but still within the valuation range set by an independent financial adviser. The company is exploring alternative uses for the funds, including investing further and managing debt levels. Ng also stressed that SPH will not return capital to shareholders unless it has a clear plan for the funds.

images.alt_text: SPH CEO Ng Yat Chung said: "As a matter of principle, we should not be thinking about returning capital to shareholders unless we have no idea what we want to do with the capital."

site_title: Cultivated calories
summary: Startups in Singapore are developing cell-grown meats to produce cultivated meat, which could be more environmentally friendly and healthier. However, producing it is expensive, averaging around $1,000 per kilogram. Companies are working to lower production costs, and BMW has introduced a new feature called xDrive to its X3 SUV. In other news, a writer shares her musings on running and sustainability, and a financial literacy program is launched to support women. These developments highlight the intersection of technology, sustainability, and innovation in various industries.

site_title: Ukraine crisis could cut 1% off global growth this year: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) estimates that the Ukraine crisis could cut 1% off global growth this year, adding 2.5 percentage points to inflation. Targeted government spending hikes could reduce the war's economic impact by around half without adding to inflation. The OECD warns of a 1.4% negative impact on the eurozone economy and 0.9% on the US economy, primarily due to Europe's dependence on Russian energy imports. Central banks should focus on normalizing monetary policy while being prepared to intervene in financial markets.

site_title: Will the Fed cause a recession with its rate hikes?
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates further to combat inflation, with some economists warning this could lead to a recession. Economist David Rosenberg believes the Fed's aggressive rate hikes could choke off demand, causing a recession. He cites the example of Paul Volcker, who raised interest rates in the 1980s, but at the cost of two recessions. Rosenberg also notes that high inflation, food and energy prices, and a potential European recession could also contribute to a recession. However, other economists, including those from the Federal Reserve and Capital Economics, are more optimistic, predicting a strong economy and minimal risk of recession.

site_title: Bank of Japan vows to stick with stimulus
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reaffirmed the need for continued monetary stimulus, citing Japan's differing inflation dynamics compared to the US, making it challenging to reach its 2% inflation goal. The BOJ is expected to maintain its current settings, amid speculation about potential normalization steps. Inflation is expected to rise in April due to the removal of cheaper cell phone fees from calculations, potentially reaching 2% or higher, with economists warning of a sluggish economy still struggling to regain its pre-pandemic level.

site_title: Some areas of Shenzhen to restart work, public transport on Mar 18
summary: Shenzhen authorities announced that five districts in China's southern city can restart work and resume public transport from March 18, following "community-wide Covid-19 dynamic clearance." Certain areas in these districts still require Covid control measures, while other districts must adopt differentiated measures for companies.

site_title: Further savings withdrawals can hurt Malaysia's pension scheme
summary: Malaysia's decision to allow a fourth Covid-related withdrawal from Employees Provident Fund (EPF) savings may harm the country's pension system in the long term, experts warn. With 6.1 million EPF members having less than RM10,000 left, academics say this won't address short-term financial struggles and may lead to asset sales, reducing the pension fund's investments. Economists estimate the impact to be minimal, but experts propose reforms, such as a tiered dividend structure, progressive contribution system, and expanding into healthcare schemes to create a sustainable retirement plan for Malaysians.

site_title: The future of SPH Media - it isn't enough to be trusted
summary: Singapore Press Holdings' (SPH) new media arm, SPH Media Trust (SMT), faces significant challenges in the digital era, with better-resourced social media giants and consumers preferring online streaming platforms. To survive, SMT needs innovation, but its current monopoly environment and limited competition hinder this. Trust is crucial, but it doesn't guarantee subscriptions. SMT must deliver a best-in-class user experience, address its value proposition, and adopt a consumer-focused mindset, prioritizing the interests of Singaporeans and reflecting diverse perspectives. By doing so, SMT can re-occupy its role as a national crucible of ideas, fostering a national consensus.

site_title: Pfizer, Moderna sued by Alnylam in new fight over Covid shots
summary: Alnylam Pharmaceuticals has filed lawsuits against Pfizer and Moderna, alleging infringement of its patents for Covid-19 vaccines. Alnylam claims its lipid nanoparticle technology is a crucial component of the vaccines, developed to deliver mRNA treatments. The company is seeking damages, but has stated it won't impede vaccine production or distribution. Moderna has called the lawsuit "blatant opportunism," while Pfizer has not commented.

site_title: Singapore exports expected to stay buoyant but economists warn of headwinds
summary: Singapore's exports are expected to remain buoyant, but economists warn of headwinds from the Russia-Ukraine war and China's lockdowns. The country's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) growth eased to 9.5% in February, the slowest in 6 months, due in part to a decline in non-monetary gold shipments. Despite this, demand for key exports such as electronics is expected to stay strong.

site_title: F&B salaries up 20% in 2 years and set to rise further
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) industry is facing manpower woes, with wages rising by 20% over the past 2 years. To cope with this, F&B operators are planning to raise salaries further, with some expecting a 10% increase in total employment expenses this year. New entrants to the industry may offer higher salaries, driving staff turnover, while established players focus on retention and developing a new generation of talent. The industry is under pressure to provide competitive salaries due to the tight labor market and reduced availability of foreign labor.

site_title: Fewer commercial strata units in city centre will benefit shoppers, tenants: consultants
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in Singapore has introduced a new policy to restrict commercial properties in key areas from being subdivided into individual strata units. The move aims to improve tenant mixes, mall upkeep, and reduce vacant units in the Orchard Road shopping belt and Central Business District (CBD). Real estate consultants welcome the change, citing benefits such as improved tenant diversity, curated offerings, and lower vacancy rates. However, some experts note that single ownership can also lead to more efficient management and higher rents, and that the policy's impact on strata retail will depend on market demand and supply dynamics.

site_title: Malaysia's plan for sole 5G network positive for telecoms industry: analysts
summary: Malaysia plans to lease out a single 5G network to telcos, with the government retaining a 30% stake. Telcos can acquire up to a 70% stake in state agency DNB, bringing certainty to the industry after months of deliberation. Analysts say the decision is a relief, as a second 5G provider was recommended by telcos due to transparency and pricing issues. The single network model may be inefficient, but the government's offer could help assuage concerns and lead to more reasonable wholesale pricing.

site_title: Generic drugmakers sign on to make cheap version of Pfizer Covid pill
summary: Thirty-five generic drugmakers worldwide will produce cheap versions of Pfizer's Covid-19 oral antiviral Paxlovid for 95 low- and middle-income countries, under a UN-backed deal. The pills, which reduced hospitalizations by 90% in a clinical trial, will be royalty-free in low-income countries and 5-10% royalty in middle-income countries. Pfizer aims to produce at least 120 million treatment courses this year, but will provide around 10 million to low- and middle-income countries.

site_title: STI up for third consecutive day on positive global developments
summary: Singapore shares rose for a third consecutive day, driven by positive global developments. The Straits Times Index (STI) advanced 0.97% or 31.81 points to 3,322.71, with the exception of the Jakarta Composite Index. Optimism was fueled by US monetary policy clarity, China's market support pledge, and progress in Russia-Ukraine peace talks. Despite volatility concerns, the medium-term outlook remains positive, with no recession in sight.

site_title: Aircraft insurers brace for deluge of Russia claims
summary: Aircraft insurers are preparing for a surge in claims from lessors of planes stuck in Russia since sanctions began. Insurers are cancelling policies, including war risk coverage, and may challenge existing claims. The potential loss is considered staggering, potentially the largest aviation insurance loss in market history, according to Marsh insurance broker.

site_title: RHB upgrades Singapore technology stocks to 'overweight'
summary: RHB upgraded Singapore technology stocks to "overweight" due to undemanding valuations following a global tech sector correction. Analyst Jarick Seet cited robust outlooks for certain companies, including Frencken Group and Venture Corp, and expects the easing of global component shortages to lead to better full-year results and positive rerating of the sector. Seet also highlighted China's central government's coordination of capital market regulations, which should positively impact global tech stocks and Singapore's tech counters.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after Fed-driven rally
summary: US stocks opened lower on March 17, 2022, following the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance on inflation, which investors are closely monitoring alongside the Ukraine crisis. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 67.71 points, the S&P 500 dropped 12.75 points, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 75.83 points. These losses come after the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records on July 11, 2022.

site_title: US mortgage rates jump, topping 4% for first time since 2019
summary: US mortgage rates have jumped to 4.16%, surpassing 4% for the first time in almost 3 years, according to Freddie Mac. The average 30-year loan rate rose from 3.85% last week and is the highest since April 2019. The surge is linked to a 25 basis point interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve, which aims to combat inflation. The increase in borrowing costs makes homeownership increasingly out of reach for many Americans, with monthly payments on a $300,000 loan rising to $1,460.

site_title: US housing starts rebound sharply in Feb; building permits fall
summary: US housing starts rebounded 6.8% in February to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.769 million units, exceeding economists' forecasts. Permits for future homebuilding fell 1.9% to 1.859 million units. Despite rising mortgage rates, homebuilding is likely to remain supported by a shortage of homes available for sale, with a backlog of unsold homes waiting to be started.

images.alt_text: US housing starts jumped 6.8 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.769 million units in February.

site_title: US homebuilder sentiment drops to lowest in 6 months
summary: US homebuilder sentiment has dropped to a 6-month low in March, reaching 79, according to the National Association of Home Builders (NAHB)/Wells Fargo gauge. Labour and supply constraints, rising mortgage rates, and soaring materials prices have contributed to the decline. Builders are reporting growing concerns and expect higher interest rates to price prospective homebuyers out of the market. Sales expectations for the next 6 months have slumped to 70, the lowest since June 2020, with the North-east and South experiencing decreases in builder sentiment.

site_title: China finds way to do 'Covid Zero' while keeping factories open
summary: China has found a way to maintain its "Covid Zero" policy while allowing factories to reopen, as seen in Shenzhen, where tech company Foxconn Technology Group partially resumed operations using a "closed-loop" system, where workers are ferried from dormitories to factories for regular testing and checks. This approach may provide a blueprint for shielding the economy and supply chains from the virus.

site_title: Indonesia makes U-turn to replace palm oil export curbs with levy
summary: Indonesia has made a policy U-turn, removing export volume restrictions on palm oil products and replacing them with a levy. The country's Trade Minister, Muhammad Lutfi, announced the change in a parliamentary hearing, citing supply scarcity and a price disparity between the domestic market obligation and market price. The export levy will be raised from a combined maximum of US$375 per tonne to between US$575 and US$675 per tonne, with the maximum crude palm oil levy to be applied when prices reach US$1,500 per tonne.

site_title: A war of surprises in Ukraine, both tragic and inspiring
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has defied expectations, with Ukraine giving Russians a "tutorial on fighting and dying for freedom and self-determination" despite being invaded by Russia. Meanwhile, Chinese President Xi Jinping's "zero tolerance" Covid-19 strategy has led to widespread lockdowns and a surge in the omicron variant, hurting Russia's oil price strategy. The war has also revealed extraordinary acts of courage, such as Marina Ovsyannikova's public dissent against Putin, and kindness, like Airbnb's makeshift foreign aid system. Global networks are connecting people worldwide to support Ukraine, with over $17 million donated through Airbnb and 36,000 people signing up to welcome refugees.

site_title: Ho Bee Land divests Munich office asset, books gain of 44.8m euros on notes investment
summary: Ho Bee Land divested its Munich office asset, Elementum, generating an estimated gain of 44.8 million euros (S$67.1 million) from its notes investment. The company booked this gain after selling the property, which was initially acquired through a 92 million euro note investment in 2018. The proceeds from the sale will be used for working capital purposes, and the divestment's impact on net tangible assets per share would have increased earnings per share.

site_title: Off the grid ways to enjoy nature
summary: Local residents and expats have sought alternative ways to connect with nature during the pandemic, such as cycling and outdoor activities. One family, Joanna Cheng-Ajlani and her family, took a 2-day Mongolian yurt getaway to push their comfort zones and explore new experiences. This trip exemplifies the desire for novel ways to enjoy nature amidst travel restrictions.

site_title: Amazon closes MGM deal after regulators decline to oppose it
summary: Amazon has closed its $8.5 billion acquisition of film studio MGM after US regulators declined to challenge the deal. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) failed to take action before the deadline, and European Union regulators also gave the deal their approval. The deal adds 25,000 hours of content to Amazon's streaming services, including the James Bond franchise. Amazon's acquisition is its largest since buying Whole Foods in 2017, and it cements the company's position as a major player in the streaming industry.

site_title: China's President Xi says country will 'stick with' zero-Covid strategy
summary: China's President Xi Jinping reaffirmed the country's commitment to its zero-Covid strategy, citing the need to "stick with" scientific accuracy and curb the spread of the epidemic. The strategy has been challenged by the highly transmissible Omicron variant, leading to lockdowns and restrictions in cities such as Shenzhen. Xi emphasized the need for targeted measures, including vaccination, rapid testing, and drug research, to control outbreaks and prevent imported infections.

site_title: Bank of England raises rates to 0.75%, less sure about future moves
summary: The Bank of England raised interest rates to 0.75% for a third consecutive meeting, as expected, but softened its language on future increases. Eight out of nine MPC members voted to raise rates, with Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe voting to keep rates on hold due to higher commodity prices. Inflation is forecast to reach 8% in April, with the risk of peaking higher later this year. Policymakers pushed back against bets of sharp rate hikes by the end of the year, citing risks on both sides of their judgement.

site_title: Razer posts US$46.2m net profit in FY2021, but warns of slowing momentum
summary: Razer posted a net profit of US$46.2 million in FY2021, up 833% from US$5.6 million the previous year, driven by strong demand for gaming and remote work hardware. Total revenue rose 33.3% to US$1.62 billion, with hardware sales increasing 34% to US$1.45 billion. The company expects a "high base effect" amid slowing growth momentum, but plans to invest in new areas, including furniture and lifestyle categories.

site_title: Singapore's weekly infection growth rate for Covid-19 drops to 0.73
summary: Singapore's weekly Covid-19 infection growth rate dropped to 0.73, a decrease from 0.76 the previous day. The Ministry of Health reported 10,713 new cases, a drop from 11,278 on Wednesday. The lower rate indicates a slowing increase in new cases, but the number of infections remains high.

site_title: The Fed could trigger a recession by going too far to raise interest rates
summary: The US economy may fall into a recession this year due to the Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes to combat inflation, which has reached a 40-year high. Economist David Rosenberg warns that the Fed's actions could choke off the demand side of the economy, leading to a recession. High interest rates hurt the stock and housing markets, which could reduce consumer spending and income. Rosenberg cites historical precedents, such as Paul Volcker's aggressive rate hikes in the 1980s, which led to two recessions. Despite this, many economists, including Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, remain optimistic about the economy's resilience.

images.alt_text: The economist David Rosenberg says it's not just possible, but likely, that the US economy will fall into a recession this year, partly because the Federal Reserve will go too far in raising interest rates to fight inflation, which is at a 40-year high.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil exports grew 9.5% in February, easing from the previous month. The city's hotel market is poised for a steady rebound as border restrictions ease, with visitor arrivals expected to increase. Malls and shops in the city centre may see improvements due to new restrictions on strata units. Meanwhile, the Singapore Exchange Regulation launched 8 sustainability courses for listed company directors, and shares rose for a third consecutive day following positive global developments.

site_title: Top London auction houses cancel June Russian Art Week
summary: London's top auction houses Christie's, Sotheby's, and Bonhams have cancelled sales of Russian art in June due to Western sanctions on Russia. The decision follows Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with Britain imposing sanctions on hundreds of Russian individuals and entities. The art market's response aims to avoid doing business with those on sanctions lists, potentially affecting Russian buyer numbers, which have fallen since the 2008 financial crash. The cancellation may also impact collectors and dealers working with Russian art, amid concerns of accidentally transacting with sanctioned individuals.

site_title: Deliveroo reports rising annual losses as costs jump
summary: Deliveroo, a UK-based international takeaway food app, reported a 36% increase in annual losses to £308.5 million due to rising costs, offset by a 57% surge in revenue to £1.8 billion. The company attributed the losses to inflation and the Ukraine war. Despite strong sales growth, Deliveroo faces questions over its sustainability, with investors concerned about its high marketing expenditure. Founder Will Shu forecast breakeven by mid-2024, but analysts expect challenges in the competitive market.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam mulls easing Covid rules as public tolerance 'fading'
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam is considering easing Covid-19 restrictions due to waning public tolerance. The city has seen nearly a million cases and 4,600 deaths in less than 3 months, despite strict measures. Lam's administration has faced criticism for unclear messaging and handling of the crisis. A roadmap for easing restrictions is not available, but Lam aims to balance public health concerns with growing public frustration.

site_title: Accenture warns of potential impact from Russia-Ukraine conflict
summary: Accenture forecasts third-quarter revenue above Wall Street estimates, excluding the impact of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, which has increased economic and political uncertainty. The company's shares rose nearly 5% in premarket trading. Accenture previously discontinued business in Russia and is strategically investing in cloud, acquisitions, and partnerships to gain more market share. The company expects revenue between $15.70 billion and $16.15 billion for the current quarter, above analysts' average estimate.

site_title: Tartuffe, France's most popular play, returns to the Singapore stage
summary: Wild Rice's production of Tartuffe, France's most popular play, is returning to the Singapore stage. The play, which premiered in Singapore in 2011, stars Dennis Sofian, Benjamin Chow, Jo Tan, Oon Shu An, and Ivan Heng. The production will bring the classic play to life with a talented cast and crew. The exact dates for the production are not specified, but it is expected to be a highly anticipated event in Singapore's theatrical scene.

site_title: Platforms offer driver rebates, discounts to switch to non-petrol vehicles as higher fuel prices bite
summary: Singapore's ride-hailing and food delivery platforms, including Grab, Gojek, and foodpanda, are offering driver rebates and discounts to help them cope with rising fuel prices. The platforms have partnered with petrol stations to provide discounts, with Grab offering up to 29% off and foodpanda offering up to 30% off at Esso petrol stations. In response to fuel surcharges, Uber and Lyft have introduced temporary surcharges in the US. To offset fuel costs, foodpanda is raising riders' service fees, while Gojek is reviewing support measures and fares to ensure fair compensation to its driver partners.

site_title: Bank of England raises rates to 0.75%, less sure about future moves
summary: The Bank of England raised interest rates to 0.75% for the third meeting in a row, as expected, but softened its language on future increases. Eight out of nine members voted for the rate hike, with Deputy Governor Jon Cunliffe dissenting. Policymakers warned of higher inflation, reaching around 8% in April, and potential energy bill increases in the autumn. They also pushed back against bets of sharp rate hikes by the end of the year, citing risks on both sides of the judgment.

site_title: Ukraine crisis could cut 1% off global growth this year: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) estimates the Ukraine crisis could cut 1% off global growth this year and add 2.5 percentage points to inflation. Targeted government spending hikes of 0.5% of GDP could reduce the war's economic impact by half without significantly adding to inflation. The negative impact on the eurozone economy could be up to 1.4% and in the US, it would be about 0.9%. Central banks are advised to focus on normalizing monetary policy and intervene as necessary to keep financial markets functioning.

site_title: Creme de cassis for the 21st century
summary: Creme de cassis, a French liqueur made from black currants, has been produced commercially since 1841. Initially banned in the US in 1911 due to a disease-resistant strain of the berry being introduced, the ban was lifted in New York in 2003. Today, the liqueur is used in various cocktails, such as the El Diablo and Manhattan, and can be enjoyed on its own as a sweet and acidic flavor enhancer. A contemporary approach to the classic liqueur has been developed by Rachael Petach, who sweetens her C Cassis with honey and uses a botanical approach to the flavor profile.

images.alt_text: Stirred into a split of bourbon and rye, creme de cassis helps create a contemporary take on a manhattan.
An El Diablo, a spicy-sweet mix of tequila, creme de cassis, fresh lime and ginger beer.

site_title: Banyan Tree president Eddy See appointed group CEO, taking role count to 3
summary: Banyan Tree Group has appointed president Eddy See as its new group CEO, taking the total number of CEOs to three. See, 58, will also serve as managing director of the hospitality management business unit, overseeing short and long-term goals and strategies to drive business performance. The appointment is part of the company's leadership development and succession planning.

site_title: Calling digitally-savvy global citizens: How about joining a country club in the Cloud?
summary: Figment's founder Fang Low is exploring the metaverse for a new living space concept. He previously successfully launched a co-living business in the physical world, but instead, he's focusing on the virtual space. Low sees the metaverse as an opportunity to reimagine living spaces, potentially targeting cities like Hong Kong and Dubai. This venture represents a new direction for the company, shifting its focus from physical to virtual living.

site_title: Toyota pushes ahead with production schedule despite hurdles
summary: Toyota plans to assemble 800,000 vehicles per month globally in the April-June quarter, down from a year earlier. Despite normal factory operations, the automaker won't recover lost output due to the pandemic and chip shortages. Toyota faces challenges from the Covid pandemic, cyberattacks, and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The company lowered its production plans and warned that exceeding its targets is unlikely due to rising risks. An earthquake in Japan also halted several plants, further impacting production. Toyota's manufacturing situation remains at its limit.

site_title: Ping An Insurance profit falls 29% amid premium income pressure
summary: China's Ping An Insurance reported its largest annual profit fall since 2008, with a 29% decline to 101.6 billion yuan in 2021 due to pressure on premium income. Life insurance premium income fell 4.1% year-on-year, while property and casualty insurance premium income fell 5.5%. The decline was attributed to uncertainty in consumer spending on long-term protection products, driven by complex economic situations and COVID-19 resurgences.

images.alt_text: China's Ping An, the country's largest insurer by market value, reported its biggest annual profit fall since 2008 on Thursday (Mar 17) amid pressure on its premium income.

site_title: Taiwan central bank surprises, raises benchmark rate to curb inflation
summary: Taiwan's central bank raised its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 1.375% to curb inflation, exceeding expectations. The move follows the US Federal Reserve's rate hike and high commodity prices due to the Ukraine war. The bank revised its 2022 GDP growth outlook to 4.05% and predicted a 2.37% consumer price index increase. The rate hike aims to maintain price stability and curb anticipation of domestic inflation.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall amid strong demand for workers
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell to 214,000 in the week ended March 12, down 15,000 from the previous week. Economists forecast 220,000 applications, but the actual number was lower. This marks a significant drop from the record high of 6.149 million in early April 2020. The strong demand for labor and low unemployment rate contribute to high inflation, while the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points, aiming to push borrowing costs to restrictive levels by 2023. The labor market remains tight, with 11.3 million job openings at the end of January.

images.alt_text: The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits fell last week as demand for labour remained strong.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust's N-E Japan properties sustain 'minor physical damage' from quake
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust's properties in northeastern Japan, DPL Sendai Port and DPL Koriyama, sustained "minor physical damage" from a magnitude 7.4 earthquake on March 16. A preliminary inspection by the property manager found no casualties, and all properties remain operational. The trust will continue to monitor the situation and provide updates. The company's units closed at S$0.815, up 0.6% or S$0.005, before the update.

site_title: Bank of Japan vows to stick with stimulus
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that monetary stimulus must continue due to Japan's differing inflation dynamics compared to the US, keeping its 2% price goal out of reach. The central bank is expected to leave its main settings unchanged on Friday, amid a weakening yen and rising US interest rates. Inflation is expected to rise to 2% or higher, driven by commodity price surges and stagnant wages, and Japan's economy is struggling to regain its pre-pandemic level. The BOJ will prioritize sustainable inflation over short-term goals.

site_title: Singapore artists hold exhibition to help Russia-Ukraine war victims
summary: Singapore artists are holding an anti-war exhibition to raise funds for Ukrainian war victims. Approximately 2 dozen artists, including notable figures like Jeremy Hiah and Shengen Lim, are showcasing their artworks, with sales proceeds going to support Ukrainian families displaced by the conflict. The exhibition, which runs until March 31, features a range of art pieces, from paintings to collages, with prices ranging from S$10 to S$2,000. The event aims to raise awareness and funds for the victims of the war, with all proceeds also supporting the non-profit organization Artists At Risk.

site_title: Indonesia central bank holds rates, sees no need to act until price risks grow
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, kept interest rates at record lows, citing no need to hike rates until inflation rises. The benchmark 7-day reverse repurchase rate remains at 3.50%, with the central bank acknowledging risks from the war in Ukraine and rising energy prices. Governor Perry Warjiyo stated that monetary policy responds to fundamental inflation rises, not volatile food or administered prices, and maintained its 2022 GDP growth target at 4.7-5.5%. The rupiah has held up well despite US monetary tightening plans.

site_title: Simple pleasures at Willow
summary: Nicolas Tam's solo debut at Willow restaurant in Singapore offers a thoughtful and precise menu that balances comfort food and fine dining flair. The restaurant, part of the Ebb & Flow group, serves a unique blend of Japanese and Singaporean cuisine, with dishes like smoked sawara and umeboshi sauce, and a hybridized chawanmushi. Prices are steep at $148 for lunch and $198 for dinner, but the quality of ingredients and Tam's mastery of Japanese cooking techniques justify the cost. With a strong team and passion, Tam's approach works for now, but a clearer definition of Willow's direction is needed for long-term success.

site_title: A war of surprises in Ukraine, both tragic and inspiring
summary: Vladimir Putin's war against Ukraine has been marked by unexpected surprises, with many of the bad surprises coming for him and the good surprises for Ukraine and its allies. Putin had expected a swift victory, but instead, Ukrainians have shown remarkable courage and resilience in resisting Russian aggression. Meanwhile, China's Covid-19 strategy has backfired, leading to widespread lockdowns and economic losses. The war has also revealed extraordinary acts of kindness, including a grassroots aid system using Airbnb to support Ukrainian hosts and refugees. These surprises highlight the interconnectedness of the world and the power of global networks to shape the course of events.

site_title: QT Vascular to acquire 3 Eastern Dental Surgery clinics for S$1.3m
summary: QT Vascular has entered into conditional sale and purchase agreements to acquire three Eastern Dental Surgery clinics in Singapore for S$1.3 million. The clinics, located in Jurong West, Bukit Batok, and Jurong East, are expected to support the company's investments and ventures in the healthcare business. The acquisition represents a premium of 2,094.2% over the net total assets of Eastern Dental Surgery Group, which reported net profit of S$380,000 in 2021. The deal is conditional upon seller approvals and is expected to be completed within a 3-year handover period.

site_title: Airbus interested in taking over Atos' cybersecurity business: report
summary: Airbus is reportedly interested in acquiring Atos' cybersecurity business, citing a source. Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury believes the topic is too complicated, and the company has opted against buying Atos as a whole. This comes after Atos' cybersecurity arm, BDS, was not for sale, with French defense company Thales previously exploring a plan to buy the business. No outright takeover is currently on the cards, but Airbus is in discussions with its partners and suppliers about the potential acquisition.

site_title: Homebuilder sentiment in US drops to lowest in 6 months
summary: US homebuilder sentiment fell to a 6-month low in March, dropping to 79 from 81 in February, due to labor and supply constraints, rising mortgage rates, and reduced sales prospects. This decline is attributed to soaring materials prices and workers shortages, which have reduced inventory and pushed up prices. The National Association of Home Builders (NAHB) expects housing affordability to erode further as the Federal Reserve prepares to raise interest rates to contain inflation.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's empire faces fresh risks to nascent recovery
summary: Li Ka-shing's conglomerate CK Hutchison Holdings reported a 15% increase in profit to HK$33.5 billion in 2021, driven by recovering retail and port operations. However, the company's net income remains 16% lower than pre-pandemic levels in 2019. Risks to the company's recovery include global economic uncertainty, new Covid-19 variants, and currency fluctuations, particularly due to the war in Ukraine and currency fluctuations. The company raised its full-year dividend, but warned of uncertain economic outlook for 2022.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open higher awaiting BoE rate call
summary: European stocks rose at the open on March 17, 2022, ahead of the Bank of England's interest rate decision to combat UK inflation. London's FTSE 100 climbed 0.5%, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices rose 0.4% and 0.6%, respectively. The Bank of England's rate decision follows the Federal Reserve's US borrowing cost hike.

site_title: Bank of England set to lift key rate to pre-pandemic level
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise its benchmark interest rate to 0.75% on Thursday, marking the third consecutive increase in rates, as policymakers respond to a worsening inflation outlook. The rate hike is in response to high energy prices and inflation, which may peak at 7.25% this year. The move is part of the global effort to rein in inflation, following the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. Investors will closely watch the minutes for any signals on future policy decisions, including a potential 50-basis-point increase in June.

site_title: China finds way to do 'Covid Zero' while keeping factories open
summary: China has implemented a "closed-loop" system in Shenzhen, allowing some companies to partially resume operations while keeping workers in a bubble to prevent Covid-19 spread. This system, used by iPhone maker Foxconn and other manufacturers, involves regular testing and travel between company-run dorms and factories. The move may help minimize economic disruption as China's "Covid Zero" strategy continues, with economists warning about the impact of lockdowns on the country's economy. The system's effectiveness in preventing outbreaks has been compared to China's use of a bubble during the Beijing Winter Olympics.

site_title: Japan earthquake halts work at Toyota and Nissan plants
summary: A magnitude 7.4 earthquake struck northern Japan, halting work at Toyota and Nissan plants in Iwate and Miyagi prefectures. Toyota's factories remain suspended, with some equipment damaged at Denso's Fukushima plant. Nissan's Iwaki factory, already scheduled to close, has no reported damage or injuries. Operations are set to resume at Toyota's engine factory in Miyagi after safety checks. The earthquake killed 4 people and injured over 100.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor and Nissan Motor halted operations at plants in northern Japan after a magnitude 7.4 earthquake struck off the coast of Fukushima prefecture late on Wednesday (Mar 16).

site_title: Japan chip heavyweights halt output after quake, in another blow for auto industry
summary: Japanese chipmakers Renesas Electronics and Murata Manufacturing Co suspended operations after an earthquake hit Japan's north-east, affecting the global auto supply chain. Renesas halted production at 2 semiconductor plants, while Murata stopped operations at 4 factories. The disruptions are the latest blow to the industry, with Toyota Motor Corp estimating a 10% lower global production target in May and 5% lower in June. The quake's impact on supply chains remains uncertain, with Renesas assessing damage at its Naka plant.

site_title: Fear of overpaying replaces Fomo in cooling Kiwi housing market
summary: New Zealand's housing market is experiencing a shift from frenzied price increases driven by Fomo to a fear of overpaying. After a year of record-low borrowing costs and tight supply, a credit squeeze and rising interest rates have cooled the market. House sales in February were the lowest for the month since 2011, and prices are now 2.3% below their November peak. Some economists predict prices could sink as much as 10% this year, with a credit crunch and rising interest rates to blame.

site_title: S Korea looks to end Covid restrictions despite record surge in cases, deaths
summary: South Korea has recorded a record 621,328 new daily Covid-19 cases and 429 deaths, driven by the highly infectious Omicron variant. Despite the surge, the government plans to end most Covid restrictions, including a curfew on eateries and vaccine passes, citing low public concern about severe health impacts. Nearly 63% of the population has received booster shots, and experts believe widespread vaccination has helped limit deaths and cases. The government expects to ease further measures, such as gathering limits, as early as Friday.

site_title: CLI, Frasers Hospitality don't see big hit to Shenzhen businesses from temporary lockdown
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) and Frasers Hospitality don't expect a significant impact from Shenzhen's temporary lockdown on their businesses. CLI operates integrated developments in Shenzhen, with some food and beverage outlets offering takeaways and delivery, while lodging properties remain operational. Frasers Hospitality's Fraser Suites Shenzhen occupancy is over 80% due to its location in the business district and long-stay guests. The companies are prioritizing health and safety, with some staff staying at the property for daily testing. Shares in CLI and Frasers Property show minimal impact from the lockdown.

images.alt_text: At Fraser Suites Shenzhen, many senior executives make up the strong base of long-stay guests, said Frasers Hospitality chief operating officer Mark Chan.

site_title: Singapore exports expected to stay buoyant but Ukraine war, China lockdowns pose headwinds
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 9.5% in February, slower than expected, but still buoyant. The slowdown was attributed to a decline in non-monetary gold exports and base effects. Despite this, economists predict NODX could rise slightly sequentially excluding volatile segments. The Russia-Ukraine war and China's lockdowns pose headwinds, but the impact on Singapore's exports is expected to be limited. Economists warn of downside risks due to geopolitical tensions and supply chain disruptions, but overall, the export environment remains supportive.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 19.56 points or 1.24% to 1590.88. The index saw 3.34 billion lots traded worth RM3.70 billion, with 756 gainers outpacing 296 losers.

site_title: Ho Bee Land divests Munich office asset, books gain of €44.8m on notes investment
summary: Ho Bee Land divested its Munich office asset, Elementum, generating an estimated gain of €44.8m (S$67.1m) from its notes investment. The company had invested in the property in 2018, and the sale will be used for working capital purposes. The divestment accounted for 4% of Ho Bee's net asset value and 8.6% of its total net profits. The move is expected to boost the company's earnings per share, although the exact timing is unclear.

site_title: Malaysia's plan for sole 5G network positive for telecoms industry: analysts
summary: Malaysia has decided to lease out a single 5G network to telcos, despite initial concerns from the industry. The government will retain a 30% stake in the state agency Digital Nasional Berhad (DNB), while telcos will acquire up to a 70% stake. Analysts say this decision brings certainty to the industry and allows for greater oversight and transparency. The single network model is expected to be financially neutral to telcos, and may help alleviate concerns about competition and pricing.

site_title: Competition for Asia Pacific real estate assets to intensify in 2022: JLL
summary: Investor confidence in Asia Pacific real estate remains strong, with 9 in 10 expecting increased capital deployment in 2022, driven by record US$177.3 billion in 2021. Competition for assets is expected to intensify, with 41% anticipating volumes to rise to between US$178 billion and US$192 billion. Key sectors include logistics assets in Sydney, multifamily properties in Japan, and office space in Singapore. Investors are focusing on core-plus and value-add strategies, and direct deals, joint ventures, and platform/entity level deals to deploy capital amid increased competition and uncertainty.

site_title: Russian government sites facing unprecedented cyberattacks: report
summary: Russian government websites are facing unprecedented cyberattacks, with technical efforts to filter foreign web traffic underway. The attacks have targeted government entities and state-owned companies, including the Kremlin, Aeroflot, and Sberbank, amid events in Ukraine. The cyberattacks have increased in power, reaching 1 terabyte, 2-3 times more powerful than previous incidents.

site_title: SGX RegCo launches sustainability courses; board directors are required to attend
summary: SGX RegCo has launched 8 sustainability courses for listed company directors to fulfill sustainability reporting rules. The courses, offered by various providers, cover different topics and will be conducted virtually or in-person. Directors must attend one of the courses to meet SGX sustainability reporting rules, which require confirmation of training in the first sustainability report for financial years starting Jan 1, 2022. The courses aim to train directors in sustainability issues crucial for long-term corporate governance.

site_title: Hong Kong raises benchmark interest rate after Fed tightens
summary: Hong Kong's monetary authority raised its benchmark interest rate by 25 basis points to 0.75% following the US Federal Reserve's move, maintaining financial system stability amid market volatility. This decision mirrors the Fed's rate hike, as Hong Kong's currency is pegged to the US dollar. Despite this, HSBC and Standard Chartered announced they wouldn't change their lending rates, providing the economy with some breathing room. Economists have downgraded Hong Kong's growth forecasts due to the ongoing pandemic, and the HKMA cautioned that the global outlook remains uncertain.

site_title: Europe car sales hit record low for February over supply snarls
summary: Europe car sales plummeted to a record low in February, with new-vehicle registrations in the EU falling 6.7% to less than 720,000. Supply chain issues, exacerbated by the war in Ukraine, are expected to delay a recovery of European auto sales in 2022, with Bloomberg Intelligence predicting flat sales this year. Some markets, like Germany and Spain, reported modest growth, while others, such as Italy and France, experienced double-digit declines. The industry faces ongoing challenges from semiconductor shortages, the war in Ukraine, and fresh Covid outbreaks in China.

site_title: Thousands of households without power in north-east Japan after earthquake kills 4
summary: A magnitude 7.4 earthquake struck north-east Japan, killing at least 4 people and injuring nearly 100. Thousands of households remain without power, with 36,400 households affected by Tohoku Electric Power Co, although most are expected to have supply restored later. The quake also severed transport links, with Shinkansen bullet train service indefinitely suspended and major highways closed for safety checks. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida warned of a possibility of further strong tremors over the next two to three days.

site_title: Japanese households' financial assets accumulate to record high: BOJ data
summary: Japanese households' financial assets reached a record 2,023 trillion yen as of December, up 4.5% from the previous year, according to Bank of Japan data. Households held 530 trillion yen of Japanese government bonds, accounting for 43.4% of the total market. This marks a significant increase from previous years, highlighting the growing financial wealth of Japanese households.

site_title: Cathay Pacific says not routing flights through Russian airspace
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has stated it is not routing flights through Russian airspace, following other Asian airlines in avoiding the area due to the Ukraine invasion. This decision may result in longer flight times. The airline reviews its flight routings internally and in consultation with external parties.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.58 points or 0.61% to 1,580.90 at 9:08 am on Thursday, driven by a higher volume of 150.95 million lots worth RM125.94 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 323 to 67.

site_title: New Zealand's Fonterra says China demand holding up despite Covid-19, growth concerns
summary: New Zealand's Fonterra, the world's largest dairy exporter, reports a 13% fall in half-year profit due to rising input costs and lower milk collections. Demand for dairy products in China remains strong despite economic slowdown concerns and Covid-19 outbreaks, with Fonterra's margins squeezed by raw milk prices. The company's chief financial officer says Fonterra could switch product mix to consumer goods if lockdowns in China hurt demand, but so far, higher wholesale dairy prices have not affected margins. Fonterra's interim dividend remains unchanged at 5 New Zealand cents per share.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump to 1-month high after Fed rate hike
summary: Australian shares rose 1% to a 1-month high, reaching 7,250.8, driven by gains in financial and mining stocks after the US Federal Reserve increased interest rates as expected. The Fed forecast 7 rate hikes for the year to contain rising price pressures. Financials, including the "Big Four" banks, rose 1% in their highest since early January, while miners rose 1.3% in their best session since March 7.

site_title: Volkswagen joins sustainable mining initiative to boost scrutiny
summary: Volkswagen has joined the Initiative for Responsible Mining Assurance (Irma), a group setting environmental and social standards in mining, to ensure sustainable raw materials for its electric vehicles. As the world's No 2 carmaker, VW aims to boost scrutiny and transparency in the mining industry. Other carmakers, including General Motors and Ford, are also members of Irma. VW is focusing on cobalt and rare earth magnets, key components in EV batteries, and has partnered with a mine operator to test new certification standards. This move is part of VW's efforts to strengthen its European supplier network and reduce environmental impact.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit 2-week high on Fed rate hike; won jumps most in 2 years
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.33% to a near 2-week high, driven by tech heavyweights tracking US peers after the Federal Reserve's rate hike. The Korean won jumped 1.76% to its sharpest gain in nearly 2 years, while chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix rose 1.14% and 6.44%, respectively. Foreigners turned net buyers for the first time in 9 sessions, gobbling up 462.6 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Fertiliser prices to stay high amid supply holdups from Russia-Ukraine war: analysts
summary: Fertiliser prices are expected to remain high due to ongoing supply disruptions from the Russia-Ukraine war, affecting major producers of fertiliser components. The prolonged conflict may also limit food production, driving up food prices. Analysts, including Maybank's Ong Chee Ting, attribute recent price rallies to supply-side disruptions, further exacerbating existing pressure on food prices caused by pandemic-related supply-chain problems and demand shifts.

images.alt_text: FERTILISER prices are expected to stay high as supplies remain disrupted amid geopolitical conflicts in areas that are the major producers of fertiliser components.

site_title: Australia's ASX restores futures, options trading after outage
summary: Australia's ASX (Australian Securities Exchange) restored futures and options trading after a brief outage due to a "hardware-related issue." The halt occurred at 10 am Sydney time and was resolved at 2.11 pm Sydney time. The issue did not affect equities trading, which remained uninterrupted. This marks the latest disruption to ASX's trading systems, following a similar incident in November 2020 and a brief outage of its market announcement platform in February.

site_title: Oil's typical buying buzz pauses in Asia as Russia upends market
summary: Asian oil buyers are pausing spot purchases due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which is disrupting the trading cycle in the world's largest crude-consuming region.
