The situation has sparked criticism of her handling of the crisis, with many blaming the administration for the spiraling deaths and unclear messaging.

site_title: ComfortDelGro appoints SBS Transit chief executive Cheng Siak Kian as deputy CEO
summary: ComfortDelGro appoints Cheng Siak Kian, CEO of SBS Transit, as its group deputy CEO, effective immediately. This move aligns with the company's succession strategy, following a year-long search for a suitable candidate. Cheng will focus on the group's overseas businesses and global expansion strategy, working closely with current CEO Yang Ban Seng, who will step down as SBS Transit's executive deputy chairman at the upcoming AGM on April 28.

site_title: Japan sets Apr 8 for auction of oil from reserve
summary: Japan will hold an auction on April 8 to sell approximately 1.89 million barrels of crude oil from its national reserve, as part of a US-led coordinated release of reserves to cool rising prices. The sale is expected to take place from May 20, with the oil supply available to winning bidders. This move is part of a shift in the composition of the national reserve, in response to a US request. The sale is aimed at addressing rising oil prices and is part of a global effort to stabilize the market.

site_title: Aston Martin launches 'swan song' V12 Vantage before going electric
summary: Aston Martin launched the last V12 Vantage sports car, a limited-run model with 333 units globally, priced around $300,000. The carmaker has already sold all units before shifting to electric vehicles in 2025, with plans for all new car lines to have an electric option by 2026. The V12 Vantage marks the end of Aston Martin's petrol-powered era, following a successful turnaround under investor Lawrence Stroll, who brought in fresh investment in 2020. The carmaker's first fully-electric vehicle is set to launch in 2025.

site_title: Climate Impact X launches digital platform Project Marketplace
summary: Climate Impact X (CIX), a Singapore-based carbon exchange and marketplace, launched its digital platform Project Marketplace, enabling businesses to list, compare, buy, and retire carbon credits. The platform offers verified carbon projects, third-party ratings, and satellite monitoring technology to create trust in the voluntary carbon market. With a focus on natural climate solutions, CIX aims to accelerate corporate climate action by providing high-quality carbon projects, with over 100 companies already onboarding. The platform is designed for a seamless user experience, with features such as one-click retirement and transfers, and is expected to launch auction and spot exchange platforms in the coming quarters.

images.alt_text: Screenshot of the Project Marketplace platform, which was launched by Climate Impact X on Wednesday (Mar 16). Apart from Project Marketplace, CIX is also developing 2 other platforms - the Auction and the Exchange - which are expected to launch in the second quarter of 2022 and fourth quarter of 2022, respectively.

site_title: RISC-V chip technology firm SiFive raises US$175m, valued at US$2.5b
summary: SiFive, a RISC-V chip technology firm, raised US$175 million in its latest funding round, valuing the company at US$2.5 billion. The funding, led by Coatue, brings SiFive's total funding to over US$350 million. Intel, a significant investor, has expressed support for the RISC-V ecosystem, and SiFive plans to move towards an initial public offering (IPO) with institutional investors. The company's business model involves designing RISC-V chip cores and charging for the designs, aiming to challenge Arm's dominance in the chip industry.

site_title: Hyundai launches plant to produce Indonesia's first electric car
summary: Hyundai launched a new plant in Indonesia, producing the country's first locally assembled electric vehicle. The plant, part of President Joko Widodo's goal to develop a full EV supply chain, will utilize Indonesia's mineral resources, including nickel, cobalt, and copper. The plant, with a starting capacity of 150,000 vehicles per year, will be linked to a Hyundai-LG joint venture battery plant set to open in 2024. By 2024, all EVs produced in Indonesia will use locally made batteries and other key components.

site_title: 7.3-magnitude quake hits east Japan, tsunami advisory issued
summary: A 7.3-magnitude earthquake struck east Japan on March 16, 2022, causing a tsunami advisory for parts of the northeast coast. The quake, centered off the Fukushima region, left 2 million households without power, including 700,000 in Tokyo. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida pledged to gather information and rescue those affected. The Japan Meteorological Agency reported no immediate damage or injuries, but the country remains haunted by the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster.

site_title: Singapore as a leading Maritime City - a roadmap for the future
summary: Singapore has been ranked as the world's leading maritime city for a fifth consecutive time, according to a report by DNV and Menon Economics. The city-state's success is attributed to its strategic port location, growing cluster of maritime services companies, and resilience during pandemic disruptions. However, the coming decade will bring new challenges, including advancements in energy and technology, which will impact the maritime sector. To stay competitive, Singapore needs to foster stronger inter-industry linkages, nurture talent, and accelerate innovation in areas such as data sharing and security.

site_title: Media cloud tech startup Amagi is unicorn after Accel funding
summary: Amagi, a cloud-based media tech startup, has reached unicorn status after securing $95 million in funding from Accel, Norwest Venture Partners, and Avataar Ventures. The New York-based company, which offers broadcast and targeted-ad services, now values over $1 billion. Clients include major media companies like NBCUniversal, CBS, and Rakuten Group. Amagi plans to expand globally with increased marketing efforts, new product offerings, and acquisitions. The company has seen rapid growth, tripling its annual rates over the past three years, driven by the shift to streaming services.

site_title: Singapore shares rise amid Asia rally
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.7% on Wednesday, driven by a rally in regional peers and easing inflation concerns. The decline in Covid-19 cases in China and lower crude prices also contributed to the gains. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index surged 9.08%, while other regional markets such as South Korea, Japan, and Malaysia also saw significant increases. The top-performing stocks on the Singapore Straits Times Index were Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and UOB, while Sembcorp Industries was the only blue-chip counter to end the day in the red.

site_title: Globalisation isn't over, but we need to ditch the fantasies it ushered in
summary: Globalization is not coming to an end, contrary to fantasies that emerged in the aftermath of the Cold War. Intellectual debates shifted from university seminars to mainstream media, producing works like Francis Fukuyama's "The End of History" and Samuel Huntington's "Clash of Civilizations." However, the rise of new global economic players, such as China and India, has led to a new intellectual consensus embracing globalization. The author argues that this consensus has been misguided, and it's time to reassess the concept of globalization and its implications.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport Group has exposure to 4 airports in Russia due to a subsidiary's involvement. Car dealers are expected to trim EV prices ahead of a new COE rule. Malaysia plans to reopen all international borders, including Causeway and Second Link land checkpoints. Grab faces possible class action suits from US shareholder rights law firms following a 37% drop in its share price. Income tax will apply to NFT transactions, according to Singapore's Finance Minister Wong.

site_title: Pair of Jalan Besar shophouses for sale with S$23m guide price
summary: Two freehold shophouses in Singapore's Jalan Besar have been put up for sale via expression of interest with a guide price of S$23 million (S$2,520 per square foot). The 3,267 sq ft property, comprising two storeys and a 4-storey rear extension, is located near Farrer Park and Bendemeer MRT stations and within a 10-minute drive to the Central Business District. The sale price translates to a high-end price point, testing demand for prime Singapore projects above S$3,000 psf benchmark.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Carsome acquires 51% of used car dealer CarTimes in an initial public offering (IPO) push. Most oil retailers in Singapore lowered pump prices this week, but petrol prices remain above S$3 per liter. A GST hike may not lead to public action against firms raising prices due to cost pressures. A new restriction on strata subdivision may not affect commercial en bloc sales, but hinder existing unit owners' plans. EcoWise, a company facing financial difficulties, flagged "material uncertainty" about its ability to continue operations. Singapore shares rose amid an Asia-wide rally.

site_title: Europe: Stocks surge at the open
summary: European stock markets opened sharply higher on March 16, driven by a rally in Asia and concerns over the war in Ukraine, Covid lockdowns in China, and a US Federal Reserve meeting. The FTSE 100 rose 1.3% to 7,265.53 points, while eurozone markets surged over 2%. Oil prices plummeted due to fears of reduced demand in China. Investors are cautious about the war in Ukraine, with concerns about Russia's ability to service its debt.

site_title: Can Germany break up with Russian gas?
summary: Germany is considering breaking up with Russian gas due to the country's significant reliance on Russian imports. Nearly 55% of Germany's natural gas comes from Russia, and the country has been warned by successive US administrations to avoid dependence on a despotic regime. A study by German economists estimates that eliminating Russian gas imports would require cutting gas consumption by 30%, which could be achieved with modest regulation and higher prices. However, the elasticity of substitution for natural gas is low, making it difficult to achieve significant reductions in consumption. Despite the potential economic costs, Germany is exploring options to reduce its reliance on Russian gas, potentially marking a significant shift in its energy policy.

site_title: Beef up support network so lifelong learning can yield payoffs
summary: Singapore's skills training programs, such as SGUnited Skills, aim to support lifelong learning and skills upgrading in the face of technological transformation and pandemic-induced upheaval. However, concerns remain about the value of educational credentials and the need for sustained efforts to match changing industry needs. Vulnerable workers, including mature and mid-career learners, face unique challenges, including limited access to training and resources. To address these issues, Singapore needs to provide greater support, including subsidies, flexible training options, and a positive learning environment, to ensure that skills training programs yield desired returns on investment for both workers and the country.

site_title: Thailand to relax entry rules for tourists as war hits arrivals
summary: Thailand plans to relax entry rules for vaccinated tourists amid the ongoing pandemic and economic recovery. The country's main Covid task force will consider waiving the mandatory pre-arrival Covid-free certificate and lowering the minimum medical insurance requirement to $10,000. Travelers will still need to undergo an RT-PCR test on arrival and a self-administered rapid antigen test on day five. The move aims to support the tourism industry, which has been impacted by the pandemic and Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The nation's main Covid task force will consider on Friday a Health Ministry proposal to waive the RT-PCR test requirement before travelling to Thailand.

site_title: UMNO's comeback brings more flux to Malaysia's politics
summary: Malaysia's opposition party Barisan Nasional (BN) has made a comeback into power, winning the Johor state election and following a similar victory in the Melaka state election last November. BN's resurgence is attributed to the party's dominant component, United Malays National Organisation (UMNO), led by president Ahmad Zahid Hamidi and former Prime Minister Najib Razak, who face graft charges. The comeback has raised expectations for an early election, which could be called this year ahead of July 2023. The move has added to the flux in Malaysia's politics, which has seen a change of leadership three times since 2020, amid rising discontent among Malaysians.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.91 points to 1,571.32 on Wednesday, driven by gains. The index saw 732 gainers compared to 263 losers, with a total trading volume of 2.593 billion lots worth RM 2.711 billion.

site_title: Oil pares some losses after shedding most of Russian war gains
summary: Oil prices rose amid a broader market rally, halting a slump that erased most of the gains following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Oil futures climbed to near $98 a barrel, reversing a 20% decline since the invasion. The International Energy Agency warned Russia's oil output may drop by a quarter next month. Geopolitics and fear drove volatility, with the US Federal Reserve expected to tighten monetary policy on Wednesday, adding to bearish sentiment.

site_title: Hong Kong to close off beaches after mainland China uproar
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam announced the closure of most beaches due to a surge in residents ignoring COVID-19 distancing measures. The decision comes after photos of maskless residents sparked outrage in mainland China, which has been battling a surge in cases. Hong Kong has not gone into a full lockdown, but has strict measures in place, including mask-wearing while hiking and gatherings of two or less. The move is seen as a response to China's anger over Hong Kong's handling of the crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks soar as China pledges support
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 9.08% on March 16, 2022, after Chinese authorities pledged support to the battered markets, citing measures to maintain capital market stability and handle risks for troubled property developers. The Hang Seng Index rose 1,672.42 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 3.48%. Mainland Chinese tech firms, including Alibaba, Tencent, and NetEase, saw significant gains, with some stocks rising over 20%. The news provided relief to investors after a sell-off sparked by concerns over the Ukraine war and US interest rate hikes.

site_title: Toyota cuts April-June production plan as strains persist
summary: Toyota Motor has cut its Japan production plan for the April-June quarter by 20% in April, 10% in May, and 5% in June, reflecting ongoing disruptions. The move comes as the global auto industry faces supply-chain challenges, including the Covid pandemic, cyberattacks, and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The revision has been communicated to business partners, with more detailed figures to be released later. This is the latest in a series of production cuts by the automaker, which has struggled to boost output after months of disruptions.

site_title: Reeling from China's crackdown, Alibaba and Tencent readying big job cuts
summary: Alibaba Group and Tencent Holdings, two of China's largest internet companies, are preparing to cut tens of thousands of jobs due to the regulatory crackdown and slowing economy. Alibaba is estimated to cut around 15% of its workforce, or about 39,000 staff, while Tencent plans to make employees redundant in some business units, with a 10-15% headcount cut in its video streaming and search unit. The job cuts are a response to the impact of China's regulatory crackdown and a slowing economy, which has sharply slowed sales growth and smashed share prices for internet companies.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound from 3-day rout on Wall Street, China rally; Fed in focus
summary: South Korean shares rebounded 1.44% on Wednesday, March 16, after a 3-day rout, tracking a Wall Street rally ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting and improved risk appetite following Chinese equities' surge. The benchmark Kospi rose 37.70 points to 2,659.23, while the won strengthened and bond yields rose.

site_title: Indonesia's Garuda seeks another court extension to verify US$10b claims
summary: Indonesia's state-controlled carrier Garuda Indonesia has asked a Jakarta court for another 60-day extension to verify over $10 billion worth of claims in its debt restructuring process. The airline aims to slash liabilities from $9.8 billion to $3.7 billion, but creditors have submitted $13.8 billion in claims. Garuda wants to finalize negotiations with all parties before the deadline, citing unverified claims and future liabilities under long-term leases. A court decision is expected on March 21.

site_title: Malaysia to stick with plans for single, state-run 5G network
summary: Malaysia's finance minister has decided to stick with plans for a state-run 5G network, despite objections from telcos, which had recommended a second network to boost competition. The government will retain a 30% equity stake in Digital Nasional Bhd (DNB) and offer up to 70% to telcos. The decision aims to maintain policy continuity, with the minister stating that a single wholesale network model is the preferred approach.

site_title: NortonLifeLock's US$8.6b Avast deal hits snag as UK raises concerns
summary: NortonLifeLock's $8.6 billion acquisition of Avast has hit a snag as the UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) launched a deeper investigation into the deal due to concerns over competition. The CMA stated that the merger could harm competition and lead to British customers receiving a worse deal when looking for security software, resulting in Avast shares plummeting 11%. The proposed merger aimed to create a leader in consumer security software for over 500 million customers.

site_title: ecoWise shareholders with 11.3% stake to convene EGM to oust deputy CEO, appoint 3 directors
summary: Eight ecoWise shareholders, holding an 11.3% stake, plan to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on April 14 to remove deputy CEO Cao Shixuan and appoint three new non-executive directors. The shareholders, who collectively own 107 million shares, had previously requisitioned for an EGM in 2022 and 2023, but it was blocked by an interim injunction. The new directors, Danny Oh Beng Teck, Gan Fong Jek, and Tan Poh Chye Allan, have been interviewed by ecoWise's sponsor. The EGM will determine the company's composition, with the outcome potentially leaving only one executive director.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise on oil price drop, gains in Chinese stocks
summary: Japanese shares rose for a third consecutive session, driven by a drop in oil prices and gains in Chinese stocks. The Nikkei share average increased 1.7% to 25,762.01, while the Topix rose 1.46% to 1,853.25. The gains were fueled by a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike expected to boost risk appetite, and China's Vice Premier Liu He's announcement of economic measures. Chipmakers Tokyo Electron and SoftBank Group were top gainers.

site_title: Japan set to remove most Covid-19 restrictions as new infections ebb
summary: Japan is set to announce the lifting of most Covid-19 restrictions on March 21, as new infections caused by the Omicron variant continue to decline. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida is expected to ease curbs on Tokyo and other prefectures, including border measures and local business restrictions. The move comes after a slow start to Japan's Covid-19 vaccine booster program, with 71% of vulnerable elderly population receiving a third dose. Experts warn that the current Omicron wave may not be over, but the restrictions have lost effectiveness in changing public behavior.

site_title: Rising vaccination to boost Indonesia consumption amid volatile commodity prices: Fitch
summary: Indonesia's consumer confidence and spending are expected to recover as vaccination rates rise, driving economic and social activity. The country's consumption-driven economy is reliant on private spending, which is expected to grow despite the government's efforts to reduce fiscal stimulus. However, volatile commodity prices, including oil and food, could drive inflationary pressures and erode purchasing power. Fitch Ratings notes that while commodity prices are expected to moderate over the medium term, regulatory uncertainty will continue to pressure the sector.

site_title: Carsome acquires 51% of used car dealer CarTimes in IPO push
summary: Carsome, a used car platform backed by Qatar Investment Authority and Temasek-linked investors, has acquired a 51% stake in Singapore-based CarTimes Group, a used car dealer and parallel importer, for around US$60 million. The deal, valued at half in cash and half in shares, aims to boost Carsome's inventory and expertise in running a physical car dealership. The acquisition is part of Carsome's push to list on the public market and compete in the region's US$55 billion automotive market.

site_title: New iPhones help 5G handsets capture more than half the market
summary: Apple's iPhones led the mobile industry to a milestone in January, with 51% of smartphone sales being 5G handsets for the first time, according to Counterpoint Research data. This marks a significant shift towards 5G connectivity, seen as key for transformative technologies like autonomous driving and factory automation. The milestone comes as 5G adoption accelerates globally, with China being a major driver of expansion.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher as tech, banks gain, Fed outcome in focus
summary: Australian shares closed 1.1% higher at 7,175.2 points on Wednesday, driven by technology and healthcare stocks amid expectations of a 25 basis point interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve. Technology stocks rose 3.7%, while financial stocks climbed for a third session, and energy stocks gained 0.2% following rising crude prices. The gains were attributed to investors picking up high-quality stocks at low prices, despite a rate hike, and easing commodity price pressures.

site_title: Hong Kong pushes to open Greater Bay Wealth Connect to brokers
summary: Hong Kong regulators have given in-principle approval to expand the Wealth Management Connect program to hundreds of licensed brokerages, offering more competition to existing banks in the US$500 million annual fee market. The program, launched last year, allows for cross-border investments in the Greater Bay Area and currently has 23 approved banks. However, a hurdle remains as brokerages are prohibited from distributing and soliciting clients in mainland China. Expansion is expected to require approval from mainland Chinese regulators and will need to address issues such as product offerings and advisory services.

site_title: China markets rebound but analysts flag downside risks to growth
summary: China's stock markets rebounded on Wednesday after registering heavy losses earlier due to lockdown fears. The rebound was partly attributed to assurances from Chinese authorities that the market will remain stable and support overseas share listings. However, analysts flag concerns over downside risks to China's growth, citing potential disruptions to exports, retail sales, and industrial production due to the lockdowns. Some analysts have lowered their growth forecasts for China, citing spikes in commodity prices and the "zero-Covid" policy. Despite this, they expect the Chinese authorities to implement fiscal easing and interest rate cuts to boost the economy and reach this year's GDP growth target.

site_title: Covid curbs bite at Chinese ports, threatening global supply chains
summary: China is experiencing its biggest spike in Covid-19 infections since 2020, with the Omicron variant spreading across major manufacturing hubs. This has led to movement controls, paralyzing factories producing goods such as flash drives and car parts. As a result, queues of container ships outside Chinese ports are lengthening, threatening global supply chains. Shipowners, logistics firms, and analysts warn of a fresh wave of supply chain shocks, highlighting the potential for widespread disruptions to global trade and commerce.

site_title: Pump prices lower at oil retailers
summary: Singapore oil retailers have lowered pump prices, with all retailers cutting prices by between S$0.04 and S$0.14. Petrol prices remain above S$3 per litre, with the largest reductions by Shell and the smallest by Esso. The cuts follow a decline in Brent crude prices, which have fallen from a 14-year high of US$140 a barrel to under US$100. Antitrust authorities are monitoring the situation to prevent petrol companies from profiteering from the recent surge in crude oil prices.

site_title: Condo and HDB rents continue to climb, both rising over 1% in February
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB rents rose 1.4% and 1.7% respectively in February, marking 14 consecutive months of growth for condos and 20 months for HDB flats. Overall, condo rents increased 11.8% and HDB rents rose 12.4% on a year-on-year basis. Property analysts attribute the increase to construction delays and a lack of new housing supply, with some households temporarily renting accommodations due to the pandemic. Analysts predict further rent increases, with HDB and condo rents expected to rise 8-12% this year.

site_title: Crypto startup founded by ex-Meta employees raises US$200m
summary: Crypto startup Aptos, founded by ex-Meta employees, has raised $200 million at a valuation of over $1 billion. Led by Andreessen Horowitz, the funding includes notable crypto investors such as Tiger Global and FTX. Aptos' blockchain technology is built on expertise developed at Meta, where the founders were part of the Diem stablecoin project. The company plans a public launch in the third quarter of this year, following a testing phase open to developers.

site_title: China's monthly new home price growth slows in February
summary: China's new home prices stagnated in February, with average prices flat at 0.00% month-over-month, according to official data. This marks the slowest pace of growth since December 2015. Despite easing property curbs, demand remains fragile, with new home sales down 9.6% year-on-year. Authorities have rolled out city-specific policies to boost buying sentiment, but a nationwide rebound has yet to materialize.

site_title: Samsung Electronics sees strong year for chip and components unit: CEO
summary: Samsung Electronics expects its chip and components division to perform strongly this year, outperforming the global chip market's forecast annual growth of 9%. Co-CEO Kyung Kye Hyun plans to boost supply by improving operations and increasing capacity, particularly in China. The company aims to improve both profitability and supply by optimizing line operations and processes. Samsung's foundry business will focus on producing made-to-order chips in growth fields like high-performance computing and AI, and is addressing low yields in its cutting-edge 5-nanometre or less chip production.

site_title: Firms seeking to profit from GST hike could have actions made public: committee
summary: A Singaporean committee, the Committee Against Profiteering (CAP), will monitor prices of essential items ahead of the GST hike in 2023 and 2024. Businesses that raise prices due to genuine cost pressures will not face action, but those that profit from the hike may have their actions made public. The committee will review each piece of feedback on a case-by-case basis and may work with partner agencies to investigate and review feedback from the public.

images.alt_text: Businesses who raise prices due to genuine cost pressures will not face action from the authorities.

site_title: China vows to keep markets stable, support foreign listings
summary: China has vowed to stabilize its financial markets and support foreign listings amid concerns over property market risks, overseas listings, and internet companies. A meeting of China's top financial policy committee led by Vice-Premier Liu He promised to introduce policies that benefit markets and boost economic growth. The move aims to provide relief to investors and address concerns driving a sell-off in Chinese equities earlier this week.

site_title: EcoWise flags 'material uncertainty' in its ability to continue operations
summary: EcoWise, a Singapore-based environmental solutions provider, has flagged "material uncertainty" in its ability to continue operations due to financial difficulties. The company is being chased by several banks in Malaysia for payments totaling over RM3 million, and has also failed to pay a security deposit of S$691,200 to the National Environment Agency for extending its lease. EcoWise has invited external professional firms to help negotiate with banks and assess the viability of its business, and is exploring alternative measures to manage its cash flow situation.

site_title: Australia unveils A$500m in critical minerals funding to offset China dominance
summary: Australia has announced A$500 million in funding to boost critical minerals production, aiming to diversify supply and counter China's dominance in the global market. The funding will support projects in Western Australia, including a rare earth separation plant, a battery material refinery, and a vanadium processing plant. The move is part of Australia's efforts to strengthen its economy and address diplomatic tensions with China. The funding follows an announcement by Prime Minister Scott Morrison to build a A$4.3 billion naval dry dock in Western Australia.

site_title: WTA head Simon says players should not be banned over Ukraine crisis
summary: WTA head Steve Simon says individual tennis players from Russia and Belarus should not be penalized for their countries' involvement in the Ukraine crisis. Despite concerns that players may be blocked from competing in tournaments, Simon stated that the WTA has never banned athletes due to their leadership's political positions. The organization would only change its stance if governments restrict players' entry, Simon said, emphasizing that athletes should not be penalized for decisions made by their authoritarian leaders.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on banks, tech boost; Federal Reserve meeting in focus
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 7,130.6 points, driven by gains in banking and technology stocks, with tech stocks up 2.9% and financials for a third consecutive session. Healthcare stocks also advanced 1.5%, while energy stocks declined 0.9% due to falling oil prices. The rally comes ahead of the US Federal Reserve's meeting, where investors expect interest rate hikes, and follows a Wall Street rally overnight.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam says scope to further delay chief executive election
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam said the city's chief executive election, set for May, has "scope" to be further delayed due to the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak. The election was originally scheduled for March 27 but was postponed to May 8. Lam cited "legally speaking" as the reason for potential further delays, leaving the decision to the central government. The city is battling a highly transmissible Omicron variant, with over 760,000 infections and 4,500 deaths reported, sparking pressure from China and criticism from netizens.

site_title: Asia: Markets bounce as Hong Kong tech sees bargain-buying
summary: Asian markets experienced a rebound on Wednesday, led by Hong Kong's tech sector, which saw a 6% gain in the Hang Seng Tech Index. JD.com, Alibaba, and Tencent also rose more than 6% each. The rally followed a sharp drop in oil prices, which fell below $100 for the first time in a week. However, concerns over the Russia-Ukraine war and the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes remain, with the central bank's meeting on Wednesday expected to signal a series of hikes this year.

site_title: Man to be charged for alleged rent deposit scams involving over S$50,000
summary: A 32-year-old man in Singapore has been arrested and charged with cheating in connection with 24 alleged rental scams, resulting in losses of over S$54,700. The scams involved victims paying deposits via bank transfer for residential units advertised online, but the man failed to meet them. The offence carries a potential 10-year imprisonment term and fine. Authorities advise the public to verify details and contact numbers with real estate agencies and inspect units before paying deposits.

site_title: North Korea 'projectile' launch ends in failure
summary: North Korea launched a suspected projectile on Wednesday, but it appears to have failed immediately after launch. The launch, North Korea's tenth suspected weapons test this year, comes as the US warned of a "serious escalation" of the country's nuclear program. Analysts believe the test was likely of the Hwasong-17, dubbed a "monster missile." The failed launch may indicate Pyongyang's attempts to demonstrate new technical achievements before its founding leader's 110th birth anniversary in April, which is marked by military parades or launches.

site_title: HDB raises S$1b from bond issuance to finance green building projects
summary: HDB has raised S$1 billion from its inaugural green bond issuance to finance its green building projects. The 5-year fixed rate green notes, rated "AAA" by Fitch Ratings, will be used to finance 30 eligible projects that meet the Green Finance Framework's parameters. The proceeds will exclusively fund projects with Green Mark certification of GoldPlus or higher. HDB plans to review its Green Projects Register annually and issue at least 1 green bond per year.

site_title: Federal Reserve set to raise interest rates to rein in inflation
summary: The US Federal Reserve is set to raise interest rates to combat rising inflation, with the benchmark rate expected to increase by 0.25 percentage points from zero. The decision comes amid concerns about inflation, supply chain disruptions, and the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict, which has sent oil prices surging. Economists project six or seven rate increases this year, with the goal of tamping down inflation and supporting the recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open sharply higher on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 2.79% to 18,928.20 on Wednesday, driven by bargain buying after a 10% loss in the previous three days due to tech firm routs. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 1.43% and 1.80%, respectively. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and marked a reversal from the previous day's decline.

site_title: Kyiv says 'fundamental contradictions' in talks with Russia
summary: Ukraine's presidential aide, Mykhailo Podolyak, stated that talks with Russia have fundamental contradictions but room for compromise. Talks resumed on Tuesday, with both sides signaling progress. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov mentioned discussions on giving Ukraine neutral military status and demilitarizing the country. President Volodymyr Zelensky expressed optimism, saying the Russians have realized they won't achieve anything through war. The negotiations are set to continue, with Lavrov meeting Turkish counterpart Mevlut Cavusoglu in Moscow on Wednesday.

site_title: PropertyGuru to debut on NYSE as investors approve SPAC deal
summary: PropertyGuru, an online real estate marketplace, will debut on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on March 18, after shareholders approved its merger with Bridgetown 2, a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) backed by billionaires Richard Li and Peter Thiel. The combined entity will trade under the ticker PGRU. This move comes at a challenging time for SPACs, which have seen diminishing investor interest, regulatory crackdowns, and falling stock prices. Despite this, PropertyGuru is attempting to list, marking its entry into the US market.

site_title: DeFi startup Treehouse clinches US$18m in seed round
summary: A Singapore-based DeFi startup, Treehouse, has secured US$18 million in a seed funding round led by an undisclosed large fintech investor. The funding will be used to expand its flagship product, Harvest, which provides DeFi analytics and risk management solutions. Other investors include Lightspeed Venture Partners, Binance, and SoftBank Vision Fund. Treehouse's platform delivers data, analytics, and insights to help DeFi investors make informed decisions. The company plans to use the funds to expand features, scale infrastructure, and build a community. This investment is seen as "game-changing" for the industry.

images.alt_text: Above: Treehouse's flagship product, Harvest. The DeFi startup clinched US$18m in a seed funding round.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, ComfortDelGro, ABR, Azeus, OxPay Financial
summary: Keppel Corporation is set to acquire a 50% stake in Cleantech Solar Asia for $115 million, accelerating its renewable business plans. ComfortDelGro Corporation acquired Rothery's Coaches business in Rockhampton, Queensland for $6.74 million. ABR Holdings acquired a 20% stake in Chilli Padi Holding for $4.4 million. Azeus Systems Holdings appointed a new CEO, Michael Yap, and OxPay Financial lodged a police report against former employees suspected of wrongdoing.

site_title: Blue Origin to fly SNL star Pete Davidson to space next week
summary: Pete Davidson, a comedian and boyfriend of Kim Kardashian, will join 5 paying customers on Blue Origin's fourth commercial flight to space next week. He will be an 'honorary guest' on a suborbital flight, expected to last around 10 minutes, and experience weightlessness at 106 km high. This is Davidson's first space travel, following in the footsteps of celebrities like William Shatner and Michael Strahan, who have also flown with Blue Origin.

site_title: Japan government considering fresh stimulus package: Kyodo
summary: Japan's government is considering a fresh economic stimulus package in response to the economic impact of the Ukraine crisis. Ruling coalition officials have called for a spending package to cushion the blow from rising energy and food prices. The move comes as the fiscal 2022 budget is set to pass parliament. The stimulus package aims to mitigate the economic impact on households and retailers.

site_title: Animoca, Ripple back crypto custodian at US$300m valuation
summary: Hex Trust, a Hong Kong startup offering crypto custody services, has raised US$88 million in a Series B round led by Animoca Brands and Liberty City Ventures, valuing the company at US$300 million. Existing investors Ripple, Terra, Morgan Creek, and Primavera Venture Partners also participated. Hex Trust will use the funds to expand in Europe and the Middle East, and obtain additional licenses. The company has seen its assets under custody rise to US$5 billion from US$6 million in 2021, and aims to double client numbers and assets this year.

site_title: Pfizer asks FDA to clear another booster for older adults
summary: Pfizer has asked the FDA to clear an additional Covid-19 booster shot for seniors, aged 65 and older, to protect vulnerable adults as immunity from the first 3 doses wanes. The company submitted real-world data from Israel showing a fourth shot reduced infection and severe illness rates. Pfizer is also studying an Omicron-specific vaccine and a hybrid shot targeting earlier variants, with data expected in April.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.04% to 1,557.99 points. The index saw 146.41 million lots traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 272 to 94. This follows a broader market trend, as European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector concerns, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: NFTs are coming to Instagram, Zuckerberg says
summary: Mark Zuckerberg confirmed that Meta is building technical functionality to display and mint NFTs on Instagram. He did not provide specifics on when the feature will be available. This move comes after former Meta executive David Marcus mentioned the company was exploring NFT features last August. Zuckerberg also discussed the war in Ukraine, calling it a "massively destabilising world event" at the SXSW conference.

site_title: Gold flat in cautious trade ahead of Fed decision
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,920.71 per ounce, holding near a 2-week low, ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike decision to combat inflation. Investors were cautious, with US Treasury yields rising to their highest in over two-and-a-half years. The expected rate hike has led to a decrease in gold futures, with US gold futures falling 0.3% to $1,923.90. The Fed's announcement is expected to impact the market's outlook and commodity prices.

site_title: Japan to revoke Russia's most-favoured nation trade status: sources
summary: Japan will revoke Russia's most-favoured nation trade status due to the invasion of Ukraine, according to sources. The move will lead to increased tariffs on certain seafood products, including sea urchins and crab, imported from Russia. This decision follows Japan's existing sanctions on Russia-bound exports and assets of Russian officials, business executives, and banks. The revocation is part of further G-7 nations' efforts to hold Russia accountable for its actions.

site_title: DBS appoints veteran as new country CEO for China
summary: DBS has appointed Ginger Cheng, a veteran banker, as its new country CEO for China, effective April 1, subject to regulatory approval. Cheng, who has spent 20 years at DBS, takes over from Neil Ge, who will retire at the end of June. Cheng's appointment is seen as a testament to the bank's deep bench strength and commitment to grooming talent. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta praised the appointment, saying it adds to the bank's already strong set of female leaders in top management.

site_title: Ardern opens border to foreigners as 'Fortress New Zealand' ends
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced the reopening of the country's border to foreigners on April 12, bringing an end to the "Fortress New Zealand" policy. Vaccinated Australians will be allowed to enter without isolation, while other visa-waiver countries will be permitted to enter on May 1. The move aims to boost the tourism industry, which has been decimated by the two-year absence of foreign visitors, and is expected to help spur economic recovery.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday; STI up 1.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.4% to 3,282.06 on Wednesday, driven by gains in oil and gas companies Sembcorp Marine and RH Petrogas. Food tech company Oceanus declined 5%, despite being the most actively traded counter. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also opened higher. The rally follows global market momentum, with US stocks surging on Tuesday after crude prices fell and the Federal Reserve kicked off a policy meeting.

site_title: Singapore calls on China to use 'enormous influence' on Russia
summary: Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan urged China to use its influence on Russia to end the war in Ukraine, warning that Beijing's decisions could determine the global economy's future. Singapore, the first South-east Asian nation to impose unilateral sanctions on Russia, has restricted trade financing and suspended flights to Moscow. Balakrishnan hopes China will use its influence discreetly but effectively, calling for a return to multilateral rules-based world order and criticizing the US for abandoning talks on the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip on worries over China Covid-19 surge
summary: European stocks fell 0.3% on Tuesday, led by commodity-linked sectors, amid concerns over China's surge in Covid-19 cases. The Stoxx 600 index dropped, with French luxury goods maker LVMH and Dutch tech investor Prosus experiencing significant losses. The market is also awaiting interest rate hikes from the US Federal Reserve and the Bank of England, with investors worried about economic growth and demand for European companies selling into China.

site_title: Biden's Federal Reserve nominee Sarah Bloom Raskin withdraws: source
summary: US President Joe Biden's Federal Reserve nominee Sarah Bloom Raskin withdraws her name from consideration due to opposition from Republicans and a key Democratic lawmaker over her stance on climate change. The boycott by Republican senators in the Senate stalled the confirmation process. Raskin cited the boycott as a factor in her decision to drop out, stating there is "hard and urgent work ahead" for the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after US gains on oil pullback
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, following US gains as investors took a breather after another steep drop in crude prices. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.75% to 25,536.60, while the Topix index increased 0.77% to 1,840.77. This follows US stocks extending their gains, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff threats.

site_title: India acts to seize gap in wheat export market left by Ukraine war
summary: India is implementing measures to become a dominant exporter of high-quality wheat, following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The country will test wheat quality, provide extra rail wagons, and prioritize wheat exports at ports. This comes as India, the world's second-largest wheat producer, seeks to capitalize on surplus stocks and rising global prices. The measures are expected to be implemented within two weeks and aim to establish India as a reliable supplier to importers.

site_title: Microsoft, Temasek invest in ConsenSys at US$7b valuation
summary: Microsoft, Temasek Holdings, and SoftBank Group invested US$450 million in ConsenSys at a US$7 billion valuation, more than doubling its previous valuation. ConsenSys, founded by Ethereum co-founder Joseph Lubin, raised funds to buy Ether for its treasury, expand its MetaMask crypto wallet, and plan a major redesign. The funding will also support the hiring of over 300 new employees by year-end, bringing the total to over 1,000. Lubin downplayed the threat of Ethereum losing dominance in decentralized finance applications, citing its stronger security compared to smaller blockchains.

site_title: Olam Group falls 0.6% on first day of trading to close at S$1.75
summary: Olam Group's VC2 shares began trading on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard at S$1.69, down 4% from the previous day's closing price of S$1.76. The shares experienced initial sell-downs, but recovered to trade at S$1.71 after 838,000 shares changed hands. The company's first day of trading ended with a 0.6% decline, closing at S$1.75.

site_title: China economy starts year strongly as Covid, war risks loom
summary: China's economy started the year with a strong 7.5% industrial output growth in the first two months, beating economists' expectations. Retail sales rose 6.7% and investment climbed 12.2%, but a worsening Covid outbreak and global energy price spikes pose risks. The government has pledged fiscal and monetary support, but growth targets may be challenging to achieve, with a 5.5% target likely to be difficult to meet.

site_title: Vicenta Lodge in Kembangan sold for S$27.2m in collective sale
summary: Vicenta Lodge, a 16-unit freehold residential development in Kembangan, Singapore, was sold via private treaty for S$27.2 million. The collective sale, which closed on March 10, marked a significant decrease from its reserve price in April 2021 and previous sales in 2018 and 2021. The sale price is also lower than the property's original asking price of S$29 million.

site_title: Pfizer-BioNTech seek US approval of second Covid booster for 65+
summary: Pfizer-BioNTech have requested US emergency approval for a second Covid booster shot for people aged 65 and older, based on Israeli studies showing increased immunogenicity and lower infection rates. The request comes as case levels decline globally, but protection from prior doses begins to fade. The companies claim the additional booster would help maintain immunity and prevent severe illness.

site_title: Brazil unveils plan to cut taxes on forex transactions by 2029
summary: Brazil's government has published a decree to phase out taxes on foreign exchange transactions, known as IOF taxes, by 2029. The reduction will be gradual, with an immediate 0% tax rate on loans up to 180 days abroad and a decrease in tax rates on credit card transactions and foreign currency purchases by 2028. The move aims to join the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and will result in an annual impact of 7.7 billion reais (S$2.03 billion).

site_title: Oil price benchmarks fall below US$100, first time in weeks
summary: Oil prices dropped below $100 per barrel for the first time in weeks due to Russia's suggestion to revive the Iran nuclear deal, which could lead to increased Iranian oil exports and sanctions relief. The price decline, nearly $40 for Brent and $30 for US crude, follows Russia's invasion of Ukraine and amid growing pandemic lockdowns in China. Volatility remains, with traders concerned about the potential impact on global demand, and the US Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hike on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Oil prices tumbled more than 6 per cent on Tuesday to their lowest in almost three weeks, as Russia suggested it would allow a revival of the Iran nuclear deal to go forward and as traders worried growing pandemic lockdowns in China could dent demand.

site_title: Singapore business sentiment moderates slightly in Q2 on global uncertainty: SCCB
summary: Singapore's business sentiment has moderated slightly in the second quarter of 2022, according to the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau (SCCB). The quarterly Business Optimism Index (BOI) dipped to +5.35 percentage points from +5.91 percentage points in Q1, with only 1 indicator showing improvement. Selling prices increased, while new orders and volume of sales fell. The SCCB expects the overall outlook to remain cautiously optimistic, despite global uncertainties and ongoing supply chain disruptions, with domestically-oriented sectors expected to remain strong.

site_title: Better than Alpha: An optimal way to think about alpha
summary: Investors can improve their outcomes by adopting a 3-step framework to capture excess returns, known as "alpha." The framework, developed by Christopher M Schelling, focuses on "behavioural alpha" (smart thinking), "process alpha" (development of smart habits), and "organisational alpha" (smart governance). By prioritizing System 2 thinking for high-impact decisions, streamlining decisions, and implementing smart habits and governance, investors can mitigate their biases and achieve better investment outcomes without exhausting their limited resources.

site_title: Foreign investors keen on Malaysia industrial properties
summary: Foreign investors are showing interest in Malaysia's industrial properties, particularly big plots in prime locations with good accessibility and proximity to business hubs or ports. This is driven by the global supply chain disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic and the Russia-Ukraine conflict. As international borders reopen, foreign companies are expected to increase their interest in Malaysia's industrial real estate, with developers receiving increasing enquiries for industrial properties.

site_title: Russia says quitting Council of Europe
summary: Russia has announced its withdrawal from the Council of Europe, effective immediately, amid pressure over its invasion of Ukraine. The move, which marks Russia's quarter-century membership, will see the country lose its rights to the European Convention on Human Rights and its citizens will no longer be able to file applications to the European Court of Human Rights. The decision, made by the Russian foreign ministry, also paves the way for Russia to reimpose the death penalty, a move previously proposed by former President Dmitry Medvedev.

site_title: US: Stocks rally on pullback in oil prices
summary: US stocks surged on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index rising 1.8%, 2.1%, and 2.9% respectively. The rally followed a drop in crude prices, which fell to under $100 a barrel due to concerns over weakened Chinese demand. Despite elevated producer price increases, the Federal Reserve is expected to begin interest rate increases to curb inflation. US air carriers, such as American Airlines and Delta Air Lines, were standouts, while petroleum-linked equities suffered losses.

site_title: Grounded cruise ship freed off Dominican Republic
summary: A cruise ship, Norwegian Escape, carrying 3,000 tourists, ran aground off the Dominican Republic's coast on Monday. After eight hours, the ship was refloated without major incidents, and all passengers and crew were unharmed. The ship returned to Puerto Plata for inspections before being allowed to set sail. An investigation commission has been established to look into the incident, which was attributed to strong 30 knot winds. The ship, over 300m long and weighing 165,000 tons, will face further inspections before resuming its journey.

site_title: Omicron spread could pare South-east Asia growth forecasts by up to 0.8 percentage point: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) warns that the spread of the Omicron virus variant could shave up to 0.8 percentage point off South-east Asia's 2022 growth forecast of 5.1%. Vietnam, Thailand, Malaysia, and Laos are the most vulnerable markets, with potential downgrades of 1.9 points in Vietnam and 1.1 points in Thailand. The ADB expects inflation to be a main impact, while the war in Ukraine is expected to have a limited effect on growth projections. The region's economic output is likely to be down 10.3% in 2022 compared to a baseline without the pandemic.

site_title: Kitchen Culture's AGM to review a turbulent FY2021
summary: Kitchen Culture, a Singapore-based kitchen systems vendor, is set to review its FY2021 results at its annual general meeting. The company has faced significant challenges, including the termination of its CEO and executive chairman, Lim Wee Li, in May 2021. Kitchen Culture's diversification efforts into fintech, healthcare, and fund management have been unsuccessful, resulting in a net loss of S$11.5 million and negative operating cash flows. The company's statutory auditors have issued a disclaimer of opinion on its FY2021 financial statements, citing internal control weaknesses and unauthorised transactions.

site_title: Japan's February exports rise 19.1% yoy: MOF
summary: Japan's exports rose 19.1% in February from the previous year, exceeding economists' expectations of a 21.0% increase. This follows a 9.6% growth in January. February imports gained 34.0% year-over-year, resulting in a trade deficit of 668.3 billion yen.

site_title: Denmark mulls cigarette sale ban for next generations
summary: Denmark is considering banning the sale of cigarettes and other nicotine products to individuals born after 2010 to ensure a tobacco-free future generation. The health minister aims to prevent 31% of 15-29-year-olds from smoking, which causes 13,600 deaths annually. A poll shows 64% of Danes support the plan, with 67% among 18-34-year-olds. This move follows New Zealand's plan to ban tobacco sales by 2027. Denmark also plans to raise the drinking age from 16 to 18 to address youths' alcohol consumption.

site_title: Indonesia's micro SMEs fertile ground to grow new generation of unicorns
summary: Indonesia's micro SMEs are being targeted by startups and fintech companies, with 5 new unicorn firms emerging in 2021, the most in any year. Fintech startup Broom connects second-hand car dealers with financing partners, while others like KoinWorks and Payfazz offer online financial services. The country's digital economy is expected to grow, with a forecasted valuation of $146 billion by 2025, making it a fertile ground for new startups to emerge. Investors are seeking opportunities in sectors targeting MSMEs, with many potential unicorns on the horizon.

site_title: Geopolitics and ballpark estimates
summary: A major geopolitical conflict in Europe has jolted financial markets and raised risk assessments worldwide, complicating the global economic outlook. Geopolitical risk, measured by the Geopolitical Risk Index, suggests the Russia-Ukraine escalation is among the top 10% of global events since 1900, with potential impacts on global growth and inflation. Estimates using the index and other measures indicate a subtraction of between a tenth and seven-tenths from global growth, with the greatest negative impact concentrated in the first 4 quarters.

site_title: New chairman's 18 lawsuits in China are a non-issue: Nutryfarm
summary: NutryFarm International has appointed Wu Yongqiang as its new executive chairman despite 18 civil suits in China, which the company has deemed commercial in nature and not involving fraud or misconduct. The company's nominating committee has assessed that Wu's character and integrity are satisfactory, and there is no potential conflict of interest with his role on KTL Global's board. Wu has pledged to resign from Nutryfarm's board if he becomes bankrupt or if the civil suits disqualify him.

site_title: Singapore Tourism Board seeks proposals for Jurong Lake tourism project
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has launched a request for proposals (RFP) to develop and operate an integrated tourism development at Jurong Lake District, a 6.8-hectare site next to Jurong Lake in Singapore's largest business district outside the CBD. The project, announced nearly three years ago, aims to become a key lifestyle and tourism hub. The RFP seeks proposals from developers to create a unique and sustainable tourism experience, with the project expected to enhance Singapore's tourism industry and attract more visitors to the area.

site_title: Why China and Russia are transforming Nato's fortunes
summary: NATO has experienced a significant turnaround in fortunes following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with the crisis underlining the alliance's continued relevance. Despite criticism from French President Emmanuel Macron and former US officials, including John Bolton, NATO has demonstrated resilience. The alliance has also seen increased commitment from member countries, including Germany, to meet the 2% defense spending target. This shift in sentiment could continue if concerns about China's growing global assertiveness and potential alliance with Russia also grow. The upcoming meeting of NATO defense ministers will focus on the Russia-Ukraine crisis and the alliance's response.

site_title: Australia to lift entry ban for cruise ships after 2 years
summary: Australia is lifting its 2-year entry ban for international cruise ships, effective April 17, as the country begins to live with the coronavirus. The ban was implemented in March 2020 due to concerns over the spread of the virus through cruise ships. The move comes after Australia fully reopened its airports to vaccinated international travelers last month. The tourism industry, which welcomed over 600,000 cruise ship passengers in 2019, is expected to benefit from the easing of restrictions.

site_title: Reit distributions to fund your retirement may be less than what you anticipate
summary: S-Reits, a popular asset class for income-seeking investors, may not deliver the expected returns for those planning to retire on a Reit portfolio. Some S-Reits have raised more funds from unitholders than they have distributed, despite showing positive dividend yields and total annual returns. For example, IReit Global has raised S$352 million from unitholders while paying out S$239.3 million in distributions since its IPO. Analysts attribute this to Reits' capital-intensive nature and need to fund acquisitions through equity raisings.

site_title: EU bans champagne, luxury car, apparel exports to Russia
summary: The European Union has banned exports of luxury items, including champagne, high-end cars, and fashion apparel, to Russia as part of new sanctions. The 29-page list includes 15 individuals and nine companies, targeting the elite and oligarchs in Russia. The ban also restricts investments in and assistance to Russia's energy sector, and bars credit rating agencies from evaluating Russian institutions and companies. The EU aims to target luxury goods to avoid affecting ordinary Russians, with specific restrictions on items worth over €50,000.

site_title: Euro rises on hopes of progress in Ukraine peace talks
summary: The euro rose 0.5% to 1.0999 against the dollar on hopes of progress in Ukraine peace talks, with one of Ukraine's top aides suggesting the war could end by May. Oil prices dropped to their lowest in almost 3 weeks, easing fears of supply disruptions, and the US dollar fell ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting. The eurozone's dependence on Russian energy and the single currency's negative correlation with oil prices are key drivers of the euro's recent rise.

site_title: Hazmat suits and panic buying: pandemic images return to China
summary: China is experiencing its worst Covid-19 outbreak since 2019, with daily caseloads around 5,300, prompting the return of mass testing and restrictions. The Omicron variant is shaking Beijing's "zero-Covid" strategy, and Shanghai has been affected with restrictions on movement, mask mandates, and dine-in bans in some districts. Residents are expressing frustration with the measures, citing anxiety and economic impacts, while some citizens still support the controls, citing low death tolls and restored normalcy.

site_title: Lessons from the past for today's tech bear market
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index recently slipped into bear market territory, down 21% from its November peak. However, the impact has been much worse, with the actual decline being significantly higher. Experts warn that investors shouldn't expect a pivot from the Federal Reserve despite its independence being tested. Meanwhile, Asia is expected to drive and gain from dollar asset diversification, while a low-profile property trust is exploring a data centre gambit. Productivity gains are seen as key to unlocking wealth creation, and de-dollarisation and shifting safe havens are also on the radar.

site_title: US Senate approves bill to make daylight saving time permanent
summary: The US Senate has unanimously passed the Sunshine Protection Act, which aims to make daylight saving time permanent starting in 2023. The bill, which was sponsored by Senators Marco Rubio and Ed Markey, would end the twice-yearly clock changes and allow states like Arizona and Hawaii to remain on standard time. Supporters argue that the change would improve children's outdoor playtime and reduce seasonal depression, while opponents claim it could lead to safety issues and disrupt businesses. The bill now needs to be passed by the House of Representatives before it can be sent to President Joe Biden for signature.

images.alt_text: The US Senate on Tuesday passed legislation that would make daylight saving time permanent starting in 2023, ending the twice-annual changing of clocks in a move promoted by supporters advocating brighter afternoons and more economic activity.

site_title: Keppel consortium takes remaining 50% stake in Cleantech Solar Asia
summary: Keppel Corporation, along with Keppel Asia Infrastructure Fund LP and a co-investor, has acquired the remaining 50% stake in Cleantech Solar Asia (CSA) for $115 million. This deal accelerates Keppel's plans to grow its renewable business and increases its stake in CSA to 75.5%. The transaction is expected to close in H1 2022, pending regulatory and other approvals.

site_title: URA bars strata subdivision for commercial properties in key parts of Central Area
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) in Singapore has banned the strata subdivision of commercial properties in key areas of the Central Area, including Orchard Road and the Singapore River. The restriction applies to redevelopment proposals under the Central Business District (CBD) Incentive and Strategic Development Incentive (SDI) schemes. The move aims to ensure the upkeep and quality of commercial properties, and prevent fragmented ownership issues. Analysts predict that the restriction will limit the number of commercial strata units in the area, making them more attractive to family offices and high-net-worth individuals.

site_title: 41% of Singapore workers 'would pick remote working over bigger bonus'
summary: A survey by Randstad Singapore found that 41% of workers in Singapore prefer remote working over a bigger bonus. This is due to benefits such as saving time and money, having more personal time, and higher productivity. 80% of respondents received a salary increment in 2022, with 43% anticipating a bonus payout averaging 1-3 months. The survey suggests that employers must share profits to retain valued employees, and that adjusting work policies and benefits schemes is crucial to meet changing employee expectations.

site_title: Sustainability agenda 'no longer a box-checking exercise'
summary: Financial executives emphasize the importance of sustainability beyond "box-checking exercises" in times of rising geopolitical tensions and inflationary pressures. Companies and investors must prioritize responsible investments to avoid potential share price crashes. A commitment to sustainability is seen as crucial for future shareholders and investors. Stakeholders recognize the need for a balance between commercial profits and sustainable practices. Experts highlight the need for regulations, transition finance, and social sustainability to tap into private capital for sustainable public infrastructure and support communities at the "base of the pyramid".

site_title: Ukraine economy could collapse if war drags on: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns that Ukraine's economy could collapse if the war with Russia drags on, with potential output contraction of 10-35% and a threat to global food security. The conflict has already caused widespread destruction and damage, estimated at $100 billion, and could lead to soaring energy and agriculture prices, fuelling inflation. The IMF cautions that the situation will worsen if the conflict is prolonged, and has approved a $1.4 billion emergency aid program for Ukraine.

images.alt_text: A closed PrivatBank CJSC branch in Kyiv. Banks and the government continue to function in Ukraine despite the large-scale destruction of infrastructure.

site_title: SPACs and listed plays: Investors need more than luck to back the right managers
summary: Investors in special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) need to carefully assess the management team to determine if they are strategic, driven, and possess integrity. While retail investors may be drawn to the potential upside of investing in a promising technology company, they must also consider the risks of investing in a SPAC. Faith in management is crucial, as it is in investing in listed companies or trusts. Investors can gain insights by attending investor days, broker events, or annual general meetings, and studying management track records. To make informed decisions, investors must weigh the potential benefits of investing in a SPAC against the risks and carefully evaluate the management team.

site_title: Serial System's stink of a dispute with durian partners lingers on
summary: Serial System's subsidiary Bast Investment is facing a dispute with its durian business joint venture, Musang Durians Frozen Food, over a RM15.4 million (S$5 million) claim for repayment of a shareholder's loan. Bast claims the loan, including unpaid interest, while Musang Durians and its managing director, Dato' John Lee Siew Neng, have responded with a counterclaim for RM3.9 million. Serial System is confident of success in the litigation and intends to pursue the claim and defend the counterclaim. The dispute is expected to have minimal impact on Serial System's financial statements for the fiscal year ending December 2022.

site_title: South-east Asia's road to recovery presents an opportunity
summary: South-east Asia's road to recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic faces significant challenges, with aggregate output projected to remain 10% below pre-pandemic levels. The region must address rising income inequality, bolster health investment, and pursue structural reforms to improve productivity and competitiveness. Countries should prioritize universal healthcare, invest in human capital, and promote green investments to support a greener economy. By adopting a people-centred approach to recovery, South-east Asia can create more productive jobs, restore productivity trends, and usher in a new era of revitalisation.

site_title: Alpha DX flags going concern uncertainty after recent problems with creditors
summary: Alpha DX Group, a Singapore-based learning solutions company, has flagged uncertainty over its ability to continue as a going concern. The company has received a letter of statutory demand and negotiations with creditors have not yielded desired outcomes. Alpha DX's board expects a fresh injection of funds to continue operating, but its cash and cash equivalents of S$3.4 million are insufficient to cover short-term liabilities of S$7.3 million. The company is discussing potential investments with controlling shareholder Didi Investments to resolve cash flow issues.

site_title: Russia is spiralling toward a US$150b default nightmare
summary: Russia is at risk of a US$150 billion default, which could cost investors billions and severely limit its access to funding markets. The country's economy is struggling, its currency has collapsed, and its debt is considered junk. On March 16, Russia will pay US$117 million in interest on dollar bonds, a crucial moment for debt holders who have seen the value of their investments plummet since Russia invaded Ukraine last month. A default is now all but inevitable, and its consequences could be severe for the global economy.

site_title: Nick Candy says funds ready to bid for Chelsea Football Club
summary: UK property developer Nick Candy says he has funding ready to bid for Chelsea Football Club and is in talks with potential partners, including British businessman Martin Broughton. Candy expects the sale to be completed within two months, and fans would have a role in the club's running if his consortium wins. As a property developer, Candy could play a key role in any redevelopment of Stamford Bridge, a move that would be welcomed by Chelsea fans who have been uncertain due to the UK government's restrictions on the club's sale following the sanctioning of its Russian owner Roman Abramovich.

site_title: All eyes on FOMC meeting as stagflation risks loom
summary: The US economy is facing stagflation risks, with the Federal Reserve acknowledging that rising prices are a problem that needs to be tackled. The first hint of this came after August's jobs miss, when only 235,000 jobs were created. Since then, the Fed has lowered its GDP growth estimate to 0.5% for the first quarter of 2022, and has retired the word "transitory" when describing inflation. The looming FOMC meeting will determine the Fed's next steps to address these concerns.

site_title: Ukraine war causing shipping turmoil
summary: The ongoing Ukraine war is causing significant disruptions to global shipping and trade, with the International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) warning of a potential shortage of seafarers due to flight cancellations and security concerns. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has condemned Russian actions, calling for the country to cease its "unlawful activities" affecting seafarers and international shipping. Sanctions on Russia are disrupting global trade, with many countries suspending trade with the country and pulling out of Russian-controlled assets. The IMO has proposed measures to ensure seafarers can continue working on international fleets, but the situation remains chaotic.

site_title: Football violence pandemic spreads in Latin America
summary: Violence linked to football fan unrest has surged in Latin America, with several deadly incidents reported in Mexico, Colombia, and Brazil. Outbreaks of violence, including mass brawls and savage attacks, have occurred in stadiums and outside venues, resulting in 157 deaths in Brazil between 2009 and 2019. Experts attribute the problem to underlying issues such as toxic masculinity, unemployment, and inequality, which are inadequately addressed by authorities. While some countries have enacted laws to punish hooligans, measures often focus solely on security, ignoring social background frustrations.

images.alt_text: Images of a mass brawl at a game in Mexico on Mar 5 that left 26 seriously injured, and led to 14 arrests have went viral.

site_title: Singapore shares buck regional trend, STI up 0.12%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.12% to 3,236.04, bucking regional trends due to gains from local banks. The Straits Times Index (STI) was led by DBS and UOB, with DBS up 2.2% and UOB up 1.4%. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong fell 5.72%, while Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 0.15%. The decline in Shenzhen's lockdown and decline in oil prices eased inflation fears, contributing to the positive sentiment in Singapore.

site_title: Amazon, Walmart online orders likely delayed by China lockdowns
summary: A lockdown in Shenzhen, China, has likely delayed online orders from Amazon and Walmart due to production and delivery disruptions. The lockdown, which began on March 13, has halted operations in the city and nearby Dongguan, a key manufacturing hub. Logistics firms and warehouses are not operating or are operating at reduced capacity, causing delays in deliveries. The disruption affects major online marketplaces and companies like Shenzhen Tomtop Technology and Sailvan Times, which export goods to the West. Representatives from Amazon and Walmart have not commented on potential delivery delays.

site_title: Companies' flight from Moscow sets some hard precedents
summary: Companies are rapidly exiting Russia and Belarus following Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine, with many multinational corporations withdrawing from the region in response to the crisis. While some companies, such as Danone and Uniqlo, have chosen to remain in Russia, others have cancelled projects or paused operations due to concerns over supply chains, staff and customer reactions, and potential sanctions. Experts warn that companies must set a clear ethical benchmark for their decisions and consider the long-term implications of their actions, rather than reacting to "collective craziness" or short-term pressure.

site_title: Are stop-losses for wimps?
summary: A former banking colleague questioned the effectiveness of stop-losses, calling them for "wimps." The author argues that stop-losses serve as a hedge against loss-making positions, mitigating behavioral biases. However, for most investors, stop-losses may hinder wealth accumulation due to their restrictive nature. The author suggests that context is crucial, as stop-losses can be beneficial in high-risk, short-term trades but may not be suitable for long-term investments. Ultimately, the decision to use stop-losses depends on individual investment strategies and risk tolerance.

images.alt_text: The longer your time horizon, the less desirable a stop-loss is, especially for diversified allocations or long-term structural themes.

site_title: Bentley to roll out 1 electric model a year for 5 years from 2025
summary: Bentley plans to release one electric model annually for five years starting from 2025, following a significant increase in profit and deliveries of hybrid models in 2021. The move aligns with parent Volkswagen's efforts to expand electric offerings. Bentley aims to be end-to-end carbon-neutral by 2030, having invested 3 billion euros in sustainable initiatives. The company's CEO expressed confidence in its ability to remain a benchmark in sustainable luxury mobility.

site_title: Covid-19 cases in Singapore back above 10,000, weekly infection rate lowest since Dec 30
summary: Singapore reported 15,851 new Covid-19 cases on March 15, bringing the total above 10,000 for the first time in two days. The weekly infection growth rate fell to 0.8, the lowest since December 30, with 1,311 hospitalisations and six deaths. The number of local cases detected through antigen rapid tests (ARTs) was 13,786, and 40 patients were in the intensive care unit.

site_title: Norges Bank says wealth fund's Russia exit to occur over time
summary: Norway's $1.3 trillion sovereign wealth fund has removed Russia from its benchmark index and will sell all its Russian investments over time due to closed markets and sanctions. The move was made in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine on February 27. A recommendation to lift the freeze on investments in Russia will be made once markets are functioning normally. The fund's removal of Russian assets is the latest step in Norway's response to the crisis.

site_title: Too early to speculate about secondary sanctions on China: economists
summary: US officials are considering imposing secondary sanctions on China if it provides economic or financial support to Russia, amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine. However, economists believe it's too early to speculate on the economic fallout, as Singapore is unlikely to follow suit due to its neutral stance. Singaporean officials have stated that they will only take a stand to uphold existential principles, not to take sides. Markets are already factoring in the risk, leading to a recent stock market sell-off, but economists expect the impact on Singapore to be limited, mainly through weaker global growth and trade volumes.

site_title: Mercedes takes on Tesla with new US battery plant, electric SUV
summary: Mercedes-Benz has opened its first US electric vehicle battery factory in Alabama, with Japanese battery maker Envision AESC set to supply modules for US-made EVs. The plant, which employs 600 workers, is part of Mercedes' $44 billion plan to go all electric by 2030. The company also previewed a large electric SUV, the EQS, and smaller EQE SUV, to be built at a nearby assembly facility. This move aims to challenge Tesla in the US market and Europe, as Mercedes seeks to accelerate its shift to electric vehicles and reduce carbon emissions.

site_title: GoTo IPO aims for 18t rupiah, but timing raises questions
summary: Indonesia's largest tech firm, GoTo, has announced its initial public offering (IPO) aiming to raise 17.992 trillion rupiah ($1.69 billion). The company, a merger of ride-hailing and e-commerce firms, plans to sell 52 billion new shares at a price range of 316-346 rupiah per share.
