site_title: Price of 95-octane petrol surges past S$3 per litre at Shell, Esso
summary: Singapore's 95-octane petrol price surged past S$3 per litre at Shell and Esso, with prices rising 21-27 cents per litre. Diesel prices also increased, with Shell and Esso seeing rises of 25-27 cents per litre. The price surge is attributed to surging international oil prices amid economic recovery demand and supply concerns from the Russia-Ukraine war.

site_title: Construction spotted at North Korea nuclear test site for first time since 2018
summary: North Korea has been spotted with construction at its closed nuclear test site, Punggye-ri, for the first time since 2018, according to US-based analysts. The site, which has been shuttered since a 2018 moratorium, shows early signs of activity, including building and repair work. The construction and repair work indicate that North Korea has made a decision about the test site, but it's unclear what is being built or why. The development raises concerns that North Korea could resume nuclear testing, despite stalled denuclearization talks.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies appear to remain a small window for Russians
summary: Russian investors continue to use Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies despite tightening sanctions. Data from Kaiko shows a rise in rouble-denominated Bitcoin trading volume on March 6, with most transactions conducted with the Tether stablecoin. The average trade size reached a 10-month high of around $580 on February 24. Only a fraction of Bitcoin's global trading volume, around $14.2 million, comes from Russia. Despite efforts to block sanctioned users, exchanges like Binance and Coinbase remain open to ordinary Russians.

site_title: Europe: Shares skid to near 1-year low on Russia oil ban prospects
summary: European stocks closed near a one-year low on Monday, down 1.1% due to concerns over Russia's invasion of Ukraine and potential oil ban. The FTSE 100 ended 0.4% lower, with energy stocks rising 4.3% despite rising oil prices above $130 a barrel. German and Italian shares confirmed a bear market, with the Stoxx 600 index cutting losses by 3% to close at a near one-year low.

site_title: US announces new emissions standards for trucks and buses
summary: The US has announced new emissions standards for trucks and buses starting from 2027, with stricter limits on nitrogen oxides and greenhouse gas emissions. The proposed standards are expected to prevent 2,300 deaths and 18,000 cases of childhood onset asthma by 2045. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) will also allocate $1.4 billion to expand green public transit and award $17 million for electric zero-emission school buses. However, an advocacy group criticized the measures as insufficient and falling short of state-level standards.

site_title: Coinbase blocks 25,000 crypto wallets linked to Russia users
summary: Coinbase blocks over 25,000 crypto wallet addresses linked to Russian individuals or entities believed to be engaging in illicit activity, representing about 0.2% of its monthly transacting users. The move is part of Coinbase's efforts to comply with US sanctions and identify addresses potentially linked to sanctioned individuals, which are then added to an internal blocklist. The company shares the information with the government to support sanctions enforcement.

site_title: Nearly all Russia forces deployed, US says as it adds troops to Europe
summary: The US has confirmed that nearly all of Russia's combat forces are deployed along the Ukraine border, with President Vladimir Putin intensifying operations. The Pentagon has added 500 US troops to Europe to bolster Nato security, amid warnings of mounting civilian casualties and Russian strikes. Despite a slowdown in the invasion, Russian forces have engaged in long-range attacks to make up for their lack of movement on the ground, with concerns growing over the potential recruitment of foreign fighters, including Syrians.

images.alt_text: Russia has committed nearly all its combat power stationed along the border into Ukraine, the Pentagon said Monday as it announced 500 more US troops were deploying to Europe to boost Nato security.

site_title: China open to mediating on Ukraine, says Russia friendship 'rock solid'
summary: China reaffirmed its "rock solid" friendship with Russia, despite international condemnation of Russia's Ukraine invasion. Foreign Minister Wang Yi stated that Beijing is open to mediating peace in Ukraine, marking a shift in China's stance. This comes after China refused to condemn Russia last month, instead highlighting a "no limits" strategic partnership between the two countries. China's willingness to mediate may help alleviate international pressure on Russia.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Tuesday's open extending global losses; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.4% on Tuesday, extending losses in regional and global markets due to the ongoing Russian-Ukraine crisis. The Straits Times Index dropped to 3,174.40 after 89.8 million securities changed hands. Oil-related stocks were among the top traded, while local banks such as DBS, UOB, and OCBC declined. Global markets also plummeted, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average sinking 2.4% and the S&P 500 dropping 3%.

site_title: SGX suspends trading of PJSC Gazprom GDR on Russia sanctions
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) suspended trading of PJSC Gazprom global depositary receipts (GDRs) due to Singapore's sanctions against Russia amid its invasion of Ukraine. The suspension aims to ensure the market remains fair, orderly, and transparent. Issuers with exposure to sanctions-related risks must assess their risks, obtain adequate safeguards, and submit remediation proposals within 12 months to avoid removal from the official list.

site_title: What would be the impact of a US ban on Russia crude?
summary: The US is considering banning imports of Russian crude oil, amid the ongoing invasion of Ukraine. A bipartisan bill, the Ban Russian Energy Imports Act, has been introduced, which would prohibit all US imports of Russian energy. Russia accounts for less than 10% of US oil imports, making a ban relatively easier to implement. Experts say a ban could offset some of the lost barrels, with Iran potentially being a quick replacement. However, a US ban would need to be joined by Europe to have a significant impact on oil prices, which have risen 30% due to the invasion.

site_title: Will Ukraine's tragedy spur UN Security Council reform?
summary: The Russia-Ukraine conflict has exposed weaknesses in the UN Security Council, particularly its veto power held by permanent members. The council's inability to impose comprehensive sanctions on Russia has hindered efforts to deter aggression and encourage peaceful conflict resolution. To address this, the authors propose changing Article 27 to allow a large double majority to override a veto, enabling the council to play a greater role in mitigating global threats. This reform could be proposed by the US and its allies, sending a message of determination to create a more equitable multilateral system.

site_title: Zelensky says Russian forces scuppering civilian evacuations
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Russian forces of scuppering civilian evacuations through humanitarian corridors agreed upon with Moscow. Russian tanks and artillery destroyed buses meant to evacuate civilians from Mariupol, and mines were also laid on the road. Zelensky described the actions as "cynicism" and vowed to continue negotiations for a peace deal. Despite Russia's announcement of local ceasefires to facilitate evacuations, Ukraine refused to allow civilians to leave through corridors that led to Russia or Belarus.

site_title: ANZ sees RBNZ hiking by 50 bps in both April and May
summary: ANZ Bank economists predict the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) will hike interest rates by 50 basis points at both April and May policy meetings, reaching a peak of 3.5% in April 2023. This aggressive tightening is due to rising world oil prices threatening to destabilize inflation expectations in New Zealand. The official cash rate (OCR) is currently at 1.0% and has been raised from 0.25% in three moves.

site_title: Livingstone Health to develop hospital in Vietnam through partnership
summary: Livingstone Health Holding has partnered with National Phytopharma Joint Stock Company and Truth Assets Management (S)(TAM) to develop a Livingstone-branded hospital in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. The multidisciplinary specialist healthcare group will provide project ideation and strategy, while TAM will assess potential healthcare project investment. The partnership aims to leverage Singapore's medical tourism expertise and expand into Vietnam, with no expected impact on Livingstone's net tangible assets or earnings per share. The move follows a press statement on March 8, 2022.

images.alt_text: Livingstone Health chief business officer Dax Ng (right) and Phytopharma chairman Nguyen Cong Chien (left).

site_title: New tripartite standard to improve well-being of lower-wage workers
summary: Singapore has introduced a new Tripartite Standard on Advancing Well-being of Lower-Wage Workers to improve the employment practices of lower-wage workers. The standard includes guidelines on workplace support, training, and mental well-being. Employers that adopt the standard will receive "PW Mark Plus" accreditation. The Progressive Wage Model (PWM) will also be rolled out, with cumulative wage increases of up to 84% for entry-level cleaners by 2028. The scheme aims to cover over 94% of full-time lower-wage workers by 2028.

site_title: Brent seen at US$100 in 2022 as tight market fuels volatility
summary: Maybank Research predicts oil prices will remain volatile and high, averaging around $93 per barrel, with Brent crude potentially reaching $100 per barrel in 2022. Global demand is rising while supply remains disrupted by geopolitical tensions and under-investment. The market is expected to remain under-supplied for 2-3 years due to declining global capex and low oil inventories. A US-Iran nuclear agreement may ease short-term concerns but is not a long-term solution, and Russia's sanctions impact will also affect the market.

site_title: Caveat emptor - Pitfalls in the red-hot Australian property market
summary: The Australian property market experienced a 22% rise in median prices last year, its best performance in three decades, driven by low interest rates and a steady influx of economic migrants. However, the market is now slowing due to young couples being priced out and the collapse of immigration. Potential investors should be cautious of pitfalls, including defective buildings, flood-prone areas, and misleading sales tactics. With the Australian economy rebounding, investors should scrutinize all factors before making a decision.

site_title: Why was Singapore's anti-spoofing registry shut and replaced?
summary: Singapore's SMS SenderID Protection Registry pilot, aimed at preventing SMS spoofing attacks, has been shut and will be rebuilt by the Singapore Network Information Centre (SGNIC). The pilot, launched in response to a spate of attacks targeting OCBC customers, was shut due to loopholes in the system, which allowed scam messages to be sent to users while investigations were underway. The new system will automatically block spoofed messages using protected sender IDs, eliminating the need for investigations, and will be implemented in collaboration with local mobile network operators and tier 1 SMS aggregators.

site_title: Grab at risk of US class action lawsuits after shares fall
summary: Grab Holdings Inc. is facing a risk of US class action lawsuits after its shares fell, according to a March 2022 report. The company's stock plummeted, prompting concerns about potential legal action. Grab did not comment on the matter.

site_title: Oil prices hit 14-year highs on Russia oil ban talks, Iran deal delay
summary: Oil prices surged to 14-year highs, reaching $123.21 a barrel for Brent and $119.40 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate, amid concerns over Russia's oil ban and Iran deal delay. The US and European allies are considering banning Russian oil imports, while a potential ban could drive prices to over $300 per barrel. Meanwhile, talks to revive Iran's 2015 nuclear deal with world powers are stalled, and analysts predict Iran will take several months to restore oil flows.

site_title: China warns US against forming Pacific 'Nato' and backing Taiwan
summary: China warned the US against forming a Pacific version of NATO, calling it a "pervasive action" that will "doom to fail." Foreign Minister Wang Yi stated that the US's Indo-Pacific strategy aims to create Asia's answer to NATO, citing Taiwan and Ukraine as examples of security disputes. China claims Taiwan will "eventually return to the motherland," and warned that US ties with Taiwan would bring "unbearable consequences." Wang also criticized Russia for undermining China's sovereignty on Taiwan, despite a "rock-solid" relationship with Russia.

site_title: Asian markets dive as oil prices spike, Ukraine crisis rattles investors
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Monday as crude oil prices surged to record highs due to concerns over a potential US embargo on Russian oil imports and escalating tensions between Ukraine and Russia. The US Congress is exploring an embargo, while Opec+ has agreed to only a modest supply increase, keeping supply tight. Benchmark Brent prices reached US$137.59, and West Texas Intermediate Crude touched US$129.77. This has led to fears of a supply crunch and volatility in the oil market, posing a "clear and present threat to the global recovery".

site_title: EY appoints new country managing partner for Singapore, Brunei
summary: EY appoints Liew Nam Soon as its new country managing partner for Singapore and Brunei, effective July 1, 2022. Liew, currently EY Asean regional managing partner, will succeed Max Loh, who retires on June 30. Liew prioritizes developing talent, leading-edge capabilities, and driving client focus, while continuing to lead EY's Asean regional operations.

site_title: Sushi Kou, Casa among fine dining closures
summary: Sushi Kou, a popular Japanese restaurant in Singapore, is set to close on March 31 amid a spate of resignations, including its head chef. The closures follow others, such as Casa by Remy Lefebvre and 1-Altitude, which have also shut down in recent months. Sushi Kou, which opened in 2020, was known for its expensive sushi omakase and required advance bookings due to its popularity. The closure marks the latest fine dining casualty in Singapore's culinary scene.

site_title: DBS sets up board sustainability committee
summary: DBS Bank has established a board sustainability committee (BSC) to oversee material environmental, social, and governance (ESG) matters. This move is the bank's first in Singapore and aims to enhance governance and focus on its sustainability agenda. The BSC, chaired by CEO Piyush Gupta, will govern ESG matters including sustainability strategies, climate-related issues, and stakeholder engagement. The bank's sustainability agenda spans three pillars: responsible banking, responsible business practices, and creating impact beyond banking.

site_title: Putin's rouble workaround still leaves bond payments in doubt
summary: Russia has allowed companies to pay foreign creditors in roubles, following President Vladimir Putin's decree, to service debt while capital controls remain in place. The decree establishes temporary rules for sovereign and corporate debtors to make payments in roubles to countries that engage in hostile activities against Russia. This move may leave bond payments in doubt, particularly for bonds denominated in foreign currencies, as investors weigh the impact of sanctions imposed on Russia. The central bank may allow foreign creditors to receive payments in their currency if they obtain special permission.

site_title: US: Dow ends -2.4%, Nasdaq -3.6% on mounting economic worries
summary: US stocks plummeted on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 2.4% to 32,817.38, and the S&P 500 sinking 3.0% to 4,201.08. The Nasdaq Composite tumbled 3.6% to 12,830.96, driven by mounting economic worries over Russia's attack on Ukraine and spiking commodity prices. Investors fear the rising costs will slow the economy, leading to a decline in stock prices.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks plunged on Monday in the latest rout following Russia's attack on Ukraine as worries mount that spiking commodity prices will slow the economy.

site_title: Apple likely to launch new low-cost 5G iPhone
summary: Apple is expected to launch a new low-cost 5G iPhone SE at its annual spring product launch event, potentially priced at $399, according to analysts. The new phone would be the first update to the iPhone SE in 2 years, featuring an improved camera and faster processor. The launch is expected to cater to price-sensitive consumers, particularly younger individuals, and is predicted to account for 10% of global iPhone shipments. The event is also expected to feature new iPad Air and high-end Mac Mini models.

site_title: Strata units in GB Building for sale; Oxley Tower F&B units re-launched at lower guide price
summary: Three strata commercial units in the GB Building in Singapore's Central Business District have been launched for sale through an expression of interest (EOI) exercise, with a combined guide price of S$69 million. The units include a 13,067 sq ft retail podium and two office units with strata areas of 12,594 sq ft and 5,425 sq ft. The retail podium and eighth-floor office space are vacant, while the third-floor office space is tenanted. The units can be purchased individually or collectively as a portfolio, and equity sale is also available.

images.alt_text: The portfolio of 3 commercial units at GB Building has an overall guide price of S$69m, and a combined strata floor area of 31,086 square feet.

site_title: Singtel's NCS acquires Aussie IT company The Dialog Group for A$325m
summary: Singtel's technology services arm, NCS, has acquired Australian IT company The Dialog Group for A$325 million (S$328 million) to gain a foothold in the Australian market quickly. The acquisition is expected to be completed in 3 months and will help NCS grow its talent pool, providing end-to-end solutions to clients. NCS CEO Ng Kuo Pin believes the acquisition will help the company capture Australia's growing IT spending market, which is expected to grow by 6.5% this year.

site_title: Traveloka fuels up 'buy now, pay later' engine for super app take-off
summary: Traveloka, an Indonesia-based travel booking company, is expanding its growth beyond its core platform. The company has introduced a "buy now, pay later" (BNPL) service in e-commerce, allowing users to split payments into instalments over up to 12 months. Traveloka is also investing in food delivery and fintech, with a focus on consumer credit and data-driven decision-making. The company is preparing for a potential initial public offering (IPO) and is cautious about regulatory risks, while maintaining a positive outlook on its growth story.

site_title: Avoid standing naked when the tide goes out
summary: The article discusses the challenges of inflation and the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy in 2022. With inflation running high, policymakers must tackle the issue, and economists debate the number of rate hikes needed. The author argues that the Fed should focus on achieving a positive real bond yield to attract investors to the US Treasury market. China's real rate is seen as a benchmark, currently around 2%, compared to the US's negative 5% real return. The article concludes that the Fed's independence is being tested, but investors should not expect a pivot in monetary policy.

site_title: The Batman scores US$128m, second-biggest pandemic debut
summary: The Batman, starring Robert Pattinson, collected a record-breaking US$128.5 million in its box office debut, becoming the second pandemic-era movie to cross the US$100 million mark in a single weekend. This feat surpasses previous films like Spider-Man: No Way Home and solidifies the film's commercial success, despite a hefty production budget of US$200 million. The Batman's success can be attributed to its unique take on the character, positive reviews, and strong reception from ticket buyers, making it a commercial winner for Warner Bros.

site_title: Malaysia to reopen all international borders, including Causeway, Second Link checkpoints
summary: Malaysia is set to reopen its international borders, including the Causeway and Second Link checkpoints, after 2 years of closure due to the coronavirus pandemic. Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob is expected to announce the exact opening date on March 8. Tourists must provide proof of accommodation, sufficient funds, and a travel itinerary to enter the country. The reopening is seen as a boost to Malaysia's economy, which is recovering from the pandemic, although it is expected to rebound at a slower pace than before.

site_title: How Tenaga Nasional is trying to stop illegal Bitcoin mining
summary: Tenaga Nasional, Malaysia's national utility, is proposing a special tariff for Bitcoin mining operators to combat electricity theft. The company has seen a surge in cases of illegal mining, with 7,209 cases reported in 2021, resulting in an estimated RM2.3 billion in electricity theft. Tenaga Nasional is working with authorities to arrest power thieves, and technology such as smart metering and digital power quality products can help prevent future theft. The company aims to protect public electricity supply and security.

site_title: Some EU nations baulk at push to advance Ukraine's membership bid
summary: Western European Union countries, including Germany and the Netherlands, are opposing the grant of Ukraine candidate status ahead of a summit in France, citing a desire to focus on practical support and ending the war rather than embarking on a lengthy membership process. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky formally applied for EU membership last month, with 9 member states supporting his bid. EU leaders will discuss Ukraine's request when they meet on March 10, potentially deciding to back candidate status or find a compromise.

site_title: War stokes rally in SGX's oil, commodity stocks
summary: A recent rally in oil and commodity stocks on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) has been fueled by robust demand and tight market conditions, driven by a sharp increase in crude prices. Last year, crude prices averaged 73% higher than 2020, with energy stocks experiencing a significant turnaround from "doom" to "boom." This surge in energy stocks has been driven by investor interest, with analysts praising a change of heart by Canadian investment bank RBC Capital Markets. The rally has also been influenced by global events, including US tariffs and sanctions.

site_title: UBS bonus pool rises 10% as Archegos collapse mars dealmaking boom
summary: UBS Group raised its bonus pool for last year by 10% to US$3.7 billion, despite a 10% decline in average trader bonuses due to the collapse of Archegos Capital Management. CEO Ralph Hamers received 11 million Swiss francs, while former CEO Sergio Ermotti earned 13.3 million francs in 2020. The bank balances talent retention after a bumper year for dealmaking, with banks across Europe and Wall Street increasing staff compensation amid booming markets.

site_title: Confusion, but not panic, reigns in global finance in Russia's wake
summary: Western allies' sanctions against Russia are causing large potential losses for their own banks, companies, and investors, often in unexpected ways. Despite the growing losses, market participants are not yet seeing panic, with many citing the system's ability to absorb shocks and fat buffers at financial institutions. The losses are being felt globally, with the European debt market experiencing a shortage of collateral and internet companies in Russia facing unexpected bills. Experts warn that the situation is rapidly evolving and that the system's ability to absorb losses is not guaranteed, with the potential for a broader financial crisis if losses spread and panic sets in.

site_title: Stakes rise as Putin says war in Ukraine will continue
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin reiterated that the war in Ukraine will continue until Ukraine accepts his demands, including demilitarization and halting resistance. Putin stated that Ukraine must accept his terms to end the conflict, dimming hopes for a negotiated settlement. The war is now entering its 2-week mark, with potentially catastrophic implications for Ukrainian civilians and challenges for Ukraine's successful defense.

site_title: Shatec rebrands its mentoring programme
summary: Shatec has rebranded its mentoring program, Mentoring@SHATEC, which brings together private sector mentors and students from the hospitality and culinary industry. The program, launched in 2015, has been updated to include corporate social responsibility and sustainability modules. The rebranded program aims to support mentees in their careers and community involvement. Over 70 industry experts and 20 students from more than 30 organizations have convened under the new program, which will last for a year and include on-site tours and panel discussions.

site_title: Russia's war on Ukraine: Drawing first lessons and considering the outlook
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has resulted in significant losses for Russia, with its economy expected to fall behind even further due to Western sanctions. China, however, is likely to benefit from the situation, as Russia becomes increasingly dependent on China for economic support. The US and Europe are working to decouple from Russia, which could lead to China being subject to US sanctions. The conflict has shifted the global landscape to a world of relative gains, where measures that inflict losses on one side but gains on another are acceptable. Alternative scenarios, including a change in Russian leadership or a wider conflict, are possible, but nuclear deterrence is expected to prevent a wider war.

site_title: Uniqlo owner pledges to stay in Russia as wave of companies exit
summary: FAST Retailing, the parent of Uniqlo, will continue to operate all 50 of its stores in Russia despite international pressure to isolate the country following its invasion of Ukraine. CEO Tadashi Yanai stated that clothing is a necessity of life and that the people of Russia have the same right to live as others, differing from other companies like Nike and Inditex that have closed stores or suspended operations. This move runs counter to a trend of companies pulling out of Russia due to trade restrictions and financial penalties.

site_title: Immutable raises US$200m in Series C round led by Temasek
summary: Immutable, a Sydney-based blockchain company, raised US$200 million in a Series C financing round led by Temasek, with other investors including Tencent, Animoca Brands, and AirTree Ventures. The funding brings its valuation to US$2.5 billion and will be used to fund global expansion, invest in its Immutable X platform, and scale its Immutable Gaming Studio. The company plans to hire 200 new employees and expand into new verticals, with current partners including GameStop, TikTok, and Opensea.

site_title: Oil plays extend active trading as prices surge on supply fears
summary: Oil prices surged to near their all-time high levels since 2008, with Brent at US$139.13 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate at US$130.50, due to supply fears fueled by US and European allies exploring a Russian oil embargo and delays in the return of Iranian crude. Oil plays on the Singapore Exchange saw brisk trading, with RH Petrogas rising 24.2% and Interra Resources climbing 20.8%. The surge in oil prices was largely driven by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's announcement on Sunday that the US and its European allies were exploring banning imports of Russian oil.

site_title: Grab at risk of US class action lawsuits after shares fall
summary: Grab, a Singapore-based ride-hailing and food delivery company, has seen its shares plummet 37% to US$3.17 after reporting a US$1.1 billion loss in its fourth quarter. The company's listing in the US has led to a slew of class action lawsuits, with at least 6 law firms investigating potential securities fraud and other unlawful business practices. Law firms are seeking shareholders with significant losses, with some firms looking for losses of US$20,000 to US$100,000. The lawsuits are a reality of listing in the US, where law firms can roll out investigations on contingency, potentially resulting in settlements rather than trials.

site_title: Strong enforcement measures will guard against new EP system fraud
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Tan See Leng announced strong enforcement measures to prevent fraud in the new Complementarity Assessment Framework (Compass), a points-based system assessing Employment Pass (EP) applicants and their employers. Similar verification processes will be developed to prevent fraud for job roles listed on the official "shortage occupation list" as well as other new criteria. This move aims to prevent employers from gaming the system.

site_title: Higher tech co-funding for some farms, new disposable bag charge
summary: Singapore has announced measures to improve its food and climate resilience, including a higher co-funding rate for certain farm types and the introduction of a disposable bag charge. The Agri-Food Cluster Transformation (ACT) Fund will provide up to 70% co-funding for farms of fruited vegetables, mushrooms, and shrimp. A new lease-based system for sea-based farms will also be introduced, with temporary occupation licenses and annual fees set to start in 2023. Additionally, large supermarkets with an annual turnover of over S$100 million will have to charge at least S$0.05 per disposable carrier bag from mid-2023.

site_title: Omicron threat draws mixed reactions from analysts covering Dairy Farm
summary: Dairy Farm International's rating has been downgraded to "neutral" by RHB Research due to a 62% decline in net profit amid the pandemic, affecting its normal store operations and reduced traffic. The move comes as the Omicron variant continues to spread through key operating markets.

site_title: President Biden shifts to the political centre
summary: President Joe Biden's State of the Union address may have boosted his public approval ratings, with a recent NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist opinion poll showing a 8-point increase to 47% overall approval and significant gains in support for his handling of the Ukraine crisis, coronavirus pandemic, and economy. The poll also found that Biden's handling of the economy improved to 55% approval, up 8 points from a previous poll. However, his rating on the economy remains low, with 53% disapproving, and his foreign policy decisions have weakened American standing on the world stage, according to 51% of Americans.

site_title: Investors can no longer afford to ignore geopolitical risk
summary: Energy majors BP and Shell are exiting their Russian operations amid the ongoing invasion of Ukraine, with BP announcing it will withdraw from the country. Total, which has a 20% stake in Rosneft, has also said it won't invest in new Russian projects. The move comes as investors and companies are forced to confront the reality that business cannot ignore geopolitical risk, particularly in industries like oil and gas that are deeply tied to local politics. The decision highlights the need for companies to examine their ethical responsibilities and potential ties to authoritarian regimes.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: US President Donald Trump has imposed a 50% copper import tariff, affecting refined metal. The move is part of his efforts to support domestic copper producers. The tariff has contributed to a 2% increase in oil prices, with investors weighing the impact of market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks have edged down from records amid tariff threats, including a fresh salvo on Canada.

site_title: Arms industry eyes boost as Europe looks to bolster defences
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has revitalized European defence spending, with Germany, Denmark, and Poland pledging to increase their military budgets. Germany's €100 billion allocation for a one-time defence spending boost is seen as a new era for EU defence spending. European arms makers, such as Airbus, MBDA, and Leonardo, are exhibiting at the World Defence Show in Saudi Arabia, with many expecting increased sales. The conflict has reignited interest in security issues and could lead to European states seeking to purchase advanced weaponry from European consortia.

site_title: China property shares firm after friendly policy tone
summary: Chinese property shares rose 1.5% on Monday after Premier Li Keqiang confirmed city-specific policy easing for the sector, despite no full-scale relaxation. Analysts say this tone is more positive than previous comments. Country Garden and China Overseas Land & Investment gained 5.6% and 3.7%, respectively. The government will support commercial housing to meet homebuyers' needs and implement city-specific policies to promote healthy development. Analysts expect local governments to introduce policy fine-tuning measures, including down-payment ratio reduction and home-purchase restriction removal.

site_title: Douglas Foo steps down from SMF presidency
summary: Singapore Manufacturing Federation (SMF) president Douglas Foo has stepped down from his leadership role, effective February 25, 2022. Ryan Chioh, the current deputy president, will act as president in the interim until a new president is appointed. Foo, who was re-elected in 2021, had served for three consecutive terms, with a proposed constitutional amendment allowing him to serve again. However, this was met with mixed reactions, leading to a proxy vote and virtual EGM, which ultimately allowed Foo to remain as president. The reason for Foo's departure is unclear.

site_title: Russia says deals with 'unfriendly' countries such as Singapore will require approval
summary: Russia has introduced a new rule requiring approval from a government commission for corporate deals with companies and individuals from "unfriendly" countries, including Singapore, the US, EU member states, and others. The move follows severe economic sanctions over the Ukraine conflict. The government has also allowed debtors to temporarily pay foreign currency debts owed to overseas creditors in roubles, with payments exceeding 10 million roubles (US$76,046) a month. The list of "unfriendly" countries includes 10 nations and territories.

site_title: Foreign investors cut China government bond holdings in February
summary: Foreign investors significantly reduced their holdings of Chinese government bonds in February, with offshore holdings falling 1.41% to 2.48 trillion yuan, the largest drop in 3 years. This decrease was attributed to rising geopolitical risks and a global flight to safety. Quasi-sovereign bond holdings, typically the most liquid instruments, also declined 2.66% to a 7-month low. Analysts attribute the drop to global risk-off sentiment, with funds potentially seeking liquidity in emerging markets like China.

site_title: Euro set for biggest 3-day drop in 2 years
summary: The euro plummeted over 1% against the US dollar on Monday, its largest 3-day drop in 2 years, amid soaring oil prices and concerns of a stagflationary shock that could harm European recovery hopes. The single currency's drop was broad-based, with fluctuations against the Swiss franc and other currencies. Oil prices soared to their highest levels since 2008, fueling fears of inflation and economic impact, with Goldman Sachs predicting a 0.6% drop in real economic growth in the euro area.

site_title: Japan transport ministry raids Hino Motors after false emissions data; shares tumble
summary: Japan's transportation ministry raided Hino Motors Ltd on Monday, days after the truck maker admitted to falsifying emissions data. The company's shares plummeted 17% after discovering "misconduct" in engine performance and emissions certificates. Hino has suspended sales of affected vehicles and is investigating earnings impact. The ministry's raid is part of a growing trend of Japanese automakers involved in improper emissions tests, following similar incidents at Mazda, Suzuki, and Yamaha. The government is seeking to regain public trust, with the transportation minister calling the matter "extremely regrettable."

site_title: Supreme Court spurns Google bid to avoid shareholder lawsuit
summary: The US Supreme Court declined to hear Alphabet Inc's appeal to dismiss a shareholder lawsuit accusing Google of concealing a security glitch that exposed private user data in 2018. The lawsuit, led by Rhode Island, claims Google made false statements to avoid regulatory scrutiny and reputational harm. A lower court's ruling revived the lawsuit, which was initially dismissed in 2020. The Supreme Court's decision leaves in place a ruling that the company intentionally concealed the data exposure from investors.

site_title: Q&M Dental CEO to take 29% stake in No Signboard Holdings
summary: Q&M Dental CEO Dr Ng Chin Siau has entered a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire a 29% stake in No Signboard Holdings for S$1. As a condition, Dr Ng will extend an interest-free loan of S$2.6 million to the company. No Signboard's controlling shareholder GuGong currently holds 54.9% of shares, and the deal is subject to regulatory approval.

site_title: Seeing value in pursuing further studies in real estate
summary: Real estate studies are gaining consideration in Singapore due to the sector's resilience and growth potential. The industry's high demand for skilled professionals, particularly in finance and spatial planning, is driven by the rise of integrated projects and the increasing complexity of real estate development. Top property groups have leaders with spatial and financial backgrounds, and a degree in real estate can provide valuable skills in a vital and growing sector.

site_title: Higher technology co-funding for some types of farms, new lease system for sea farms
summary: Singapore aims to strengthen its food supply resilience with co-funding for technology in certain farms. The Agri-Food Cluster Transformation (ACT) Fund will offer 70% co-funding for fruited vegetables, mushrooms, and shrimp until 2025. New sea spaces will be launched for local aquaculture, with farms required to pay for leases under a new system. Longer leases will be introduced for new land parcels and sea farms will pay for the use of sea spaces with a new lease-based system starting from end-2022.

site_title: Singapore O&G gets S$0.295-a-share takeover offer from vehicle linked to Dymon Asia
summary: Singapore O&G Group, a healthcare service provider, has received a voluntary takeover offer from NewMedCo Group at S$0.295 per share, representing a 15.7% premium over the last trading price. The offeror, linked to Dymon Asia, aims to privatize the company, citing flexibility and cost savings. Singapore O&G's management and capital resources are expected to remain unchanged, with the company to continue operating under its current structure.

site_title: Rupee sinks to record low as India markets sell off on oil surge
summary: The Indian rupee plummeted to a record low, falling 1.1% to 76.9812 per dollar, amid a surge in oil prices, which have risen over 60% this year. The decline has darkened India's economic outlook, with stocks and bonds also slumping. The country's high dependence on imported oil makes it vulnerable to price shocks, and geopolitical tensions are exacerbating investor sentiment. The rupee has become Asia's worst performer this year, with the Reserve Bank of India likely to continue selling USD to curb losses.

site_title: Uber raises earnings outlook on ride-hail rebound; shares gain
summary: Uber Technologies Inc raised its earnings forecast for the current quarter, citing a faster-than-expected rebound in ride-hailing demand due to the Omicron variant. The company expects adjusted earnings of $130-150 million, surpassing analyst projections. CEO Dara Khosrowshahi attributed the recovery to healthy demand across all use cases, including travel, commuting, and going out at night. Airport gross bookings surged 50% in February and are expected to be strong during the upcoming travel season.

site_title: Caveat emptor : Pitfalls in the red-hot Australian property market
summary: The Australian property market, which experienced a 22% rise in median property prices last year, is showing signs of slowing down due to a decrease in demand from young couples and professionals. The low interest rate regime and lack of suitable housing land have contributed to the market's growth, but the current pace of growth is expected to slow. Potential investors should be cautious of pitfalls, including buying off the plan, which can result in defective buildings, and being aware of the risks associated with investing in areas prone to flooding.

site_title: Malaysia ready to reopen all international borders, including Causeway, Second Link land checkpoints
summary: Malaysia is set to reopen its international borders, including the Causeway and Second Link land checkpoints, after 2 years due to the coronavirus pandemic. Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob is expected to announce the exact opening date on Tuesday. Automated gates at international entry points, including KLIA and the Sultan Iskandar Building, have been reactivated. The move comes after officers were recalled from temporary depots to prepare for the reopening. The reopening is expected to mark a significant milestone in Malaysia's recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: European gas roars to record 345 euros on Russian supply fears
summary: European gas prices reached a record 345 euros per megawatt-hour due to concerns over Russian supply amid US consideration of curbs on Russian oil imports. Benchmark gas prices jumped 79% and crude oil rose past $139 a barrel in London. Metals, including copper and gold, also surged. The US House is exploring legislation to ban Russian oil imports, which could lead to "extreme" measures to ration supplies if Russian gas flows to Europe are disrupted.

site_title: BT Explains: Why was Singapore's anti-spoofing registry shut and replaced?
summary: Singapore's SMS SenderID Protection Registry pilot, launched in January 2022 to combat SMS spoofing attacks targeting OCBC customers, will be shut and rebuilt by the Singapore Network Information Centre (SGNIC). The pilot, initiated in response to a spate of attacks, aimed to enhance the security of SMS services. The shutdown and rebuild will allow for improvements and enhancements to the registry, ultimately improving the protection of consumers from SMS spoofing attacks.

site_title: Ed Sheeran denies borrowing ideas in 'Shape of You' copyright trial
summary: British singer Ed Sheeran has denied borrowing ideas from grime artist Sami Chokri and music producer Ross O'Donoghue for his 2017 hit "Shape of You". Sheeran testified in a London High Court trial, saying he was not aware of Chokri at the time and had not copied lines and phrases from their 2015 song "Oh Why". Sheeran's lawyers argue that his songwriting style was spontaneous and not influenced by other artists, while Chokri and O'Donoghue claim the similarities between the two songs are "strikingly similar" and "extremely likely" to be a result of Sheeran's borrowing.

site_title: Nordic Group's offer for Starburst closes with 94.3% valid acceptances
summary: Nordic Group's voluntary offer for Starburst Holdings has closed with 94.3% valid acceptances, surpassing the 90% threshold. As a result, Nordic Group will exercise its right to compulsory acquisition of the remaining shares at the offer price of S$0.238. Following the acquisition, Starburst Holdings will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Putin's rouble workaround still leaves bond payments in doubt
summary: Russia has allowed companies to pay foreign creditors in roubles, as per a decree signed by President Vladimir Putin, to service debt while capital controls remain in place. The decree specifies countries that engage in hostile activities against Russia and its companies. Russian corporate bonds denominated in foreign currencies have plummeted, and clearing houses have excluded securities issued by Russian entities from transactions. The rule applies to amounts exceeding $81,358 per month, and foreign creditors from non-sanctioned countries may receive payments in their currency with special permission.

site_title: US: Wall St opens mixed on inflation angst as oil breaches US$130
summary: US stocks opened mixed on March 7, 2022, amid concerns over inflation and slowing economic growth. The Dow Jones fell 0.10%, while the S&P 500 opened lower by 0.04%. However, the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.11%. The prospect of a ban on oil imports from Russia pushed oil prices above $130 a barrel. Despite this, the US stock market continued to edge closer to record highs.

site_title: SPH 'unable to comment' on any special dividend from sgCarMart divestment
summary: SPH (Singapore Press Holdings) is "unable to comment" on whether it will declare a special dividend following the divestment of sgCarMart to Toyota, valued at S$150 million. The company had received an offer from consortium Cuscaden Peak to buy SPH, with a virtual Investors' Day scheduled for Tuesday. The Cuscaden Implementation Agreement states that if SPH declares a dividend, Cuscaden can reduce its cash consideration by the amount of the dividend.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Maybank Research predicts volatile oil prices, with Brent expected to average US$100 in 2022, due to rising global demand and supply disruptions. A new Tripartite Standard aims to improve lower-wage workers' well-being, while stronger enforcement measures will combat EP system fraud. Singtel's NCS acquired an Australian IT company for A$325m, and Grab faces possible class action suits from US shareholder rights law firms. Singapore's O&G received a takeover offer, and Asian markets tumbled due to oil price spikes and the Ukraine crisis.

site_title: Binance acquires stake in Malaysian fintech company MX Global
summary: Cryptocurrency exchange Binance has made an undisclosed investment in Malaysian fintech company MX Global, following a halt on its operations in the country due to licensing issues. MX Global, a recognized market operator-digital asset exchange, has received approval from Malaysia's Securities Commission. The investment aims to build brand awareness, hire talent, and develop new features within the country's regulatory framework. Binance's CEO Changpeng Zhao sees potential in Malaysia's crypto and blockchain community, with plans to expand its presence in the region.

site_title: Vanguard is grabbing flows in US$6.8t ETF world
summary: Vanguard is expanding its market share in the US$6.8 trillion ETF industry by slashing fees across 82 funds, with the average cost dropping to 9 basis points. The firm's aggressive fee-cutting has drawn record flows of $58 billion this year, surpassing its competitors and putting it on track to become the largest ETF manager within the next two years. This move has accelerated the takeover of stock index funds, while smaller issuers are forced to offer niche and riskier strategies to survive. Vanguard's unique ownership structure allows it to charge low fees, funneling excess funds into fee reductions.

images.alt_text: Every year over the past 2 decades, in the good times and the bad, there's been one sure-fire trend in Wall Street money management: Vanguard tightens its grip on the ETF market.

site_title: Hong Kong's Covid death rate now world's highest
summary: Hong Kong's Covid-19 death rate has surpassed the world's highest, with a 7-day rolling average of 27 deaths per 1 million people, doubling the rate in Latvia. The city reported 161 fatalities, mostly elderly and unvaccinated, and 25,150 new cases on Monday. Authorities plan to tackle the outbreak with mass testing and a potential lockdown, while residents and expatriates are fleeing the city. Globally, the death toll from Covid-19 neared 6 million.

site_title: Fintech startup Zeta raises US$30m, teams with Mastercard
summary: Zeta Services, a fintech startup, has raised US$30 million from investors including Mastercard, valuing it at US$1.5 billion. The 5-year collaboration aims to help customers launch credit card services, with Mastercard providing fraud detection and risk solutions. Zeta will enable faster and more flexible card issuance, targeting US$60 billion in purchase volume over the next 5 years. The startup has added 2 major US banks to its customer roster, moving towards digitization in the banking industry.

images.alt_text: Zeta Services, a banking and credit card technology unicorn, has raised US$30 million from investors including Mastercard, and the two announced a 5-year collaboration to help customers launch credit card services.

site_title: Morgan Stanley and Citi strategists see equities storm forming
summary: Equity markets are experiencing a global downturn, with Morgan Stanley and Citi strategists warning of a perfect storm gathering. A bear market is unfolding, and earnings delivery is crucial amid declining liquidity. Gas and oil prices are soaring, leading to "demand destruction" concerns. Strategists recommend a defensive stance, prioritizing companies with superior operational efficiency and earnings stability. A global gauge of analyst estimates on corporate profits has turned negative for the first time since September 2020, eroding confidence in risk assets.

site_title: Breaking the boardroom bias: a case for women in leadership
summary: Singapore has made significant progress in having women in leadership positions, with 13.1% of companies having female CEOs, the highest percentage globally. However, the city-state still lags behind in terms of women holding board seats, ranking 28th out of 51 countries with 17.6%. Despite this, Singapore's progress is notable, with countries like Malaysia and the Philippines ranking higher in this regard. The top spot for women in board seats is held by France with 43.2%. This highlights the need for continued efforts to promote women in leadership positions.

site_title: Apple expected to launch new low-cost 5G iPhone
summary: Apple is expected to launch a new low-cost 5G iPhone SE at its spring product launch event on March 8, alongside a new iPad Air and high-end Mac Mini. The new iPhone SE would retain its current price of $399, potentially attracting price-sensitive consumers and boosting Apple's unit iPhone estimate for 2022. The new phone is expected to feature an improved camera and faster processor, and will primarily target first-time buyers in the US, Japan, and Western Europe, accounting for 10% of global iPhone shipments.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 31.38 points to 1,572.56, following a decline in volume and a higher number of losers compared to gainers.

site_title: Singapore stocks slide on Monday as oil prices surge; STI down 1.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.2% on Monday, March 7, 2022, as oil prices surged amid escalating tensions in Russia and Ukraine. The STI lost 38.96 points to 3,187.82 points, with Dairy Farm International being the biggest loser and UOL Group the biggest gainer. Asian markets also declined, with Japan's Nikkei falling 2.9% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng tumbling 3.9%. Analysts attribute the decline to the region's reliance on imported energy and the looming stagflationary wave.

site_title: Cryptocurrency exchange FTX to start European operations
summary: FTX Trading, a prominent US cryptocurrency exchange, is set to launch European operations through a partnership with a licensed investment firm in Switzerland. The company will operate from Cyprus, with approval from the Cypriot financial regulator CySEC. FTX Europe will offer the parent company's products and services to EU clients via the passporting regime, allowing it to operate across borders. The move aims to provide a safe and secure environment for crypto trading in Europe, as CEO Sam Bankman-Fried stated.

images.alt_text: Cryptocurrency exchange operator FTX Trading is poised to start offering services in Europe and the Middle East, following its rapid rise to become one of the US's most prominent venues for trading digital assets.

site_title: Responsible companies must deliver sustainable value over the long term
summary: Temasek International emphasizes the importance of companies delivering sustainable value over the long term, balancing profit and purpose. The state-owned but independently operated investment company believes its purpose transcends profit maximization, guiding its three roles: active investor, forward-looking institution, and trusted steward. Temasek expects its portfolio companies to honor their obligations to stakeholders while pursuing commercial objectives, with sustainability at the core of its decision-making.

site_title: Investors can no longer afford to ignore geopolitical risk
summary: Major oil and gas companies, including BP and Shell, are exiting their operations in Russia amid the ongoing conflict with Ukraine. This move marks a significant shift, as companies acknowledge that business and politics cannot be separated. Analysts and experts say that the industry's significant influence in countries where it operates means that politics is always present. Companies are now expected to consider their responsibilities to employees, customers, and the broader impact of their operations, and to provide better answers to questions about their involvement in geopolitics.

site_title: Douglas Foo steps down from SMF presidency
summary: Singapore Manufacturing Federation (SMF) president Douglas Foo has stepped down, effective February 25. Ryan Chioh, deputy president and managing director of FarEastFlora.com, will act as interim president until a new president is appointed. The reason for Foo's departure is unclear, with SMF stating a press release will be shared soon for details on the new president.

site_title: Audemars Piguet tops Patek Philippe in revenue, report says
summary: Audemars Piguet surpassed Patek Philippe in revenue for the first time, with sales of 1.58 billion francs, according to a Morgan Stanley report. The Swiss watch industry saw a rebound in sales of high-end timepieces, driven by deep-pocketed buyers who cancelled travel plans during the pandemic. Rolex had its best year ever, with record sales of 8 billion francs, and Richemont's Cartier and Vacheron Constantin also saw significant gains. The report highlights a shift towards a select few high-end brands, with watches priced above 3,000 francs accounting for 73% of sales.

site_title: Uniqlo owner pledges to stay in Russia as wave of companies exit
summary: Fast Retailing Co, owner of Uniqlo, will continue to operate its 50 stores in Russia despite international pressure to isolate the country following its invasion of Ukraine. CEO Tadashi Yanai stated that clothing is a necessity of life and that companies should oppose war, but there are no plans to suspend operations. This decision runs counter to moves by other major brands to exit or suspend operations in Russia.

site_title: Asia-Pacific travel faces bumpy recovery, says Booking.com executive
summary: Asia-Pacific travel is trailing the rest of the world and will experience a bumpy recovery due to border restrictions and fewer arrivals from Russia. Booking.com's managing director for the Asia-Pacific, Laura Houldsworth, notes that countries in the region have been slower to open borders than other destinations, and the conflict in Ukraine will impact travel demand among eastern Europeans. Destinations with fewer entry restrictions will have an advantage, and countries like Australia, Cambodia, and the Philippines have recently dropped quarantine requirements for vaccinated tourists, offering a glimmer of optimism for the region's tourism recovery.

site_title: Avoid standing naked when the tide goes out
summary: The article discusses the impact of inflation and rising interest rates on the global economy, particularly in the US and China. With inflation running as high as 7%, the US Federal Reserve is debating the need for rate hikes to control inflation. The article suggests that the Fed should focus on finding an "appropriate real bond yield" to entice investors to the US Treasury market. China, on the other hand, is easing monetary and fiscal policy, with potential rate cuts ahead. The article also highlights opportunities in Chinese manufacturing, software, and defense stocks, which are expected to perform well in 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong shares end sharply down
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted nearly 4% on Monday, March 7, 2022, due to the ongoing Russian invasion of Ukraine, which continues to impact global markets. The Hang Seng Index dropped 3.93% to 21,045.21, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined by 2.17% and 2.70%, respectively.

site_title: Bitcoin drops to 1-week low as oil shock batters risk assets
summary: Bitcoin dropped to a 1-week low of US$37,596, falling 3.7% in early Monday trading in Asia, amid concerns over Russia's invasion of Ukraine and soaring commodities prices. The decline marked the largest single-day drop since February 24 and wiped out early-week gains. Oil prices surged, putting pressure on inflation, and investors are increasingly turning to traditional assets. Experts warn that cryptocurrencies may not be a hedge against government asset seizures, and Bitcoin is trading in line with other risk assets.

site_title: Aedge Group appoints Tembusu blockchain fund partner as adviser
summary: Aedge Group has appointed Khoong Hock Yun, partner of Tembusu Partners blockchain fund, as an adviser with immediate effect. Khoong will provide strategic advice on technology adoption, strengthen the company's manpower business, and explore strategic investments. He brings over 3 decades of experience in the public and private sectors, including a previous role at the Infocomm Media Development Authority of Singapore. The appointment aims to leverage technology to enhance manpower productivity, transforming Aedge Group's businesses with industry expertise and connections.

site_title: UBS has US$200m exposure to Russian assets in loans to rich
summary: UBS has a US$200 million exposure to Russian assets used as collateral in loans to clients, primarily wealthy Russians. The bank identified a small number of clients sanctioned due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with less than US$10 million in outstanding loans. UBS is working to implement sanctions imposed by Switzerland, the US, and others, and has a total emerging market exposure of US$20.9 billion, including US$634 million to Russia.

site_title: Metro celebrates its 65th anniversary
summary: Metro Holdings is celebrating its 65th anniversary, founded in 1957 by Ong Tjoe Kim as a textile shop in Singapore. The company has grown to become a retail and property investment giant, with a portfolio spanning Asia, Europe, and Australia. After its mainboard listing in 1973, Metro expanded to 11 stores in Orchard Road and other locations. Today, the company is led by executive chairman Wong Sioe Hong and group CEO Yip Hoong Mun, with a focus on property investment and development amidst a volatile retail industry.

site_title: Ex-India stock exchange boss arrested in mystic scam
summary: Former India National Stock Exchange CEO Chitra Ramkrishna has been arrested in a corporate misgovernance scandal involving a supposed Himalayan yogi. She allegedly took business advice from the mystic during her 2013-2016 tenure, and regulators say she "abdicated all her powers" to the unknown person. Ramkrishna's former protege Anand Subramanian, who was arrested last month, allegedly manipulated her for personal gain. Both executives are barred from leaving India or accessing financial markets.

site_title: First Singaporean appointed as FATF president from July
summary: Singapore's T. Raja Kumar has been appointed as the first Singaporean president of the Financial Action Task Force (FATF), effective July 1, 2022, for a 2-year term. Raja, a senior advisor at the Ministry of Home Affairs, will lead the global anti-money laundering and terrorism financing watchdog, succeeding Marcus Pleyer. This marks Singapore's first FATF presidency, and Raja's experience includes serving as co-chairman of the National Interagency Committee on Anti-Money Laundering and Countering Financing of Terrorism.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares sink most in 5 weeks as oil surges on Ukraine war concerns
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average plummeted 2.94% to 25,221.41, its largest drop in over 5 weeks, due to concerns over the Russia-Ukraine war and resulting oil price surge. Energy and utilities sectors rose, while consumer cyclicals and tech slumped. Japanese chipmakers, including Tokyo Electron and Renesas, fell sharply. The broader Topix also dropped 2.76%. Market experts attribute the drop to spreading panic, awaiting US market reaction.

site_title: South Korea bans transactions with Russia central bank
summary: South Korea has banned all transactions with Russia's central bank, citing international financial restrictions against Moscow due to its invasion of Ukraine. This move follows similar actions by Western governments, international organizations, and major companies to isolate Russia. South Korea has also tightened export controls against Russia and suspended financial transactions with several major Russian banks. The decision is part of a series of punitive measures taken by Seoul against Russia and its ally Belarus, in an effort to condemn the invasion.

site_title: Will Ukraine's tragedy spur UN Security Council reform?
summary: The Russia-Ukraine conflict has highlighted weaknesses in the UN Security Council, particularly its veto power. The UN Charter's first purpose is to maintain international peace and security, but the Security Council's five permanent members have consistently blocked efforts to address conflicts. This has hindered the organization's ability to prevent threats to peace and suppress aggression. Reforming the Security Council is being considered as a potential solution to address these issues and promote more effective international cooperation.

site_title: Europe: Stocks extend slump at open
summary: European stock markets plummeted at the open on Monday, March 7, 2022, with Frankfurt diving 3.6% and Paris shedding 3.0%. The losses were driven by investors seeking safer assets like gold. Outside the eurozone, London lost 0.8%, while mining and oil giants saw gains due to soaring metals and crude values.

site_title: Confusion, but not panic, reigns in global finance in Russia's wake
summary: Western allies' sanctions against Russia have led to large potential losses for their own banks, companies, and investors, but market participants report no panic. Unlike previous sanctions, which often preceded financial crises, this time there's a sense of controlled uncertainty. Experts attribute this to the gradual implementation of sanctions and the diversification of global financial markets. While some losses are expected, there's no immediate indication of a full-blown crisis, with the market instead showing a mix of caution and resilience.

site_title: Biden shifts to the political centre, as Putin's aggression gives him a lift
summary: President Joe Biden's State of the Union address has boosted his public approval ratings, with a 8-point increase to 47% after the speech. His handling of the Ukraine crisis improved to 52%, and his handling of the coronavirus pandemic rose to 55%. Biden's shift to the political center, as seen in his address, may have helped him regain support among independent voters. However, his rating on the economy remains low, with 53% disapproving of his management. The long-term impact of the speech on Biden's presidency and the 2024 presidential race remains uncertain, with the Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's expected interest rate hikes potentially affecting the economy.

site_title: Large supermarkets must charge at least S$0.05 for disposable carrier bags
summary: Singapore's Minister for Sustainability and the Environment, Grace Fu, announced that large supermarkets with an annual turnover of over S$100 million will charge at least S$0.05 for disposable carrier bags starting mid-2023. This charge aims to encourage sustainable habits and reduce the use of single-use bags. The charge will cover about two-thirds of supermarket outlets in Singapore, and collected proceeds will be used to support charitable programs or sustainability initiatives.

site_title: S&P 500 targets are being slashed as oil's surge roils markets
summary: The S&P 500 index target is being lowered due to rising inflation and economic growth concerns fueled by a surge in crude oil prices. Yardeni Research now expects the index to fall to 4,000 by the end of 2022, a drop of 8% from current levels. Evercore ISI has also cut its target to 4,800 from 5,100, citing a stagflationary outlook and the risk of a recession. The Federal Reserve's interest-rate hikes aim to dampen inflation, but the conflict in Ukraine and its impact on commodity flows may chill investment and consumer spending.

site_title: Grab faces possible class action suits from US shareholder rights law firms
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing and financial services company, has become a target for possible class action suits from US shareholder rights law firms after its share price dropped 37% to US$3.17 following a quarterly loss report. At least 6 law firms have announced investigations into claims of inaccurate statements, possible fraud, and US Securities Law violations. The firms are looking for shareholders with significant losses, with some requiring at least US$20,000 or US$100,000 in losses. If a lawsuit is successful, it may result in a settlement by Grab's insurer, rather than a trial.

site_title: Microsoft unveils 4th data centre in India
summary: Microsoft has unveiled its 4th data centre in India, marking a long-term investment in the country's growing digital market. The new centre is located in Telangana and is part of the company's efforts to expand its public cloud services in India, where the market is expected to reach $10.8 billion by 2025. Microsoft India head Anant Maheshwari stated that the company is continuing to grow its workforce in India and already serves over 340,000 companies. The move follows competitors Amazon and Adani Group, which have also announced plans to build data centres in the country.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on Ukraine crisis; won at weakest since May 2020
summary: South Korean stocks closed 2.29% lower on Monday, marking their largest fall in a week-and-a-half, amid fears of a stagflationary shock due to the Ukraine crisis. The Kospi index fell 62.12 points to 2,651.31, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading the declines. The Korean won weakened to its lowest close since May 2020, and South Korea tightened its financial sanctions against Russia. Foreigners sold 1.17 trillion won worth of shares, driving the won down to 1,227.1 per dollar, its lowest close since May 2020.

site_title: Sushi Kou, Casa among fine dining closures
summary: Sushi Kou, a popular Japanese restaurant, will close on March 31 due to a spate of resignations, including its head chef, who is opening a new restaurant with a different investor. This is part of a trend of fine dining closures in Singapore, including Casa by Remy Lefebvre and 1-Altitude. The restaurant, owned by Edo Sushi Pte Ltd, had previously struggled with high staff turnover and had posted job notices to recruit new staff.

site_title: Asia's top IT outsourcer plans overhaul to hit US$50b sales
summary: Tata Consultancy Services (TCS), Asia's largest software outsourcing provider, plans to overhaul its organisational structure to align with the changing needs of its clients. The company aims to double its revenues to $50 billion by 2030 and create 4 internal teams to target startups and large global firms. The new structure will cater to the diverse needs of clients, from sub-$5 billion startups to large corporations, and will include innovation centers in the US and Europe. TCS also plans to manage its surging staff costs, which led to missing analyst estimates last quarter.

site_title: Russia's war on Ukraine : First lessons and outlook
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has led to significant geopolitical implications. Despite warnings from the US and UK, many nations, including Germany, underestimated the threat. Russia's economy is likely to suffer greatly due to severe sanctions, potentially leading to a significant decline in GDP. The country may become isolated, reliant on China for economic support, and a quasi-tributary state. China, on the other hand, may gain leverage and accelerate its decoupling from the West. The conflict will likely lead to a world where relative gains are prioritized over absolute gains, and win-lose scenarios become more common.

site_title: UK house prices surge at strongest annual pace since 2007
summary: UK house prices surged 10.8% in the past year, reaching a record £278,123, the fastest annual pace since 2007. This growth, driven by low borrowing costs and a demand for space, may slow as consumers face a cost of living squeeze due to rising taxes and energy bills. Halifax warns that geopolitical events and higher interest rates will weigh on buyer demand, potentially slowing house price growth. Affordability remains a concern for first-time buyers, who face a brutal cost of living squeeze.

images.alt_text: UK house prices surged at the fastest annual pace since before the global financial crisis started in 2007.

site_title: Aston Martin to partner Britishvolt in quest for high-end electric car
summary: Aston Martin is partnering with Britishvolt to develop high-performance battery cells for its electric vehicles, set to launch in 2025. The deal will support Aston Martin's plans to minimize battery-performance compromises and meet customer demands for fast charging. Britishvolt secured £1.7 billion in private funding, and the collaboration complements Aston Martin's partnership with Mercedes-Benz Group. The partnership aims to provide high-end electric vehicles with repeatable performance and high-performance charging capabilities.

site_title: Asian markets dive as oil prices spike, Ukraine crisis rattles investors
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Monday amid rising oil prices, which surged to US$137.59 and US$129.77 due to US Congress exploring an oil embargo on Russia and escalating tensions between Ukraine and Russia. The Singapore Straits Times Index fell 1.2%, with other Asian markets also experiencing significant declines, including Japan's Nikkei 225, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index, and South Korea's Kospi. Experts warn of a global recovery threat from the volatile oil market, with potential policy responses including monetary concessions and increased pressure on Opec+ oil producers.

site_title: China property shares firm after friendly policy tone
summary: China property shares rose 1.5% on Monday after Premier Li Keqiang confirmed city-specific policy easing for the sector, despite no full-scale relaxation. This move reversed morning losses, with Country Garden and China Overseas Land & Investment gaining 5.6% and 3.7%, respectively. Analysts say the tone of Li's comments was slightly more positive, with potential policy adjustments including downpayment ratio reductions and removal of home-purchase restrictions. This comes as China's home sales volume dropped 40% in the first two months of the year.

site_title: Unilever pledges new nutrition targets after investor pressure
summary: Unilever has pledged to publish new nutrition benchmarks for its food brands, responding to investor pressure to improve consumer health. The company will assess its products against 6 government-endorsed measures, including UK and European regulations, and publish annual reports globally and in 16 key markets starting in October. This move follows a resolution by investors and health campaigners calling for Unilever to set targets for healthy products. The resolution has been withdrawn, and the company's new targets aim to increase the share of healthy products sold.

site_title: Strata units in GB Building for sale; Oxley Tower F&B units re-launched at lower guide price
summary: Three strata commercial units in GB Building are up for sale through an expression of interest exercise. The portfolio has an overall guide price of S$69 million and a combined strata floor area of 31,086 sq ft. The units comprise a retail podium and office units on the third and eighth floors. This marks the re-launch of Oxley Tower's F&B units at a lower guide price, following an initial launch in 2021.

site_title: Saudi prince's US$500b 'Neom' mega-project woos Wall Street
summary: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman is seeking international interest in his $500 billion "Neom" mega-project, a high-tech hub built from scratch on the Red Sea coast. Executives will attend a meeting in New York in April to gauge interest, following a similar event in London last year. The project aims to diversify the economy and boost investment, but faces controversy and skepticism, including a violent relocation process for local residents and questions over its feasibility.

site_title: South Korea scrambles to rework Covid-19 poll plans after early voting lapses
summary: South Korea's election officials scrambled to rework voting plans after early voting was marred by long waits and ballot mix-ups during the Covid-19 pandemic. A record 37% turnout in two-day absentee voting highlighted a tight race between ruling Democratic Party candidate Lee Jae Myung and opposition candidate Yoon Suk Yeol. The National Election Commission apologized for failing to ensure a stable process, with some voters receiving ballots already marked or waiting in long queues. Officials vowed to tighten procedures ahead of Wednesday's wider vote, amid concerns about the country's democratic history and voter frustration.

site_title: Ukraine asks UN court to end Russia invasion
summary: Ukraine has submitted an urgent case to the International Court of Justice (ICJ) in The Hague, requesting Russia to immediately halt its invasion. Kyiv alleges that Russia's war is based on false allegations of genocide in Ukraine's Donetsk and Lugansk regions. Ukraine claims Russia is planning "acts of genocide" in its offensive, which began on February 24. The case will be heard by ICJ judges, with a decision pending.

site_title: Strong enforcement measures will guard against new EP system fraud
summary: Singapore's government will implement strong enforcement measures to prevent employers from gaming the new Complementarity Assessment Framework (Compass) system for Employment Pass (EP) applicants. The system, set to start in 2023, assesses applicants and employers based on criteria such as job role, salary, and educational qualifications. Authorities will develop verification processes to prevent fraud, including checking if job roles are listed on the official "shortage occupation list." Employers found to have falsely declared information will be taken to task.

site_title: New tripartite standard on how firms should improve well-being of lower-wage workers
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower has introduced a new tripartite standard to improve the well-being of lower-wage workers, focusing on training, rest areas, and mental well-being. Employers that adopt the standard will receive the "PW Mark Plus" accreditation. A Progressive Wage Mark accreditation scheme will also be introduced, with suppliers awarded government contracts required to be accredited from 2023. The Progressive Wage Model has seen significant progress, with cumulative wage increases of up to 84% for entry-level cleaners by 2028, covering around 94% of full-time lower-wage workers.

site_title: China's economy resilient despite uncertainties caused by Ukraine crisis: state planner
summary: China's economy remains resilient despite uncertainties from the Ukraine crisis, according to the country's state planner. China aims for a slower 5.5% economic growth this year due to a downturn in the property sector and uncertain global recovery. The National Development and Reform Commission plans to enhance policy coordination and roll out policies favorable for growth. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to implement effective measures.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at 1-week low as global equity sell-off weighs
summary: Australian shares ended at a 1-week low on March 7, 2022, due to a global equity sell-off triggered by the Russia-Ukraine crisis. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1% to 7,038.60, marking a second consecutive session of losses. The energy and mining sectors gained, but were outweighed by declines in technology and financial stocks. Crude prices rose to their highest since 2008, raising concerns about higher global inflation and policy uncertainty.

site_title: Price of 95-octane petrol surges past S$3 per litre at Shell
summary: Shell's 95-octane petrol price surged past S$3 per litre, with increases of up to 21 Singapore cents per litre. This marks the latest upward climb in local pump prices, with 21 cents per litre added to both 95 and 98-octane fuel.

site_title: Singtel's NCS acquires Aussie IT company The Dialog Group for A$325m
summary: Singtel's technology services arm, NCS, has acquired Australian IT company The Dialog Group for A$325 million (S$328 million), aiming to expand its presence in the Australian market and become a pan-Asian B2B digital services provider. The acquisition is expected to be completed in 3 months, subject to regulatory approval. NCS CEO Ng Kuo Pin believes the deal will help the company gain a foothold in Australia quickly and capitalize on growing IT spending in the country, which is expected to grow by 6.5% this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens 3% down on Ukraine crisis
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index dropped 3% in morning trade on March 7, 2022, amid concerns over the war in Ukraine and rising crude oil prices. The benchmark index fell 787.97 points to 25,197.50, while the broader Topix index fell 2.91% or 53.69 points to 1,791.25. Global markets also declined, with the S&P 500 and Dow Jones losing 0.8% and 0.5% respectively. The US administration's consideration of banning Russian crude oil imports and Brent oil prices nearing an all-time record are cited as key factors.

site_title: Beng Kuang to acquire stake in A*Star spin-off
summary: Beng Kuang Marine has agreed to acquire a 10% stake in I.O.T Workz, an A*Star spin-off company providing IoT-centric solutions.
