The WHO declared a public health emergency of international concern on January 30, 2020, but it was only the March 11 announcement that prompted widespread action. The organization is upset that governments did not heed the earlier warning, and the pandemic has claimed over 6 million lives and infected 450 million people. WHO officials argue that the warning was more important than the announcement and that the world was "well warned" about the impending pandemic.

site_title: A*Star sets up new research institute focused on sustainability
summary: A*Star has established the Institute of Sustainability for Chemicals, Energy and Environment to support Singapore's sustainability goals. The institute will focus on low-carbon technologies, sustainable materials, and green manufacturing processes, and will partner with academia, public agencies, and industry to help industries transition to renewable carbon and green chemistry. This reorganisation combines A*Star's strengths in sustainable polymer materials, climate change modelling, and simulation capabilities. The institute will be overseen by Yeoh Lean Weng, A*Star's chief sustainability officer.

site_title: US, UK ban Russian oil as EU eyes bonds
summary: The US and UK have banned the import of Russian oil, with the US move targeting the main artery of Russia's economy and the UK phasing in the restrictions over several months. The European Union is considering issuing joint bonds to counter the fallout from Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The ban is a significant escalation of Western efforts to hobble Russia's economy, which will further strain global crude markets. The move is expected to increase volatility and weigh on the market, with oil prices already rising amid the ban.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on energy, tech boost; New Zealand ekes out gains
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,997.60, driven by energy stocks on surging oil prices and tech gains, despite weak global sentiment amid a US oil imports ban. Tech stocks led the advance, with Life360 and Block shares jumping 4.1% and 3.9%, respectively. Energy players rebounded with a 1.7% gain, while gold stocks rose 1.3%. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.1%, but remains in correction territory.

site_title: Singapore stocks slide on Monday as oil prices surge; STI down 1.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.2% on Monday, closing at 3,187.82 points, amid a surge in oil prices and escalating tensions in Russia and Ukraine. Asian markets also declined, with Japan's Nikkei down 2.9%, South Korea's Kospi shedding 2.3%, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng tumbling 3.9%. The STI's biggest losers included Dairy Farm International and local lenders DBS, OCBC, and UOB. Analysts attributed the market's decline to stagflationary pressures and the region's reliance on imported energy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed lower on Friday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 14.60 points to 1,603.94. The market saw 3.445 billion lots traded worth RM3.294 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 849 to 239.

site_title: Bali welcomes first foreign tourists after Covid quarantine rule lifted
summary: Bali welcomed its first foreign tourists on March 7, 2022, after Indonesia lifted its Covid-19 quarantine rule for arrivals. The move, part of a broader easing of curbs, allows fully vaccinated tourists to skip a 3-day mandatory quarantine and remain on the island for 4 days. The pilot programme aims to boost tourism, which accounts for over 50% of Bali's economy, after the island drew 6.2 million foreign visitors in 2019.

site_title: S$500m in aviation support for Singapore Changi Airport
summary: Singapore aims to restore Changi Airport passenger traffic to at least 50% of pre-pandemic levels in 2022 through a S$500 million aviation support package. The package includes wage support, fee rebates, and funds to encourage industry transformation. The government plans to transition to vaccinated, quarantine-free travel from Vaccinated Travel Lanes, allowing fully vaccinated travelers from low-risk countries to enter Singapore without quarantine. Experts are cautiously optimistic about the target, citing the success of Australia's similar policy, but warn that geopolitical uncertainties and air travel demand will impact the goal.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts downgrade China Aviation Oil on uncertain outlook
summary: Analysts from DBS Group Research and RHB downgraded their calls on China Aviation Oil (CAO), lowering target prices to S$0.85 and S$1, respectively. The downgrades come as both teams cut earnings estimates due to uncertainty surrounding China's reopening to international travel and delays caused by the Omicron variant. RHB maintains a "neutral" rating, while DBS downgraded to "hold". The analysts attribute the uncertainty to CAO's reliance on international traffic, particularly at Shanghai Pudong International Airport Aviation Fuel Supply Company, which is heavily dependent on international border controls.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on Ukraine concerns, looming US rate hike
summary: South Korea's stocks closed 0.59% lower on Monday, impacted by Russia-Ukraine concerns and a US interest rate hike. The benchmark Kospi fell 15.63 points to 2,645.65. Foreigners sold 639 billion won worth of shares, and the Korean won weakened. The US Federal Open Market Committee is expected to hike interest rates, while the Bank of Japan and Bank of England also meet this week. South Korea's presidential office warned of a possible North Korean intercontinental ballistic missile test.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as tech stocks, banks drag; New Zealand drops
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% on Monday, led by tech stocks and banks, despite gains in miners and energy stocks due to rising commodity prices. The tech sub-index slid 3.9%, with Block Inc's shares declining 9%. Energy stocks, however, rose 6% due to robust commodity prices. Gold miners jumped 4.7%, with Resolute Mining and De Grey Mining leading gains. In New Zealand, the S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.9%.

site_title: Rihanna's lingerie company weighs IPO at US$3b valuation
summary: Rihanna's lingerie company, Savage X Fenty, is reportedly considering an initial public offering (IPO) valued at $3 billion or more. The company, which aims to cater to customers often overlooked by traditional brands, has already raised $125 million in funding. With plans to expand into brick-and-mortar stores, Savage X Fenty is poised for growth. A listing could happen as soon as this year, but no final decision has been made.

images.alt_text: Singer-turned-fashion-entrepreneur Rihanna is working with advisers on an initial public offering (IPO) that could value her Savage X Fenty lingerie company at US$3 billion or more, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Iskandar boleh
summary: Iskandar Malaysia, a booming growth corridor in southern Malaysia, has seen its economic prospects dwindle in recent years. The area, once a magnet for Singaporean investors, now faces a glut of unsold properties and low yields. The COVID-19 pandemic further exacerbated the situation, with new launches and transactions hitting their lowest points in 2020. Despite efforts to revitalize the area, Iskandar's real estate market remains stagnant, with a stock overhang of 23,224 units worth RM21 billion. The area's development agenda has been hijacked by real estate, and its inability to provide scalability and a human capital pool has limited its appeal to multinational corporations. However, Iskandar Malaysia aims to turn South Johor into a flourishing economic zone by 2025, with plans to double its population and workforce and woo investments of RM383 billion.

site_title: Supporting clients in uncertain times
summary: Private banks are advising clients to rebalance their portfolios amid market volatility, with a focus on sustainable investments and discretionary mandates. Top bankers expect increased adoption of sustainable investments and discretionary mandates, driven by clients' growing interest in long-term wealth management and legacy needs. High-net-worth individuals are seeking guidance and delegation of portfolio management, with 1 in 5 acknowledging feelings of nervousness and uncertainty. Private banks are investing in growth, technology, and talent to meet clients' needs, with a focus on recovery and sustainability in 2022.

site_title: Oil jumps in volatile trade amid CPC pipeline disruption
summary: Oil prices rose in volatile trading amid disruption to Russian and Kazakh crude exports via the Caspian Pipeline Consortium (CPC) pipeline. Brent crude futures rose 4.5% to $120.64 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures rose 4.4% to $114.10 a barrel. The market remains on edge due to the prospect of further sanctions on Russia and plunging US crude stockpiles, which fell by 4.3 million barrels for the week ended March 18. Analysts predict record backwardation and tight supplies, with some forecasting US$150 a barrel by summer.

site_title: UBS bonus pool rises 10% as Archegos mars dealmaking boom
summary: UBS Group raised its bonus pool for 2021 by 10% to US$3.7 billion, reflecting the bank's need to retain talent after a bumper year for dealmaking but losses from the collapse of Archegos Capital Management. CEO Ralph Hamers received 11 million Swiss francs, while former CEO Sergio Ermotti earned 13.3 million francs in 2020. The bank set aside more funds for employee bonuses compared to the previous year, amid increased competition for talent in Europe and the US.

site_title: Maersk suspends all container shipping to Russia
summary: Maersk suspends all container shipping to and from Russia due to Western sanctions on Moscow following its invasion of Ukraine. New bookings within ocean and inland routes will be temporarily suspended, but exemptions will be made for foodstuffs, medical, and humanitarian supplies. Maersk operates shipping routes to multiple Russian ports, including St. Petersburg, Kaliningrad, Novorossiysk, Vladivostok, and Vostochny.

site_title: Amid its aggression, Russia is losing a global soft-power battle
summary: Russia is losing a global soft-power battle amidst its aggression, with diplomatic and cultural rebukes, including the cancellation of major sporting events, taking a toll on its international reputation. Economic sanctions have also contributed to this decline. President Vladimir Putin's potential 30-year tenure, surpassing Joseph Stalin's record, poses a significant concern for Russia's global standing. The country's soft-power loss is a stark contrast to its military might, highlighting the complexities of international relations and the impact of leadership on global perceptions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished with a 0.55% gain, adding 123.42 points to the Hang Seng Index at 22,467.34, despite concerns over the Ukraine war's impact. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.09%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.83%. The Federal Reserve's head easing rate hike concerns eased some pressure, but traders remain fearful.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks finished with small gains on Thursday (Mar 3) after the head of the Federal Reserve eased concerns the bank would embark on an aggressive programme of rate hikes, though traders remain fearful about the impact of the Ukraine war.

site_title: Within days, Russia's war on Ukraine squeezes the global economy
summary: Russia's war on Ukraine has darkened the global economic outlook, with the price of oil, natural gas, and other staples spiking due to financial sanctions and disruptions to supply chains. The US, Europe, and their allies have tightened the screws on Russia's financial transactions, freezing hundreds of billions of dollars of the central bank's assets. This gamble between a financial clock and a military clock could vaporize Russia's resources and heighten the risk to the global outlook, with inflation already a concern and the potential for stagflation. The sanctions are expected to have a significant impact on Eastern European countries, Turkey, and the US economy, with rising energy prices and transport costs.

site_title: Airspace closures after Ukraine invasion hit global supply chains
summary: Airspace closures due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine are disrupting global supply chains, affecting around 20% of the world's air cargo. Airlines like Lufthansa, Air France KLM, and Finnair have cancelled flights due to reciprocal airspace bans, while others like Korean Air Lines and Japan's ANA Holdings continue to use Russian airspace. This may lead to further cost inflation and soaring air freight rates, exacerbating existing inflation.

images.alt_text: Transport between Europe and north Asian destinations such as Japan, South Korea and China has become particularly problematic due to reciprocal airspace bans that bar European carriers from flying over Siberia and Russia airlines from flying to Europe.

site_title: Why conquest doesn't pay in the modern world
summary: Conquest is unlikely to pay in the modern world, as argued by British author Norman Angell in his 1909 book The Great Illusion. Despite historical examples of powers enriching themselves through military prowess, the modern world's "vital interdependence" among nations makes conquest unprofitable. The rise of a global economy, international division of labor, and financial systems makes it difficult to conquer another country without cutting off one's own access to these resources. Additionally, modern war requires significant resources, including ammunition, fuel, and labor, making it expensive and unsustainable. The legacy of Hitler's economic failures also serves as a warning for future prospects.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend gains on mining, energy boost
summary: Australian shares rose for a fifth session, driven by mining and energy stocks, following strong commodity prices and a rebound in global markets. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 0.7% to 7,166.60, with energy stocks leading gains and miners rising 2.2%. The gains followed US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's signals of less aggressive interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose for a fifth session on Thursday, driven by mining and energy stocks on the back of strong commodity prices, and as global markets rebounded after the US Federal Reserve chairman assuaged worries about aggressive rate hikes.

site_title: McDonald's, Pepsi, others should consider pausing Russia operations: NY pension fund
summary: New York state's pension fund chief, Thomas DiNapoli, has urged major global brands like McDonald's, Pepsi, and Estee Lauder to consider pausing their operations in Russia due to the country's invasion of Ukraine and sanctions. The letter cited significant risks to companies, including legal, compliance, operational, human rights, and reputational risks. DiNapoli's letter also stated that pausing operations in Russia would help condemn the country's actions and support a strong global economy. Several companies, including Nike and Ikea, have already announced plans to stop operations in Russia.

images.alt_text: Major global brands, including McDonald's Corp, Pepsi Co and the Estee Lauder Cos, should consider pausing their operations in Russia, New York state's pension fund chief wrote in letters to several companies on Friday (Mar 4).

site_title: Telenor's fire sale of Myanmar unit includes US$100m in funds: sources
summary: Norway's telecommunications company Telenor is selling its troubled Myanmar operations to conglomerate Shwe Byain Phyu (SBP) and Lebanese investment firm M1 Group for $105 million, with $55 million paid over 5 years. The sale includes $100 million in retained earnings held by the unit, which will be transferred to new buyers. The move comes after Telenor wrote off its Myanmar operations for $783 million due to pressure from the junta to activate intercept surveillance technology, amid concerns that Telenor's exit could allow the junta to track political opponents.

site_title: NFT watchdogs say scammers abusing Twitter to take down warnings
summary: NFT watchdogs on Twitter are being silenced by the platform's content moderation policies, which can be exploited by scammers to have their warnings and tips removed. Despite this, some vigilantes continue to raise red flags on dubious projects, often using Twitter threads with screen grabs of codes. However, they have faced wrongful suspensions, with some accounts being blocked or having their content tagged as "sensitive content." Industry experts say that automated content moderation policies may be leading to these suspensions, and that a combination of human reviews and machine-learning algorithms is needed to better protect users.

images.alt_text: Amid a spate of fraud in the non-fungible tokens (NFTs) market, watchdogs have emerged on Twitter to discredit suspicious projects. But some say they are easily silenced by a "loophole" in the platform's content moderation policies.

site_title: Japan's services sector activity falls at fastest pace in 21 months
summary: Japan's services sector activity shrank in February at the quickest pace in nearly 2 years, according to a survey, as consumer sentiment declined due to record Omicron infections. The au Jibun Bank Japan Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 44.2, marking the fastest rate of contraction since May 2020. Despite rising input prices, businesses cut prices to stimulate demand, but the sector's activity is expected to grind to a near halt this quarter due to coronavirus curbs and supply bottlenecks.

site_title: ST Engineering shares rise amid geopolitical tensions, turbulent stock market
summary: ST Engineering's share price has risen 6.6% this week, driven by geopolitical tensions, its safe-haven nature, and earnings prospects. Analysts point to increased defence spending in Europe, particularly in Germany and France, as a factor contributing to the stock's ascent. The company's diversified business, robust earnings, and record high order book have also boosted investor confidence. Experts believe ST Engineering's strengths, including a 8% profit compound annual growth rate and a 30% defence revenue share, will support its sustained rise in earnings.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering posted 9.3 per cent higher net profit at S$570.5 million for FY2021 as revenue for the year climbed 7.5 per cent to S$7.69 billion versus a year ago.

site_title: Oil spikes as Russian supply disruptions increase amid sanctions
summary: Oil prices surged, reaching a peak of $113.02 a barrel, amid supply disruptions from Russia's energy exports due to sanctions. Russian oil exports account for 8% of global supply, with disruptions resulting in postponed sales, rejected imports, and buyers seeking alternative crude. Despite a coordinated oil release by the International Energy Agency, prices remained above $100, with US President Joe Biden warning Vladimir Putin that Russia "has no idea what's coming." Exxon Mobil also announced it would exit Russia oil and gas operations.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose by more than US$8, touching a peak of US$113.02 a barrel, the highest since June 2014, before easing to US$111.53, up by US$6.56 or 6.3 per cent by 0950 GMT.
